('42', 0, 2, 3, 109) MY DEAR BHRRR, You were right in your surmise about absence of any letter from me.
('42', 0, 2, 4, 192) 1 God is great and good and even merciful.
('42', 0, 2, 5, 235) I am following the events in Bardoli.
('42', 0, 2, 6, 273) Every word of what you say is well deserved by Vallabhbhai.
('42', 0, 2, 7, 333) Don’t flatter yourself with the belief that if the Government invite you as their guest, they will house you at Sabarmati.
('42', 0, 2, 8, 456) The Ashram is too near for the Sabarmati guest house.
('42', 0, 3, 9, 510) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('42', 0, 5, 11, 568) 2. NECESSITY OF DISCIPLINE
('42', 0, 6, 12, 595) Some workers in the Khadi Service write : 3
('42', 0, 7, 13, 639) Here there is an obvious confusion of ideals.
('42', 0, 7, 14, 685) Distorted notions of superiority and inferiority have given rise to indiscipline in al most all the national organizations.
('42', 0, 7, 15, 809) Many people think that to abolish distinctions of rank means passport to anarchy and licence.
('42', 0, 7, 16, 903) Whereas the meaning of abolition of distinctions should be perfect discipline,—perfect because of voluntary obedience to the laws of the organization to which we may belong, i.e., the laws of our being.
('42', 0, 7, 17, 1106) For man is himself a wonderful organization and what applies to him applies to the social or political organizations of which he may be a member.
('42', 0, 7, 18, 1252) And even as though the different members of the body are
('42', 0, 8, 19, 1309) 1 Following the death of Maganlal Gandhi, Gandhiji had not sent any letter to the addressee.
('42', 0, 8, 20, 1402) 2 Abbas Tyabji who was at the time assisting Vallabhbhai Patel in the Bardoli struggle had, while giving an account of the arrest and trial of Ravishanker, mentioned the possibility of his own arrest.
('42', 0, 8, 21, 1603) 3 The letter is not reproduced here.
('42', 0, 8, 22, 1640) The workers had complained that though they were required to attend Khadi Office punctually the Secretary himself was not punctual.
('42', 0, 8, 23, 1772) They had asked: “.
('42', 0, 8, 24, 1791) Why should this inferiority and superiority prevail among workers in the same field?”
('42', 1, 0, 1, 1877) 2 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 1, 1, 2, 1917) not inferior to any, they are voluntarily subject to the control of the mind, whilst the body is in a healthy state, so have the members of an organization, whilst none is superior or inferior to any other, to be voluntarily subject to the mind of the organization which is the head.
('42', 1, 1, 3, 2201) An organization which has no directing mind or which has no members co operating with the mind suffers from paralysis and is in a dying condition.
('42', 1, 1, 4, 2348) The correspondents who have signed the letter I have reproduced to not realize that if they do not accept the elementary discipline involved in giving regular attendance, that Khadi Office of which they are members cannot work profitably to its purpose, i.e., service of Daridranarayana.
('42', 1, 1, 5, 2636) Let them realize that the voluntary discipline of a khadi office should be much stricter than the compulsory discipline of a Government office.
('42', 1, 1, 6, 2780) If the chief of the Khadi Office concerned does not attend always in time, it is highly likely that he is engaged in khadi work even when he is not at his office.
('42', 1, 1, 7, 2943) For whilst the staff has fairly regular hours the chief has no hours of receration.
('42', 1, 1, 8, 3027) If he is honest and realizes the responsibilities of his high office, he has to work day and night in order to make khadi what it should be.
('42', 1, 1, 9, 3168) It is one thing to come into a going concern, totally another to enter a newly formed organization intended to be the largest of its kind in the world.
('42', 1, 1, 10, 3320) Such an organization requires the vigilant, intelligent and honest watch not of one worker but of thousands.
('42', 1, 1, 11, 3429) These workers have to come into being by belonging to the existing organizations and imposing on themselves the hardest discipline of which they way be capable.
('42', 1, 2, 12, 3590) Young India, 3 5 1928
('42', 1, 3, 13, 3612) 3. THANKS Friends from far and near have overwhelmed me with their kind messages in what has been to me the greatest trial of my life.
('42', 1, 3, 14, 3747) It was foolish of me but it is nevertheless true that I had never contemplated Maganlal Gandhi’s death before mine.
('42', 1, 3, 15, 3863) The cables, telegrams and letters I have received from individuals, associations and Congress Committees have been a great solace to me.
('42', 1, 3, 16, 4000) The senders will forgive me for not making personal acknowledgments.
('42', 1, 3, 17, 4069) I assure them all that I shall try to become worthy of the affection they have bestowed upon me and of the silent devotion with which Maganlal Gandhi served the ideals he held in common with me.
('42', 1, 3, 18, 4264) M. K. G. Young India, 3 5 1928

('42', 2, 1, 2, 4336) 4. LETTER TO VIRUMAL BEGRAJ THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, May 4, 1928
('42', 2, 2, 3, 4399) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('42', 2, 2, 4, 4432) You do not want me to answer your questions as a lawyer; for my law may not be accepted.
('42', 2, 2, 5, 4521) But as a layman, it seems to me that neither the Bava nor his widow nor the Brahmin in the other case have any right to the properties mentioned by you and held under the circumstances described by you.

('42', 2, 3, 8, 4813) 5. LETTER TO P. T. PILLAY THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, May 4, 1928
('42', 2, 4, 9, 4874) DEAR FRIEND, I do not consider the burning of Manusmriti to be on a par with the buring of foreign cloth.
('42', 2, 4, 10, 4980) Burning of foreign cloth is like burning a thing that is injurious; but the burning of Manusmriti is at best like the burning of an advertisement for foreign cloth showing nothing but childish rage.
('42', 2, 4, 11, 5179) Moreover, I do not regard Manusmriti as an evil.
('42', 2, 4, 12, 5228) It contains much that is admirable, but in its present form it undoubtedly contains many things that are bad and these appear to be interpolations.
('42', 2, 4, 13, 5376) Whilst a reformer would therefore treasure all excellent things in that ancient code, he would expurgate all that is injurious or of doubtful value.
('42', 2, 4, 14, 5525) If we are to attain swaraj by effort from within, I do consider removal of untouchability like achieving Hindu Muslim unity as a condition precedent to the attainment of swaraj.
('42', 2, 4, 15, 5703) But when the English rulers resist the demand for swaraj because we have not attained fully removal of untouchability, I rgeard their resistance as hypocritical and illegitimate.
('42', 2, 5, 16, 5882) Yours sincerely, SJT.
('42', 2, 5, 17, 5904) P. TIRUKOOTASUNDARAM PILLAY SINDUPPONDURAI TINNEVELLY From a microfilm: S.N. 13211

('42', 3, 5, 16, 7325) He was the popular hero of the day and the place was crowded with, I think, 15,000 Bengalees who had come to welcome him.
('42', 3, 5, 17, 7447) My friend was the one Englishman present.
('42', 3, 5, 18, 7489) For three hours the orators of Bengal spoke in praise of themselves and Mr. Gandhi: and then came the great moment, when Mr. Gandhi rose and all this vast assembly settled themselves on their haunches waiting for their great orator to speak.
('42', 3, 5, 19, 7731) His speech consisted of one sentence, and one sentence only: ‘The man to whom I owe most and to whom all India owes most is a man who never set his foot in India—and that was Christ.’ And then he sat down.’” Cranna had asked: “Has this your confirmation?” 3Economics of Khaddar 4 An article by Mahadev Desai appeared in Hindi Navajivan, 10 5 1928, and a summary by Haribhau Upadhyaya in Young India, 9 8 1928, under the title “Khadi in Central India”.

('42', 4, 1, 2, 8224) 8. INDULGENCE IN THE NAME OF DEVOTION Thanks to Shri Jaydayalji Goenka, an attempt is nowadays being made to create a spirit of devotion in the Marwari society.
('42', 4, 1, 3, 8385) With this object in view bhajan groups have been formed and bhajan bhavans 1
('42', 4, 2, 4, 8462) are also being run.
('42', 4, 2, 5, 8482) One such bhavan called Govind Bhavan has been started in Calcutta.
('42', 4, 2, 6, 8549) At Shri Jaydayalji’s instance, a certain gentleman was put in charge of it.
('42', 4, 2, 7, 8625) He indulged in debauchery in the name of devotion.
('42', 4, 2, 8, 8676) He accepted puja from women; women regarded him as God and worshipped him; he gave them his left overs to eat and debauched them.
('42', 4, 2, 9, 8806) The simple hearted women believed that having physical relations with one who had attained self realization could not be regarded as sinful.
('42', 4, 2, 10, 8947) Although the incident is painful, it does not surprise me.
('42', 4, 2, 11, 9006) All around us we find people who gratify their lust under the guise of devotion.
('42', 4, 2, 12, 9087) And so long as the essence of devotion is not understood, is it surprising that robberies are committed in the name of religion?
('42', 4, 2, 13, 9216) It would be surprising if false devotees did not bring evil.
('42', 4, 2, 14, 9277) I am a votary of Ramanama and the dwadashamantra but my worship is not blind.
('42', 4, 2, 15, 9355) For anyone who is truthful, Ramanama is like a ship.
('42', 4, 2, 16, 9408) But I do not believe that anyone who repeats Ramanama hypocritically is saved by it.
('42', 4, 2, 17, 9493) Instances are cited of Ajamil and others; they are poetical creations and even there there is a hidden meaning.
('42', 4, 2, 18, 9605) Purity of sentiments has been attributed to them.
('42', 4, 2, 19, 9655) Anyone believing that Ramanama would calm his passions is rewarded by repeating it and is saved.
('42', 4, 2, 20, 9752) The hypocrite repeating Ramanama in pursuit of his passions is not saved but is doomed— “A person will meet the fate conforming with his sentiment.” Devotees should bear two things in mind : One, that devotion does not merely consist in repeating the name but also in sacrificial activity that must constantly go with it.
('42', 4, 2, 21, 10074) There is a belief nowadays that worldly activities have no connection with dharma or devotion.
('42', 4, 2, 22, 10169) This is untrue.
('42', 4, 2, 23, 10185) The truth is that all activities in this world are related to dharma or adharma.
('42', 4, 2, 24, 10266) The carpenter who practises his trade merely in order to earn a living, steals wood and spoils his work is guilty of adharma.
('42', 4, 2, 25, 10392) Another practises his trade for the good of others, say, for making a bed for a sick person, does not
('42', 4, 3, 26, 10494) 1 Institutions for bhajans
('42', 5, 0, 1, 10521) 6 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 5, 1, 2, 10561) commit any theft and works to the best of his abilities and repeats Ramanama while working.
('42', 5, 1, 3, 10653) This constitutes work done in pursuit of dharma.
('42', 5, 1, 4, 10702) This carpenter is a true devotee of Rama.
('42', 5, 1, 5, 10744) A third carpenter, whether deliberately or through ignorance, gives up his trade in order to repeat Ramanama, begs for himself and his children, and if asked to make something for a sick person says: “For me there is only Rama.
('42', 5, 1, 6, 10972) I would know no sick man and no happy man.” This carpenter is a degraded creature fallen into the well of ignorance.
('42', 5, 1, 7, 11089) Man does not pray to God through speech alone but through thought, word and deed.
('42', 5, 1, 8, 11171) If any one of these three aspects is missing, there is no devotion.
('42', 5, 1, 9, 11239) A fusion of these three is like a chemical compound.
('42', 5, 1, 10, 11292) In the case of the latter, if a single ingredient is not present in its proper proportion, the expected result does not follow.
('42', 5, 1, 11, 11420) The devotees of today appear to think that the limits of devotion are reached in the use of beautiful language and hence ceasing to be devotees become mere rakes and corrupt others too.
('42', 5, 1, 12, 11606) In the second place, how and where should man, who has a physical form, worship God?
('42', 5, 1, 13, 11691) He is omnipresent.
('42', 5, 1, 14, 11710) Hence the best and most understandable place where He can be worshipped is a living creature.
('42', 5, 1, 15, 11804) The service of the distressed, the crippled and the helpless among living things constitutes worship of God.
('42', 5, 1, 16, 11913) The repetition of Ramanama is also meant to help us learn to do so.
('42', 5, 1, 17, 11981) If Ramanama does not thus result in service, it is both futile and a sort of bondage, as it proved in the case of the man in Govind Bhavan.
('42', 5, 1, 18, 12121) Let this instance serve as a warning to all devotees.
('42', 5, 1, 19, 12175) Now a few words to the women.
('42', 5, 1, 20, 12205) The man who makes others worship him necessarily becomes depraved; but why should the women become so?
('42', 5, 1, 21, 12308) If they must worship human beings, why should they not worship an ideal woman?
('42', 5, 1, 22, 12387) Moreover, why worship any living being?
('42', 5, 1, 23, 12427) The saying of the learned Solon is worthy of being carved in one’s heart—“No man can be called good while he is alive.” 1 Those who were good one day have become wicked the following day.
('42', 5, 1, 24, 12615) Moreover, we cannot even spot hypocrites.
('42', 5, 1, 25, 12657) Hence God alone should be worshipped.
('42', 5, 1, 26, 12695) If a human being has to be worshipped he should be worshipped only after his death.
('42', 5, 1, 27, 12779) This is so because after his death we worship only his virtues, not his physical form.
('42', 5, 1, 28, 12866) It is necessary that men repeatedly, insistently and courteously point this out to our gullible sisters.
('42', 5, 1, 29, 12971) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 6 5 1928
('42', 5, 2, 30, 13007) 1 The saying attributed to Solon, however, is: “Call no man happy till he be dead.”

('42', 6, 1, 2, 13132) 9. LETTER TO MANILAL AND SUSHILA GANDHI Silence Day, May 7, 1928
('42', 6, 2, 3, 13197) MANILAL AND SUSHILA, What shall I write to you this time?
('42', 6, 2, 4, 13255) There has been no change at all in my routine work, nor do I think constantly about any particular matter, and yet I feel that a change has come over my life these days.
('42', 6, 2, 5, 13425) Imperceptibly and involuntarily, a struggle is going on within me.
('42', 6, 2, 6, 13492) Maganlal’s soul rules over my heart.
('42', 6, 2, 7, 13529) The thought of his death fills me with a kind of happiness.
('42', 6, 2, 8, 13589) Ba, I and all of us had always believed that I would die first.
('42', 6, 2, 9, 13653) Had it happened so, I feel, as I see the unmanageable growth of our activities, that he would have been crushed by their weight.
('42', 6, 2, 10, 13782) We are all thinking how to limit them.
('42', 6, 2, 11, 13821) I do not know if any of us will be able to cope with the work.
('42', 6, 2, 12, 13884) But I put my trust in God.
('42', 6, 2, 13, 13911) He who has steered the ship so far will steer it in future too.
('42', 6, 2, 14, 13975) No matter if Maganlal has died or others die.
('42', 6, 2, 15, 14021) All of us will die but the truth which we have thought and lived will never die.
('42', 6, 2, 16, 14102) I don’t think I can write to the others today.
('42', 6, 3, 17, 14149) Blessings from BAPU From a photostat of the Gujarati: G.N. 4737

('42', 7, 6, 10, 15083) DEAR MOTILALJI, I have your letter.
('42', 7, 6, 11, 15119) As I have no power in me to resist you, I have sent you just now a wire 1 saying I would be in Bombay as desired by you.
('42', 7, 6, 12, 15240) But as I have said in my wire, I have really no confidence in myself to render active service at the present moment.
('42', 7, 6, 13, 15357) My views are like that of a mad man.
('42', 7, 6, 14, 15394) Here, Maganlal’s death has cast upon me a tremendous burden; but it is a task which pleases me and which, if I can consolidate, is likely to be of great service to the country if not now certainly in the near futrue.
('42', 7, 6, 15, 15611) And to tear myself away from that work even for a day in the vain hope of doing something in Bombay is not a pleasant contemplation.
('42', 7, 6, 16, 15744) But unless you countermand your orders, you will find me in Bombay on 16th.
('42', 7, 7, 17, 15820) If none of these big political bodies which you mention want a constitution for swaraj, what can we do?

('42', 7, 7, 19, 16019) I have no faith in a legislative solution of the communal

('42', 8, 5, 19, 17925) 14. MILL CLOTH v.
('42', 8, 5, 20, 17943) KHADI A friend writes in effect :
('42', 8, 6, 21, 17977) Several Congressmen are nowadays advocating the use of indigenous mill cloth side by side with khadi.
('42', 8, 6, 22, 18079) There is a movement to give mill cloth a place in Congress khadi shops.
('42', 8, 6, 23, 18151) Will you not give your clear opinion on this point?
('42', 8, 6, 24, 18203) I know what it is but all Congress workers do not.
('42', 8, 6, 25, 18254) They would like to have your guidance especially in view of your recent articles on the part the indigenous mills may play in the boycott movement.
('42', 8, 6, 26, 18402) The Congress resolutions on khadi are unequivocal.
('42', 8, 6, 27, 18453) For those therefore who wish to respect them there is no course open but to
('42', 8, 7, 28, 18529) 1 From the postmark
('42', 9, 0, 1, 18549) 10 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 9, 1, 2, 18590) avoid the use of cloth manufactured in our mills.
('42', 9, 1, 3, 18640) But in these days of growing anarchy, it is idle to quote Congress resolutions either to support or to oppose particular conduct on the part of Congressmen.
('42', 9, 1, 4, 18797) Let us therefore re examine the question of Congressmen optionally using indigenous mill cloth in the place of foreign cloth, or hawking such mill cloth.
('42', 9, 1, 5, 18951) We know the experience of Bengal.
('42', 9, 1, 6, 18985) The swadeshi movement of Bengal during the partition days suffered a check because of the greed and dishonesty of mill owners.
('42', 9, 1, 7, 19112) They inflated prices and even sold foreign cloth in the name of swadeshi.
('42', 9, 1, 8, 19186) There is no warrant for the belief that they would behave better on this occasion.
('42', 9, 1, 9, 19269) Indeed the facts about spurious khadi that I have brought to light show that the mills will not be slow to exploit the swadeshi spirit for their own benefit as opposed to the larger benefit of the consumer.
('42', 9, 1, 10, 19476) But even if the mills were to play the game, Congressmen will not need to use mill cloth or to advertise it.
('42', 9, 1, 11, 19585) The mills playing the game means their advertising and selling khadi, their assimilation of the khadi, spirit, their recognition of the predominance of khadi over mill cloth.
('42', 9, 1, 12, 19760) It must be definitely realized that mills alone, even if they wished, cannot in our generation displace foreign cloth.
('42', 9, 1, 13, 19879) Therefore there be in the country an agency that would devote its attention, so far as boycott of foreign cloth is concerned, exclusively to khadi propaganda.
('42', 9, 1, 14, 20038) That agency has been the Congress since 1920. Khadi production and khadi propaganda act at once as a check upon the greed of mills and also, strange as it may appear, as an indirect but very effective encouragement to mills in their struggle against foreign competition.
('42', 9, 1, 15, 20309) Exclusive devotion to khadi on the part of Congressmen enables khadi to find a foothold and enables mills effectively to carry on their operations where the Congress has as yet no influence worth the name.
('42', 9, 1, 16, 20515) Hence it is that the mills have never resented the khadi propaganda.
('42', 9, 1, 17, 20584) On the contrary many of their agents have assured me that they have benefited by the khadi propaganda inasmuch as it has created an anti foreign cloth atmosphere enabling them to sell their comparatively coarser count cloth.
('42', 9, 1, 18, 20809) Stop exclusive khadi propaganda, play with mill cloth and you kill khadi and in the long run you kill even mill cloth, for it cannot by itself stand foreign competition.
('42', 9, 1, 19, 20979) In a competition between indigenous and foreign mills the one disturbing factor of healthy mass sentiment will be wholly wanting, if there was no khadi spirit.
('42', 9, 1, 20, 21139) Last but not least the inestimable value of khadi consists in its
('42', 10, 0, 1, 21205) VOL. 42: 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 11
('42', 10, 1, 2, 21247) capacity for tremendous mass education, mass uplift and sub stantial relief of growing starvation.
('42', 10, 1, 3, 21346) Whereas mill cloth affords no work and no financial help to the masses, every yard of khadi means so much work and money to the masses who are being doubly ruined for want of work and wages.
('42', 10, 1, 4, 21537) Therefore for every patriotic lover of the country there is no escape from exclusive use of and propaganda of khadi.
('42', 10, 1, 5, 21654) Young India, 10 5 1928

('42', 11, 1, 2, 23204) 16. DEADLY MARCH OF CIVILIZATION (?)
('42', 11, 2, 3, 23241) “Although at the time of writing (1917) foreign cloths are being imported to a certain extent into the Shan States, it is the custom for all Shan women to weave cloth for their own garments and those of their families.
('42', 11, 2, 4, 23460) The cotton from which the cloths are made is grown locally and prepared by the women.
('42', 11, 2, 5, 23546) In Shan villages nearly every house has a loom made sometimes of bamboo, sometimes of heavy wood, and generally kept on the ground in the open space beneath the living rooms.
('42', 11, 2, 6, 23721) The raw cotton is prepared by drying the balls in the sun, extracting the seeds by passing them through the usual small two roller gin and then opening it out by catching the partly cleaned cotton up from the revolving basket in which it is placed, by means of an instrument shaped like the bow of a violoncello.
('42', 11, 2, 7, 24034) After the cotton fibres have been separated in this way they are made into slivers and wound round a stick about 8 in.
('42', 11, 2, 8, 24153) long and 3 4 in.
('42', 11, 2, 9, 24170) thick, from which the cotton is converted into thread by a
('42', 11, 3, 10, 24229) form of spinning jenny.” From Burmese Textile from the Shan and Cachin Dt.
('42', 11, 3, 11, 24304) Notes from Bankfield Museum, by Laura E. Start 1917. But for the hypnotic spell under which the intoxicating education of our times drives us to live, we would consider it a sacrilege to deprive people of their own existing honourable occupation in the distant, vague and often hope of bettering their fleeting material condition.
('42', 11, 3, 12, 24635) If civilization means change of form merely without regard to substance it is an article of doubtful value.
('42', 11, 3, 13, 24743) And yet that is what the foregoing paragraph sent by Sjt.
('42', 11, 3, 14, 24801) Balaji Rao means.
('42', 11, 3, 15, 24819) Under the guise of the civilizing influence of commerce the innocent people of Burma are being impoverished and reduced to the condition of cattle.
('42', 11, 3, 16, 24967) As Sjt.
('42', 11, 3, 17, 24975) Madhusudan Das has pointed out, people who merely work with cattle and forget the cunning of the hand by giving up handicrafts are impoverished not only in body but also in mind.
('42', 11, 3, 18, 25154) Young India, 10 5 1928

('42', 12, 6, 14, 25941) I must try to answer your questions today.
('42', 12, 6, 15, 25984) What you say about prayer at the Ashram is largely true.
('42', 12, 6, 16, 26041) It is still a formal thing, soulless; but I continue it in the hope of it becoming a soulful thing.
('42', 12, 6, 17, 26141) Human nature is much the same whether in the East or in the West.
('42', 12, 6, 18, 26207) It does not therefore surprise me that you have not found anything special about prayers in the East and probably the Ashram prayer is a hotchpot of something Eastern and something Wes tern.
('42', 12, 6, 19, 26398) As I have no prejudice against taking anything good from the West or against giving up anything bad in the East, there is an unconscious blending of the two.
('42', 12, 6, 20, 26556) For a congregational life a congregational prayer is a necessity and, therefore, form also is necessary.
('42', 12, 6, 21, 26661) It need not be considered on that account to be hypocritical or harmful.
('42', 12, 6, 22, 26734) If the leader at such congregational prayer meetings is a good man the general level of the meeting is also good.
('42', 12, 6, 23, 26848) The spiritual effect of an honest intelligent attendance at such congregational prayers is undoubtedly great.
('42', 12, 6, 24, 26958) Congregational prayer is not intended to supplant individual prayer, which, as you well put it, must be heart felt and never formal.
('42', 12, 6, 25, 27091) It is there you are in tune with the Infinite.
('42', 12, 6, 26, 27138) Congregational prayer is an aid to being in tune with the Infinite.
('42', 12, 6, 27, 27206) For man who is a social being cannot find God unless he discharges social obligations and the obligation of coming to a common prayer meeting is perhaps the supremest.
('42', 12, 6, 28, 27374) It is a cleansing
('42', 12, 7, 29, 27392) 1 It appears the letter was dictated on May 10 and dispatched the next day after revision.
('42', 13, 0, 1, 27483) 14 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 13, 1, 2, 27524) process for the whole congregation.
('42', 13, 1, 3, 27560) But, like all human institutions, if one does not take care, such meetings do become formal and even hypocritical.
('42', 13, 1, 4, 27675) One has to devise methods of avoiding the formality and hypocrisy.
('42', 13, 1, 5, 27742) In all, especially in spiritual matters, it is the personal equation that counts in the end.
('42', 13, 1, 6, 27835) The roll call is not the ordinary roll call.
('42', 13, 1, 7, 27880) It is a note of the results of the daily yajna, that is, sacrifice.
('42', 13, 1, 8, 27948) Everyone says what he has spun.
('42', 13, 1, 9, 27980) Spinning has been conceived in a sacrificial spirit.
('42', 13, 1, 10, 28033) The idea is to see God through service of the millions.
('42', 13, 1, 11, 28089) The day must not close without every member of the congregation confessing whether he or she has or has not performed the daily sacrifice to the measure of his or her promise.
('42', 13, 1, 12, 28265) It is therefore not business at the end of the prayer, but it is the finishing touch to the prayer.
('42', 13, 1, 13, 28365) It is not done at the beginning of the meeting, because those who are late should have the opportunity of registering their sacrifice.
('42', 13, 1, 14, 28500) Remember, too, this is a sacrifice not intended to be made in secret.
('42', 13, 1, 15, 28570) It is designed to be done in the open.
('42', 13, 1, 16, 28609) In my opinion, Christianity or the message of Jesus is a response to the human want even as are the messages of Krishna, Buddha, Muhammad and Zoroaster.
('42', 13, 1, 17, 28762) Though they were designed and delivered at different places and at different times, they have also a universal value.
('42', 13, 1, 18, 28880) According to the needs of the time one message puts more emphasis on one thing than upon another.
('42', 13, 1, 19, 28978) A man of religion will not hesitate to profit by all these messages and according to his predilection derive more comfort from one than from another.
('42', 13, 1, 20, 29128) I do believe that real art consists in seeing the hidden beauty of moral acts and effects and, therefore, much that passes for art and beauty is, perhaps, neither art nor beauty.

('42', 21, 6, 8, 40634) 34. CELEBRATING PENANCE A friend writes to say : 2
('42', 21, 7, 9, 40685) I congratulate this friend on showing so much courage and disregarding an unworthy practice.
('42', 21, 7, 10, 40778) If other Jains, Vaishnavas, etc., follow this example, welfare activities in the country will be helped and pleasures enjoyed in the name of religion will be somewhat curtailed.
('42', 21, 7, 11, 40956) We are so much given to enjoyments that we convert the purest of pure activities into excuses for them.
('42', 21, 7, 12, 41060) Putting aside the spiritual benefits of fasting, we seek greatness thereby and then make fasting an occasion for indulging our palate.
('42', 21, 7, 13, 41195) Indeed those who would practise austerities should abstain from proclaiming the fact with beat of drums or causing others to do so and they should not become proud.
('42', 21, 7, 14, 41360) And if relatives and such others wish to put such penance to good use, they should quietly and without a motive make that an occasion for making donations to worthy causes.
('42', 21, 7, 15, 41533) There is another point too in this friend’s letter.
('42', 21, 7, 16, 41585) Institutions like orphanages and children’s homes expect donations for a feast on such occasions.
('42', 21, 7, 17, 41683) This is a deplorable custom.
('42', 21, 7, 18, 41712) By establishing orphanages, orphans should be given a sense of belonging.
('42', 21, 7, 19, 41786) And if these latter are given this sense of belonging, they should never be fed
('42', 21, 8, 20, 41866) 1Vide “Letter to Devchand Parekh”, 11 5 1928. 2 The letter is not translated here.
('42', 21, 8, 21, 41949) The correspondent had referred to the practice current among Jains of celebrating the end of a religious fast on Vaishakh Sud 3 by feasting on a lavish scale, accepting gifts and singing as at a wedding.
('42', 21, 8, 22, 42153) The correspondent had however refrained from such celebration and saved Rs. 201, which he sent to Gandhiji to spend on any cause he liked.
('42', 22, 0, 1, 42292) VOL. 42: 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 23
('42', 22, 1, 2, 42334) on meals which have been begged from others.
('42', 22, 1, 3, 42379) It is one thing to obtain donations for running orphanages and another to feed its inmates with whatever donors wish to give them.
('42', 22, 1, 4, 42510) In the one case the purpose is to run an institution while in the other the self respect of the orphans is touched.
('42', 22, 1, 5, 42626) Moreover, institutions accepting such meals endanger the health of their inmates, make them fussy about food and cause them harm.
('42', 22, 1, 6, 42756) Hence if such institutions insist upon donations instead of meals and if donors insist upon not giving feasts by way of donations, they will be contributing to public welfare.
('42', 22, 1, 7, 42932) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 13 5 1928
('42', 22, 2, 8, 42969) 35. THE YAJNA IN BARDOLI
('42', 22, 3, 9, 42994) So far Vallabhbhai has not asked for any financial assistance for the yajna that is going on in Bardoli; now, however, the time for that has come.
('42', 22, 3, 10, 43141) Satyagrahi soldiers like Shri Ravishanker and Shri Chinai are in prison.
('42', 22, 3, 11, 43214) Others too will follow them as they ought to.
('42', 22, 3, 12, 43260) If the people have any fire in them and if the Government does not wish to yield till the end, not a single soldier will remain outside prison nor a single landowner will own any property our remain outside prison.
('42', 22, 3, 13, 43475) All wars are alike up to a certain point, whether they be satyagrahi in nature or those involving brute force.
('42', 22, 3, 14, 43586) Both certainly involve sacrifice.
('42', 22, 3, 15, 43620) In the Great War in Europe, soldiers on both sides were ruined, the warriors of both sides lost their lives.
('42', 22, 3, 16, 43729) Myriads of people in Germany were rendered homeless.
('42', 22, 3, 17, 43782) However, here the similarity between brute force and satyagraha ends.
('42', 22, 3, 18, 43852) The satyagrahi ruins himself.
('42', 22, 3, 19, 43882) He deliberately gives up the momentary pleasure of ruining the enemy and finds happiness in his own renunciation.
('42', 22, 3, 20, 43996) Hence a satyagrahi struggle may be called a yajna.
('42', 22, 3, 21, 44047) It involves self purification.
('42', 22, 3, 22, 44078) In this sacrifice, financial support has chiefly come till today from Bardoli itself.
('42', 22, 3, 23, 44164) Whatever contribution has been sent by anyone voluntarily has been accepted.
('42', 22, 3, 24, 44241) To do so hereafter would be beyond our capacity.
('42', 22, 3, 25, 44290) Tomorrow the people of Bardoli may have no homes, no possessions, no fields, no cattle.
('42', 22, 3, 26, 44378) In such circumstances, Vallabhbhai has a right to ask for outside assistance.
('42', 22, 3, 27, 44456) Everyone should read Vallabhbhai’s leaflet appealing for funds and those who aprove of this movement in Bardoli and those who see purity and courage in it should contribute all they can.
('42', 22, 3, 28, 44643) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 13 5 1928
('42', 23, 0, 1, 44680) 24 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 23, 1, 2, 44721) 36. PRIMARY EDUCATION–I
('42', 23, 2, 3, 44745) Among the aims of the Gujarat Vidyapith is that its activity should be primarily concerned with village education.
('42', 23, 2, 4, 44860) Village educ ation today has broadly come to mean primary education.
('42', 23, 2, 5, 44929) The task of this Vidyapith is not to turn out schoolteachers or clerks but to train village workers.
('42', 23, 2, 6, 45030) If the Vidyapith must be near a city, its task is to contribute towards changing the attitude of the city if possible.
('42', 23, 2, 7, 45149) In other words, the cities which today flourish on the ruins of villages should so change that they serve the villages.
('42', 23, 2, 8, 45269) Whether or not the cities change, the Vidyapith must convert to this viewpoint as many as possible of the young men and women there.
('42', 23, 2, 9, 45402) Hence it is necessary that primary education should be considered from various points of view.
('42', 23, 2, 10, 45497) I wish to dwell on only one idea in this article.
('42', 23, 2, 11, 45547) From many years of reflection and quite a few experiments, I have come to the conclusion that primary education should be given for at least a year without using any text books and even after that pupils should make the minimum use of them.
('42', 23, 2, 12, 45788) When a child is learning the alphabet, when he is trying to master the forms of numerals and letters, his senses remain dormant and his intelligence, instead of blossoming, becomes stunted.
('42', 23, 2, 13, 45978) A child starts learning immediately after birth but it does so mainly through the eyes and ears.
('42', 23, 2, 14, 46075) It learns language as soon as it starts speaking.
('42', 23, 2, 15, 46125) Hence the child is as its parents are.
('42', 23, 2, 16, 46164) If the latter are cultured, the child pronounces words correctly and imitates the right ways of the home.
('42', 23, 2, 17, 46270) This alone constitutes his true education and were it not that our civilization has become so disrupted, children would be receiving the best education in the home itself.
('42', 23, 2, 18, 46442) But we are not yet in such a happy situation.
('42', 23, 2, 19, 46488) There is no alternative to sending children to schools.
('42', 23, 2, 20, 46544) However, if children must go to shcools, these should feel like homes to them and their teachers should be as parents.
('42', 23, 2, 21, 46663) The education given also should be similar to that which is im parted in a cultured home.
('42', 23, 2, 22, 46753) In other words, children must receive their primary education from teachers through the spoken word.
('42', 23, 2, 23, 46854) By receiving education in this manner can a child gain in a year through his eyes and ears ten times the knowledge he can acquire through the alphabet.
('42', 24, 0, 1, 47006) VOL. 42: 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 25
('42', 24, 1, 2, 47048) The child will have got a general knowledge of history and geography in the first year through play and in the form of stories.
('42', 24, 1, 3, 47176) He will have learnt some poems by heart with their correct pronunciation.
('42', 24, 1, 4, 47250) He will have memorized his tables.
('42', 24, 1, 5, 47285) Moreover, as the child will not be burdened with having to identify letters of the alphabet, his mind will be kept from withering and his eyes will not be misused.
('42', 24, 1, 6, 47449) The child’s hand, instead of being used to form crooked letters on a slate and trying to understand the difficult symbols that are letters, would rather be engaged in drawing geometrical lines and recognizing pictures.
('42', 24, 1, 7, 47668) This is the primary education of the hands.
('42', 24, 1, 8, 47712) And if we wish to impart primary education to the crores of children of Gujarat and of India, we shall not be able to do so in any other way.
('42', 24, 1, 9, 47854) Under the present circumstances, it is impossible for this country to see that books reach crores of children.
('42', 24, 1, 10, 47965) I admit that if it is necessary to supply children with books in order to give them primary education, we should try to do so, whatever the cost.
('42', 24, 1, 11, 48111) However, if books are regarded as superfluous and harmful, the practical argument may be put forward.
('42', 24, 1, 12, 48213) What is unnecessary or harmful from an ethical standpoint is also found to be impractical.
('42', 24, 1, 13, 48304) In a civilization that is from flaws, the ethical and the practical are not opposed to each other and should not be.
('42', 24, 1, 14, 48421) It is clear that such education cannot be given by the teachers of present day primary schools.
('42', 24, 1, 15, 48517) These teahcers may thrash the children and make them learn the alphabet and perhaps a few numbers.
('42', 24, 1, 16, 48616) The poor teacher himself does not have the general knowledge which I visualize for the child in the first year.
('42', 24, 1, 17, 48728) When the teachers themselves do not know how to speak the language in its pure form, how can the children learn it from them?
('42', 24, 1, 18, 48854) We shall consider this idea in the second part.
('42', 24, 2, 19, 48902) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 13 5 1928
('42', 25, 0, 1, 48939) 26 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('42', 27, 4, 9, 52174) 41. THE ONLY ISSUE The Bardoli campaign is going on merrily.
('42', 27, 4, 10, 52235) At the rate the for feiture notices are being served, practically the whole of the Taluk of Bardoli should be in Government’s possession and they can pay themselves a thousand times over for their precious assessment.
('42', 27, 4, 11, 52453) The people of Bardoli if they are brave will be none the worse for dispossesion.
('42', 27, 4, 12, 52534) They will have lost their possessions but kept what must be the dearest of all to good men and women—their honour.
('42', 27, 4, 13, 52649) Those who have stout hearts and hands need never fear loss of belongings.
('42', 27, 4, 14, 52723) But forfeiture notices having failed the Government, are now adding to them the imprisonment of workers.
('42', 27, 4, 15, 52828) They are holding.
('42', 27, 4, 16, 52846) mock trials such as we saw during the Punjab martial law days.
('42', 27, 4, 17, 52909) The prosecutor is asking for and the obliging special magistrate is giving deterrent sentences which are all rigorous.
('42', 27, 4, 18, 53028) These too like disposse ssion will do good to the willing victims.
('42', 27, 4, 19, 53095) Suffering willingly under gone never harms the sufferer.
('42', 27, 4, 20, 53152) What however goes against the grain is dishonesty and insolence of office.
('42', 27, 4, 21, 53227) The Commissioner, Northern Division has written a letter to a correspondent is full of insulting insinuations and untruths.
('42', 27, 4, 22, 53351) It is an untruthful insinuation to suggest that the campaign was started by Kheda agitators.
('42', 27, 4, 23, 53444) It was started by the Bardoli people themselves and the only person whose help and advice they sought was Sjt.
('42', 27, 4, 24, 53555) Vallabhabai Patel whom I presume the Commissioner knows somewhat.
('42', 27, 4, 25, 53621) Whether he can truthfully be called agitator in the sence intended by Commissioner must be left to the reader to judge.
('42', 27, 4, 26, 53741) It is untruthful to say that the officers of the Government are subjected to “spying, mobbing and other indignities”.
('42', 27, 4, 27, 53859) The workers are described as “the swarm of agitators living on
('42', 28, 0, 1, 53922) VOL. 42: 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 29
('42', 28, 1, 2, 53964) them (the people of Bardoli) and misguiding them”.
('42', 28, 1, 3, 54015) This is an insult for which under better times and if the nation was conscious of its strength the Commissioner would be made to offer a public apology.
('42', 28, 1, 4, 54168) Let him know that those whom in his anger and intoxication of power he calls a “swarm of agitators” are honourable servants of the nation giving their free services to Bardoli at considerable sacrifice.
('42', 28, 1, 5, 54371) Among these, besides Vallabhabhai Patel who is a Barrister, are the hoary headed Abbas Tyabji, another Barrister and an ex Chief Judge of Baroda, Imamsaheb Bawazir, who is practically a fakir needing no support from Bardoli, and Dr. Sumant Mehta and his equally cultured wife.
('42', 28, 1, 6, 54648) Dr. Sumant Mehta who has been ailing for some time has gone to Bardoli at considerable risk to his health.
('42', 28, 1, 7, 54755) These four by the way do not belong to Kheda at all.
('42', 28, 1, 8, 54808) Then there is the Darbarsaheb of Dhasa and his intrepid wife Bhaktiba who for the sake of their country have sacrificed their estate.
('42', 28, 1, 9, 54942) They are not living upon the people of Bardoli.
('42', 28, 1, 10, 54990) There are doctors Chandulal and Tribhuvan das, again not of Kheda.
('42', 28, 1, 11, 55057) Add to these Fulchand Shah, his wife, and his lieutenant Shivanand (already in jail).
('42', 28, 1, 12, 55143) These again do not belong to Kheda and have for years dedicated themselves to silent service.
('42', 28, 1, 13, 55237) It is the wail of Bardoli that has called these and others whom I can name.
('42', 28, 1, 14, 55313) If the Commissioner has any sense of honour about him he will volunteer an apology to these ladies and gentlemen.
('42', 28, 1, 15, 55427) In fact the Kheda workers are in a hopeless minority among the numerous workers.
('42', 28, 1, 16, 55508) The Commissioner pompously trots out the adverse vote of the Bombay Council and conveniently suppresses the two previous votes of the Council that had gone against the Government and that were by them treated as beneath contempt and beneath notice.
('42', 28, 1, 17, 55757) The Commissioner suppresses the very relevant truth that before resorting to direct action the people of Bardoli tried every means known as constitutional to get redress and hopelessly failed.
('42', 28, 1, 18, 55950) The Commissioner throws dust in the eyes of the public when he suggest that if the sorely tried people of Bardoli give up their campaign he would gladly investigate the case of any village that may be found to have been wrongly grouped.
('42', 28, 1, 19, 56187) He suppresses the truth that the point at issue is not the wrong grouping of this village or that; the point at issue is the palpably wrong method of assessment.
('42', 28, 1, 20, 56349) And the people of Bardoli do not insist upon their point being accepted but they do insist upon an independent and impartial tribunal being appointed to investigate the justice of their complaint and to abide by
('42', 29, 0, 1, 56561) 30 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 29, 1, 2, 56602) the judgment of that tribunal whatever it may by.
('42', 29, 1, 3, 56652) Here there is no shirking of payment, no question of redress of individual hardship.
('42', 29, 1, 4, 56737) The question is one of principle.
('42', 29, 1, 5, 56771) The people of Bardoli deny the right of the Government to dictate without proper investigation any increase in the assessment.
('42', 29, 1, 6, 56898) Let me add that this is no no tax campaign launched for any political end.
('42', 29, 1, 7, 56973) This is a campaign directed towards a well defined specific grievance affecting the people of a whole Taluk.
('42', 29, 1, 8, 57082) It is therefore the height of impudence and gross untruth for the Commissioner to say :
('42', 29, 2, 9, 57170) No one is more anxious than I that the poor cultivators should not be ruined by the swarm of agitators who are living on them and misguiding them.
('42', 29, 3, 10, 57317) There are five taluks in Kaira District from which these agitators come, the revision settlements of which have been postponed for 2 years on account of floods.
('42', 29, 3, 11, 57478) Nearly half a crore of rupees has been advanced by Government in Kaira District for flood relief in the last 7 or 8 months.
('42', 29, 3, 12, 57602) If they succeed in Bardoli, the recovery of Government assessment and takavi in Kaira District would be imperilled.
('42', 29, 3, 13, 57718) If the “agitators” succeed, it will not be the takavi to Kheda that will be in jeopardy.
('42', 29, 3, 14, 57807) If it is withheld by the borrowers the Government will find the arch agitator Vallabhbhai Patel to be their unpaid collector of the loans.
('42', 29, 3, 15, 57946) What however will happen if the agitators succeed is that the Government officers will not dare to insult honoured servants of the people and utter untruths as the Commiss ioner, Northern Division has done and that the people will be able to have some redress against grossly unfair and unjust assessment as the Bardoli assessment is claimed to be.
('42', 29, 3, 16, 58295) One word to the people.
('42', 29, 3, 17, 58319) The Government in their wisdom and in order to emphasize the fact that this rule is sustained by the policy of divide et impera have drafted in the midst of an over whelmingly large Hindu population Mussalman officials and Pathan hirelings.
('42', 29, 3, 18, 58560) As satyagrahis the people can easily checkmate the Government.
('42', 29, 3, 19, 58623) Let them treat the officials and the Pathans as friends.
('42', 29, 3, 20, 58680) Let them not distrust or in any the slightest manner fear or molest them.
('42', 29, 3, 21, 58754) They the officials are our countrymen, the Pathans are our neighbours.
('42', 29, 3, 22, 58825) Ere long the Government will discover their mistake and know that the honour of a Hindu is as dear to a Mussalman as to a Hindu and vice versa.
('42', 29, 3, 23, 58969) The people of Bardoli have the chance of demonstrating this in a concrete manner.
('42', 29, 3, 24, 59051) Let them vindicate the law of satyagraha which is also the law of Love and they will melt even the stony heart of an autocratic Commissioner.
('42', 29, 3, 25, 59193) Young India, 17 5 1928
('42', 30, 0, 1, 59216) VOL. 42: 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 31
('42', 30, 1, 2, 59258) 42. SUPPRESSED CLASSES AND BAGHAT STATE
('42', 30, 2, 3, 59298) After all the Rana Saheb of Baghat did receive on the 5th instant a deputation on behalf of the Arya Pratinidhi Sabha, Punjab, consisting of Rai Saheb Lala Ganga Ram, Pandit Chamupati, M.A., Dewan Ram Sharan Das of Ludhiana, Pandit Dharmavir Vedalankar and Lala Shankar Nath, Advocate, Simla, to discuss the situation that had arisen out of the recent attitude of the State in the matter of wearing of the sacred thread by Kolis, reclaimed by the Arya Samaj.
('42', 30, 2, 4, 59757) The deputation has been permitted to issue the following agreed statement of what happened at the interview :
('42', 30, 3, 5, 59867) The members of the deputation thanked Rana Saheb for the cordial hospitality extended to them, and explained the position of the Shastras and the Arya Pratinidhi Sabha in this behalf.
('42', 30, 3, 6, 60051) His Highness gave a patient hearing to their representation and assured them that his State gave perfect liberty to all well established religious societies to propagate their religion among his subjects.
('42', 30, 3, 7, 60256) The members expressed their gratitude for the courtesy with which their representation was heard and the encouraging reply vouchsafed to them and withdrew.
('42', 30, 3, 8, 60412) The agreed statement betrays too much caution and great timidity on the part of the State.
('42', 30, 3, 9, 60503) The State would have gained in public estimation by a frank confession of the wrong done to the suppressed classes and the insult offered to a great religious organiz ation.
('42', 30, 3, 10, 60677) However let us be thankful for small mercies.
('42', 30, 3, 11, 60723) The wrong and the insult will be forgotten if the letter and the spirit of the promise made by the Rana Saheb are fulfilled.

('42', 30, 5, 13, 60871) 43. MAGANLAL GANDHI MEMORIAL
('42', 30, 6, 14, 60900) The Council of the All India Spinners’ Association passed the following resolution at its meeting on the 12th instant :
('42', 30, 7, 15, 61020) Resolved that a khadi museum be organized in memory of the late Sjt.
('42', 30, 7, 16, 61089) Maganlal K. Gandhi and that an appeal be made for rupees one lakh for this purpose, the location of the Memorial and other details of the administration to be decided by the Council.
('42', 30, 7, 17, 61272) The numerous messages of condolence sent to me from all parts
('42', 31, 0, 1, 61334) 32 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 31, 1, 2, 61375) of India and distant South Africa show the place that the deceased found in the affections of the public.
('42', 31, 1, 3, 61481) A silent worker so good and popular as the deceased deserves a memorial.
('42', 31, 1, 4, 61554) The Council of the All India Spinners’ Association after deep consideration came to the conclusion that there could be no better memorial to the deceased than that a khadi museum be established at some suitable place.
('42', 31, 1, 5, 61772) The deceased himself had conceived the idea and as was his wont had utilized a room in the Satyagraha Ashram for a miniature museum.
('42', 31, 1, 6, 61905) But the manner in which khadi has progressed requires a permanent and commodious building and a collection worthy of the deceased and the movement.
('42', 31, 1, 7, 62053) Such a museum cannot cost anything less than one lakh of rupees.
('42', 31, 1, 8, 62118) Hence the minimum amount ofone lakh fixed by the Council.
('42', 31, 1, 9, 62176) A khadi museum to be a house of serious study and instruction is capable of limitless expansion.
('42', 31, 1, 10, 62273) With one lakh of rupees the Council hopes only to make a modest yet substantial beginning and give permanent shape to the scheme the deceased had in view.
('42', 31, 1, 11, 62428) In accordance with the response the public may make, the museum may have a full set of books dealing with the past and the present of cotton culture, the specimens of the finest to the coarsest khadi produced in the past and in the present, the specimens of spinning wheels, hand gins, carding bows and handlooms from the most ancient obtainable to the most modern.
('42', 31, 1, 12, 62794) There may be a plot of ground attached to the museum where experiments can be made in cotton growing to suit not the world market and the princes of exploitation but the humble villa ger.
('42', 31, 1, 13, 62982) This latter was being done by the deceased at the Satyagraha Ashram.
('42', 31, 1, 14, 63051) The cotton grown at the Ashram has become very popular with spinners.
('42', 31, 1, 15, 63121) Home grown cotton, which is well picked and which does not need to un dergo the devitalizing process of pressing, saves immense labur and time for the carder and enables the spinner to draw a stronger thread.
('42', 31, 1, 16, 63330) These and many other things can be done at the proposed museum if the response is liberal and exceeds the minimum fixed by the Council.
('42', 31, 1, 17, 63466) The machinery to give effect to the scheme is to be the All India Spinners’ Association which is a growing organization of men determined upon doing solid and constructive work.
('42', 31, 1, 18, 63644) The venue of the museum is not fixed as the Council has a choice of more places than one.
('42', 31, 1, 19, 63734) Sabarmati naturally occurs first to the mind.
('42', 31, 1, 20, 63780) And if it is found to be otherwise the most convenient spot, no doubt it will be chosen by the Council.
('42', 31, 1, 21, 63884) It hopes to make the Museum
('42', 32, 0, 1, 63912) VOL. 42: 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 33
('42', 32, 1, 2, 63954) as businesslike as was the deceased himself.
('42', 32, 1, 3, 63999) No false sentiment will therefore be allowed to weigh with the Council in the choice of the venue.
('42', 32, 1, 4, 64098) All subscriptions will be acknowledged in these columns.
('42', 32, 1, 5, 64155) Payments may be made either to the Secretary, Sjt.
('42', 32, 1, 6, 64206) Shankerlal Banker, Mirzapur, Ahmedabad, or to Sheth Jamnalalji Bajaj, 395, Kalbadevi Road, Bombay, or to the Manager, Satyagraha Ashram, Sabarmati.

('42', 32, 3, 10, 64564) The Department of Industries in the Nizam’s dominions recently sent its inspector to study the technique of khadi at the Staygraha Ashram and sent also two young men to learn the various processes.
('42', 32, 3, 11, 64762) The young men were not able to finish the course, as the climate and perhaps the life at the Ashram did not agree with them.
('42', 32, 3, 12, 64887) The point is that a beginning has been made, the inspector Moulvi Mahomed Ali was full of enthusiasm and he seemed to realize as never before the importance of the spinning wheel.
('42', 32, 3, 13, 65067) Let me hope that the Department of Industries will keep in touch with the Technical Department of the A.I.S.A. and organize the charkha work in Hyderabad in a proper businesslike manner, as it is being done in Mysore, where the other day the Dewan Mr. Mirza Mahomed Ismail personally inspected the khadi work being done through the suppressed classes.

('42', 35, 6, 8, 69706) 49. PRIMARY EDUCATION–II
('42', 35, 7, 9, 69731) The problem is how to impart the education we discussed in the last issue and wherefrom to get the teachers to impart it.
('42', 35, 7, 10, 69853) This is the real problem regarding education.
('42', 35, 7, 11, 69899) The Government Training College has not solved this problem.
('42', 35, 7, 12, 69960) It has not even solved the problem of the three Rs—that is, reading, writing and arithmetic.
('42', 35, 7, 13, 70053) Even of these three so little is learnt that neither the pupils nor the public profit much by it.
('42', 35, 7, 14, 70151) Hence this task has to be taken up by the National College.
('42', 35, 7, 15, 70211) It is the duty and the right of the latter to find new methods in the field of education which would sustain the national cause.
('42', 35, 7, 16, 70340) And in my humble opinion, we can take these methods in a very small measure from Europe and in an even smaller measure from the current trends in India.
('42', 35, 7, 17, 70493) In every country education is for the preservation of its independence.
('42', 35, 7, 18, 70565) Hence we shall have to conduct new experiments in our education.
('42', 35, 7, 19, 70630) In doing so, we may well make ourselves familiar with the experience in Europe; but we should not conclude that all that if found there is good or what is good under the conditions prevailing there will be good for us.
('42', 35, 7, 20, 70849) One of the conclusions that emerges from this is that we should regard with suspicion the methods practised in the Government schools.
('42', 35, 7, 21, 70984) Since the education imparted by the Government is fatal to swaraj as well as to our civilization, it is possible that if we follow the opposite methods in many matters we may find
('42', 35, 8, 22, 71164) 1 This was sent in reply to a telegram received on May 19 from Mahomed Ali, Inspector, Industries, Aurangabad, which read: “Khadi Exhibition spinning demonstration succesful by your blessings.
('42', 35, 8, 23, 71357) Maharajah Bahadur kissed your yarn and sends best salaams and promises to spin.
('42', 35, 8, 24, 71437) Your blessings required.”
('42', 36, 0, 1, 71463) VOL. 42: 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 37
('42', 36, 1, 2, 71505) the right path.
('42', 36, 1, 3, 71521) Let us take an example.
('42', 36, 1, 4, 71545) The medium of instruction there is English, hence we must conclude that the medium of national education cannot be English.
('42', 36, 1, 5, 71669) They put up huge expensive buildings in which to give education.
('42', 36, 1, 6, 71734) We should realize that this is improper.
('42', 36, 1, 7, 71775) Our School buildings should be simple and inexpensive.
('42', 36, 1, 8, 71830) Stress there is purely on literary learning and India’s industries are ignored.
('42', 36, 1, 9, 71910) We know that this is improper.
('42', 36, 1, 10, 71941) In that form of education, teaching of religion, that is, religion not of any particular community but universal religion, has no place.
('42', 36, 1, 11, 72078) We know that this leads to a negation of education.
('42', 36, 1, 12, 72130) The history that is taught in Government schools is, if not false, written from the British standpoint.
('42', 36, 1, 13, 72234) The very same facts have been interpreted differently by German, French and American historians.
('42', 36, 1, 14, 72331) Contemporary events are interpreted by the Government in one way and by the people in another, as in the case of the massacre in the Punjab.
('42', 36, 1, 15, 72472) The economics taught in Government schools upholds the British system while we, on the other hand, view it differently.
('42', 36, 1, 16, 72592) Government schools make a plea for the town civilization, whereas the villages are the soul of our national civilization.
('42', 36, 1, 17, 72714) In Government primary schools, their teachers, with the minimum amount of knowledge, are employed without regard to their character and on the minimum salaries possible, whereas in national primary schools, the teachers being self sacrificing and persons of character and learning (and not because they are in in a sorry plight), should accept the smallest salaries.
('42', 36, 1, 18, 73081) We can now have an idea of the kind of education that should be given in the city schools.
('42', 36, 1, 19, 73172) Our pupils should live in villages, lend stability to village civilization, be familiar with the needs of villages, rid them of such faults as they may have, teach their children not to become city dwellers but to remain villagers, i.e., to become farmers.
('42', 36, 1, 20, 73429) Hence so long as the existing system of education in the cities is not basically changed without fear, we shall not attain one of the basic ideals of the Vidyapith nor may we be said to practise it.
('42', 36, 1, 21, 73628) Let us take only one example: In Ahmedabad itself we are running a university, a new Gujarati school and a Vinay Mandir.
('42', 36, 1, 22, 73749) We shall have the right to run them only when we attempt to make villagers out of the children who study in them, when we succeed in making them take interest in village life, when we make them understand the latter, and, finally, when those of them who are about
('42', 37, 0, 1, 74013) 38 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 37, 1, 2, 74054) to leave the Vinay Mandir or the University, spread out into the villages and start serving the villagers.
('42', 37, 1, 3, 74161) We shall consider next how this can be done.
('42', 37, 1, 4, 74206) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 20 5 1928

('42', 38, 5, 14, 76313) S. Ganesan, the enterprising publisher of Madras, has now brought out a translation from the original of my History, if it may be so called, of Satyagraha in South Africa.
('42', 38, 5, 15, 76485) The translation has been carefully made by Sjt Valji Gavindji Desai.
('42', 38, 5, 16, 76554) The volume is well printed, is bound in khadi, covers 511 pages and is rightly dedicated by the publisher to the late Maganlal Gandhi.
('42', 38, 5, 17, 76689) The book contains 50 chapters and covers practically the whole of the period of my stay in South Africa.
('42', 38, 5, 18, 76794) Those numerous readers who are following “The Story of My Experiments with Truth” cannot afford to be without this volume, if they will rightly understand the implications of truth as they have occurred to me and the very wonderful and matchless force which I have called or rather which Maganlal Gandhi called ‘satyagraha’ otherwise rendered as ‘love force’, ‘soul force’, ‘truth force’, as distinguished from the force connoted by the term ‘passive resistance’.
('42', 38, 5, 19, 77258) Satyagraha is not conceived as a weapon merely of the weak.
('42', 38, 5, 20, 77318) It is the strongest force that one can possibly imagine or wish for and is a complete substitution for brute force.
('42', 38, 5, 21, 77434) Those who will understand how the former worked in South Africa in the face of all odds should possess this volume.
('42', 38, 5, 22, 77550) It can be had from S. Ganesan, Publisher, Triplicane, Madras, S. E., price Rs. 4 8 0.

('42', 39, 4, 5, 77918) 54. BUYING MERIT
('42', 39, 5, 6, 77935) A correspondent draws my attention to the institution of lotteries in Goa for the purpose of supporting hospitals.
('42', 39, 5, 7, 78050) The correspondent tells me that lakhs of rupees are spent by people in British India in these lotteries in the vain hope of suddenly becoming rich without effort and yet gaining heavenly merit.
('42', 39, 5, 8, 78244) Here is an extract from an advertisement sent by the correspondent :
('42', 39, 6, 9, 78313) Behold the sick.
('42', 39, 6, 10, 78330) He that giveth to the poor lends to God.
('42', 39, 6, 11, 78371) Then why not help our poor by staking a rupee at this drawing?
('42', 39, 6, 12, 78434) It is a comely way of exerc ising charity.
('42', 39, 6, 13, 78477) The advertisement contains a portrait of a hoary headed rever end gentleman.
('42', 39, 6, 14, 78554) It would be interesting to know the condition of the hospitals built with the monies gained from these lotteries.
('42', 39, 6, 15, 78668) Meanwhile it is worth while to examine the ethics of founding charitable institutions with monies collected by an appeal to man’s greed, enhancing it by a promise of merit if the purchaser of such a lottery ticket should fail to get the tempting prize or prizes as lakhs of purchasers must fail.
('42', 39, 6, 16, 78964) As it is, the haste to be rich without working and waiting for the happy day pervades the atmosphere.
('42', 39, 6, 17, 79066) Everyone who spends a rupee on the race course or in a lottery ticket erects the pyramid of his hope on the foundation of the ruin of a multitude of such hopes of men and women having equal right with the few lucky (?) winners of prizes.
('42', 39, 6, 18, 79304) It is difficult, however, to single out the lottery system for criticism, when the gambling spirit possesses even those who are ranked among the most respectable.
('42', 39, 6, 19, 79467) The share market is nothing but a feverish gamble.
('42', 39, 6, 20, 79518) And yet who is free from that fever?
('42', 39, 6, 21, 79555) Every man who finds himself rich in a day by manipulating the share market knows that the sudden accession of wealth means desolation of many a widow’s home.
('42', 39, 7, 22, 79713) 1 Not reproduced here
('42', 40, 0, 1, 79735) VOL. 42: 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 41
('42', 40, 1, 2, 79777) the relatives of the widows who bought shares had, no doubt, almost the same kind of hope that the clever speculator of our imagination had.
('42', 40, 1, 3, 79918) Cotton, rice and jute are, strange as it may appear, objects of such speculation.
('42', 40, 1, 4, 80000) The system of lottery is but a crude extension of the same gambling spirit.
('42', 40, 1, 5, 80076) It is no doubt good to treat the lottery as disrespectable, but it is better to make the acquaintance of the spirit that is common to the lottery and the share market and thus deal with the root cause of the disease rather than its worst symptom.
('42', 40, 1, 6, 80323) It is, therefore, to be wished that the worst symptom will enable us to reach the root cause and deal effectively with it.
('42', 40, 1, 7, 80446) But it is a far off hope.
('42', 40, 1, 8, 80472) Let not my mention of the pervasive nature of the disease make a single person connected with these lotteries seek justification for his participation in the lottery system.
('42', 40, 1, 9, 80646) And the caution is all the more necessary when the lottery is in connection with a charitable institution.
('42', 40, 1, 10, 80753) Surely it is bad enough to want to be rich without deserving, but it is positively wrong to connect charity with a gamble.
('42', 40, 1, 11, 80876) Those who throw away rupees in lotteries must not think that they gain merit even whilst they are hoping to satisfy an unlawful ambition.
('42', 40, 1, 12, 81014) We may not hope to serve God and Mammon at the same time.
('42', 40, 1, 13, 81072) And why do the Christian conductors of the Goan hospitals degrade religion by exploiting the evil tendency of human nature?
('42', 40, 1, 14, 81196) Do they imagine that they please God by attempting to support a hospital by making lakhs of people morally diseased?
('42', 40, 1, 15, 81313) Are they not robbing Peter to pay Paul?
('42', 40, 1, 16, 81353) What will it profit them to heal a few bodies if at the same time they wound a thousand times more souls?
('42', 40, 1, 17, 81459) Young India, 24 5 1928
('42', 40, 2, 18, 81482) 55. SPINNING IN MUNICIPAL SCHOOLS The Secretary, Khadi Board, Jalgaon, sends me a well prepared tabulated report of takli and charkha spinning in its municipal schools.
('42', 40, 2, 19, 81651) The report covers the period between 15th June, 1927 and 15th February, 1928. 149 girls and 126 boys were spinning either on the takli or the wheel.
('42', 40, 2, 20, 81800) The time allowed was from 25 minutes to 50 minutes per day.
('42', 40, 2, 21, 81860) The total output was 4,48,000 yards.
('42', 40, 2, 22, 81897) The maximus speed on the takli was 125 yards per hour and on the wheel 325 yards.
('42', 40, 2, 23, 81979) This is a creditable record.
('42', 40, 2, 24, 82008) What has been possible in the Jalgaon Municipal schools is possible in all the municipal schools.

('42', 41, 1, 2, 82147) can be shown that if the nation willed it, it could get all the yarn it needs through it schools going children and teach them self repect and self reliance during their scholastic life, a period which some falsely think is one of irresponsibility and indulgence.
('42', 41, 1, 3, 82411) I note that only boys spinning on the wheels do their own carding.
('42', 41, 1, 4, 82478) The implication is that the others do not.

('42', 45, 4, 11, 88308) 65. LETTER TO JANAKDHARI PRASAD
('42', 45, 5, 12, 88340) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, May 25, 1928
('42', 45, 6, 13, 88376) DEAR JANAKDHARI BABU, I have your letter.
('42', 45, 6, 14, 88418) There should be nothing between God and us, if we are to be nearest to Him.
('42', 45, 6, 15, 88494) Love between husband and wife is a hindrance, for that love as we understand it, is necessarily exclusive and necessarily personal.
('42', 45, 6, 16, 88626) 2. Faith in God cannot be reasoned out.
('42', 45, 6, 17, 88666) It does not come from the head but from the heart, and, things of the heart are spontaneous and instinctive.
('42', 45, 6, 18, 88775) Our very weakness and limitations should inspire faith in the Perfect and the Limitless.
('42', 45, 6, 19, 88864) And if we have that faith, we would necessarily be without troubles, miseries and the like.
('42', 45, 6, 20, 88956) 3. Why do you say that you are not serving the public cause because you are drawing Rs. 50 per month?
('42', 45, 6, 21, 89058) Everyone who serves the Charkha Sangh undoubtedly serves the nation.
('42', 45, 6, 22, 89127) It would be foolish to expect in this poor country to work without even being fed.
('42', 45, 6, 23, 89210) That other people have no regard or love for you because you are not a flourishing lawyer is no cause for sorrow.
('42', 45, 6, 24, 89324) But it is a good cause for
('42', 46, 0, 1, 89351) VOL. 42: 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 47
('42', 46, 1, 2, 89393) congratulation, if you can be happy without wealth and public esteem.
('42', 46, 1, 3, 89463) Why should Babu Vindeshwari Prasad seek your protection?
('42', 46, 1, 4, 89520) If he has the conviction that it would be right in giving up his practice, he should delight in earning his starvation wage as millions of our countrymen are doing.
('42', 46, 1, 5, 89685) If he is repentant that he gave up his practice, he should resume it.
('42', 46, 1, 6, 89755) As for your children the true education that you can give them is to bring them up as honest labourers.
('42', 46, 1, 7, 89859) And that education can profit them and the country; and instead of your children being a burden on you, will be blessing to both.
('42', 46, 1, 8, 89989) I hope your wife has completely recovered.
('42', 46, 1, 9, 90032) Let me say that the Ashram constitution is undergoing a drastic revision and at the present moment, the desire is not to take any more for at least one year.
('42', 46, 1, 10, 90190) Therefore, if your wife should desire to come here during the next one or two months, please write to me before you think of sending her.
('42', 46, 2, 11, 90328) Yours sincerely, M. K. GANDHI

('42', 47, 1, 2, 91228) 67. LETTER TO KISHORELAL MASHRUWALA
('42', 47, 2, 3, 91264) Friday, Jeth Sud 6, 1984 [May 25, 1928]
('42', 47, 3, 4, 91304) KISHORELAL, I have read both your letters carefully.
('42', 47, 3, 5, 91357) What I said, and the manner in which I said it, does not seem to have been correctly reported to you.
('42', 47, 3, 6, 91459) There is nothing new in the changes I have suggested.
('42', 47, 3, 7, 91513) I have not made any change in the definition of an Ashram inmate.
('42', 47, 3, 8, 91579) The only significance of the change is that we should strive hard to follow the ideal which we have always kept before us.
('42', 47, 3, 9, 91702) I never put pressure on anyone, and have never wished to do so.
('42', 47, 3, 10, 91766) I have recently refused to do that on two friends who wish to run separate kitchens for themselves.
('42', 47, 3, 11, 91866) I, therefore, see no compulsion in regard to anything.
('42', 47, 3, 12, 91921) I employ earnest argument (with love) and try to explain everything clearly.
('42', 47, 3, 13, 91998) I am of the view that those who have joined the Ashram should conform to the moral growth or changes in the Ashram.
('42', 47, 3, 14, 92114) They cannot say that they will obey certain rules only and that, if new rules are made and applied, it would be breach of contract.
('42', 47, 3, 15, 92246) No institution can continue to exist on that condition.
('42', 47, 3, 16, 92302) There can be fixity only about concerete matters, such as salary, period, etc.
('42', 47, 3, 17, 92381) At the Ashram, however, generally speaking, we have no restrictions other than moral.
('42', 47, 3, 18, 92467) Even so, we decided to enforce the rule about brahmacharya only after all the inmates had been invited to discuss it and everyone had accepted its necessity.
('42', 47, 3, 19, 92625) I did say, when reading out this rule, that those who could not or did not wish to observe it, could leave the Ashram.
('42', 47, 3, 20, 92744) The common kitchen is functioning satisfactorily at present.
('42', 47, 3, 21, 92805) I shall not inflict anything more on you.
('42', 47, 3, 22, 92847) I have written even this unwillingly.
('42', 47, 3, 23, 92885) Really speaking, you should not, in your present illness and from that distance, strain yourself thinking about the changes taking place here.
('42', 47, 3, 24, 93028) Maybe it is morally wrong for you to do so.
('42', 47, 3, 25, 93072) How are you now?
('42', 47, 3, 26, 93089) There is of course no question of your staying at Santa Cruz.
('42', 47, 3, 27, 93151) You are fit enough to come here.
('42', 47, 3, 28, 93184) You can take your treatment even here.
('42', 47, 3, 29, 93223) The climate here is certainly better than there.
('42', 47, 3, 30, 93272) If, however, you decide to come, I hope you will not think of going away again.
('42', 47, 4, 31, 93352) Blessings from BAPU

('42', 48, 10, 12, 93861) 69. LETTER TO MAHADEV DESAI May 26, 1928
('42', 48, 11, 13, 93902) MAHADEV, You send me enough every time.
('42', 48, 11, 14, 93942) How did all of you imagine something which had not occurred to me even in my dreams?
('42', 48, 11, 15, 94027) On that occasion, the day before yesterday, I did not aim my remarks against anyone in particular.
('42', 48, 11, 16, 94126) I opened the subject in a general way as affecting all eighty people.
('42', 48, 11, 17, 94196) Even in my mind I did not, and do not, blame, or think harsh things about those who cannot join the common kitchen; where was the question then of my saying such things in the meeting?
('42', 48, 11, 18, 94381) It should be enough, therefore, if I say that there was no violence in my heart.
('42', 48, 11, 19, 94462) I said harsh things only on that evening.
('42', 48, 11, 20, 94504) On that occasion, I was not at all pained by the opposition.
('42', 48, 11, 21, 94565) I was unhappy because of the weakness displayed by all.
('42', 48, 11, 22, 94621) I liked Narahari’s frankness very much indeed, but I did not like that he and others should have lost the use of their reason.
('42', 48, 11, 23, 94748) If it was I who had deprived them of their reason, what a worthless fellow I must be?
('42', 48, 11, 24, 94834) As I tried to think what my duty in these circumstances was, and as I realized it, I awoke and was immediately at peace.
('42', 48, 11, 25, 94955) Do you know that I have put on two pounds in nine days?
