('42', 50, 5, 8, 97009) 72. PRIMARY EDUCATION III
('42', 50, 6, 9, 97035) The problems of primary education or village eduction can be solved only when we thoroughly change the curricula of the Vidya Mandir and the University and when the teachers have understood my viewpoint.
('42', 50, 6, 10, 97239) Today we hesitate to effect certain changes for fear of losing pupils, for fear of public opinion or from a sense of false prestige.
('42', 50, 6, 11, 97372) If we had no hesitation these Vidya Mandirs would produce a fine set of people who would serve the villages and this would somewhat atone for the sins of the cities.
('42', 50, 6, 12, 97538) The pupils of these Mandirs would become first class spinners, carders and weavers; they would have the best knowledge of cotton growing, they would know carpentry to suit the needs of the village; in other words, they would know how to make good spinning wheels, they would know how to repair—if not make—bullock carts, ploughs, etc., they would know sewing enough for the needs of the village, their handwriting would be as beautiful as pearls, they would have a basic ability to write, they would know Indian multiplication tables, they would be familiar with ancient literature like the Mahabharata and the Ramayana and their modern spiritual meaning; they would know village games; they would be familiar with the rules of hygiene, they would be good home doctors, i.e., they would be able to diagnose common ailments and prescribe remedies for them; they would know how to clean village dumping grounds, ponds wells and so on.
('42', 50, 7, 13, 98471) 1 By Reinhold Niebuhr
('42', 51, 0, 1, 98493) 52 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 51, 1, 2, 98534) other words, education in these schools would be such that it enables the pupils to serve the villages in every way and the expenses incurred should be regarded as having been incurred on primary education.
('42', 51, 1, 3, 98741) Only when we do so and are able to do so, can we be said to have truly entered the villages.
('42', 51, 1, 4, 98834) But directly such a question is raised, such a change brought about and such an ideal proclaimed, our Vidya Mandirs will become empty.
('42', 51, 1, 5, 98969) Should such a contingency arise I would be willing to welcome it in the cause of truth.
('42', 51, 1, 6, 99057) But so long as the ideal of the Vidyapith regarding village education remains what it is, not to do this would amount to untruth and betrayal.
('42', 51, 1, 7, 99200) However, it is my belief as well as my experience that if we remain steadfast in our objective, the public will in the end understand it and help in advancing it.
('42', 51, 1, 8, 99363) If we looked into the causes of failures— so called or so considered—we would find that those who believed in the ideals were themselves disloyal, half baked and half hearted.
('42', 51, 1, 9, 99539) He who doubts will perish, but people instead of taking his doom for what it is think that it was his ideal that was wanting in some way and so failed.
('42', 51, 1, 10, 99691) It is my firm belief that if our Vidya Mandirs had teachers with faith and a spirit of self sacrifice, they would overflow with pupils.
('42', 51, 1, 11, 99827) People can recognize a genuine thing.
('42', 51, 1, 12, 99865) Often it seems to tate time, but that is merely an illusion.
('42', 51, 1, 13, 99926) It is a rule without an exception that the straight path is the quickest.
('42', 51, 1, 14, 100000) An institution which panders to people’s weaknesses and their love of pleasure may fill in no time.
('42', 51, 1, 15, 100100) So what?
('42', 51, 1, 16, 100109) That certainly does not prove its success.
('42', 51, 1, 17, 100152) One consequence may however flow from the acceptance of my viewpoint.
('42', 51, 1, 18, 100222) Those pupils who have come in the hope of getting the same kind of education as is imparted in Government schools, those who have come in the hope of acquiring fitness to lead a city life, would be disappointed and leave our Mandirs.
('42', 51, 1, 19, 100456) But it would be as well.
('42', 51, 1, 20, 100481) We as well as they would be saved from a false situation, would be able to render true service to one another.
('42', 51, 1, 21, 100592) I should like to close this series by dilating a little more on the idea with which I started it.
('42', 51, 1, 22, 100690) And then I hope to discuss a few questions I have before me on this subject.
('42', 51, 1, 23, 100767) If the view that a knowledge of the alphabet should be totally avoided during the first year of primary education is correct, some of its desirable consequences ought to be apparent in the Vidya Mandirs and the University.
('42', 52, 0, 1, 100990) VOL. 42: 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 53
('42', 52, 1, 2, 101032) Nowadays the cult of bookish knowledge has increased a great deal.
('42', 52, 1, 3, 101099) New books are being published every day.
('42', 52, 1, 4, 101140) Anyone who has any command over language, anyone who has reflected even a little, becomes eager to put his ideas into print and believes that in so doing he is rendering national service.
('42', 52, 1, 5, 101328) Consequently, an unbearable burden is placed on the brains of pupils and the pockets of their guardians.
('42', 52, 1, 6, 101433) The pupil’s intellect becomes confused.
('42', 52, 1, 7, 101473) Their brains stuffed with a multitude of facts have no room for any original thought.
('42', 52, 1, 8, 101559) And even facts instead of being properly arranged lie about in disorder in these brains like things in the house of an idle person.
('42', 52, 1, 9, 101691) They are of no use either to themselves or to the public.
('42', 52, 1, 10, 101749) Hence in my opinion the numerous books that are published nowadays should not be given to the pupils.
('42', 52, 1, 11, 101851) Even literate puplis should receive the larger part of their education orally from the teachers.
('42', 52, 1, 12, 101948) They should read the minimum number of books but should reflect on what they read and while doing so translate into practice whatever they find acceptable.
('42', 52, 1, 13, 102104) By doing so, the life of the pupils will become interesting, thoughtful, wise, steadfast, pure and energetic.
('42', 52, 1, 14, 102214) Such education befits a poor nation and will prove useful to the pupils and the public.
('42', 52, 1, 15, 102302) Hence the solution to the serious problem before the Vidyapith depends on the capacity of its present teachers to imbibe its ideals and to make a mighty effort to put them into practice.

('42', 60, 1, 2, 113193) 87. BARDOLI ON TRIAL
('42', 60, 2, 3, 113214) One may hastily think that the Government is on its trial in Bardoli.
('42', 60, 2, 4, 113284) But that would be a wrong opinion.
('42', 60, 2, 5, 113319) The Government has been tried and found wanting scores of times.
('42', 60, 2, 6, 113384) Frightfulness’ is its code of conduct when its vital parts ar affected.
('42', 60, 2, 7, 113456) If its prestige or its revenue is in danger, it seeks to sustain it either by means fair or foul.
('42', 60, 2, 8, 113554) It does not hesitate to resort to terrorism and cover it with unblushing untruths.
('42', 60, 2, 9, 113637) The latest information that Pathans are now being posted in villages with instructions to surround the houses of the villagers day and night need not cause either surprise or anger.
('42', 60, 2, 10, 113819) The surprise is that they have not yet let loose in Bardoli a punitive police and declared martial law.
('42', 60, 2, 11, 113923) We ought by this time to know what a punitive police or martial law means.
('42', 60, 2, 12, 113998) It is evident that by the latest form of ‘frightfulness’ the Government is seeking to good people into some act of violence, be it ever so slight, to justify their enactment of the last act in the tragedy.
('42', 60, 3, 13, 114204) Will the people of Bardoli stand this last trial?
('42', 60, 3, 14, 114254) They have already staggered Indian humanity.
('42', 60, 3, 15, 114299) They have shown heroic patience in the midst of great provocation.
('42', 60, 3, 16, 114366) Will they stand the greatest provocation that can be offered?
('42', 60, 3, 17, 114428) If they will, they will have gained everything.
('42', 60, 3, 18, 114476) Imprisonments, forfeitures, deportations, death, must all be taken in the ordinary course by those who count honour before everything else.
('42', 60, 3, 19, 114616) When the terror becomes unbearable, let the people leave the land they have hitherto believed to be theirs.
('42', 60, 3, 20, 114724) It is wisdom to vacate houses or places that are plagueinfected.
('42', 60, 3, 21, 114789) Tyranny is a kind of plague and when it is likely to make us angry or weak, it is wisdom to leave the scene of such temptation.
('42', 60, 3, 22, 114917) History is full of instances of brave people having sought exile in preference to surrender to zoolum.
('42', 60, 4, 23, 115020) Let me hope however that such a step will not be necessary.
('42', 60, 4, 24, 115080) One hears rumours of intercessions by well meaning friends.
('42', 60, 4, 25, 115140) They have the right, it may be even their duty, to intercede.
('42', 60, 4, 26, 115202) But let these friends realize the significance of the movement.
('42', 60, 4, 27, 115266) They are not to represent a weak cause or a weak people.
('42', 60, 4, 28, 115323) The people of Bardoli stand for an absolutely just cause.
('42', 60, 4, 29, 115381) They ask no favour, they seek only justice.
('42', 60, 4, 30, 115425) They do not ask anyone to consider their case to be true.
('42', 60, 4, 31, 115483) Their cause is to seek an independent, open, judicial inquiry and they undertake to abide by the verdict of such a tribunal.
('42', 60, 4, 32, 115608) To deny the tribunal is to deny justice which the Government have hitherto done.
('42', 60, 4, 33, 115689) The means at the
('42', 61, 0, 1, 115706) 62 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 61, 1, 2, 115747) disposal of the people are self suffering.
('42', 61, 1, 3, 115790) In such a cause then minimum and maximum are almost convertible terms.
('42', 61, 1, 4, 115861) Those who rely upon self suffering for redress of a grievance cannot affort to rate it higher than it actually is.
('42', 61, 1, 5, 115976) Those, therefore, who will intervene will harm the people and their cause, if they do not appreciate the implications of the struggle which cannot be lightly given up or compromised.
('42', 61, 1, 6, 116159) The public have a duty to perform by the satyagrahis.
('42', 61, 1, 7, 116213) The response is already being made to Vallabhbhai’s appeal for funds.
('42', 61, 1, 8, 116283) It will be remembered that he refused to make the appeal as long as it was possible to refrain.
('42', 61, 1, 9, 116379) The imprisonments have made the appeal imperative.
('42', 61, 1, 10, 116430) I have no doubt that the response will be quick and generous.
('42', 61, 1, 11, 116492) Equally necessary is the expression of enlightened public opinion.
('42', 61, 1, 12, 116559) Let the public study the facts carefully and then cover the whole of the land with public meetings.
('42', 61, 1, 13, 116659) I like the suggestion made by Sjt.
('42', 61, 1, 14, 116694) Jairamdas that June 12th or any other suitable day should be proclaimed as Bardoli Day when meetings representing all parties may be held to pass resolutions and make collections in aid of the sufferers of Bardoli.
('42', 61, 1, 15, 116909) Young India, 31 5 1928
('42', 61, 2, 16, 116932) 88. UNTOUCHABILITY IN THE SOUTH Though untouchability appears in its worst and crudest form in the extreme south, that is Kerala, not much, at least not enough is being done by the reformers in the south to stamp out the evil.
('42', 61, 2, 17, 117159) They will not even finance the movement to the extent that is necessary and possible for them.
('42', 61, 2, 18, 117254) When, therefore, I started collections during my visit to Calicut amongst the people locally, I was glad to find that the South Indian colony in Bombay signified their intention of making a much more substantial collection than was made in Calicut and giving it to me when I passed through Bombay.
('42', 61, 2, 19, 117552) In continuation of their promise a deputation came to me in Bombay during my recent visit and assured me that they had not forgotten it but that they were waiting for a favourable season for making the collections.
('42', 61, 2, 20, 117767) One of them now writes :
('42', 61, 3, 21, 117792) Many a young man with meagre salary is wasting his money in races and other city inducements, and if only we could wean them from their present tendencies, much could be expected of them for their own benefit as well as for the benefit of the city of Bombay.
('42', 62, 0, 1, 118051) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 63
('42', 62, 1, 2, 118094) I hope that this reform movement will take deep root amongst the South Indian young men.
('42', 62, 1, 3, 118183) I would advise them not to wait for a “favourable season”.
('42', 62, 1, 4, 118242) For any time is a favourable season for doing good work or begging or giving in a good cause.
('42', 62, 1, 5, 118336) No cause can be better than the cause of the untouchables, the “unapproachables” and the “invisibles”.
('42', 62, 1, 6, 118439) If the young men from the south living in Bombay will only deny themselves some of the costly luxuries such as smoking, races, visits to teashops, etc., there will be a fat collection.
('42', 62, 1, 7, 118624) Every religion enjoins the setting apart of a certain portion of one’s income for charitable purposes.
('42', 62, 1, 8, 118727) Unfortunately young men nowadays in most cases have given the go by to religion.
('42', 62, 1, 9, 118808) But if the practice of invariably allocating a certain portion of one’s income to charitable purposes can be revived, causes such as those of the untouchables need never wait for a “favourable season”

('42', 66, 4, 8, 124068) 96. LETTER TO TARABEHN JASANI
('42', 66, 5, 9, 124098) June 2, 1928
('42', 66, 6, 10, 124111) TARA, I do not have even a moment’s respite.
('42', 66, 6, 11, 124156) So I could not write to you.

('42', 66, 6, 13, 124236) 1. Devotion to God means rendering selfless service to all Gods’s creatures.
('42', 66, 6, 14, 124313) 2. The purpose of such devotion is self realization.
('42', 66, 6, 15, 124366) 3. Actionless devotion is no devotion; it is merely delusion.
('42', 66, 7, 16, 124428) 5. By being a burden on others one does not pursue devotion, one only denigrates God.
('42', 66, 7, 17, 124514) 6. It is devotion of a pure kind if a man, after seeing to his essential needs, spends all the remaining time in the service of all living creatures.
('42', 66, 7, 18, 124664) It is possible for one to reach the stage where one can serve by thought alone.
('42', 66, 7, 19, 124744) But none of us have reached that stage.
('42', 66, 7, 20, 124784) Therefore, for a man of flesh and blood, service of all that lives is the only way of devotion.
('42', 66, 7, 21, 124880) Such service must be selfless, altruistic.
('42', 66, 7, 22, 124923) 7. God means pure consciousness that pervades this world and without which not a single business of the world can go on for a single moment.

('42', 67, 4, 10, 125562) 97. IMPORTANCE OF BARDOLI The lustre of the Bardoli Satyagraha increases day by day.
('42', 67, 4, 11, 125647) Whose heart would not jump for joy at seeing Shri Vithalbhai Patel’s letter which I have just received?
('42', 67, 4, 12, 125751) A translation of it is published in this very issue.
('42', 67, 4, 13, 125804) However, the fulfilment of the expectations with which he has written that letter lies in the hands of the Bardoli satyagrahis themselves.
('42', 67, 4, 14, 125943) The Government’s notice too has been published along with Shri Vithalbhai’s letter.
('42', 67, 4, 15, 126027) The gist of the note is that the so called satyagrahis are no satyagrahis but cowards, and, because they are cowards, they secretly go and pay up their revenue dues.
('42', 67, 4, 16, 126193) There are other such points mentioned in the note, which deserves to be considered by the satyagrahis.
('42', 67, 4, 17, 126296) The Government has built its castle of hopes of the people’s weaknesses, whereas the Himalayas of the hopes of the satyagrahis and their well wishers like Vithalbhai rest on the styagrahis’ courage and determination.
('42', 67, 4, 18, 126513) Being built by man, a castle crumbles.
('42', 67, 4, 19, 126552) The Himalayas being a gift of God, will stand firm and if they should fall it would be the end of everything.
('42', 67, 4, 20, 126662) It is indeed true that man forges his own fetters and he himself can break them.
('42', 67, 4, 21, 126743) The yajna at Bardoli is intended to prove this.
('42', 67, 5, 22, 126791) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 3 6 1928
('42', 67, 6, 23, 126827) 1 Illegible in the source.
('42', 68, 0, 1, 126854) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 69
('42', 68, 1, 2, 126897) 98. QUESTIONS ON EDUCATION–I
('42', 68, 2, 3, 126926) Having written the three articles on primary education, it is now easy for me to answer the following questions :
('42', 68, 3, 4, 127040) Q. 1. You once said reducing the burden imposed by English on students would amount to saving so many years of their life.
('42', 68, 3, 5, 127163) If we interpret national education to mean nation wide education, how much would be the burden imposed upon society?
('42', 68, 3, 6, 127280) How much, that is, in terms of years?
('42', 68, 4, 7, 127318) A. Let me first explain the meaning of the phrase “reducing the burden imposed by English”.
('42', 68, 4, 8, 127410) It is not my contention that students should not be taught English at all.
('42', 68, 4, 9, 127485) But let us learn English as a foreign language in the same way that a Frenchman learns it.
('42', 68, 4, 10, 127576) If we learn English only to that extent, we shall not have to carry the burden of thinking in English, speaking or writing it with correctness.
('42', 68, 4, 11, 127720) In my opinion, at least five years of the student’s life are wasted in carrying this burden.
('42', 68, 4, 12, 127813) Not onle this.
('42', 68, 4, 13, 127828) Because of the strain caused during these five years, his capacity to think is affected, he becomes enfeebled in the body and, like blotting paper absorbing ink, he starts merely imitating in a superficial manner.
('42', 68, 4, 14, 128042) How much a person would learn if he spent five years in getting the knowledge he needs through his mother tongue!
('42', 68, 4, 15, 128156) How much time he would save thereby!
('42', 68, 4, 16, 128193) He would readily learn the best thoughts in his won language and be spared the burden of learning the difficult pronunciation of a foreign language.
('42', 68, 5, 17, 128342) Q. 2. Child education at one end and university education at the other are very expensive.
('42', 68, 5, 18, 128433) Can these both be included in national education?
('42', 68, 5, 19, 128483) Alternatively, do you have any scheme for providing equally solid education at a lower cost?
('42', 68, 6, 20, 128576) A. I have tried to show in those three articles how child education could become inexpensive, almost self supporting.
('42', 68, 6, 21, 128694) If we can fashion a university education which will aid primary education, it can be made inexpensive and students can acquire the necessary knowledge useful to the nation.
('42', 68, 6, 22, 128867) If the phrase “solid education” implies eduction similar to that provided by Government schools, the question is irrelevant, as I do not regard that education as solid.
('42', 68, 6, 23, 129036) The education given in the national university or primary schools is distinct from that provided by Government schools and is very often of a novel and original kind.
('42', 68, 6, 24, 129203) It is therefore solid in its own way.
('42', 69, 0, 1, 129241) 70 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 69, 1, 2, 129282) Q. 3. Advocates of tradition try to inculcate in pupils devotion for the guru.
('42', 69, 1, 3, 129361) They tell the pupils that learning can be acquired only by pleasing the guru and in no other manner; that if one does not please the guru, does not serve him and attend on him he may out of slyness withhold knowledge; that one should always be flattering him to keep him from wicked in this way.
('42', 69, 1, 4, 129657) Is this a definition of gurubhakti?
('42', 69, 2, 5, 129693) A. I am a believer in gurubhakti.
('42', 69, 2, 6, 129727) However, every teacher cannot become a guru.
('42', 69, 2, 7, 129772) The guru disciple relationship is spiritual and spontaneous, it is not artificial, it cannot be created through external pressure.
('42', 69, 2, 8, 129903) Such gurus are still to be found in India.
('42', 69, 2, 9, 129946) (It should not be necessary to warn that I am not speaking here of gurus who give moksha.) The question of flattering such a guru just does not arise.
('42', 69, 2, 10, 130097) The respect towards such a guru can only be natural, the guru’s love is also of the same kind.
('42', 69, 2, 11, 130192) Hence the one is alwarys ready to give and the other is always ready to receive.
('42', 69, 2, 12, 130273) Common knowledge, on the other hand, is something which we can accept from anyone.
('42', 69, 2, 13, 130356) I can learn a lot from a carpenter with whom I have no connection and of whose faults I am aware; I can acquire a knowledge of carpentry from him just as I purchase goods from a shopkeeper.
('42', 69, 2, 14, 130546) Of course, a certain type of faith is required even here.
('42', 69, 2, 15, 130604) I cannot learn carpentry from a carpenter if I do not have faith in his knowledge of that subject.
('42', 69, 2, 16, 130703) Gurubhakti is an altogether different matter.
('42', 69, 2, 17, 130749) In character building, which is the object of education, the relationship between the guru and his disciples is of utmost importance and where there is no gurubhakti in its pure form, there can be no character building.
('42', 69, 3, 18, 130969) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 3 6 1928

('42', 73, 1, 2, 135313) 105. LETTER TO V. J. PATEL
('42', 73, 2, 3, 135340) ASHRAM, Wednesday, Jeth Vad 4 [June 6, 1928] 1
('42', 73, 3, 4, 135387) BHAISHRI VITHALBHAI, I have received Swami’s letter.
('42', 73, 3, 5, 135440) I feel that we certainly cannot agree to the condition that the farmers should from today put into the bank the money which they will have to pay if the decision of the committee to be appointed goes against them.
('42', 73, 3, 6, 135654) I see Vallabhbhai’s as well as the farmers’s lack of trust in it.
('42', 73, 3, 7, 135720) At present the farmers are putting up a fight saying that the enhanced revenue is unjustifiable.
('42', 73, 3, 8, 135817) The Government has no reason to believe that they would not pay or Vallabhbhai would not help them even if the decision of the commi ttee by which they would themselves agree to abide went against them.
('42', 73, 3, 9, 136020) Therefore, at least for the sake of our self respect, we cannot agree to the condition that we deposit the money in the bank.
('42', 73, 3, 10, 136146) All the terms of agreement will be made in pubic.
('42', 73, 3, 11, 136196) Even Vallabhbhai’s terms of agreement will be made in public.
('42', 73, 3, 12, 136258) The people will certainly pay up the revenue without the additional amount, that is, nearly five lakhs.
('42', 73, 3, 13, 136362) To collect the remaining money should be very easy for the Government.
('42', 73, 3, 14, 136433) I smell a rat in the talk of somehow recovering the additional amount first.,It will never satisfy us if they appoint a committee in name only.
('42', 73, 3, 15, 136577) The committee should be impartial and open.
('42', 73, 3, 16, 136621) We have not the slightest right to be so spiritless after the people have shown so much strength.
('42', 73, 3, 17, 136719) If ultimately the people are to lose, they will do so.
('42', 73, 3, 18, 136774) We should have no hand in their discomfiture.
('42', 73, 3, 19, 136820) You can judge better than I when and at whose invitation you should go to Mahabaleshwar.
('42', 73, 3, 20, 136909) I do not think that now I have left any part of Swami’s letter unanswered.

('42', 76, 1, 2, 140063) 110. THE TWO SIDES
('42', 76, 2, 3, 140082) The communique of the Government of Bombay on the Bardoli Satyagraha is in keeping with the letter of the Commissioner, Northern Division, which I had the painful duty of criticizing only the other day.
('42', 76, 2, 4, 140285) 1 This communique opens with a repetition of the insult that Sjt.
('42', 76, 2, 5, 140351) Vallabhbhai and his co workers are outsiders.
('42', 76, 2, 6, 140397) Instead of being described as such they described as “persons who do not reside there” (in Bardoli).
('42', 76, 2, 7, 140498) The communique then shamelessly refers to the fact that when the attempt at distraint had failed, the Government resorted to an “organized attachment of buffaloes and movable property.” Sjt.
('42', 76, 2, 8, 140689) Vallabhbhai’s publicity department has shown what the attachment of buffaloes has meant.
('42', 76, 2, 9, 140778) The communique further triumphantly refers to the fact that “forty Pathans were obtained to assist the Mamlatdar and Mahalkaris in the work of attachment and the care of animals attached.”.
('42', 76, 2, 10, 140968) The publicity department has again shown us what the introduction of Pathans has meant.
('42', 76, 2, 11, 141056) Even without the assistance of the department, we could have guessed the meaning of this introduction.
('42', 76, 2, 12, 141159) Whether it is the Government or private people who employ Pathans, people know why the services of these friends are enlisted.
('42', 76, 2, 13, 141286) Lest, however, the accepted meaning might be attached to the enlistment of Pathans, the com munique proceeds : “Unfounded allegations have been made against these Pathans.
('42', 76, 2, 14, 141458) Government are satisfied that their conduct has been exemplary in every respect”.
('42', 76, 2, 15, 141540) Who does not laugh at this explanation?
('42', 76, 2, 16, 141580) If, as the Government contend, the Pathans have been employed in order to replace the Vethias who are alleged to be under threat of excommunication, it is relevant to ask why Pathans have been chosen instead of Vethias from other places or some other mild mannered men.
('42', 76, 2, 17, 141850) The Government pooh pooh the notion as incredible that "five parties, each of five Pathans, working under the eye of a responsible officer of Government, can terrorize a population of 90,000 persons”.
('42', 76, 2, 18, 142051) Again experience of the people of India shows what one Pathan armed with authority can do in a whole village.
('42', 76, 2, 19, 142161) It is no doubt humiliating to think that Pathans or anybody else can terrorize large masses of men, but unfortunately it is a fact of daily occurrence in this fearridden, terror stricken India.
('42', 76, 2, 20, 142355) And I would consider the Bardoli struggle to be well fought, even without any further result, if the people of Bardoli shed
('42', 76, 3, 21, 142479) 1 Vide “The Only Issue”, 17 5 1928.
('42', 77, 0, 1, 142515) 78 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 77, 1, 2, 142556) their fear of men and authority and turn the Pathans into friends.
('42', 77, 1, 3, 142623) But the communique is not satisfied with a recital of the coercive measures taken in respect of movable property; it refers to forfeiture of lands.
('42', 77, 1, 4, 142771) The Government are not ashamed to own that “up to date of the communique 1,400 acres of such land have been disposed of under forfeiture notices and that about 5,000 acres more will be disposed of in due course unless the arrears due thereon be sooner paid“, and unnecessarily add that “such lands once disposed of would never be returned“.
('42', 77, 1, 5, 143112) There are several other statements in the communique which are open to criticism, but I forbear.
('42', 77, 1, 6, 143209) The communique announces some insulting accommodation for those who would pay the assessment on or before the 19th instant.
('42', 77, 1, 7, 143333) It is for the people of Bardoli to return the only answer open to self respecting men and women.
('42', 77, 1, 8, 143430) When they embarked upon this struggle, they knew the cost of resistance.
('42', 77, 1, 9, 143503) I have little doubt that they will not fail to render a good account of themselves when the last heat of the struggle commences as they did during the opening stages.
('42', 77, 1, 10, 143670) In marked contrast to the communique comes the letter addressed to me by Sjt.
('42', 77, 1, 11, 143748) Vithalbhai Patel announcing a handsome monthly donation of Rs. 1,000 so long as the struggle lasts.
('42', 77, 1, 12, 143848) Throughout his brilliant career as the Speaker of the Assembly Sjt.
('42', 77, 1, 13, 143916) Vithalbhai Patel has upheld the rights of the people.
('42', 77, 1, 14, 143970) Occupancy of office has not in the slightest degree made him lose his head or compromise the honour of his country.
('42', 77, 1, 15, 144086) Whilst he has acted with strict impartiality, he has neither hesitated not been afraid to act on behalf of the people wherever the holding of his office has permitted him to do so.
('42', 77, 1, 16, 144267) The alien rulers have established a slavish tradition that those who are in the pay of the Government must in all circumstances refrain from showing their sympathy for the people when the latter engage in any fight with the Government, and this even when the Government act in a manner contrary to laws promulgated by themselves.
('42', 77, 1, 17, 144597) Vithalbhai Patel has broken through that unhealthy and slavish tradition and has been able to do so because he has accepted his office not for its honour, not for the salary it brings him, but, as he puts it in his letter, as a trust on behalf of those who have elected him to the office.
('42', 77, 1, 18, 144886) It must be remembered that the Speaker is not a statutory servant of the Crown.
('42', 77, 1, 19, 144966) He is a popular representative and without taking an active part in political controversies and the like, he has a perfect right to show his sympathy for the people.
('42', 78, 0, 1, 145132) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 79
('42', 78, 1, 2, 145175) been elected as the Speaker, Sjt.
('42', 78, 1, 3, 145209) Vithalbhai ceased to be a party man; but he did not and could not cease to be representative of the combined parties who called him to preside over their deliberations.
('42', 78, 1, 4, 145378) I therefore tender him my congratulations for the manly stand he has taken up on behalf of the people.
('42', 78, 1, 5, 145481) If entry into legislative bodies created by the alien Government can be held at all justifiable, he has shown to those who may enter these bodies and accept office the way to act nobly and fearlessly.

('42', 78, 2, 7, 145703) 111. CASH V. CREDIT
('42', 78, 3, 8, 145723) The Secretary, All India Spinners’ Association, writes as follows:
('42', 78, 4, 9, 145790) The credit sales of the provincial branches of the Association amount to Rs. 1,54,488 13 81 2 representing 15 per cent of the capital invested in these
('42', 78, 5, 10, 145942) branches, and this is in spite of the resolution passed by the Council putting a ban generally on credit sales.
('42', 78, 5, 11, 146054) This is largely due to the misgivings of our workers.
('42', 78, 5, 12, 146108) They fear that the sales will go down if credits are completely stopped.
('42', 78, 5, 13, 146181) The fear is groundless.
('42', 78, 5, 14, 146205) The Tamilnad has done away with all credit sales, and it after all shows the largest sales amongst all the khadi depots throughout India.
('42', 78, 5, 15, 146343) You may inform your various branches and the public that past experience shows that khadi work loses through these credit sales as well by reason of the purchasers making default as b reason of the locking up of capital which is none too large.
('42', 78, 5, 16, 146588) I entirely endorse the warning uttered in the foregoing letter.
('42', 78, 5, 17, 146652) So long as khadi remains an infant national industry requiring delicate nursing and protection from the public, there should be no credit sales in khadi depots.
('42', 78, 5, 18, 146813) We must simply rely upon the support of a patriotic public and if we cannot command cash sales, we may regard the disinclination to pay cash as a sign that khadi does not enjoy the benefit of public protection.
('42', 78, 5, 19, 147024) But my own personal experience throughout my extensive wanderings has shown that people gladly pay cash for khadi when they require and receive credit in respect of their other purchases.
('42', 78, 5, 20, 147212) To pay cash for khadi that the people want is the least protection that khadi is entitled to.
('42', 78, 5, 21, 147306) Managers of sale depots must not be afraid of losing custom if they do not give credit.
('42', 78, 5, 22, 147394) They must rely upon their ability to carry on propaganda in their neighbourhood in favour of khadi for commanding cash sales.
('42', 78, 5, 23, 147520) And in no case are they warranted in giving credits in spite of instructions
('42', 79, 0, 1, 147597) 80 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 79, 1, 2, 147638) from headquarters to the contrary.
('42', 79, 1, 3, 147673) Discipline demands that if they have no confidence in themselves to carry on khadi depots successfully without being able to give credit, they should give such notice to the head office and ask to be relieved of their charge.
('42', 79, 1, 4, 147899) The head office should be trusted to know what is best on the whole for turning khadi into a business proposition as quickly as possible.
('42', 79, 1, 5, 148037) Young India, 7 6 1928
('42', 79, 2, 6, 148059) 112. INDIANS IN SOUTH AFRICA Two very important cases have been decided recently by the Transvaal Provincial Division of the Supreme Court on South Africa.
('42', 79, 2, 7, 148215) One of them, S. B. Medh V. Immigrants Appeal Board, though important in itself, affects only a few special cases of Indians who received exemption certificates under the Smuts Gandhi Settlement as being educated Indians.
('42', 79, 2, 8, 148436) It was contended by the Union Government that the exemptions were not complete.
('42', 79, 2, 9, 148516) I need not go into greater detail.
('42', 79, 2, 10, 148551) The Court has now found that the exemptions were complete in the sense submitted on behalf of the appellant.
('42', 79, 2, 11, 148660) The other case, Days Purshottam V. Immigrants Appeal Board, has farreaching consequences for the Indian settlers.
('42', 79, 2, 12, 148774) The judgment in this case lays down that section 5 of Act 37 of 1927 does not possess retrospective effect.
('42', 79, 2, 13, 148882) Hence certificates obtained by fraudulent means do not become cancellable at the will of the Immigration Board or the Immigration Officer.
('42', 79, 2, 14, 149021) If this judgment stands, holders of certificates even though they were originally tainted will remain undisturbed.
('42', 79, 2, 15, 149136) This is a great victory for the settlers.
('42', 79, 2, 16, 149178) I have no desire to see fraud in any shape or form protected.
('42', 79, 2, 17, 149240) But the case of these settlers is not one of ordinary fraud.
('42', 79, 2, 18, 149301) In many cases, at least up to 1914 the Asiatic Office was a corrupt department and it made it practically impossible for bona fide entrants to enter unless they resorted to some crooked means so as to satisfy the greed of the Asiatic officers.
('42', 79, 2, 19, 149545) Where Govern ment officials are privy to fraud, it ill becomes that Government to punish the helpless victims.
('42', 79, 2, 20, 149656) Cables from the South African settlers tell me that the Government are appealing against the two decisions.
('42', 79, 2, 21, 149764) I venture to suggest to the Union Government that it would be more in keeping with their conciliatory attitude and the spirit of the new understanding that they do not seek to deprive the Indians of the advantage the two appeals give them.
('42', 79, 2, 22, 150004) The judgment in the first appeal protects only a
('42', 80, 0, 1, 150053) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 81
('42', 80, 1, 2, 150096) few individuals.
('42', 80, 1, 3, 150113) And in their case there is no question of fraud.
('42', 80, 1, 4, 150162) The judgment in the second appeal protects a fair number of those who are already in the Union.
('42', 80, 1, 5, 150258) It will be no serious calamity for the Union to have to absorb a few more Indians than the Government had counted upon.
('42', 80, 1, 6, 150378) The Union Government should remember that these appeals are very expensive affairs especially for the poor Indians.
('42', 80, 1, 7, 150494) It is hardly fair for an organized powerful Government to take successful citizens through appellate courts and thus exhaust them into submission or worse.
('42', 80, 1, 8, 150650) It may be well to possess a giant’s strength, but it is admittedly wrong to use it against dwarfs.
('42', 80, 1, 9, 150749) The settlers will do well not to set much store to their success in these two appeals.
('42', 80, 1, 10, 150836) They have in Sjt.
('42', 80, 1, 11, 150854) Sastri a great friend and adviser.
('42', 80, 1, 12, 150889) Let them press their suit as much as ever before him but having done so let them abide by his advice.
('42', 80, 1, 13, 150991) He will use in their behalf all the influence he has acquired with the Union Government.
('42', 80, 1, 14, 151080) I welcome their cables.
('42', 80, 1, 15, 151104) I appreciate the trust they repose in me.
('42', 80, 1, 16, 151146) But my power to help them from this distance and in the changed circumstances I found myself in 1920 is much too limited to be of value.
('42', 80, 1, 17, 151283) Their strength therefore lies in their unity, moderation and reliance upon one who is not merely Agent General for the Government of India but is their true and powerful friend and guide.
('42', 80, 2, 18, 151471) Young India, 7 6 1928

('42', 81, 4, 6, 152428) 114. DRAFT OF LETTER TO SIR LESLIE WILSON [June 7, 1928] 1
('42', 81, 5, 7, 152487) I thank you for your prompt reply to my letter of the 4th instant.
('42', 81, 5, 8, 152554) It is evident from your letter that we are working at cross purposes.
('42', 81, 5, 9, 152624) I fail to see why because I hold an important public position, I might not write to another holding an equally important public position a friendly letter drawing his attention to what I might consider to be a serious breach of law or official duty on the part of his officials.
('42', 81, 5, 10, 152903) The fact that the holding of the position I occupy prevents me from entering into proofs of statements I might make does not mean that I have no warrant for making such statements or that I might not make them confidentially to a fellow official and that in the public interest.
('42', 81, 5, 11, 153182) If you will re read my letter of the 4th instant, you will find therein that I have not said that I have no proof of the statements I have made; on the contrary, I have given you the sources of my information.
('42', 81, 5, 12, 153392) Is it not up to you now to adopt the only possible course, if you really want to have those statements proved, namely, to appoint a committee of enquiry?
('42', 81, 5, 13, 153546) Tell me how otherwise you are to be satisfied about the correctness or otherwise of the statements I have made to you.
('42', 81, 5, 14, 153665) With reference to the third paragraph of your letter, there is no question of my not believing you.
('42', 81, 5, 15, 153765) I simply quoted your own letter to show that at the time you wrote to me that letter, you had made no enquiry.
('42', 81, 5, 16, 153876) You evidently seem to think that the letter of the Commissioner is not open to objection, whereas I venture to suggest

('42', 90, 1, 2, 164768) 127. QUESTIONS ON EDUCATION–II
('42', 90, 2, 3, 164799) Q. 4. Nowadays the teacher’s task has in fact been reduced to that of a postman or a foreman.
('42', 90, 2, 4, 164893) It consists only of placing books written by educationists in the hands of pupils and of supervising whether they make use of these or not.
('42', 90, 2, 5, 165033) In addition to this, what other skill do you expect the teachers to possess?
('42', 90, 2, 6, 165110) The science of education has been developed to the extent where the term ‘teacher’ may be defined as one who can clarify the meaning of difficult passages and prepare abstracts of long chapters.
('42', 90, 2, 7, 165305) Why should we not now accept this ideal?
('42', 90, 3, 8, 165346) A. I keep on feeling that teachers in the true sense of the word are essential, no matter how good the text books are.
('42', 90, 3, 9, 165465) A good teacher would never content himself with summarizing or explaining the meaning of difficult passages.
('42', 90, 3, 10, 165574) Time and again, he would go beyond the text books and present his subject to the pupil in a vivid manner in the same way as an artist does.
('42', 90, 3, 11, 165714) The best text book may be compared to the best photograph.
('42', 90, 3, 12, 165773) However, just as a painting by an artist although second rate is invariably superior to a photograph, similar is the case with a real teacher.
('42', 90, 3, 13, 165916) A true teacher introduces the pupil to his subject, creates in him interest for the subject and enables him to understand it independently.
('42', 90, 3, 14, 166056) In my opinion, one who explains difficult passages and prepares abstracts can never be regarded a good teacher.
('42', 90, 3, 15, 166168) Our endeavours should be to turn out true teachers who could be infused with a spirit of service.
('42', 90, 3, 16, 166266) It is not that stray instances of such teachers are not be found even today.
('42', 90, 4, 17, 166343) Q. 5. At the time of the educational conference at Broach you said although primary education might be free, it should not be compulsory and that even a good thing should not be compulsorily enforced on a nation which was not independent.
('42', 90, 4, 18, 166582) If today the educational structure were to come within your control, would you or would you not see that your educational system in which khadi and other national crafts have a place of primary importance was made compulsory?
('42', 90, 5, 19, 166808) A. I don’t think I have as yet the courage to make compulsory the educational system that I have conceived.
('42', 90, 5, 20, 166916) I think our country has no need of it for many years to come, because although primary education ought to be made compulsory, many conditions that go before it remain to be fulfilled.
('42', 90, 5, 21, 167100) I feel that if we put before the people the type of education that will further their growth and also meet with
('42', 91, 0, 1, 167212) 92 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 91, 1, 2, 167253) their approval, they will readily welcome it without any effort on our part.
('42', 91, 1, 3, 167330) Q. 6. Do you believe that teachers have a right to give any kind of religious instruction which is in accordance with their viewpoint?
('42', 91, 1, 4, 167465) A. Teachers who teach under a common administrative system have no right to impart religious instruction according to their own viewpoint.
('42', 91, 1, 5, 167604) As in the case of other subjects, religious instruction too must be given in accordance with the scheme provided by the administrative authorities.
('42', 91, 1, 6, 167752) Every teacher will have his own method of teaching within that framework; however, such instruction may be imparted only in accordance with the ideals that have been laid down by the authorities with regard to religion.
('42', 91, 1, 7, 167972) It is true that instruction in other subjects can be imparted by one who has read certain books on these subjects.
('42', 91, 1, 8, 168087) That is not the case of religious instruction.
('42', 91, 1, 9, 168134) It is never given through books.
('42', 91, 1, 10, 168167) The method of imparting this instruction is quite different from that followed in the case of other subject.
('42', 91, 1, 11, 168276) Whereas the latter is communicated through the intellect, the former can proceed from one’s heart alone.
('42', 91, 1, 12, 168381) Hence so long as the teacher is not steeped in religion, he should not impart religious instruction.
('42', 91, 1, 13, 168482) Although in this manner the means of imparting religious instruction are different, nevertheless it is necessary to have a certain amount of understanding about the way in which it is to be done.
('42', 91, 1, 14, 168678) In other words, one cannot impart education which would encourage violence where non violence has been accepted as the supreme dharma.
('42', 91, 1, 15, 168813) Or, instruction antagonistic to other religions cannot be imparted where the ideal of love, tolerance and compassion towards all religions has been accepted as the ideal.
('42', 91, 1, 16, 168984) In short, there can be no place for a state of anarchy with regard to religious instruction where its necessity has already been accepted.
('42', 91, 1, 17, 169123) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 10 6 1928
('42', 91, 2, 18, 169160) 128. THE YAJNA AT BARDOLI The satyagraha being offered at Bardoli is certainly a kind of yajna.
('42', 91, 2, 19, 169256) All altruistic work is directed towards the welfare of others.
('42', 91, 2, 20, 169319) Since the peasants of Bardoli are fighting not for their individual interest but for the benefit of society and for their self respect, it is a yajna.
('42', 91, 2, 21, 169470) Offerings are made every day.
('42', 91, 2, 22, 169500) The news of the latest of these
('42', 92, 0, 1, 169532) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 93
('42', 92, 1, 2, 169575) has just come in.
('42', 92, 1, 3, 169593) It is as follows : 1
('42', 92, 2, 4, 169614) This can be regarded as a fitting rejoinder to the Government’s notification.
('42', 92, 2, 5, 169692) I congratulate the patels and the talatis on showing courage in this manner.
('42', 92, 2, 6, 169769) I hope that they will remain steadfast in this decision and well never repent of it.
('42', 92, 2, 7, 169854) It is imperative that people get over the glamour or Government service.
('42', 92, 2, 8, 169927) Anyone whose limbs are intact and who is industrious finds no difficulty in earning his bread honestly.
('42', 92, 2, 9, 170031) If instead of welcoming the opportunity to rob people which a Government employee gets, if we considered it as something wrong and avoided it, the limbs of the Government would be weakened.
('42', 92, 2, 10, 170221) Our own people are the limbs of the Government.
('42', 92, 2, 11, 170269) If they get out, its ammunition and aeroplanes would be rendered useless.
('42', 92, 2, 12, 170343) The Government’s notification is full of untruth, arrogance and contempt for the people.
('42', 92, 2, 13, 170432) I hope no peasant of Bardoli will be lured by the temptations it holds out.
('42', 92, 2, 14, 170508) The Government has fully exploited and is still exploiting the fourfold method of sama, dama, danda, bheda.
('42', 92, 2, 15, 170616) 2 Amongst these punishment is the least blameworthy since we can recognize it.
('42', 92, 2, 16, 170695) Having endured it, we can spare ourselves its dread.
('42', 92, 2, 17, 170748) The other three are subtle.
('42', 92, 2, 18, 170776) Thse involve temptations.
('42', 92, 2, 19, 170802) Just as a fish while trying to lick the bait on the hook gets caught in it, unsuspecting and timid people get caught up in these poisonous triple strands.
('42', 92, 2, 20, 170957) The temptation offered to people who would pay up their revenue before the 19th of June constitutes the policy of bribery.
('42', 92, 2, 21, 171080) The people have a right to expect that not one peasant will break his pledge by succumbing to this bribe.
('42', 92, 2, 22, 171186) Let Bardoli ensure that the stamp of courage and forbearance which it has impressed upon the whole of India is never erased.
('42', 92, 2, 23, 171311) The policy of bheda is even more hateful than bribery.
('42', 92, 2, 24, 171366) Many kinds of rumours are afloat.
('42', 92, 2, 25, 171400) Some say the Government desires a settlement, others claim that the people are weakening; yet others say that people have started secretly paying up revenue dues; some others say that but for fear of ostracism, people are prepared to
('42', 92, 3, 26, 171634) 1 This is not translated here.
('42', 92, 3, 27, 171665) It stated that about 40 patels and eight talatis had resigned in the two preceding months as a protest against the Government’s policy of repression.
('42', 92, 3, 28, 171815) In their latest notification the Government threatened to take stricter action.
('42', 92, 3, 29, 171895) 2 Appeasement, bribery, (threat of) punishment and divisiveness
('42', 93, 0, 1, 171959) 94 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 93, 1, 2, 172000) pay up their dues; some assert that people refrain from paying up their dues for fear of the outsiders like Vallabhbhai and his colleagues, and that these poor people would like to pay up their revenue and live in peace.
('42', 93, 1, 3, 172221) All this amounts to a policy of bheda.
('42', 93, 1, 4, 172260) I do not mean to say that anyone specifically plans this so.
('42', 93, 1, 5, 172321) But a policy based on these four tactics operates by itself.
('42', 93, 1, 6, 172382) All those who are in the Government’s service know that rise in their salaries and their position is implicit in their being amenable to the policy of the Government.
('42', 93, 1, 7, 172549) Bhishma, Drona and others too had to point to their stomach before Yudhishthira.
('42', 93, 1, 8, 172630) Hence, as the movement gathers momentum, the policy of alienation will be intensified.
('42', 93, 1, 9, 172717) All satyagrahis should avoid this snare.
('42', 93, 1, 10, 172758) They should give credence to no rumour.
('42', 93, 1, 11, 172798) They should put before Sardar whatever they come to hear and should then forget all about it.
('42', 93, 1, 12, 172892) A satyagrahi should have only one consolation.
('42', 93, 1, 13, 172939) His task is accomplished when his pledge is fulfilled.
('42', 93, 1, 14, 172994) More he should not ask for and with less he should not be satisfied.
('42', 93, 1, 15, 173063) He should be resolved to sacrifice what is dearest to him at the altar of his pledge.
('42', 93, 1, 16, 173149) What could such an individual have to do with rumours?
('42', 93, 1, 17, 173204) Moreover, need he be misled or tempted by the words of anyone who has the audacity to make an outsider of their beloved Sardar?
('42', 93, 1, 18, 173332) Sardar will tell them when a settlement is about to be made.
('42', 93, 1, 19, 173393) And he should not be misled by the tald of people secretly paying up their dues.
('42', 93, 1, 20, 173474) A few weak individuals are to be found in every community.
('42', 93, 1, 21, 173533) It has been my experience that although only a few give in secretly, their number is exaggerated.
('42', 93, 1, 22, 173631) It therefore befits a satyagrahi not to believe this talk of secret paying up.
('42', 93, 1, 23, 173710) He should believe that others also have the same strength that he himself has.
('42', 93, 1, 24, 173789) But he should not feel despondent if after all some people do give in secretly.
('42', 93, 1, 25, 173869) Dharma is for them who observe it.
('42', 93, 2, 26, 173904) God’s way is for the brave; it has no room for the coward.
('42', 93, 3, 27, 173963) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 10 6 1928
('42', 93, 4, 28, 174000) 1 The first line of a song by Pritam, a Gujarati poet
('42', 94, 0, 1, 174054) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 95
('42', 94, 1, 2, 174097) 129. BARDOLI DAY The 12th of June has been fixed for expressing sympathy with the satyagrahis of Bardoli and helping them in other ways.
('42', 94, 1, 3, 174234) How should we observe this day?
('42', 94, 1, 4, 174266) All struggles involving satyagraha call for self purification.
('42', 94, 1, 5, 174329) A satyagrahi tries to make his truth triumph through his own purity and through his penance and he has faith in his endeavours.
('42', 94, 1, 6, 174457) Hence let us attain the utmost degree of purity on the 12th of June and ask God to give us the strength to bear any sufferings so that truth may triumph.
('42', 94, 1, 7, 174611) This can be regarded as first class help.
('42', 94, 1, 8, 174653) Moreover, since Bardoli is in Gujarat, that province, realizing that it has a special responsibility towards it, should start on the 12th of June a yajna for selfpurification.
('42', 94, 1, 9, 174829) If possible, on that day everywhere people should absolutely voluntarily stop their routine business—their means of livelihood—and collect funds to help the struggle in Bardoli.
('42', 94, 1, 10, 175007) Huge meeting should be held at various places in the evening and resolutions should be passed expressing sympathy with the struggle and condemning the Government’s anarchical policy.
('42', 94, 1, 11, 175190) Further, at all such meetings contributions should be collected from those who have not been approached for such contributions during the course of the day, and have come to attend the meeting.

('42', 95, 1, 2, 175462) 130. GOD OR GURU—WHO IS GREATER?
('42', 95, 2, 3, 175495) Under the above heading a gentleman has sent me the following article : 1
('42', 95, 3, 4, 175569) I have no knowledge of what the writer has said about the Marwari devotee.
('42', 95, 3, 5, 175644) I am not acquainted with the three verses from Siddhanta Rahasya 2 whose purport he has given.
('42', 95, 3, 6, 175739) But there is no doubt that a belief of the kind he has discussed does exist in Hinduism.
('42', 95, 3, 7, 175828) I myself sing the following verse every morning :
('42', 95, 4, 8, 175878) Guru is Brahma, Guru is Vishnu, Guru is God Siva, Guru verily is the supreme Brahman; to that Guru I bow.
('42', 95, 4, 9, 175984) I am convinced there are strong reasons for the Hindu belief concerning the greatness of the guru.
('42', 95, 4, 10, 176083) That is why I have been looking for the true meaning of the word ‘guru’ and saying time and again that I am in quest of a guru.
('42', 95, 4, 11, 176211) The guru in whom Brahma, Vishnu and Siva merge and who is the Supreme Brahman Himself cannot be an embodied man with his humours and diseases.
('42', 95, 4, 12, 176354) He will possess the powers of Brahma, Vishnu and Shiva.
('42', 95, 4, 13, 176410) In other words, He can only be an ideal being.
('42', 95, 4, 14, 176457) This guru, our desired god, can only be God who is the embodiment of Truth.
('42', 95, 4, 15, 176533) Hence the quest for such a guru is the quest for God.
('42', 95, 4, 16, 176587) If we look at the matter thus, the meaning of all that the writer has said is easily understood.
('42', 95, 4, 17, 176684) One who can show us God is certainly fit to be guru and may be said to be greater than God.
('42', 95, 4, 18, 176776) We see God’s creatures suf fering in many ways.
('42', 95, 4, 19, 176824) Anyone who can free us from this web would de serve a place superior to God’s.
('42', 95, 4, 20, 176903) This is also the meaning of the saying : “The servant of Rama is greater than Rama.” The meaning of all these great utterances is so simple that if we examine them with a pure heart we shall not be led astray.
('42', 95, 4, 21, 177113) Every such great utterance has an indispensable condition attached to it.
('42', 95, 4, 22, 177187) One who frees us from desire, anger and so on, initiates us into the religion of love, frees us from fear, teaches us simplicity, gives us not only the
('42', 95, 5, 23, 177339) 1 This is not translated here.
('42', 95, 5, 24, 177370) The writer had referred approvingly to Gandhiji’s view that no living being should be worshipped and no man could be called good while yet alive (vide “Indulgence in the Name of Devotion”, 6 5 1928.), but had pointed out that, according to Hindu tradition, God could be reached only by the grace of the guru and therefore one could worship the guru.
('42', 95, 5, 25, 177720) He gave the instance of a Marwari devotee from Calcutta being received by the crowds in Bombay with drums and cymbals.
('42', 95, 5, 26, 177839) 2 A work of Vallabhacharya
('42', 96, 0, 1, 177866) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 97
('42', 96, 1, 2, 177909) intelligence to establish identity with the poorest of the poor but also the heart to feel such identity, is certainly, for us, more than God.
('42', 96, 1, 3, 178052) This does not mean that such a servant of God by himself is greater than God.
('42', 96, 1, 4, 178130) If we fall into the sea we shall be drowned.
('42', 96, 1, 5, 178175) However, if we drink, when we are thirsty, a jugful of water from the Ganga which flows into the sea, taking it from near the source, that Ganga water is more to us than the sea.
('42', 96, 1, 6, 178354) But the same Ganga water is like poison if taken at the point where the Ganga meets the sea.
('42', 96, 1, 7, 178447) The same is true with regard to the guru.
('42', 96, 1, 8, 178489) To accept as guru one who is full of conceit and arrogance and hungering to be served is like drinking the poisonous water of the Ganga that carries all manner of filth into the sea.
('42', 96, 1, 9, 178672) Today we practise adharma in the name of dharma.
('42', 96, 1, 10, 178721) We cherish hypocrisy in the name of truth and degrade ourselves as well as others by pretending to be possessed of spiritual knowledge and usurping all kinds of worship.
('42', 96, 1, 11, 178891) At such a time dharma consists in refusing to accept anyone as guru.
('42', 96, 1, 12, 178960) It is doubly sinful, when a true guru cannot be found, to set up a clary figure and make a guru of it.
('42', 96, 1, 13, 179063) But so long as a true guru is not found there is merit in going on saying “Not this.
('42', 96, 1, 14, 179148) Not this.”, and it may one day lead to our finding a true guru.
('42', 96, 1, 15, 179212) There are many hazards in trying to go against the current.
('42', 96, 1, 16, 179272) I have had, as I continue to have, many experiences—bitter and sweet— of this.
('42', 96, 1, 17, 179351) I have learnt but one thing from these, viz., that whatever is immoral and must be opposed should be opposed, even if one is all alone in opposing it.
('42', 96, 1, 18, 179502) And one should have the faith that if the opposition is truthful it will one day surely bear fruit.
('42', 96, 1, 19, 179602) A devotee who is after eulogy or worship, who is offended if not given honour, is no devotee.
('42', 96, 1, 20, 179696) The true service of a devotee is to become a devotee oneself.
('42', 96, 1, 21, 179758) Hence I oppose, wherever possible, the worship of human beings which is in vogue nowadays and urge other to do likewise.

('42', 97, 1, 2, 179957) 131. WHAT DOES SELF CONTROL REQUIRE?
('42', 97, 1, 3, 179994) A gentleman who wishes to enter into an argument writes to say : 1
('42', 97, 2, 4, 180061) It is my experience that self control which requires another’s consent cannot last for any length of time.
('42', 97, 2, 5, 180168) Self restraint needs only the consent of one’s own inner voice.
('42', 97, 2, 6, 180232) It owes its strength to soul force.
('42', 97, 2, 7, 180268) And that self control which has its roots in knowledge and love cannot but leave its impress on its surroundings.
('42', 97, 2, 8, 180382) Ultimately the other party too bcomes agreeable to it.
('42', 97, 2, 9, 180437) This is true also of husband and wife.
('42', 97, 2, 10, 180476) If the husband has to wait till the wife is ready or vice versa, most probably neither will be able to shake off the desire.
('42', 97, 2, 11, 180601) In many instances where one partner relies on the other for practising self control, it finally breaks down because of this lukewarm attitude.
('42', 97, 2, 12, 180744) If we go deeper into the matter we shall find that when one partner waits for the other’s consent, he is not really prepared for self control or is not truly keen.
('42', 97, 2, 13, 180908) It is for this very reason that Nishkulanand has said : “Unless attachment goes renunciation cannot stay.” If the latter requires attachment to go along with it, one who wishes to practise self control may require the consent of the other who does not.
('42', 97, 2, 14, 181161) The above correspondent has a straight path before him.
('42', 97, 2, 15, 181217) He is yet unmarried, and if he is really determined to practise brahmacharya why should he marry at all?
('42', 97, 2, 16, 181322) His parents and other relatives will of course say from their own experience that for a youth to talk of brahmacharya is like churning the ocean and, saying so, holding out threats, displaying anger and meting out punishment, they would try to dislodge him from his pious resolve to practise brahmacharya.
('42', 97, 2, 17, 181628) However, one to whom breach of brahmacharya is the highest punishment and who would not do it even to secure an empire, how can such a one get married, giving in to anyone’s threats?
('42', 97, 2, 18, 181811) My article from which the above passage has been quoted was not meant for those who are not so firmly determined and who have not set such great store by brahmacharya.
('42', 97, 3, 19, 181979) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 10 6 1928
('42', 97, 4, 20, 182016) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('42', 97, 4, 21, 182053) The correspondent had asked whether a spouse wishing to observe brahmacharya should not first seek the concurrence of the other party.

('42', 101, 2, 3, 186633) June 11, 1928
('42', 101, 3, 4, 186647) At present you students are perhaps in a disturbed mood.
('42', 101, 3, 5, 186704) You invited me to stay here so that your state of suspense may end or for some other reason, and I agreed, hoping to ease or to end this state.
('42', 101, 3, 6, 186848) But all or most of those who extended the invitation have proved to be cowards.
('42', 101, 3, 7, 186928) Having invited me they turned me out.
('42', 101, 3, 8, 186966) The conditions laid down when I was called again were such as would not be acceptable to a self respecting man like me.
('42', 101, 3, 9, 187086) By breaking them, you let slip a good opportunity to come closer to me.
('42', 101, 3, 10, 187158) But we are not separated.
('42', 101, 3, 11, 187184) The aims of the Vidyapith form a bond between you and me.

('42', 101, 3, 13, 187312) You might have gone through these aims during the vacation.
('42', 101, 3, 14, 187372) If you had thought over them, you must have understood quite a few things.
('42', 101, 3, 15, 187447) If you did not utilize your holidays in that way you must have come back as you went home.
('42', 101, 3, 16, 187538) I have often said in the Vidyapith that you should never strive to increase your numbers.
('42', 101, 3, 17, 187628) I do not mean to say that we would not like large numbers, but their absence need cause no disappointment to us, it must not give rise to a feeling that it is all over or that we have lost the game.
('42', 101, 3, 18, 187827) We may be fewer number or more but our real strength lies in the acceptance of these ideals and in practising them to the extent it is humanly possible.
('42', 101, 3, 19, 187980) Even if there are few such students, we can surely accomplish what we want to through the Vidyapith, that is to say, freedom, not final deliverance, but deliverance in the form of swaraj; the freedom for which the Vidyapith has been established will be surely won.
('42', 101, 3, 20, 188245) If we are false we shall not get swaraj.
('42', 101, 3, 21, 188286) You will see that the changes which have taken place and which you will find taking place hereafter had to be introduced with some hesitation lest they prove burdensome to you.
('42', 101, 3, 22, 188463) What a pitiable condition this is!

('42', 104, 1, 7, 194847) He should frame his examples from conditions here, so that our history and geography too maybe learnt from this.
('42', 104, 1, 8, 194960) We have to reconstruct everything, mathematics, history, economics, geogr aphy.
('42', 104, 1, 9, 195040) If you students do not help in this, what can the teachers do?
('42', 104, 1, 10, 195103) And if the teachers themselves are immature it is obvious that the principles will crumble.
('42', 104, 1, 11, 195195) Do not give up your faith, patience and perseverance.
('42', 104, 1, 12, 195249) If you have faith in the teachers and the principles, you would not be faint of heart, nor even if your strength is small, and you will bring glory to the Vidyapith.
('42', 104, 1, 13, 195415) You will compel your teachers to give you all that they have.
('42', 104, 1, 14, 195477) If you are studious, you will be able to pester your teachers with questions about what I have spoken.
('42', 104, 1, 15, 195580) If you take enough interest here is plenty of interesting work, you will have vigorous bodies, vigorous minds and vigorous souls.
('42', 104, 1, 16, 195710) You come here to enlighten your souls.
('42', 104, 1, 17, 195749) Hence if you take interest in vocational training that is provided here, even if you have no flair for vocations, you will acquire one.
('42', 104, 1, 18, 195885) But it will not be possible if you go about your work mechanically.
('42', 104, 1, 19, 195953) If you take interest you will see that it also is a science by itself.
('42', 104, 1, 20, 196024) If you work intelligently, you will find that there is a lot of interest in it.
('42', 104, 1, 21, 196104) You will be able to prove that there is a science behind it.
('42', 104, 1, 22, 196165) Resolve that you want to become a weaver, a carpenter, and win freedom for India; that you do not want to take up a job nor be a teacher.
('42', 104, 1, 23, 196303) Determine to live by labour, by weaving khadi, by becoming a khadi worker.

('42', 105, 5, 11, 196874) 139. LETTER TO S. MURATORI
('42', 105, 6, 12, 196901) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, June 13, 1928
('42', 105, 7, 13, 196945) DEAR FRIEND, With reference to your letter of 15th May, I have no objection to your publishing an Italian translation unabridged of the firs volume of “The Story of My Experiments with Truth”.
('42', 105, 7, 14, 197138) I do not make any special conditions, but anything you may care to give will be utilized for the furtherance of my public activities.
