('42', 106, 1, 2, 197424) 140. SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM
('42', 106, 2, 3, 197447) This Ashram was opened on 25th May, 1915. A constitution was drawn up when it was founded.
('42', 106, 2, 4, 197538) It underwent a revision during my incarceration.
('42', 106, 2, 5, 197587) The copies were exhausted long ago.
('42', 106, 2, 6, 197623) My colleagues and I found it desirable to recast the constitution in view of the many changes and ups and downs that the Ashram had undergone.
('42', 106, 2, 7, 197766) Its unexpected expansion too made the old constitution out of date.
('42', 106, 2, 8, 197834) The burden of preparing the first draft fell on my shoulders.
('42', 106, 2, 9, 197896) Though pressure of work was ample excuse for the delay, I know that my subconscious self shirked the task.
('42', 106, 2, 10, 198003) I was not clear as to the changes that were to be made.
('42', 106, 2, 11, 198059) But my colleagues would give me no peace and Maganlal’s death hastened the completion.
('42', 106, 2, 12, 198146) The following constitution is the result of the joint labours of the main workers.
('42', 106, 2, 13, 198229) It is published purely as a draft, though pending revision it is to be accepted as a binding constitution by the Managing Committee.
('42', 106, 2, 14, 198362) It is published in order to secure the opinion of friends and critics known and unknown of the Ashram.
('42', 106, 2, 15, 198465) Any criticism or suggestions that may be sent will be thankfully received.
('42', 106, 2, 16, 198540) I may be permitted to mention that the Ashram represents a prayerful and scientific experiment.
('42', 106, 2, 17, 198636) The observances are many but they have been tested for the past 13 years of the existence of the Ashram.
('42', 106, 2, 18, 198741) Whilst it is impossible to claim their perfect fulfilment by any one of us, the workers have in all humility tried to enforce them in their lives to the best of their ability and with more or less success.
('42', 106, 2, 19, 198947) The curious will find that the new draft bears very close resemblance to the original constitution as it was drawn up in 1915. Founded on Vaishakh Sud 11th, Samvat 1971,—May 25th, 1915,—at Kochrab, and since removed to Sabarmati.
('42', 106, 3, 20, 199177) OBJECT The object of this Ashram is that its members should qualify themselves for, and make a constant endeavour towards, the service of the country, not inconsistent with the universal welfare.
('42', 106, 4, 21, 199373) OBSERVANCES The following observances are essential for the fulfilment of the above object : I. TRUTH Truth is not fulfilled by mere abstinence from telling or practi sing an untruth in ordinary relations with fellow men.
('42', 106, 4, 22, 199595) But Truth is
('42', 107, 0, 1, 199608) 108 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 107, 1, 2, 199650) God, the one and only Reality.
('42', 107, 1, 3, 199681) All other observances take their rise from the quest for and the worship of Truth.
('42', 107, 1, 4, 199764) Worshippers of Truth must not resort to untruth, even for what they may believe to be the good of the country, and they may be required, like Prahlad, civilly to disobey even the orders of parents and elders in virtue of their paramount loyalty to Truth.
('42', 107, 1, 5, 200019) NON VIOLENCE OR LOVE Mere non killing is not enough.
('42', 107, 1, 6, 200072) The active part of Non violence is love.
('42', 107, 1, 7, 200113) The law of Love requires equal consideration for all life from the tiniest insect to the highest man.
('42', 107, 1, 8, 200215) One who follows this law must not be angry even with the perpetrator of the greatest imaginable wrong, but must love him, wish him well and serve him.
('42', 107, 1, 9, 200366) Although he must thus love the wrongdoer, he must never submit to his wrong or his injustice, but must oppose it with all his might, and must patiently and without resentment suffer all the hardships to which the wrongdoer may subject him in punishment for his opposition.
('42', 107, 1, 10, 200639) CHASTITY (Brahmacharya) Observance of the foregoing principles is impossible without the observance of celibacy.
('42', 107, 1, 11, 200752) It is not enough that one should not look upon any woman or man with a lustful eye; animal passion must be so controlled as to be excluded even from the mind.
('42', 107, 1, 12, 200911) If married, one must not have a carnal mind regarding one’s wife or husband, but must consider her or him as one’s lifelong friend, and establish relationship of perfect purity.
('42', 107, 1, 13, 201089) A sinful touch, gesture or word is a direct breach of this principle.
('42', 107, 2, 14, 201159) CONTROL OF THE PALATE The observance of brahmacharya has been found, from experience, to be extremely difficult so long as one has not acquired mastery over taste.
('42', 107, 2, 15, 201323) Control of the palate has, therefore, been placed as a principle by itself.
('42', 107, 2, 16, 201399) Eating is necessary only for sustaining the body and keeping it a fit instrument for service, and must never be practised for self indulgence.
('42', 107, 2, 17, 201542) Food must, therefore, be taken, like medicine, under proper restraint.
('42', 107, 2, 18, 201613) In pursuance of this principle one must eschew exciting foods, such as spices and condiments.
('42', 107, 2, 19, 201707) Meat, liquor, tobacco, bhang, etc., are excluded from the Ashram.
('42', 107, 2, 20, 201773) This principle requires abstinence from feasts or dinners which have pleasure as their object.
('42', 107, 3, 21, 201868) V. NON STEALING It is not enough not to take another’s property without his permission.
('42', 107, 3, 22, 201956) One becomes guilty of theft even by using differently
('42', 108, 0, 1, 202010) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 109
('42', 108, 1, 2, 202054) anything which one has received in trust for use in a particular way, as well as by using a thing longer than the period for which it has been lent.
('42', 108, 1, 3, 202203) It is also theft if one receives anything which one does not really need.
('42', 108, 1, 4, 202277) The fine truth at the bottom of this principle is that Nature provides just enough, and no more, for our daily need.
('42', 108, 2, 5, 202394) NON POSSESSION OR POVERTY This principle is really a part of No.
('42', 108, 2, 6, 202459) V. Just as one must not receive, so must one not possess anything which one does not really need.
('42', 108, 2, 7, 202557) It would be a breach of this principle to posses unnecessary food stuffs, clothing or furniture.
('42', 108, 2, 8, 202654) For instance, one must not keep a chair if one can do without it.
('42', 108, 2, 9, 202720) In observing this principle one is led to a progressive simplification of one’s own life.
('42', 108, 3, 10, 202810) PHYSICAL LABOUR Physical labour is essential for the observance of non stealing and non possession.
('42', 108, 3, 11, 202910) Man can be saved from injuring society, as well as himself, only if he sustains his physical existence by physical labour.
('42', 108, 3, 12, 203033) Able bodied adults must do all their personal work themselves, and must not be served by others, except for proper reasons.
('42', 108, 3, 13, 203157) But they must, at the same time, remember that service of children, as well as of the disabled, the old and the sick, is a duty incumbent on every person who has the required strength.
('42', 108, 4, 14, 203342) SWADESHI Man is not omnipotent.
('42', 108, 4, 15, 203374) He therefore serves the world best by first serving his neighbour.
('42', 108, 4, 16, 203441) This is swadeshi, a principle which is broken when one professes to serve those who are more remote in preference to those who are near.
('42', 108, 4, 17, 203578) Observance of swadeshi makes for order in the world; the breach of it leads to chaos.
('42', 108, 4, 18, 203664) Following this principle, one must as far as possible purchase one’s requirements locally and not buy things imported from foreign lands, which can easily be manufactured in the country.
('42', 108, 4, 19, 203851) There is no place for self interest in swadeshi, which enjoins the sacrifice of oneself for the family, of the family for the village, of the village for the country, and of the country for humanity.
('42', 108, 4, 20, 204051) FEARLESSNESS One cannot follow Truth or love so long as one is subject to fear.
('42', 108, 4, 21, 204131) As there is at present a reign of fear in the country, meditation on and cultivation of fearlessness have a particular importance.
('42', 108, 4, 22, 204262) Hence its separate mention as an observance.
('42', 108, 4, 23, 204307) A seeker after Truth must give up the fear of parents, caste, Government, robbers, etc., and he must be
('42', 109, 0, 1, 204411) 110 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 109, 1, 2, 204453) frightened by poverty or death.
('42', 109, 2, 3, 204485) X. REMOVAL OF UNTOUCHABILITY Untouchability, which has taken such deep roots in Hinduism, is altogether irreligious.
('42', 109, 2, 4, 204602) Its removal has therefore been treated as an independent principle.
('42', 109, 2, 5, 204670) The so called untouchables have an equal place in the Ashram with other classes.
('42', 109, 2, 6, 204751) The Ashram does not believe in caste which, it considers, has injured Hinduism, because its implications of superior and inferior status, and of pollution by contact are contrary to the law of Love.
('42', 109, 2, 7, 204950) The Ashram however believes in varnashrama dharma.
('42', 109, 2, 8, 205001) The division of varnas is based upon occupation, and therefore a person should maintain himself by following the hereditary occupation, not inconsistent with fundamental morals, and should devote all his spare time and energy to the acquisition and advancement of true knowledge.
('42', 109, 2, 9, 205281) The ashramas (the four stages) spoken of in the smritis are conducive to the welfare of mankind.
('42', 109, 2, 10, 205378) Though, therefore, the Ashram believes in vasrnashrama dharma, there is no place in it for distinction of varnas, as the Ashram life is conceived in the light of the comprehensive and non formal sannyasa of the Bhagavad Gita.
('42', 109, 3, 11, 205604) TOLERANCE The Ashram believes that the principal faiths of the world constitute a revelation of Truth, but as they have all been outlined by imperfect man they have been affected by imperfections and alloyed with untruth.
('42', 109, 3, 12, 205826) One must therefore entertain the same respect for the religious faiths of others as one accords to one’s own.
('42', 109, 3, 13, 205936) Where such tolerance becomes a law of life, conflict between different faiths becomes impossible, and so does all effort to convert other people to one’s own faith.
('42', 109, 3, 14, 206101) One can only pray that the defects in the various faiths may be overcome, and that they may advance, side by side, towards perfection.
('42', 109, 4, 15, 206236) ACTIVITIES As a result of and in order to help fulfilment of these observances, the following activities are carried on in the Ashram :
('42', 109, 5, 16, 206372) I. WORSHIP The social (as distinguished from the individual) activities of the Ashram commence every day with the congregational morning worship at 4.15 to 4.45 and close with the evening prayer at 7 to 7.30. All inmates are expected to attend the worship.
('42', 109, 5, 17, 206629) This worship has been conceived as an aid to self purification and dedication of one’s all to
('42', 110, 0, 1, 206723) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 111
('42', 110, 2, 2, 206767) SANITARY SERVICE This is an essential and sacred service and yet it is looked down upon in society, with the result that it is generally neglected and affords considerable scope for improvement.
('42', 110, 2, 3, 206962) The Ashram therefore lays special stress upon engaging no outside labour for this work.
('42', 110, 2, 4, 207050) The members themselves attend to the whole of the sanitation in turns.
('42', 110, 2, 5, 207121) New entrants are generally first of all attached to this department.
('42', 110, 2, 6, 207190) Trenches are sunk to the depth of nine inches and the nightsoil is buried in them and covered with the excavated earth.
('42', 110, 2, 7, 207310) It thus becomes converted into valuable manure.
('42', 110, 2, 8, 207358) Calls of nature are attended to only at places assigned for the purpose.
('42', 110, 2, 9, 207431) Care is taken that the roads and paths should not be spoilt by spitting or otherwise.
('42', 110, 3, 10, 207517) SACRIFICIAL SPINNING Today India’s most urgent problem is the growing starvation of her millions, which is chiefly due to the deliberate destruction by alien rule of her principal auxiliary industry of hand spinning.
('42', 110, 3, 11, 207734) With a view to its rehabilitation in national life, spinning has been made the central activity of the Ashram, and is compulsory for all members, as a national sacrifice.
('42', 110, 3, 12, 207905) The following are the various branches of work in this department : 1. Cotton cultivation; 2. workshop for making and repairing spinning wheels, spindles, carding bows, etc; 3. ginning; 4. carding; 5. spinning; 6. weaving cloth, carpets, tape, rope, etc.; 7. dyeing and printing.
('42', 110, 4, 13, 208185) AGRICULTURE Cotton for the khadi work and fodder crops for the cattle are the chief activities of this department.
('42', 110, 4, 14, 208300) Vegetables and fruit are also grown in order to make the Ashram as far as possible self contained.
('42', 110, 5, 15, 208399) V. DAIRY An attempt is being made to convert into a model dairy the Ashram dairy which supplies milk to the inmates.
('42', 110, 5, 16, 208516) Since last year this dairy is being carried on in consonance with the principles of and with the pecuniary help of the All India Cow protection Association, but as
('42', 111, 0, 1, 208680) 112 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 111, 1, 2, 208722) an integral part of the Ashram itself.
('42', 111, 1, 3, 208761) There are at presnet 27 cows, 47 calves, 10 bullocks, and 4 bulls.
('42', 111, 1, 4, 208828) The average dairy output of milk is 200 pounds.
('42', 111, 2, 5, 208876) TANNERY At the instance of and with the help of the All India Cow protection Association, a tannery has been established for the tanning of dead cattle hides.
('42', 111, 2, 6, 209035) There is attached to it a sandal and shoe making department.
('42', 111, 2, 7, 209096) The dairy and tannery have been established because the Ashram believes, in spite of the claim Hindus make to the protection of the cow, that Indian cattle will further and further deteriorate and ultimately die out, carrying man along with them, unless vigorous attention is paid to cattle breeding, cattle feeding and the utilization in the country of dead cattle hides.
('42', 111, 3, 8, 209469) NATIONAL EDUCATION An attempt is made in the Ashram to impart such education as is conducive to national welfare.
('42', 111, 3, 9, 209583) In order that spiritual, intellectual and physical development may proceed side by side, an atmosphere of industry has been created, and letters are not given more than their due importance.
('42', 111, 3, 10, 209774) Character building is attended to in the smallest detail.
('42', 111, 3, 11, 209832) ‘Untouchable’ children are freely admitted.
('42', 111, 3, 12, 209876) Women are given special attention with a view to improving their status, and they are accorded the same opportunities for self culture as the men.
('42', 111, 3, 13, 210023) The Ashram accepts the following principles of the Gujarat Vidyapith : 1. The principal object of the Vidyapith shall be to prepare workers of character, ability, education and conscientiousness, necessary for the conduct of the movements connected with the attainment of swaraj.
('42', 111, 3, 14, 210303) 2. All the institutions conducted by and affiliated to the Vidyapith shall be fully non co operating and shall therefore have nothing to do with my help from Government.
('42', 111, 3, 15, 210473) 3. Whereas the Vidyapith has come into being in connection with the swaraj movement, and Non violent Non co operation as a means thereof, its teachers and trustees shall restrict themselves to those means only which are not inconsistent with truth and non violence and shall consciously strive to carry them out.
('42', 111, 3, 16, 210786) 4. The teachers and the trustees of the Vidyapith, as also all the institutions affiliated to it, shall regard untouchability as a blot on Hinduism, shall strive to the best of their power for its removal, and shall not exclude a boy or a girl for reason of his or her
('42', 112, 0, 1, 211055) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 113
('42', 112, 1, 2, 211099) untouchability nor shall give him or her differential treatment having once accorded admission to him or her.
('42', 112, 1, 3, 211209) 5. The teachers and the trustees of and all the institutions affiliated to the Vidyapith shall regard hand spinning as an essential part of the swaraj movement and shall therefore spin regularly, except when disabled, and shall habitually wear khadi.
('42', 112, 1, 4, 211460) 6. The language of the province shall have the principal place in the Vidyapith and shall be the medium of instruction.
('42', 112, 1, 5, 211580) EXPLANATION.
('42', 112, 1, 6, 211593) Languages other than Gujarati may be taught by direct method.
('42', 112, 1, 7, 211655) 7. The teaching of Hindi Hindustani shall be compulsory in the curricula of the Vidyapith.
('42', 112, 1, 8, 211746) 8. Manual training shall receive the same importance as intellectual training and only such occupations as are useful for the life of the nation shall be taught.
('42', 112, 1, 9, 211908) 9. Whereas the growth of the nation depends not on cities but its villages, the bulk of the funds of the Vidyapith and a majority of the teachers of the Vidyapith shall be employed in the propagation of education conducive to the welfare of the villagers.
('42', 112, 1, 10, 212164) 10. In laying down the curricula, the needs of village dwellers shall have principal consideration.
('42', 112, 1, 11, 212264) 11. There shall be complete toleration of all established religions in all institutions conducted by and affiliated to the Vidyapith, and for the spiritual development of the pupils, religious instruction shall be imparted in consonance with truth and non violence.
('42', 112, 1, 12, 212530) 12. For the physical development of the nation physical exercise and physical training shall be compulsory in all the institutions conducted by and affiliated to the Vidyapith.
('42', 112, 1, 13, 212707) Hindi Hindustani means the language commonly spoken by the masses of the North—both Hindu and Mussalman—and written in the Devanagari or the Arabic script.
('42', 112, 1, 14, 212863) The Ashram school has so far sent forth 15 boys and 2 grils.
('42', 112, 2, 15, 212924) KHADI TECHNICAL SCHOOL A separate technical school is conducted which prepares candidates for the Khadi Service on behalf of the All India Spinners’ Association.
('42', 112, 2, 16, 213086) There are at present 33 students from various provinces under training.
('42', 112, 2, 17, 213158) 205 students have so far availed themselves of this

('42', 117, 3, 8, 220162) The Chairman shall have the power of granting exemption from this rule in special cases.

('42', 120, 1, 2, 222994) 141. IMMOLATION OF BARDOLI
('42', 120, 2, 3, 223021) Bardoli suffers through the lawlessness of the Government of Bombay and it suffers through self imposed suffering.
('42', 120, 2, 4, 223136) Both the instance will be found in Mahadav Desai’s notes on Bardoli.
('42', 120, 2, 5, 223205) The Government are using a Nasmyth hammer to crush a fly.
('42', 120, 2, 6, 223263) For the sake of, to them, a paltry sum of Rs. 1,00,000 which the enhancement represents, they are resorting to force, untruth, flattery and bribery.
('42', 120, 2, 7, 223412) These are strong expressions, but none too strong for the doings of the Government.
('42', 120, 2, 8, 223496) Then force is on the surface for anyone to see.
('42', 120, 2, 9, 223544) Authority makes a show of force even when it is unable to command it.
('42', 120, 2, 10, 223614) In the present case it has force enough and to spare.
('42', 120, 2, 11, 223668) This method is the least dangerous for it is visible.
('42', 120, 2, 12, 223722) The other three are mischievous because they are invisible.
('42', 120, 2, 13, 223782) The insolent letter of the Commissioner, N. D., the evasive communique of the Government are instances of untruth by way both of commission and omission.
('42', 120, 2, 14, 223936) We shall know at the end of the chapter the instances of flattery and bribery.
('42', 120, 2, 15, 224015) We know how those who degraded their manhood during the Punjab martial law regime got titles and promotions.
('42', 120, 2, 16, 224124) History will repeat itself in this as yet miniature edition of the Punjab.
('42', 120, 2, 17, 224199) I do not mention here the subtle forms of flattery that the Government resort to when they want someone to do some questionable deal for them.
('42', 120, 2, 18, 224342) Most governments resort to these four methods but what pains one most is that all these forces should be set in motion by the Bombay Government in order to bend the proud spirit of people known for their docility and innocence.
('42', 120, 2, 19, 224570) It is a base calumny to suggest that they are law breakers.
('42', 120, 2, 20, 224630) If a man can lawfully repudiate a liability which he does not admit, why may not men lawfully repudiate a liability which they contend is unjustly imposed upon them by a State?
('42', 120, 2, 21, 224807) And why may not the State adopt, and be satisfied for the collection of what it considers to be its dues with, the same civil measures that are open to individuals?
('42', 120, 2, 22, 224972) But this suffering to which the people of Bardoli are being wantonly subjected is raising them since they had prepared themselves for it.
('42', 120, 2, 23, 225110) The brave stand taken by the simple peasants has undermined the very prestige to prop up which the Government are making the frantic efforts described from week to week in these pages.
('42', 120, 2, 24, 225295) But more purifying than this suffering imposed by godless and insolent authority is the suffering which the people are imposing upon themselves.
('42', 120, 2, 25, 225440) I refer to the resignations of sixty three patels and eleven
('42', 121, 0, 1, 225501) 122 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 121, 1, 2, 225543) talatis of Bardoli and Valod.
('42', 121, 1, 3, 225573) It is not a small thing for these people to give up their posts which hitherto they have used not unoften in order to make illegitimate addition to their ordinary emoluments.
('42', 121, 1, 4, 225748) It is more difficult for people such as these to give up their positions than for big Government officers to do so.
('42', 121, 1, 5, 225864) But suffering as well as bravery is the badge of the humble.
('42', 121, 1, 6, 225925) I tender my respectful congratulations to these patels and talatis.
('42', 121, 1, 7, 225993) Let them know that their sacrifice has commanded the admiration of all India.
('42', 121, 1, 8, 226071) It is sacrifice such as theirs that will in the end give us our freedom.
('42', 121, 1, 9, 226144) We are salves to our desire for office under the Government.
('42', 121, 1, 10, 226205) The latter knowing our weakness exploits it to the full for consolidation of its own power.
('42', 121, 1, 11, 226297) But if we would only believe that He who has created us is bound to support us, if we would but do His will, i.e., work with our honest hands and feet, we should never starve, we should never walk on all fours before authority.
('42', 121, 1, 12, 226525) Young India, 14 6 1928
('42', 121, 2, 13, 226548) 142. WHAT IS THE BARDOLI CASE?
('42', 121, 2, 14, 226579) The following epitome of the case has been prepared in response to many calls for the barest summary of the case for the busy reader.
('42', 121, 2, 15, 226713) 1 Though the case has been stated in ample detail in these pages, the following summary will be helpful to those who want to work for the satyagrahis, but who may not know what the case exactly is and who may have no time to go through the files of papers.
('42', 121, 2, 16, 226970) The summary is necessary because of the ever growing interest excited by the heroic sufferings of the people of Bardoli.

('42', 122, 1, 2, 227252) 143. A.I.S.A. MEMBERSHIP
('42', 122, 2, 3, 227277) The Director of the Technical Department of the All India Spinners’ Association sends me the following comparative table 1 : The table is an instructive study.
('42', 122, 2, 4, 227437) Whilst the business side of khadi shows a steady though slow improvement in quality, quantity and price and whilst the number of paid spinners is increasing, sacrificial spinning is steadily on the decline, except in Bihar and Ajmer.
('42', 122, 2, 5, 227671) It either shows that the deep conviction about the power of hand spinning to ameliorate the condition of the masses and to bring the middle class in healthy contact with the masses is lacking, or the latter, though they have the conviction, are too lazy or indifferent to make the smell but continuing measure of sacrifice required of them.
('42', 122, 2, 6, 228012) It is curious that even the national institutions such as in Gujarat are not supplying their full quota of voluntary spinners and that the workers even in the Khadi Service are disinclined to take the trouble of spinning that brings them no return.
('42', 122, 2, 7, 228261) Is it to be wondered at that the progress of khadi is not commensurate with the national requir ements?
('42', 122, 2, 8, 228365) Let khadi workers and khadi lovers take note.
('42', 122, 2, 9, 228411) Young India, 14 6 1928

('42', 126, 3, 9, 233936) 150. MY NOTES
('42', 126, 4, 10, 233950) JOURNALIST ROBBERS The proprietors and editors of some newspapers seem to be engaged in robbery.
('42', 126, 4, 11, 234047) They make it their profession to rob people’s money by inventing all sorts of pretexts, by making unfounded allegations against innocent persons and threatening them.
('42', 126, 4, 12, 234214) Some accept bribes and try to justify dishonest practices and in this manner dupe the innocent public.
('42', 126, 4, 13, 234317) A friend from Calcutta has informed me of one such instance.
('42', 126, 4, 14, 234378) A journal published there has been taking advantage of the publicity given to the immoral practices at Govindbhavan, and is making allegations against many families and persecuting the simple folk of the Marwari community.
('42', 126, 4, 15, 234601) Having concocted indecent incidents which never took place, they implicate certain family people in them.
('42', 126, 4, 16, 234707) The friend who has sent me this filthy paper wants me to write something about such journals so that they may mend their ways.
('42', 126, 4, 17, 234834) I have no such hopes for my article.
('42', 126, 4, 18, 234871) It is therefore not addressed to them but to those families who are being maligned and blackmailed by such journals.
('42', 126, 4, 19, 234988) There is a saying in English that knaves prosper among fools.
('42', 126, 4, 20, 235050) This saying is based on experience.
('42', 126, 4, 21, 235086) The critic at last tiresand gives up criticizing those who are not cowed down by any criticism.
('42', 126, 4, 22, 235182) We are too much given to a false sense of shame and a needless fear of public humiliation.
('42', 126, 4, 23, 235273) Hence anyone is able to frighten and blackmail us.
('42', 126, 4, 24, 235324) If someone maligns us or makes false allegations against us, we are somehow scared as if we merited such criticism and allegations.
('42', 126, 4, 25, 235456) Whereas the correct attitude is that whatever the criticism against us, if
('42', 127, 0, 1, 235531) 128 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 127, 1, 2, 235573) it is not just, we should not be cowed down by it or worry over it.
('42', 127, 2, 3, 235641) ABOUT TRUTHFULNESS AND OTHER VOWS An inmate of the Ashram had suggested some additions he considered essential, to the Book of Ashram Rules and as they have a subtle import and are helpful in the observance of the vows, I give below their gist.
('42', 127, 2, 4, 235886) Each vow has been finally supported by a quotation from the Hindu Shastras.
('42', 127, 2, 5, 235962) These have been deliberately omitted from the Book of Rules because the Ashram believes that the principles implicit in the vows are not a monopoly of Hinduism but are common to all faiths.
('42', 127, 2, 6, 236152) However, the statements which have been quoted in support are beautiful and are therefore given here for the reader’s information.
('42', 127, 3, 7, 236283) TRUTH As brevity is the armour of truth, it is contained in it.
('42', 127, 3, 8, 236347) ‘Truth alone will triumph and not untruth.’
('42', 127, 4, 9, 236391) NON VIOLENCE Non violence is the limit set by all religions.
('42', 127, 4, 10, 236452) ‘Sin cannot be answered by sin.’
('42', 127, 5, 11, 236485) THE VOW OF BRAHMACHARYA This vow implies complete control of all senses.
('42', 127, 5, 12, 236558) ‘Those wishing to attain God practise brahmacharya.’
('42', 127, 6, 13, 236611) ASTEYA ‘One who enjoys the gifts of God without offering them to Him is verily a thief.’
('42', 127, 7, 14, 236700) APARIGRAHA ‘Enjoy it after giving up its possession.’
('42', 127, 8, 15, 236754) THE VOW OF FEARLESSNESS Fear and morality are mutually contradictory concepts.
('42', 127, 8, 16, 236833) Fearlessness is the foundation of daivi sampad 1. ‘He alone becomes fearless who dispels fear in others.’ ASVAD To eat food with a veiw to gratifying the palate is violence.
('42', 127, 8, 17, 237007) ‘Purity of diet leads to purity of heart, this in its turn strengthens atman’s awakening which in its turn destroys all bonds.’
('42', 127, 9, 18, 237135) SWADESHI Just as non violence sets the limit for dharma, so swadeshi
('42', 127, 10, 19, 237204) 1 Divine heritage
('42', 128, 0, 1, 237222) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 129
('42', 128, 1, 2, 237266) sets the limit for conduct.
('42', 128, 1, 3, 237294) Even death is to be preferred in the discharge of one’s own dharma.
('42', 128, 1, 4, 237362) BODILY LABOUR ‘When one exerts one’s body without any desire one commits no sin.’ ABOLITION OF UNTOUCHABILITY Salutation to all—high and low.
('42', 128, 1, 5, 237504) TOLERANCE Forbearance means tolerance towards all religions.
('42', 128, 2, 6, 237565) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 17 6 1928
('42', 128, 3, 7, 237602) 151. THE GOVERNOR AND BARDOLI
('42', 128, 4, 8, 237632) Shri Munshi’s correspondence with H.E. the Governor gives a vivid picture of the existing system of government.
('42', 128, 4, 9, 237744) On the one hand, the Government writes long argumentative letters in order to humour Mr. Munshi so that he does not go over to the people’s side, while on the other it writes specious untruths attempting to prove the people wrong.
('42', 128, 4, 10, 237975) It still insists on denying what has been repeatedly and clearly put forward by the people, as if untruth by frequent repetition can become truth!
('42', 128, 4, 11, 238122) Only one point stands out in the whole letter : the Government is not prepared to change its land revenue policy.
('42', 128, 4, 12, 238236) If the revenue policy is changed, the most expensive Government in the world would cease to function or, alternatively, its expenses would be in proportion to the people’s capacity to bear them.
('42', 128, 4, 13, 238431) The Governor maintains that no independent inquiry can be held as between the Government and its people.
('42', 128, 4, 14, 238536) By saying so, he is throwing dust into the eyes of the Britishers.
('42', 128, 4, 15, 238603) An independent inquiry too will be officially conducted.
('42', 128, 4, 16, 238660) Although the judiciary is independent of the executive, it is nevertheless a Government department.
('42', 128, 4, 17, 238760) No one has demanded that the committee be appointed by the people.
('42', 128, 4, 18, 238827) But the people have asked for the appointment of neutral persons to conduct an inquiry into the case regarding the collection of land revenue in Bardoli, in a manner similar to that followed in law courts.
('42', 128, 4, 19, 239033) This does not imply that the Government should give up the business of governing.
('42', 128, 4, 20, 239115) However, it does imply the Government’s giving up its high handed autocratic ways.
('42', 128, 4, 21, 239198) And if the
('42', 129, 0, 1, 239209) 130 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 129, 1, 2, 239251) people are to have swaraj and if they want to obtain it, this autocracy must be summarily done away with.
('42', 129, 1, 3, 239357) From this standpoint, the struggle in Bardoli has now assumed a wider significance or the Government has fortunately for us lent it this significance.
('42', 129, 1, 4, 239508) Shri Munshi’s argument or his admission that satyagraha is an illegal weapon is indeed painful.
('42', 129, 1, 5, 239604) It could now be regarded as a recognized weapon.
('42', 129, 1, 6, 239653) When it was employed in South Africa, Lord Hardinge had defended it.
('42', 129, 1, 7, 239722) The Government of Bihar had accepted it in Champaran and appointed a committee.
('42', 129, 1, 8, 239802) Shri Vallabhbhai had used the very weapon in Borsad and the present Governor himself had honoured it and had met the people’s grievances.
('42', 129, 1, 9, 239940) One fails to understand why this weapon should now be regarded as illegal.
('42', 129, 1, 10, 240015) However, the relevant question at the moment is not whether satyagraha is legal or illegal.
('42', 129, 1, 11, 240107) If the people’s demand is reasonable it does not become less justified on account of their way of putting it forward.
('42', 129, 1, 12, 240225) Bringing about a solution to this problem is in the hands of the satyagrahis of Bardoli alone.
('42', 129, 1, 13, 240320) It will be solved in only one way if their sacrifice and their courage are real.
('42', 129, 1, 14, 240401) If the people do not pay the revenue, the Government will either have to write it off or appoint a committee.
('42', 129, 1, 15, 240511) The fact that the people’s honour rests in their own hands is borne out from this correspondence.
('42', 129, 1, 16, 240609) On the 12th, the people of Bardoli were praised everywhere.
('42', 129, 1, 17, 240669) From outside Bardoli people can for the present do one thing only and that is to give financial help and express their sympathy.
('42', 129, 1, 18, 240798) Financial help is coming in freely from all quarters.
('42', 129, 1, 19, 240852) Until now a lakh of rupees has come in.
('42', 129, 1, 20, 240892) The whole of India solidly supports Bardoli’s demand.
('42', 129, 1, 21, 240946) But an autocratic government bows only to force.
('42', 129, 1, 22, 240995) The people have wisely given up the use of brute force.
('42', 129, 1, 23, 241051) Bardoli has been making use of soul force in the form of satyagraha.
('42', 129, 1, 24, 241120) The might of the Government is negligible before it.
('42', 129, 1, 25, 241173) Will Bardoli honour its pledge?
('42', 129, 1, 26, 241205) It is necessary to examine a suspicion that arises out of the Government’s letter and the records of its Information Depart ment.
('42', 129, 1, 27, 241335) In H.E. the Governor’s letter the reason for withdrawing the Pathans has been stated to be deference to the people’s wishes, whereas the Government’s Information Department claims that there is likely to be little use of the Pathans now that the monsoon has set in.
('42', 129, 1, 28, 241601) The Governor [alone] would know what lies behind the two divergent accounts.
('42', 129, 1, 29, 241678) Let us, however, understand the inwardness of the reason
('42', 130, 0, 1, 241735) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 131
('42', 130, 1, 2, 241779) given by the Information Department.
('42', 130, 1, 3, 241816) During the rainy season instead of resorting to confiscation and such other measures, that is, instead of resorting openly to a policy of repression, there is the likelihood and the fear that it will resort to secret negotiations with the people.
('42', 130, 1, 4, 242063) There is a possibility that it will invite the people, send out secret agents, hold out temptations, coupled with threats, and adopt measures to divide them.
('42', 130, 1, 5, 242221) I hope people will beware of this muffled blow.

('42', 130, 2, 7, 242306) 152. QUESTIONS ON EDUCATION—III
('42', 130, 3, 8, 242338) Q. 7. Do you not feel that just as it is necessary for students to now three or four languages, it is also necessary for them to be informed about the dogmas, rituals, injunctions and superstitions of all the prevailing religions?
('42', 130, 4, 9, 242569) A. If we wish to create among students respect, tolerance and love for every religion—which is indeed religion and not irreligion, we should certainly instruct them in their principles.
('42', 130, 4, 10, 242755) I do not consider it very necessary to have a knowledge of the superstitions and rituals.
('42', 130, 4, 11, 242845) In a country lie India anyone who goes about with his eyes eyes and ears open can see for himself the superstitions and rituals.
('42', 130, 4, 12, 242974) If we wish to adopt that which is virtuous, we should not at all insist upon a knowledge of the superstitions and rituals of every religion.
('42', 130, 4, 13, 243115) It is possible that a good deal of the students’ time will be taken up by our insisting on their gaining a minute knowledge of whatever rituals and superstitions are to be found in our religion and trying to introduce any necessary reforms in them.
('42', 130, 5, 14, 243364) Q. 8. Since you believe in the system of varnas, do you not accept that persons of different varnas should be given different kinds of education?
('42', 130, 6, 15, 243510) A. I do not feel that there should be different kinds of education for the different varnas.
('42', 130, 6, 16, 243603) There is much in common among them and our education should be, as it is at present, common to all.
('42', 130, 6, 17, 243703) One of the aims of education is to make men of students and he who has become a man will easily understand the norms that apply to and should govern human beings.
('42', 130, 6, 18, 243866) My conception of the varnas is that they are based on occupations and as the four varnas have to earn their living through their own occu pations, the special features of
('42', 131, 0, 1, 244037) 132 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 131, 1, 2, 244079) each should be hereditary.
('42', 131, 1, 3, 244106) Moreover, I do not interpret the varna dharma to imply that one varna can never have the virtues of the other three.
('42', 131, 1, 4, 244223) A Brahmin will not earn his livelihood by ser ving like a Shudra; nevertheless, if he cannot serve or is ashamed to do so he is no Brahmin.
('42', 131, 1, 5, 244363) True knowledge is unattainable without disinterested service.
('42', 131, 1, 6, 244425) And although the Shudra will not live on the food received in the begging bowl after teaching the Vedas and other scriptures, neverthe less, in a well ordered society, he too will have a knowledge of the Vedas.
('42', 131, 2, 7, 244636) Q. 9. Is is true that you say that vocational training includes all education and intellectual training is merely a frill of education?
('42', 131, 2, 8, 244772) If this is so why do you welcome college education?
('42', 131, 3, 9, 244824) A. It is as much true as it is false.
('42', 131, 3, 10, 244862) Where there is blind worship of intellectual education, I would certainly say that vocational training covers everything.
('42', 131, 3, 11, 244984) In my definition of education, there is no wall of brick and cement separating intellectual training from vocational training, but the latter includes the former, that is, it provides scope for the development of the intellect.
('42', 131, 3, 12, 245212) I would make bold to say that a true development of the intellect is not possible without vocational training.
('42', 131, 3, 13, 245323) The knowledge a mason requires to earn his livelihood is not education at all in my opinion.
('42', 131, 3, 14, 245416) His education should comprise a knowledge of the place of his vocation in society, of bricks and their importance, of the need for houses and what they should be like and how closely they are connected with civilization.
('42', 131, 3, 15, 245637) We often wrongly believe that intellectual education implies a general knowledge of events.
('42', 131, 3, 16, 245729) A full development of the intellect is possible without such knowledge.
('42', 131, 3, 17, 245801) The educationist who turns the student’s brain into a storehouse of innumerable facts has himself not learnt the very first lesson in education.
('42', 131, 3, 18, 245946) It must have been clear by now what is said in the question is both true and false.
('42', 131, 3, 19, 246030) It is false if you accept my view of intellectual and vocational education.
('42', 131, 3, 20, 246106) It is true if these are regarded as mutually exclusive, if there is misconception concerning education and if in framing the question this misconceived education has been kept in mind.
('42', 131, 3, 21, 246291) It should now be understood why and under what conditions I welcome university education.
('42', 131, 3, 22, 246381) The university which I visualize will consist of masons, carpenters and weavers who will be truly intellectual social workers,—they will not be only masons, carpenters and weavers having a knowledge of their trades sufficient merely for them to earn their livelihood.
('42', 131, 3, 23, 246649) From this university I look forward to seeing a Kabir arise from the weavers, a Bhoja Bhagat from
('42', 132, 0, 1, 246747) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 133
('42', 132, 1, 2, 246791) the cobblers, an Akha from the goldsmiths and a Guru Govind from the farmers.
('42', 132, 1, 3, 246869) I regard all these four as having received intellectual education.
('42', 132, 2, 4, 246936) Q. 10. If vocational training is all that education is, why do you not entrust the Vidyapith to a committee of carpenters, blacksmiths and weavers; let them then engage professors for intellectual education as expert servants.
('42', 132, 3, 5, 247163) A. The answer to this question is covered by the answer to Question 9; nevertheless, it has been reproduced with a view to clarifying my meaning further.
('42', 132, 3, 6, 247317) If I had with me weavers, etc., like Kabir, I would certainly hand over the reins of the Vidyapith to them and these professors who impart intellectual education would not be ashamed to serve under them but rather consider it an honour to do so.
('42', 132, 3, 7, 247563) It is because we have not regarded vocational training as part of education that those practising the trades are regarded as inferior and we get little or no help from the latter in social service work.
('42', 132, 3, 8, 247766) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 17 6 1928

('42', 142, 3, 4, 261706) MY DEAR PYARELAL, I dictate this because I am spinning and I want to save the few minutes that will be required for writing to you in Gujarati.

('42', 142, 3, 7, 262111) No one else, I am confident, could have written the article, because no one else would have the penetration that you have.

('42', 142, 3, 9, 262339) I only hope that the article will be copied widely by the Indian Press.

('42', 144, 4, 8, 265669) 170. LETTER TO SHANKARAN
('42', 144, 5, 9, 265694) THE ASHRAM, SABARMATI, June 20, 1928
('42', 144, 6, 10, 265731) MY DEAR SHANKARAN, I have your letter.
('42', 144, 6, 11, 265770) The list has always remained with me and the acknowledgment was printed in Navajivan without the list having been got from me.

('42', 144, 6, 17, 266318) Mahadev had had a somewhat serious fall at the well where he was drawing water.
('42', 144, 6, 18, 266398) He was laid up for 5 days.
('42', 144, 6, 19, 266425) He is better now and in two three days he will be quite restored.
('42', 144, 6, 20, 266491) Now about your questions : Even though the cause for which a donation was given may have been fulfilled, the balance left cannot be used at the will of the donee, even though the cause for which he uses it is superior to the cause that is fulfilled.
('42', 144, 6, 21, 266741) For, what the donee may consider superior may be bad cause in the estimate of the donor.
('42', 144, 6, 22, 266830) I have just now an instance of that character on which I had to decide yesterday.
('42', 144, 6, 23, 266912) A gentleman gave Rs. 10,000 in connection with national schools to Jamnalalji.
('42', 144, 6, 24, 266991) That amount of money is still unused.
('42', 144, 6, 25, 267029) Jamnalalji wants to make use of that money for national education, but for national education which includes the untouchables.
('42', 144, 6, 26, 267156) This is a superior cause as you, Jamnalalji and I would consider.
('42', 144, 6, 27, 267222) But I have advised that without the donor’s permission, seeing that the money is
('42', 145, 0, 1, 267303) 146 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 145, 1, 2, 267345) still unused, it cannot be used.
('42', 145, 1, 3, 267378) And the donor is certain not to give his permission because of the disturbing introduction of the so called untouchables.
('42', 145, 1, 4, 267500) If Jamnalalji utilizes the money for a purpose which the donor had never intended, he would be wrong and guilty of the breach of the vow of asteya.
('42', 145, 1, 5, 267648) With reference to the second question : I take your own case.
('42', 145, 1, 6, 267710) You have reduced yourself to comparative poverty by throwing overboard your job.
('42', 145, 1, 7, 267791) Surely, you are the richer for it.
('42', 145, 1, 8, 267826) And if your personal wants are still further reduced, you would be richer again.
('42', 145, 1, 9, 267907) It is better that a man gives the whole of himself than that he must retain a part for himself and a part for society.
('42', 145, 1, 10, 268026) And when a man reduces his wants to nil, he has given away his whole self.
('42', 145, 1, 11, 268101) I hope now the thing is clear.
('42', 145, 1, 12, 268132) I am keeping well.
('42', 145, 2, 13, 268151) From a microfilm: S.N. 13429
('42', 145, 3, 14, 268180) 171. ACCUSED JUDGING
('42', 145, 4, 15, 268201) The Director of Information has entered into a remarkable refuta tion of the allegations made in these pages by Mahadev Desai regard ing the conduct of the Pathans.
('42', 145, 4, 16, 268366) 1 Mahadev Desai having had a serious fall at a well whilst he was drawing water is laid up in bed and is therefore unable to write out his weekly notes and therein take notice of this refutation.
('42', 145, 4, 17, 268562) But the Director’s refutation does not need a specialist.
('42', 145, 4, 18, 268620) The admissions made in it are damaging to his cause, which is the Government’s, and his refutations are unconvincing, where they are not utterly worthless.
('42', 145, 4, 19, 268776) But before I examine the Director’s communiques, let me make one point clear.
('42', 145, 4, 20, 268854) What is it that the Government is after in publishing these communiques through the Director of Information?
('42', 145, 4, 21, 268963) Does it seek to substitute its own courts of law and become judge in cases against its own officers?
('42', 145, 4, 22, 269064) I freely confess that so far as the public are concerned, the allegations made by the Satyagraha Publicity Office are ex parte, unproved statements.
('42', 145, 4, 23, 269213) But for this Publicity Office there is no other course open to it.
('42', 145, 4, 24, 269280) Satyagrahis, even if they have no compunction about going to courts of law, cannot go to the Bardoli courts, where they know they can get no hearing, much less justice, because their complaint is not against private individuals but against Government officers, and that too during a regime which very nearly
('42', 145, 5, 25, 269588) 1 This appeared in Young India issues of May and June, 1928.
('42', 146, 0, 1, 269649) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 147
('42', 146, 1, 2, 269693) approaches martial law.
('42', 146, 1, 3, 269717) The satyagrahis have therefore no other course open to them but to acquaint the public with the extraordinary nature of the coercive measures that the Government has adopted.
('42', 146, 1, 4, 269892) What however can be the meaning of counter allegations by the Director?
('42', 146, 1, 5, 269964) What can be the value of his denials?
('42', 146, 1, 6, 270002) He is not in the same plight as the satyagrahis.
('42', 146, 1, 7, 270051) The Government has all authority.
('42', 146, 1, 8, 270085) If the allegations made by the Satyagraha Office are untrue, the Government has its own remedy.
('42', 146, 1, 9, 270181) The Government little realizes that it has lost all credit and that even where statements made on its behalf are true, they are suspected by the people as untrue.
('42', 146, 1, 10, 270344) Such is its black record.
('42', 146, 1, 11, 270370) If then the Government has evidence to show that the allegations are untrue, let it appoint an impartial open committee of enquiry and the Satyagraha Office will under take to prove every statement made by it and apologize and otherwise suffer where its statements cannot be sustained.
('42', 146, 1, 12, 270656) But the Governor’s long and copious letters to public men leave no room for any such hope.
('42', 146, 1, 13, 270747) I therefore welcome the resolution that Sjt.
('42', 146, 1, 14, 270792) Munshi has adumbrated in his powerful letter addressed to the Governor announcing his resignation.
('42', 146, 1, 15, 270891) I tender my congratulations to Sjt.
('42', 146, 1, 16, 270927) Munshi for his resignation and more for his brave letter.
('42', 146, 1, 17, 270985) I hope he will carry out his resolve to get together a committee of investigation.
('42', 146, 1, 18, 271068) Let him get the soundest men and if I may venture to suggest, let him take a leaf out of the Government book and get colleagues drawn from the various communities.
('42', 146, 1, 19, 271232) Let him get one Parsi, one Mussalman and if possible one Christian, whether English or Indian, and let there be for this self appointed committee a proper reference within which it would work, and if it would take a little more trouble, I would suggest that it should not confine its investigations merely to the coercive measures but extend them to the case of the satyagrahis regarding the enhanced assessment.
('42', 146, 1, 20, 271645) I hope too that the committee will invite the Government to send its witnesses to present its case.
('42', 146, 1, 21, 271745) That the Government may not condescend to send witnesses to such a committee is highly likely.
('42', 146, 1, 22, 271840) If it does not, it would provide one more cause for its condemnation.
('42', 146, 1, 23, 271910) Now for the Director’s communiques.
('42', 146, 1, 24, 271946) The Governor says that the Pathans are to be withdrawn in order to “remove any misunderstanding”.
('42', 146, 1, 25, 272044) The Director says that they are being withdrawn as owing to the impending rains their service would be no longer required.
('42', 146, 1, 26, 272167) Which statement is the public to believe?
('42', 146, 1, 27, 272209) And if the Pathans are not required because of the impending rains, why is a glorified edition of the Pathans in the shape of armed police with a special
('42', 147, 0, 1, 272363) 148 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 147, 1, 2, 272405) officer and working under special magistrate required?
('42', 147, 1, 3, 272460) The people will be excused if still suspect behind the withdrawal of the Pathans a sinister design still further to encompass the satyagrahis of Bardoli and awe them into subjection.
('42', 147, 1, 4, 272643) Another communique denies that one of the Pathans was only the other day caught red handed in the act of theft.
('42', 147, 1, 5, 272755) The denial is set forth in the language of a judge as if the Director had both the complainant and the accused present before him and had come to the definite conclusion.
('42', 147, 1, 6, 272926) I have before me the statement submitted to Sjt.
('42', 147, 1, 7, 272975) Vallabhbhai Patel, as President of the Railway Union, by the Pathan watchman at Bardoli station who caught the man red handed, along with the knife and the stolen salt.
('42', 147, 1, 8, 273144) He states therein that the police authorities were trying to water down evidence and coercing him to withdraw the complaint.
('42', 147, 1, 9, 273269) But the Director comes to the following pontifical conclusion : “The police have found the case to be one fit to be classed as untrue.” No wonder because the railway Pathan will not lend himself a tool in the hands of the police.
('42', 147, 1, 10, 273499) Of equal value is the statement that “the Deputy Superintendent of Police can definitely state that the photographs taken by non co operators were not taken during the commission of the so called theft”.
('42', 147, 1, 11, 273703) But the admission that the accused Pathan was on the railway platform, that he did pick up handful—as a matter of fact two bundlefuls—of salt sufficiently damages the Government.
('42', 147, 1, 12, 273882) Who does not know that when people caught red handed are sought to be protected, the acts witnessed are watered down by a corrupt police?
('42', 147, 1, 13, 274020) In this instance salt became waste and came to be picked up from the ground.

('42', 154, 3, 6, 290343) A NOBLE SOUL GONE
('42', 154, 4, 7, 290361) As I am writing for Young India, I have a wire from Nilkanth Babu advising me of the death at Sakhigopal of Pandit Gopabandhu Das who was one of the noblest among the sons of Orissa, the land of sorrows and tears.
('42', 154, 4, 8, 290575) Gopabandhu Babu had given his all to Orissa.
('42', 154, 4, 9, 290620) I heard of him and his sterling character and steadfastness when Sjt.
('42', 154, 4, 10, 290690) Amritlal Thakkar was sent to Orissa in 1916 to distribute relief to the famine stricken.
('42', 154, 4, 11, 290779) Thakkar used to write to me how Gopabandhu Babu braved inconvenience and disease in struggling to help the helpless.
('42', 154, 4, 12, 290896) He gave up his practice and his membership of the Legislative Council during the Non co operation days and never wavered.
('42', 154, 4, 13, 291018) What was more for him was to stake the existence of his dearest creation, the Satyavadi School.
('42', 154, 4, 14, 291114) He braved the taunts of some of his closest friends and persisted to his eternal honour in what they considered to be his folly.
('42', 154, 4, 15, 291243) His one ambition in life was to see dismembered Utkal united and happy.
('42', 154, 4, 16, 291315) He had lately become a member of Lala Lajpat Rai’s society and was planning to make khadi an efficient vehicle for the economic relief of poverty and flood stricken Orissa.
('42', 154, 4, 17, 291488) The country is the poorer for the death of Pandit Gopabandhu Das.

('42', 162, 2, 3, 303374) I have never had occasion to study the history of the foundations in the West.
('42', 162, 2, 4, 303453) My knowledge of them being too cursory to be of any value.
('42', 162, 2, 5, 303512) In my judgment, the growing need of the times however is restoring to the things of the heart, that is, moral well being, its true place in life.
('42', 162, 2, 6, 303658) Social science, according to my view, should therefore be approached from that moral standpoint.
('42', 162, 2, 7, 303755) No tinkering will answer the purpose.
('42', 162, 2, 8, 303793) Your foundation 1 therefore, if it is to be true to itself, should be utilized for subverting the system under which the extraordinary accumulation of riches has been possible in America.
('42', 162, 2, 9, 303981) It would seem then that if you adopt my suggestion, it becomes for the most part independent of monetary help.
('42', 162, 2, 10, 304092) In view of my answer to the first question, I need hardly answer the second.
('42', 162, 2, 11, 304169) But I would say independently of the first that the organization of the foundation round industrial, racial and inter national relationships would be any day preferable to the tradi tional academic departments.
('42', 162, 2, 12, 304380) If the view underlying my answer to the first question is accepted, you will have to do original research work.
('42', 162, 2, 13, 304492) In view of the foregoing the answer to this is unnecessary.
('42', 162, 2, 14, 304552) It would certainly be wise to have all nations, races and classes represented.
('42', 162, 2, 15, 304631) If you can take care of the youth, the citizens will right themselves.
('42', 162, 2, 16, 304702) I should lock up in fairly commodious but not too comfortable rooms a few professors and students and insist upon their finding a way out of the present intolerable position, if you hold with me that the present is an intolerable position.
('42', 162, 2, 17, 304942) I am unable to answer this.
('42', 162, 2, 18, 304970) The idea is good.
('42', 162, 2, 19, 304988) Perhaps the most effective way of securing the proper type or exchange of visiting members would be to send out a representative to the countries from which you may want such members so that he may come in direct touch with the living institutions of the country or countries in question.

('42', 165, 0, 1, 308585) 166 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 165, 1, 2, 308627) 186. QUESTIONS ON EDUCATION—IV
('42', 165, 2, 3, 308658) Q. 11. In the aims of the Vidyapith it has been said that the progress of India depends upon its villages and not its cities.
('42', 165, 2, 4, 308784) It this is so, why do you wish to convert our city boys?
('42', 165, 2, 5, 308841) You are free to give village education to village boys, but city boys want to live city life.
('42', 165, 2, 6, 308935) Why would you not give them the kind of education that suits them?
('42', 165, 2, 7, 309002) Moreover, the funds for the Vidyapith come form cities.
('42', 165, 2, 8, 309058) We shall say nothing if you carry the ideals of the Vidyapith to the villages and collect money, foodgrains and cotton.
('42', 165, 3, 9, 309178) A. Fortunately, this question is not asked by many city dwellers or many students living in cities.
('42', 165, 3, 10, 309278) How can city people, who are beginning to repent, talk in terms of village children getting village education at their own expense?
('42', 165, 3, 11, 309410) The Vidyapith was born as a result of city people turning their attention to villages.
('42', 165, 3, 12, 309497) The city dwellers themselves took over running the Vidyapith after their eyes opened.
('42', 165, 3, 13, 309583) If it is intended chiefly to serve the villages why should the villagers pay money for running it?
('42', 165, 3, 14, 309682) Today even the educational machinery of the villages has necessarily to be run by the city dwellers.
('42', 165, 3, 15, 309783) the very same allegations that the city dwellers level against the Government can be levelled against us by villagers: ‘You city dwellers have robbed us in the past and still continue to do so.
('42', 165, 3, 16, 309977) We shall be grateful to you if you will stop doing so.
('42', 165, 3, 17, 310032) We are prepared to let bygones be bygones.’ We woke up when a few among us city dwellers understood this.
('42', 165, 3, 18, 310138) We became aware of the grave injustice that we have done to the villages and we decided to make atonement for it.
('42', 165, 3, 19, 310252) The first part of this consists of non co operation with the Government with whose strength and support it was and still is possible to suck the life blood of the villages.
('42', 165, 3, 20, 310425) And the second part consists in our learning to save ourselves from the results of co operation as we gradually understand the essence of non co operation.
('42', 165, 3, 21, 310581) If we offered non co operation and then sat down with folded hands, it could be said what we had not understood the meaning of non co operation.
('42', 165, 3, 22, 310726) It is not enough not to help one who robs us of our belongings; it is also necessary to stop him from doing so and make him give up the loot.
('42', 165, 3, 23, 310868) Then alone can we be said to have non co operated with the robber.
('42', 165, 3, 24, 310935) Non co operation can be violent or non violent, warlike or peaceful, one involving brute force or soul force.
('42', 165, 3, 25, 311045) We have chosen the latter alternative in each case and hence we
('42', 166, 0, 1, 311109) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 167
('42', 166, 1, 2, 311153) have come to the conclusion that some of us city dwellers who have robbed the wealth of the villages and live comfortably because of it should, by way of atonement, serve the villages in some way and offer them something in return.
('42', 166, 1, 3, 311385) The Vidyapith was born as a result of this trend of thought and it is because some of us are awake and are votaries of truth that we are day by day realizing the secret of non co operation and, to that extent, are making the Vidyapith purer.
('42', 166, 1, 4, 311627) It will now be understood why the main part of the funds contributed by the city dweller should be used only for the purpose of educating villagers and that this can be done at present only by the graduates from the cities who have been trained the Vidyapith.
('42', 166, 1, 5, 311887) It is my belief that if would be a betrayal of the people’s trust in us if we used the funds received in the name of the Vidyapith for some other purpose.
('42', 166, 1, 6, 312042) Those who donated money did so under the impression that it would be used to impart a type of education different from that which is currently given and which would be of the type described by me.
('42', 166, 2, 7, 312239) Q. 12. Over the past eight years, the stress of the Vidyapith has been on the abolition of untouchability.
('42', 166, 2, 8, 312346) How many Antyajas have become vinitas or snatakas as a result of this?
('42', 166, 3, 9, 312417) A. I find the question strange and ignorant, for abolition of untouchability never meant, and should never mean, that we make graduates of youths regarded as untouchables.
('42', 166, 3, 10, 312589) It is possible that some of them obtain these degrees in course of time.
('42', 166, 3, 11, 312662) That is as it should be.
('42', 166, 3, 12, 312687) It is also in the fitness of things that the Vidyapith should always be ready to help such individuals.
('42', 166, 3, 13, 312791) But to turn untouchables into graduates does not in any way form part of the programme for the abolition of untouchability.
('42', 166, 3, 14, 312915) The Vidyapith has proved its partiality for and its adherence to the cause of abolition of untouchability by forgoing thousands, if not lacs, of rupees and risking its very existence and by letting go help in the running of its administration from some individuals who were otherwise quite able to give such help.
('42', 166, 4, 15, 313229) Q. 13. We see clearly that the absence of brahmacharya has led to physical and mental enfeeblement of the nation and endeavour and enterprise have slackened.
('42', 166, 4, 16, 313387) Why then have you not permitted the use of the word brahmacharya in the last clause about the aims of the Vidyapith?
('42', 166, 5, 17, 313504) A. The questions is well put.
('42', 166, 5, 18, 313534) It is not proved that the absence of brahmacharya alone is responsible for the physical and mental
('42', 167, 0, 1, 313633) 168 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 167, 1, 2, 313675) weakening of the nation and the slowing of sustained industry and enterprise.
('42', 167, 1, 3, 313753) Why should we belittle such a diving things as brahmacharya by linking it with physical exercise, which, however good, is a transitory thing as compared to the former?
('42', 167, 1, 4, 313921) The Westerners do not practise brahmacharya, yet they are not weak physically or mentally.
('42', 167, 1, 5, 314012) Their untiring industry and spirit of adventure are worthy of imitation.
('42', 167, 1, 6, 314085) It can be said of Gurkha, Pathan, Sikh, Dogra and British soldiers—all of whom have fine physique—that none of them are brahmacharis.
('42', 167, 1, 7, 314219) Thes will outdo the students of our gymnasia in physical exercise.
('42', 167, 1, 8, 314286) We can cite many such examples, to prove that physical strength, a certain kind of mental strength, ceaseless diligence and adventure—all the four of these can be attained without practising brahmacharya.
('42', 167, 1, 9, 314491) The brahmacharya of my conception— one that leads to the attainment of the Brahman — is distinct from the above.
('42', 167, 1, 10, 314604) It is both the means and the end; hence in order to practise it, I am perpared to sacrifice my body.
('42', 167, 1, 11, 314705) One who is enamoured of the physical self will hardly be able to practise unbroken brahmacharya.
('42', 167, 1, 12, 314802) Citing the examples of the brahmacharya of Bhishma and others here would be misleading.
('42', 167, 1, 13, 314890) If we take too literally the events described in the Mahabharata, the Ramayana, etc., we shall be led along the path of untruth and fall headlong into a chasm.
('42', 167, 1, 14, 315050) We shall certainly rise if we understand their inner meaning and put it into practice.
('42', 167, 1, 15, 315137) The body is not thing to be thrown away.
('42', 167, 1, 16, 315178) It is a thing to be peserved.
('42', 167, 1, 17, 315208) If it has become the abode of Ravana, it is also the Ayodhya of Rama; it is also Kurukshetra.
('42', 167, 1, 18, 315302) We must not, therefore, ignore it.
('42', 167, 1, 19, 315337) It is necessary to keep it strong and healthy and so it must have exercise.
('42', 167, 1, 20, 315413) When we say this do we not give exercise its due?
('42', 167, 1, 21, 315463) We preserve truth, and this amount of inducement is sufficient and has been sufficient to make exercise popular among students.
('42', 167, 1, 22, 315591) On the other hand, if we try to establish an inevitable connection between exercise and brahmacharya, not only shall we be guilty of exaggeration but there will be real danger that a student who happens to lag behind in his exercises, instead of correcting the error in his reasoning, will blame brahmacharya and give it up.
('42', 167, 1, 23, 315916) Brahmacharya does not require the support of the desire for physical strength.
('42', 167, 1, 24, 315995) Its necessity can be proved in other and much better ways.
('42', 167, 1, 25, 316054) The West may have physical strength as well as mental strength but where does it have spiritual strength?

('42', 168, 0, 1, 316321) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 169
('42', 168, 1, 2, 316365) power, diligence and courage for the purpose of robbing another nation and destroying it?
('42', 168, 1, 3, 316455) And why imitate them?
('42', 168, 1, 4, 316477) Since all their strength is related to what is opposite of brahmacharya, it has proved to be fatal to the progress of the world in the right direction.
('42', 168, 1, 5, 316629) That is why I have called it monstrous.
('42', 168, 1, 6, 316669) Here I do not wish to run down the West.

('42', 168, 1, 12, 317246) In this way, realizing the frightful results of lack of brahmacharya in the world, it is desirable that we should put the ideal of brahmacharya independently before the people.
('42', 168, 1, 13, 317423) Full development of the soul is impossible without brahmacharya.

('42', 168, 1, 15, 317590) Without it, wholesome as well as continuous activity and noble courage are impossible.
('42', 168, 1, 16, 317677) Without it, the mind may well appear to be strong; however, it will be slave to a thousand passions and temptations.
('42', 168, 1, 17, 317794) And though a body that has been developed without brahmacharya may well become strong, it can never become completely healthy from the medical point of view.
('42', 168, 1, 18, 317952) It is not necessary to put on flesh and develop the muscles.
('42', 168, 1, 19, 318013) It has been my experience over a long period that without brahmacharya it is impossible to have body which, even though lean, can withstand the rigours of heat, cold and rain and remain totally free from diseases.

('42', 169, 2, 9, 319421) 187. AT THE HOUR OF DOOM The policy that the Government has been following in regard to Bardoli would seem to suggest that the hour of its doom is near!
('42', 169, 2, 10, 319574) H.E. the Governor’s letters to Shri Munshi evoke sorrow, pity and laughter.
('42', 169, 2, 11, 319650) When anyone holding a high office writes lengthy, discursive letters in his defence, we wonder why such a person should do such a thing; we feel sorry for him and then, since we cannot possibly take pity on him, we feel like laughing at him.
('42', 169, 2, 12, 319892) H.E. the Governor has surpassed his predecessors in writing letters and advancing arguments and has got entangled in his own arguments.
('42', 169, 2, 13, 320028) In other words, we may say that his subordinates who draft his letters have gradually got him into a knot.

('42', 169, 2, 15, 320338) The Governor is like a person who claims to possess something and though in a position to show it refuses to do so, and since he persists in his claim is treated as an impostor and laughed at.
('42', 169, 2, 16, 320531) Moreover, the head of the Information Department of the Governor who has come out in support of the latter has gone to the most absurd lengths.
('42', 169, 2, 17, 320675) He has tried to refute the details cited by Mahadev Desai in his report on the misbehaviour of the Pathans.

('42', 169, 2, 19, 320870) However, the Government seems to have adopted a novel practice.
('42', 169, 2, 20, 320934) The ruler, instead of conducting an impartial inquiry into the people’s protests summons the culprit to his presence, listens to his one sided story and, having dismissed the complainant, thinks he has done his duty.

('42', 170, 0, 1, 321196) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 171
('42', 170, 1, 2, 321240) demanded by the people to determine whether their grievances are real or otherwise?

('42', 172, 5, 13, 326960) Whenever there is friction and consequent suffering one should not try to make the other party suffer but take all the suffering on oneself.
('42', 172, 6, 14, 327101) BRAHMACHARYA : One should calm down all passions—whether subtle or gross—when they are about to overflow.
('42', 172, 6, 15, 327207) One should always be cheerful.
('42', 172, 6, 16, 327238) One should be engrossed all the twenty four hours in holy matters.
('42', 172, 7, 17, 327305) ASVAD : One should sit down to a meal only when one is extremely hungry and get up when one’s stomach is only half full.
('42', 172, 7, 18, 327426) One should not touch food which has been prepared by many persons with a great deal of trouble and which is likely to add to one’s temptations.
('42', 172, 8, 19, 327570) ASTEYA : One should reduce one’s need to the very minimum.
('42', 172, 8, 20, 327629) Today’s needs ought indeed to be fewer than yesterday’s
('42', 172, 9, 21, 327685) APARIGRAHA : On every Diwali and Holi day one must get rid of any money in excess of Rs. 25 that one may have in one’s possession.

('42', 173, 1, 2, 327858) should have more money than he would require for a year’s expenses.
('42', 173, 1, 3, 327926) Why expenses for a years?
('42', 173, 2, 4, 327952) BODILY LABOUR : One should not spare oneself.
('42', 173, 2, 5, 327998) SWADESHI : One should not be disloyal to one’s neighbours.

('42', 180, 2, 6, 338947) 200. THE DOOM OF PURDAH A reasoned appeal signed by many most influential people of Bihar and almost an equal number of ladies of that province advising the total abolition of the purdah has been just issued in Bihar.
('42', 180, 2, 7, 339165) The fact that over fifty ladies have signed the appeal shows that if the work is carried on with vigour, the purdah will be a thing of the past in Bihar.
('42', 180, 2, 8, 339319) It is worthy of note that the ladies who have signed the appeal are not of the Anglicized type but orthodox Hindus.
('42', 180, 2, 9, 339435) It definitely states :
('42', 180, 3, 10, 339458) We want that the women of our province should be as free to move about and take their legitimate part in the life of the community in all particulars as their sisters in Karnatak, Maharashtra and Madras in an essentially Indian way, avoiding all attempts at Europeanization, for while we hold that a change from enforced seclusion to a complete Anglicization would be like dropping from frying pan into fire, we feel that purdah must go, if we want our women to develop along Indian ideals.
('42', 180, 3, 11, 339949) If we want them to add grace and beauty to out social life and raise its moral tone, if we want them to be excellent managers at home, helpful companions of their husband and useful members of the community, then the purdah, as it now exists, must go.
('42', 180, 3, 12, 340201) In fact no serious step for their welfare can be taken unless the veil is torn down and it is our conviction that if once the energy of half of our population, that has been imprisoned artificially, is released, it will create a force which, if properly guided, will be of immeasurable good to our province.
('42', 180, 3, 13, 340509) I know the evil effects of the purdah in Bihar.
('42', 180, 3, 14, 340557) The movement has been started none too soon.
('42', 180, 3, 15, 340602) The movement has a curious origin.
('42', 180, 3, 16, 340637) Babu Ramanandan Mishra, a khadi worker, was desirous of rescuing his wife from the oppression of the purdah.
('42', 180, 3, 17, 340746) As his people would not let the girl come to the

('42', 181, 1, 23, 343142) The campaign against the purdah if properly handled means mass education of the right type for both men and women of Bihar.
