('42', 185, 4, 5, 347934) 206. QUESTIONS ON EDUCATION–V 2
('42', 185, 5, 6, 347966) Q. 14. Ever since you made your entry into the public life of this country, there has been a tendency to approach you and get your views of a problem whenever a person or persons have been in doubt and have failed to reach a clear cut conclusion.
('42', 185, 5, 7, 348213) People are eager to know from you whether a certain thing on a certain occasion is right or not.
('42', 185, 5, 8, 348310) I am only describing the situation as it really is.
('42', 185, 5, 9, 348362) It shows that all your activity is basically of a religious nature.
('42', 185, 5, 10, 348430) Would it be right that, when you are no more, these decisions be delivered by a body of persons by a majority vote if necessary?
('42', 185, 5, 11, 348559) If not, is it not necessary to create what may prove to be a continuous line of knowledgeable men, versed in the precepts of dharma?
('42', 185, 6, 12, 348692) A. I do not deem it worthy that people should approach me and ask me to pronounce judgment on disputable points.
('42', 185, 6, 13, 348805) It is true that all my activities, whatever their outward form, are fundamentally religious.
('42', 185, 6, 14, 348898) But the fact that I am asked to pronounce judgment on every disputed matter shows that people have either not understood the principles which I follow in shaping my conduct, or they have doubts about them.
('42', 185, 6, 15, 349104) And because I am known as a Mahatma or respected as a good man, and our people are credulous and not given to thinking for themselves, they continue to put all forms of questions to me.
('42', 185, 6, 16, 349290) This may gratify my sense of pride or even help me up to a point in doing my work, but it does not appear to me that it helps in any appreciable way either the people or the questioners.
('42', 185, 6, 17, 349477) Indeed, I
('42', 185, 7, 18, 349487) 1 This was an enclosure to “Letter to Mulkaraj”, 1 7 1928. 2 For the earlier questions and answers in this series, vide “Questions on Education I”, 3 6 1928, “Questions on Education II”, 10 6 1928, “Questions on Education III”, 17 6 1928 and “Questions on Education IV”, 24 6 1928.
('42', 186, 0, 1, 349769) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 187
('42', 186, 1, 2, 349813) have often felt how nice it would be if I stopped making any pronouncements and did whatever suggested itself to me silently.
('42', 186, 1, 3, 349939) But in that case I must first stop this weekly that I am now conducting, as also severely cut down much of my present correspondence.
('42', 186, 1, 4, 350073) That, however, would need a courage which I do not feel within myself.
('42', 186, 1, 5, 350144) But, there is the great friend of man, the Lord of Death, who can extend his invitation to me at any time and put a stop to all this chatter on my part whether I agree or not.
('42', 186, 1, 6, 350320) I do not see any wrong in bodies or associations of men following my principles and giving their opinions on disputed questions by a majority vote when I am no more, or even now whilst I am alive.
('42', 186, 1, 7, 350517) But as in the case of individuals so also in that of groups they must be inspired by the ideal of dharma.
('42', 186, 2, 8, 350623) Q. 15. The education in the Vidyapith is divided into three distinct stages: the primary, the secondary and the higher.
('42', 186, 2, 9, 350743) How far would it be right to name these respectively as education for the village, education for the city, and education for those who would take up social service work?
('42', 186, 3, 10, 350913) A. I do not like the meanings suggested here by the correspondent to the primary, the secondary and the higher education respectively.
('42', 186, 3, 11, 351048) Why should we want village people to be satisfied merely with primary education?
('42', 186, 3, 12, 351129) They too have a right to receive secondary and higher education—those of them at least who want it.
('42', 186, 3, 13, 351229) And the boys in the cities cannot do without primary education.
('42', 186, 3, 14, 351293) The object of all the three should be the prosperity of the villages.
('42', 186, 4, 15, 351363) Q. 16. Why do you always attach so much importance to music?
('42', 186, 5, 16, 351424) A. It is sad that the study of music is generally neglected in our country today.
('42', 186, 5, 17, 351506) Without it, the entire educational system seems to me to be incomplete.
('42', 186, 5, 18, 351578) Music brings sweetness to the individual and to the social life of the people.
('42', 186, 5, 19, 351657) Even as pranayama 1 is necessary for the regulation of breath, so is music for disciplining the voice.
('42', 186, 5, 20, 351760) Dissemination of the knowledge of music among the people will greatly help in controlling and stopping the noise which is a usual feature of public meetings in this country.
('42', 186, 5, 21, 351934) Music pacifies anger and its judicious use is highly helpful in leading a man to the vision of God.
('42', 186, 5, 22, 352034) It does not mean shouting and shrieking a tune anyhow like a rigmarole, nor does it mean the singing of stage songs.
('42', 186, 5, 23, 352151) I have already
('42', 186, 6, 24, 352166) 1 Breath control
('42', 187, 0, 1, 352183) 188 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 187, 1, 2, 352225) referred to its ordinary meaning above, but its deeper meaning is that our whole life should be sweet and musical like a song.
('42', 187, 1, 3, 352352) It goes without saying that life cannot be made like that without the practice of virtues such as truth, honesty, etc.
('42', 187, 1, 4, 352471) To make life musical means to make it one with God, to merge it in Him.
('42', 187, 1, 5, 352543) He who has not rid himself of raga and dwesha, i.e., likes and dislikes, who has not tasted of the joy of service, cannot have any understanding of celestial music.
('42', 187, 1, 6, 352708) A study of music, which does not take account of this deeper aspect of this divine art, has little or no value for me.
('42', 187, 2, 7, 352827) Q. 17. The art of painting means expression of the emotions of the artist through line and colour.
('42', 187, 2, 8, 352926) If this definition of painting were to be accepted, would you include painting as an essential part of the scheme of national education which should be universally taught to all?
('42', 187, 3, 9, 353105) A. I have never disparaged drawing and painting, though I have certainly deprecated the blots of ink and colour passing under its name.
('42', 187, 3, 10, 353241) I doubt if painting as defined by the artist could be made universal.
('42', 187, 3, 11, 353311) There is this difference between music and painting: While painting can be learnt only by a few who have a natural aptitude for it, music must be and can be learnt by all.
('42', 187, 3, 12, 353483) In painting too, drawing of straight lines and the figures of animate and inanimate objects can be taught to all.
('42', 187, 3, 13, 353597) It is certainly useful and necessary and I want it to be taught to every child before it is taught the alphabet.
('42', 187, 4, 14, 353710) Q. 18. Some people are of the view that such subjects as grammar, compound interest, higher geometry, etc., which the learners are apt to forget in after years, should not be included in the courses to be framed for purposes of national education.
('42', 187, 4, 15, 353958) Do you agree to this?
('42', 187, 4, 16, 353980) If you do, why should not Urdu also I be put in the same category?
('42', 187, 4, 17, 354047) When Hindus and Muslims feel the urge to come into close contact with each other and to understand each other’s culture, then only will the knowledge of Sanskrit and Urdu prove useful and lasting.
('42', 187, 4, 18, 354244) Knowledge of Urdu will be put to active use and hence increase only when there is respect for and a desire to learn the culture of which Urdu is the vehicle.
('42', 187, 4, 19, 354402) Until then it is bound to remain no more than a religious rite like the worship of Ganesh—a formal affair without any practical value.
('42', 187, 5, 20, 354537) A. I do not understand why grammar, compound interest and higher geometry have all been classed together.
('42', 187, 5, 21, 354643) I have always believed that grammar is absolutely necessary for the mastery of a
('42', 188, 0, 1, 354724) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 189
('42', 188, 1, 2, 354768) language, and that grammar and higher geometry are highly interesting subjects.
('42', 188, 1, 3, 354848) Both provide innocent, intellectual entertainment.
('42', 188, 1, 4, 354899) I will, therefore, accord a place to both these subjects in national education for those who go in for higher education or wish to study the science of language.
('42', 188, 1, 5, 355061) In the same way, he who wants to be good at accounts cannot do so without learning compound interest.
('42', 188, 1, 6, 355163) Therefore, all the three things mentioned by the correspondent in the question will have their due place in the syllabus for national education.
('42', 188, 1, 7, 355308) The point is that there are things which are common to all schemes of education.
('42', 188, 1, 8, 355389) Today, we have to differentiate between Government education and National education because the former is detrimental to national development.
('42', 188, 1, 9, 355532) But there are many things in Government schools which will and must also be in our schools.
('42', 188, 1, 10, 355624) Thus, though there are points of similarity between the two, the atmosphere in Government schools strengthens the bonds of slavery and is used at critical moments to suppress us.
('42', 188, 1, 11, 355803) Therefore, such schools are to be renounced.
('42', 188, 1, 12, 355848) Besides, as we have already seen, a portion, at least, of the education imparted there is wholly unnecessary; it is just a burden and nothing more.
('42', 188, 1, 13, 355996) But I am straying from the subject under discussion.
('42', 188, 1, 14, 356049) I have thought it fit to offer this clarification under the impression that I might not have grasped the point behind this question.
('42', 188, 1, 15, 356182) Urdu stands apart from the above mentioned subjects; the question of its study must be considered separately.
('42', 188, 1, 16, 356292) Hindus and Muslims will ultimately unite but in our national schools we must continue to strive unremittingly to bring them closer together.
('42', 188, 1, 17, 356433) For this, we must acquaint ourselves with each other’s religion.
('42', 188, 1, 18, 356498) If the students forget whatever little of Urdu they learn, evidently they are not serious about its study and must be learning it only because they must.
('42', 188, 1, 19, 356652) But this can also be said about Hindi.
('42', 188, 1, 20, 356691) Only God knows how interest in Hindi or Urdu can be created among the students, but there is no doubt in my mind that its knowledge is necessary for the progress of the nation.
('42', 188, 2, 21, 356868) Q. 19. Students should have full freedom; there should be nothing which will obstruct their free growth; to achieve this objective the teachers should have no prejudices for or against anything; while they teach they should so conduct themselves as though they have no partiality for any particular rule or habit or principle.

('42', 190, 1, 2, 358895) 208. MY NOTES
('42', 190, 2, 3, 358909) DEFINITION JUSTIFIED
('42', 190, 3, 4, 358930) A reader, while sending his criticism of the Satyagraha Ashram regulations 1, suggests the following definition of nonviolence:
('42', 190, 4, 5, 359058) Ahimsa means a desire not to hurt anyone, from the tiniest insect to God.
('42', 190, 4, 6, 359132) And he suggests the following for self help:
('42', 190, 5, 7, 359177) One should not heedlessly get service from another.
('42', 190, 5, 8, 359229) One should not needlessly serve another.
('42', 190, 5, 9, 359270) The definition that he has given for ahimsa is worth considering.
('42', 190, 5, 10, 359336) And what he has suggested in respect of self help, though not pertinent, is proper in these days.
('42', 190, 5, 11, 359434) Very few have the desire to serve others without any reason and there are not many such occasions too.
('42', 190, 5, 12, 359537) But the aim here is to put a stop to the giving of alms out of a religious sentiment and to such false service, and that seems but proper.
('42', 190, 6, 13, 359676) PROFESSOR’S MARRIAGE TO A YOUNG GIRL
('42', 190, 7, 14, 359713) A reader writes: 2
('42', 190, 8, 15, 359732) The writer has sent me the name and address of this professor.
('42', 190, 8, 16, 359795) This is not an easy reform to bring about.
('42', 190, 8, 17, 359838) The reformer has to make a determined attempt to change the environment wherever possible without distinction of educated and uneducated.
('42', 190, 8, 18, 359976) We should not feel disheartened about the uneducated if the educated class fails to respond.
('42', 190, 8, 19, 360069) Wherever possible, it is necessary to arouse public opinion against child marriages.
('42', 190, 8, 20, 360154) From such examples, we see every day that modern education has very little to do with spiritual progress.
('42', 190, 8, 21, 360260) And if we go deeper, we even find that on such matters public opinion is indifferent, and to some extent it even approves of such worthless customs.
('42', 190, 8, 22, 360409) If that were not so, how would any organization tolerate a man who married a girl fit to be his daughter?
('42', 190, 8, 23, 360515) And that a professor?
('42', 190, 8, 24, 360537) Why should students study at all under that type of professor?
('42', 190, 9, 25, 360600) 1 Vide “Satyagraha Ashram”, June 14, 1928. 2 The letter is not translated here.
('42', 190, 9, 26, 360680) It cited the case of a professor widower of 45 who had married a girl of 14, despite his having five children including a married daughter.
('42', 191, 0, 1, 360820) 192 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 191, 1, 2, 360862) are instances of a professor having been boycotted because he had insulted just one student.
('42', 191, 1, 3, 360955) A professor who contracts child marriage certainly dishonours students and his own society.
('42', 191, 1, 4, 361047) But the students, society and all tolerate this outrage.
('42', 191, 1, 5, 361104) It becomes almost impossible to commit a particular sin if society is not prepared to tolerate it.
('42', 191, 1, 6, 361203) Therefore, public opinion should be patiently educated against such cruel practices as child marriage, etc., and where peaceful boycott is possible, that weapon should be used in awakening public opinion.
('42', 191, 1, 7, 361408) And in accomplishing these tasks if the young people are themselves pure and disciplined, they can help a lot.

('42', 191, 6, 17, 362155) That is so because love of family is based on selfishness and the family members are worshippers of selfishness; therefore, as a normal course it may be suggested that one should plunge into the service of the country after providing for the needs of the family in accordance with the poor living conditions in India.
('42', 191, 6, 18, 362473) No one can serve the nation by leaving the family to fend for itself.

('42', 191, 6, 23, 362828) He who wishes to serve the country will continue his work by remaining above reproach in such

('42', 192, 4, 7, 363560) 210. A TRUE WORKER 1
('42', 192, 5, 8, 363581) In the death of Pandit Gopabandhu Das, India and especially Utkal has lost a true and sincere worker.
('42', 192, 5, 9, 363683) He was a gem of Orissa.
('42', 192, 5, 10, 363707) When ten years ago, (Shri Amritlal Thakkar had gone to Utkal to help during the famine, he used to write from time to time about the high mindedness of Babu Gopabandhu Das and his unceasing labours and love for the people.
('42', 192, 5, 11, 363930) During the days of Non co operation, Gopabandhu Babu was a member of the Legislative Assembly and used to practise law.
('42', 192, 5, 12, 364050) Instead of accumulating wealth through his profession he founded a school in Sakhigopal which, although popular, had connections with the Government.
('42', 192, 5, 13, 364200) He fully appreciated the principle of non co operation and severed its connections with the Government.
('42', 192, 5, 14, 364304) He gave up his legal practice and accepted a life of utter poverty; he also resigned from the Legislative Council.
('42', 192, 5, 15, 364419) It was not difficult for him to give up both these; it was, however, a great sacrifice on his part to sever the connections of his most cherished school (which had truth for its motto) with the Government and jeopardize its very existence, disregarding the warning given by his friends.
('42', 192, 5, 16, 364706) Yet, never have I known him to have a thought of regret for what he had done.
('42', 192, 5, 17, 364784) Once when the school was almost without any students, the pressure from his friends almost weakened him.
('42', 192, 5, 18, 364889) He once again applied to the Government to restore the school’s affiliation, but when the Government laid down compromising conditions, he at once repented his weakness in making the petition.
('42', 192, 5, 19, 365082) The Government, by offering such terms, proved its own unworthiness and spared Gopabandhu Babu an undesirable relation ship, for which he was grateful to God.
('42', 192, 5, 20, 365241) The weakness of those who have a simple and pure heart sometimes proves to be their strength.
('42', 192, 5, 21, 365335) And so it was with Gopabandhu Babu’s weakness.
('42', 192, 5, 22, 365382) When he spoke about this to me, on
('42', 192, 6, 23, 365417) 1 Vide also “Notes”, June 21, 1928.
('42', 193, 0, 1, 365453) 194 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 193, 1, 2, 365495) the one hand I could see in his eyes and in his speech?
('42', 193, 1, 3, 365551) his love for his beloved school and, on the other, his extremely candid admission of weakness.
('42', 193, 1, 4, 365646) This combination appeared to lend him splendour.
('42', 193, 1, 5, 365695) And when last year he took me to Sakhigopal during our tour of Utkal, it pained me to see the large buildings of the school, set in a beautiful grove, now in ruins.
('42', 193, 1, 6, 365860) But I saw no sign of despondency in him.
('42', 193, 1, 7, 365901) He had, during the last four years, realized the great value of khadi in eliminating the poverty of Utkal.
('42', 193, 1, 8, 366008) He was doing khadi work and discussed with me how to give it greater impetus.
('42', 193, 1, 9, 366086) Gopabandhu Babu had joined Lalaji’s Servants of the People Society and was its Vice President.
('42', 193, 1, 10, 366181) Let us hope the social workers in Utkal will take up the work of Gopabandhu Babu.
('42', 193, 1, 11, 366263) The noble live beyond their death, while others are as good as dead even while living.
('42', 193, 1, 12, 366350) We do but grieve over the physical disintegration of saintly persons like Gopabandhu Babu because we look at it from a selfish point of view; but such separations should not pain those who can see with a clear vision that God is not without mercy and dispenses justice.
('42', 193, 1, 13, 366620) We cannot follow their purity during their lifetime.
('42', 193, 1, 14, 366673) But we ought to obtain such strength by remembering, in the true sense, his virtues.
('42', 193, 1, 15, 366758) We find this happening in innumerable instances.
('42', 193, 1, 16, 366807) That is why we shed the fear and sorrow of death when free from delusion and thus prove the immortality of the soul.

('42', 205, 7, 10, 386382) 230. THE CURSE OF FOREIGN MEDIUM
('42', 205, 8, 11, 386415) The spirited plea on behalf of the vernaculars as media of instruction of Nawab Masood Jung Bahadur, Director of Public Instruction, Hyderabad State, recently delivered at the Karve University for Women, has evoked a reply in The Times of India from which a friend sends the following extracts for me to answer:
('42', 205, 9, 12, 386727) Whatever is valuable and fruitful in their writings is directly or indirectly the result of Western culture .
('42', 205, 9, 13, 386837) Instead of sixty, we can go back a hundred years and yet say that from Raja Ram Mohan Roy down to Mahatma Gandhi, every one of the Indians who have achieved anything worth mentioning in any direction was or is the fruit directly or indirectly, of Western education.
('42', 205, 9, 14, 387103) In these extracts what is considered is not the value of English as the medium of higher instruction in India but the importance and influence of Western culture to and on the persons mentioned.
('42', 205, 9, 15, 387298) Neither the Nawab nor anyone else has disputed the importance or the
('42', 205, 10, 16, 387367) 1 Vide the following item.
('42', 206, 0, 1, 387394) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 207
('42', 206, 1, 2, 387438) influence of Western culture.
('42', 206, 1, 3, 387468) What is resented is the sacrifice of Indian or Eastern culture on the altar of the Western.
('42', 206, 1, 4, 387560) Even if it could be proved that Western culture was superior to Eastern, it would be injurious to India as a whole for her most promising sons and daughters to be brought up in Western culture and thus become denationalized and torn from the people.
('42', 206, 1, 5, 387810) In my opinion, whatever reaction for the better the persons named in the extracts had upon the people at large was due to the extent they retained their Eastern culture in spite of the adverse influence of the Western.
('42', 206, 1, 6, 388029) I regard as adverse the influence of Western culture in this connection in the sense in which it interfered with the full effect that the best in Eastern culture might have produced on them.
('42', 206, 1, 7, 388220) of myself whilst I have freely acknowledged my debt to Western culture, I can say that whatever service I have been able to render to the nation has been due entirely to the retention by me of Eastern culture to the extent it has been possible.
('42', 206, 1, 8, 388465) I should have been thoroughly useless to the masses as an Anglicized, denationalized being knowing little of, caring less for and perhaps even despising their ways, habits, thoughts and aspirations.
('42', 206, 1, 9, 388664) It is difficult to estimate the loss of energy caused to the nation by her children being obliged to resist the encroachments of a culture which, however good in itself, was unsuited for them whilst they had not imbibed and become rooted in their own.
('42', 206, 1, 10, 388916) Examine the question synthetically.
('42', 206, 1, 11, 388952) Would Chaitanya, Nanak, Kabir, Tulsidas and a host of other reformers have done better if they had been attached from their childhood to the most efficiently managed English schools?
('42', 206, 1, 12, 389135) Have the men named by the writer of the article in question done better than these great reformers?
('42', 206, 1, 13, 389235) Would Dayanand have done better if he had become an M.A. of an Indian university?
('42', 206, 1, 14, 389317) Where is among the easy going, ease loving, English speaking rajas and maharajas brought from their infancy under the influence of Western culture one who could be named in the same breath as Shivaji who braved all perils and shared the simple life of his hardy men?
('42', 206, 1, 15, 389584) Are they better rulers than Pratap the intrepid?
('42', 206, 1, 16, 389633) Are they good specimens of Western culture, these Neros who are fiddling in London and Paris whilst their Romes are burning?
('42', 206, 1, 17, 389758) There is nothing to be proud of in their culture which has made them foreigners in their own land and which has taught them to prefer to waste the substanceof their ryots and their own souls in Europe to
('42', 207, 0, 1, 389962) 208 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 207, 1, 2, 390004) sharing the happiness and miseries of those over whom they are called by a higher Power to rule.
('42', 207, 1, 3, 390101) But the point at issue is not Western culture.
('42', 207, 1, 4, 390148) The point at issue is the medium of instruction.
('42', 207, 1, 5, 390197) But for the fact that the only higher education, the only!
('42', 207, 1, 6, 390256) education worth the name, has been received by us through the English medium, there would be no need to prove such a self evident proposition that the youth of a nation to remain a nation must receive all instruction including the highest in its own vernacular or vernaculars.
('42', 207, 1, 7, 390533) Surely, it is a self demonstrated proposition that the youth of a nation cannot keep or establish a living contact with the masses unless their knowledge is received and assimilated through a medium understood by the people.
('42', 207, 1, 8, 390758) Who can calculate the immeasurable loss sustained by the nation owing to thousands of its young men having been obliged to waste years in mastering a foreign language and its idiom of which in their daily life they have the least use and in learning which they had to neglect their own mother tongue and their own literature?
('42', 207, 1, 9, 391084) There never was a greater superstition than that a particular language can be incapable of expansion or expressing abstruse or scientific ideas.
('42', 207, 1, 10, 391229) A language is an exact reflection of the character and growth of its speakers.
('42', 207, 1, 11, 391308) Among the many evils of foreign rule this blighting imposition of a foreign medium upon the youth of the country will be counted by history as one of the greatest.
('42', 207, 1, 12, 391472) It has sapped the energy of the nation, it has shortened the lives of the pupils, it has estranged them from the masses, it has made education unnecessarily expensive.
('42', 207, 1, 13, 391640) If this process is still persisted in, it bids fair to rob the nation of its soul.
('42', 207, 1, 14, 391723) The sooner therefore educated India shakes itself free from the hypnotic spell of the foreign medium, the better it would be for them and the people.
('42', 207, 2, 15, 391873) Young India, 5 7 1928
('42', 208, 0, 1, 391895) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 209
('42', 208, 1, 2, 391939) 231. OUR TOBACCO BILL
('42', 208, 2, 3, 391961) A correspondent who is interested in a variety of reforms asks what the nation pays for her tobacco bill.
('42', 208, 2, 4, 392067) I find that we pay for unmanufactured tobacco and cigarettes 213 lakhs of rupees per year.
('42', 208, 2, 5, 392158) The cost is increasing every year.
('42', 208, 2, 6, 392193) The import of unmanufactured tobacco which was 1_ million lb.
('42', 208, 2, 7, 392255) in 1923 rose to 5 million in 1927. There was a corresponding increase in the import of cigarettes.
('42', 208, 2, 8, 392354) If the references I have consulted are reliable, we do not export any of our own tobacco.
('42', 208, 2, 9, 392444) Therefore the value of that considerable crop has to be added to the figures quoted above.
('42', 208, 2, 10, 392535) If every smoker stopped the dirty habit, refused to make of his mouth a chimney, to foul his breath, damage his teeth and dull his sense of delicate discrimination and made a present of his savings to some national cause, he would benefit both himself and the nation.
('42', 208, 3, 11, 392803) Young India, 5 7 1928

('42', 208, 5, 13, 392850) One of the many American friends who visit and sometimes stay at the Ashram writes thus 1 to Mrs. Maganlal Gandhi:
('42', 208, 6, 14, 392965) The memory of the two days I spent in 1925 at the Ashram, and particularly, in your hospitable home, stays with me like a benediction.
('42', 208, 6, 15, 393100) Mr. Maganlal Gandhi, whom I have always considered one of the rarest and most beautiful souls I ever met.
('42', 208, 6, 16, 393206) Though so true an Indian, he had a sympathy and understanding broad as life itself.
('42', 208, 6, 17, 393290) He seemed the very embodiment of that spirit of satyagraha which I had come to know through the writings of Mahatma Gandhi, in Young India.
('42', 208, 6, 18, 393430) Strength, purity and sweetness radiated from him like perfume from a flower....
('42', 208, 7, 19, 393510) One felt in his presence .
('42', 208, 7, 20, 393537) that every gift, every ability, every part of his being had been laid upon the altar, consecrated to God for the highest purpose to which man as a human being can aspire.
('42', 208, 7, 21, 393708) Not that he talked religion or stressed piety—even the tone of his voice showed the same, practical, efficient man of affairs that he was about the Ashram; but religion was the spring from which the current of his life flowed, and the sanctity which emanated from his presence was the sanctity that comesfrom surrender of
('42', 208, 8, 22, 394030) 1 Only excerpts are reproduced here.

('42', 209, 1, 2, 394109) self—the constant habit and purpose of living and doing for others.

('42', 209, 3, 4, 394244) considers all that his life means to India from the support which he gave and still continues to give to the work of the great Mahatmaji.
('42', 209, 4, 5, 394382) But I am well aware that words of commendation for the dear departed,

('42', 210, 1, 2, 395945) 234. LETTER TO MATHURADAS TRIKUMJI

('42', 210, 3, 4, 396012) MATHURADAS, I have received your letter.
('42', 210, 3, 5, 396053) Why does Dilip have to be seen by a doctor?

('42', 214, 3, 6, 400899) ANSARI, I have had a full chat with Dr. Zakir Husain.
('42', 214, 3, 7, 400953) The position is certainly very precarious.
('42', 214, 3, 8, 400996) The liabilities are accumulating and the money collected for the Jamia Millia Fund cannot be released till a proper trust deed is made, which is the condition in the original announcement.
('42', 214, 3, 9, 401185) The constitution framed is acceptable neither to Jamnalalji nor to me, nor is it in accordance with the terms we discussed when you were here.
('42', 214, 3, 10, 401328) What is to be done in the circumstances?
('42', 214, 3, 11, 401369) I feel that the new Committee should surrender all the powers to the professors who have pledged themselves to become life workers, or the committee should become an active working body and take charge of the institution so far as the financial liabilities are concerned.
('42', 214, 3, 12, 401641) But from what Dr. Zakir Husain tells me and from what I can see for myself, the Committee will not act swiftly and effectively.
('42', 214, 3, 13, 401769) And if it neither acts nor surrenders full control to the working professors, I can see nothing but a lingering death for the Jamia and that would be a terrible tragedy.
('42', 214, 3, 14, 401939) One would not mind it if it was inevitable.
('42', 214, 3, 15, 401983) What should happen to the Ajmal Jamia Fund collected up to now is difficult to say.
('42', 214, 3, 16, 402067) If a trust deed acceptable to us four collectors cannot be made, the only way possible in order to release the fund is to publish the constitution that has been framed and call upon the donors to signify their wish whether they want their donations to be given to the Committee under the constitution.
('42', 214, 3, 17, 402369) of course, this is a most unsatisfactory thing and hardly a step that can be taken, if we will cherish the memory of Hakim Saheb 1 and value the good of the Jamia.
('42', 214, 3, 18, 402533) Is it then not possible to give the full control to the working professors and then they can frame a proper trust deed and release the fund already collected and make an effort to collect more?
('42', 214, 4, 19, 402727) Yours sincerely, DR.
('42', 214, 4, 20, 402748) M. A. ANSARI 1 DARYAGUNJ, DELHI

('42', 218, 1, 2, 407071) 250. MONKEY NUISANCE
('42', 218, 2, 3, 407092) A reader writes to say: 1
('42', 218, 3, 4, 407118) This problem is worth giving a thought to.
('42', 218, 3, 5, 407161) It is not only farmers who are harassed by monkeys.
('42', 218, 3, 6, 407213) In places like Prayag, Vrindavan, etc., monkeys harass even the citizens a great deal.
('42', 218, 3, 7, 407300) People who are thus troubled would not be displeased if the animals were killed or removed by someone.
('42', 218, 3, 8, 407403) Although I thus admit that monkeys are a nuisance, I cannot immediately suggest the remedy of killing them.
('42', 218, 3, 9, 407511) There can be no comparison between a rabid dog and monkeys.
('42', 218, 3, 10, 407571) The former is bound to die from the disease itself.
('42', 218, 3, 11, 407623) Anyone who kills it saves it from the torture and spares others the danger of contracting the disease while in the case of monkeys, there is no question of doing good to them by killing them.
('42', 218, 3, 12, 407815) Again, it is not as if the nuisance of monkeys cannot be prevented without killing them.
('42', 218, 3, 13, 407904) It is often seen that, wherever there is this monkey nuisance the fault lies with us.
('42', 218, 3, 14, 407990) Monkeys are petted, they are given food and are treated in many ways which encourage them to take liberties with us.
('42', 218, 3, 15, 408107) Monkeys are a very intelligent species.
('42', 218, 3, 16, 408147) They understand us immediately.
('42', 218, 3, 17, 408179) I had seen in Vrindavan that in aIl Indian locality they would fearlessly continue to destroy things, while in the area occupied by Europeans there is no trace of monkeys because they are afraid that they would get a beating if they went there.
('42', 218, 3, 18, 408424) Tile threat of beating is also a form of violence.
('42', 218, 3, 19, 408475) There is no need to concern ourselves here in solving that complex problem.
('42', 218, 3, 20, 408551) The question is only whether or not monkeys can be saved from the final form of violence—that of killing.
('42', 218, 3, 21, 408657) I feel that so long as the situation is under our control, we may perhaps be able to spare them capital punishment.
('42', 218, 3, 22, 408773) Readers must know that nowadays trade in monkeys is being carried on a large scale.
('42', 218, 3, 23, 408857) Thousands of monkeys are exported to Europe for making various kinds of experiments on them and in fact many cruel experiments are made on them before they are killed.
('42', 218, 3, 24, 409025) Therefore, it is but proper to adopt whatever measures we can to prevent an increase in their number.
('42', 218, 3, 25, 409127) Now remains the question of death penalty.
('42', 218, 3, 26, 409170) I realize that, if it is our dharma to protect fields and, if there is no other way of protecting
('42', 218, 4, 27, 409268) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('42', 218, 4, 28, 409305) The correspondent had asked Gandhiji whether monkeys might be killed in the same way as rabid dogs.
('42', 219, 0, 1, 409405) 220 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 219, 1, 2, 409447) these from the nuisance of monkeys, then the necessity to kill them does arise.
('42', 219, 1, 3, 409527) But that is not non violence.
('42', 219, 1, 4, 409557) The slaughter of animals even for the sake of saving fields involves violence.
('42', 219, 1, 5, 409636) That some such forms of violence are part and parcel of human life and are unavoidable is a fact that we encounter at every step.
('42', 219, 1, 6, 409766) It is difficult to say when the killing of monkeys becomes actually inescapable, but it is not difficult to find out ways to spare ourselves this slaughter.
('42', 219, 1, 7, 409923) If in spite of those remedies the nuisance does not diminish, each should work out his own dharma.
('42', 219, 1, 8, 410022) There can be no uniform general rule for the killing of monkeys.
('42', 219, 1, 9, 410087) Violence is never an independent dharma.
('42', 219, 1, 10, 410128) There is only one such dharma and that is non violence.
('42', 219, 1, 11, 410184) Violence is a measure of the degradation of man; non violence is his highest achievement.
('42', 219, 2, 12, 410274) [From Gujarati]
('42', 219, 3, 13, 410290) Navajivan, 8 7 1928
('42', 219, 4, 14, 410310) 251. MY NOTES
('42', 219, 5, 15, 410324) STUDENTS’ SACRIFICE
('42', 219, 6, 16, 410344) Students are contributing to the Bardoli Satyagraha Fund by saving money on their food and clothing and by working; that is a good sign.
('42', 219, 6, 17, 410481) One more example of such sacrifice is that of the students of the Kutchi Visa Oswal Jain Hostel.
('42', 219, 6, 18, 410578) They have informed me that they had stopped drinking milk for a month and thus saved Rs. 220, which amount their association has donated to the Fund.
('42', 219, 6, 19, 410728) For this sacrifice the students deserve thanks and the Bardoli satyagrahis should note that, having accepted such sacrificial help, they have a duty to adhere more firmly to their pledge.
('42', 219, 6, 20, 410916) It is no exaggeration to say that, at present, the honour of India rests in their hands.
('42', 219, 7, 21, 411005) WHAT SHOULD STUDENTS DO?
('42', 219, 8, 22, 411030) Three students write to say: “We wish to serve the country.
('42', 219, 8, 23, 411090) Do please let us know through Navajivan how we can do this while continuing our studies and remaining where we are”.
('42', 219, 8, 24, 411207) These students have sent their names, addresses and age, and add: “Do not publish our names and addresses, etc.
('42', 219, 8, 25, 411319) Don’t even write to us.
('42', 219, 8, 26, 411343) We are not even in a position to receive your letters.” It is difficult to give advice to such students.
('42', 219, 8, 27, 411448) What advice can be given to those who cannot even receive a reply to their own letters?
('42', 219, 8, 28, 411536) Nevertheless, this much can be said that purity of soul is itself a good service to the country.
('42', 219, 8, 29, 411633) Have these
('42', 220, 0, 1, 411644) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 221
('42', 220, 1, 2, 411688) students acquired purity of soul?
('42', 220, 1, 3, 411722) Is their heart pure?
('42', 220, 1, 4, 411743) Have they been able to stay away from the polluted atmosphere prevalent amongst students?
('42', 220, 1, 5, 411833) Do they practise truth, etc.?
('42', 220, 1, 6, 411863) The very fact that they are unwilling to receive a reply implies that something is amiss.
('42', 220, 1, 7, 411953) Students should learn to shed such fears.
('42', 220, 1, 8, 411995) They should learn to put forward their views before elders with boldness and determination.
('42', 220, 1, 9, 412087) Do students wear khadi?
('42', 220, 1, 10, 412111) Do they spin?
('42', 220, 1, 11, 412125) They are taking part in national service even if they do this.
('42', 220, 1, 12, 412188) Do they serve a sick neighbour in their free time?
('42', 220, 1, 13, 412239) Do they spare some time to clean up, by their own efforts, any filth in their neighbourhood?
('42', 220, 1, 14, 412332) Many such questions can be asked, and if students can answer them satisfactorily, even today they will have a place of honour among public servants.
('42', 220, 2, 15, 412481) MARRIAGE OF OLD WITH YOUNG
('42', 220, 3, 16, 412508) Last week I had to tell the story of a professor’s marriage with a young girl.
('42', 220, 3, 17, 412587) 1 This week some Bhatia friends have written to me about the marriage of a wealthy Bhatia.
('42', 220, 3, 18, 412678) This octogenarian has got married to a young girl by giving Rs. 25,000 or 30,000 to her father.
('42', 220, 3, 19, 412774) In this marriage, it is difficult to say who is more to blame—the eighty year old man who has married for the fifth time a young girl or the father who for greed of money has sold off his daughter like a helpless cow being sent to a slaughter house I have heard that some Bhatia gentlemen made efforts to thwart this greed, but the eighty year old bridegroom, proud of his wealth, turned them out.
('42', 220, 3, 20, 413172) Only last week, I thought out the remedy to prevent such cruelty.
('42', 220, 3, 21, 413238) I can think of no other method but creating non violent public opinion and non violent boycott.
('42', 220, 3, 22, 413334) And this would mean not only boycott by the caste, but by the whole society.
('42', 220, 3, 23, 413411) All relations with such people should be severed, except when helping them when they need food, or during illness or in case of death.
('42', 220, 3, 24, 413546) Without this, it would be difficult, if not impossible, to awaken such men out of their lust.
('42', 220, 4, 25, 413640) CHILD WIDOW
('42', 220, 5, 26, 413652) The reader will recollect that I had written a few weeks ago about the intention of Shri Muljibhai Barot to marry a young girl.
('42', 220, 5, 27, 413780) Later I had congratulated Shri Muljibhai on having given up the idea of this marriage, because of the article in the Navajivan and the
('42', 220, 6, 28, 413915) 1 Vide “My Notes”, 1 7 1928, sub title, “Professor’s Marriage to a Young Girl”.
('42', 221, 0, 1, 413995) 222 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 221, 1, 2, 414037) criticism of the Brahmabhatt caste.
('42', 221, 1, 3, 414073) Subsequently I received a letter that the announcement was nothing but a fraud and that Shri Muljibhai had got married secretly without the knowledge of his caste.
('42', 221, 1, 4, 414237) I had decided to write about this last week, but could not do so for want of time.
('42', 221, 1, 5, 414320) Now news has come that Muljibhai has passed away leaving the young girl a widow.
('42', 221, 1, 6, 414401) We would not wish the death of a person whether good or bad.
('42', 221, 1, 7, 414462) We wish that the bad may develop good sense—on the principle of wishing to others what you wish for yourself.
('42', 221, 1, 8, 414572) 1 But what about the young widow?
('42', 221, 1, 9, 414606) It is for society to consider this question.
('42', 221, 1, 10, 414651) Even if a fourteen year old girl declares that she wishes to remain a widow, this has no meaning.
('42', 221, 1, 11, 414749) Such a girl would certainly wish to remarry if cruel public opinion is not against her doing so.
('42', 221, 1, 12, 414846) The leaders of the Brahmabhatt caste should rush to the rescue of this poor girl.
('42', 221, 1, 13, 414928) If the leaders have not understood their duty, the young men of the caste should patiently convince them and rescue the young girl.
('42', 221, 1, 14, 415060) If the leaders are not convinced, but if the relatives are, then too, such problems can be solved.
('42', 221, 1, 15, 415159) But to solve such problems the well wisher himself should possess the requisite qualities.
('42', 221, 1, 16, 415250) He should have purity of mind and heart and also patience.
('42', 221, 1, 17, 415309) These qualities are required for the achievement of swaraj through peaceful means; these very qualities are needed also for the solution of such problems as the marriage of young widows and so on.
('42', 221, 2, 18, 415506) HAWKING KHADI

('42', 221, 4, 27, 416191) Success and failure are one and the same to him.

('42', 222, 1, 2, 416490) METHOD OF SELF RELIANCE

('42', 229, 5, 8, 428081) 265. N0TES
('42', 229, 6, 9, 428092) EDUCATION FOR SERVICE
('42', 229, 7, 10, 428114) A friend sends the following interesting extract from The Service of Motherhood by M.E.D. Smith:
('42', 229, 8, 11, 428211) Our educational methods have been far too slipshod.
('42', 229, 8, 12, 428263) It has, for instance, been too much the practice at our universities to let the young men learn if they choose, but if they find study distasteful, then to allow them to idle their time away almost at their own pleasure.
('42', 229, 8, 13, 428484) It seems strange that it should have been overlooked what a wrong was thereby being done to the nation, for wrong it assuredly is, since every member of a nation is born into it to serve, not to be a mere passenger.
('42', 229, 8, 14, 428700) For the slack methods pursued certain of our educational heads are much to blame.
('42', 229, 8, 15, 428782) Blind to the needs of the hour and dwelling in an atmosphere of aloofness and self complacency, they have failed to appreciate the real aim and the vital importance of education.
('42', 229, 8, 16, 428961) Let us hope that in the future it will be accounted as great a disgrace to omit to take advantage of opportunities for learning as it now is for a soldier to desert his post.
('42', 229, 8, 17, 429136) Be it remembered that this is said of national education as of national military service.
('42', 229, 8, 18, 429226) It will be as wrong to serve in an army of hirelings drilled and paid to crush the spirit of their kith and kin as it would be to belong to an educational institution designed to subserve the purpose of a foreign domination.
('42', 229, 9, 19, 429451) KASHI VIDYAPITH

('42', 230, 2, 3, 429906) ARE WE GETTING POORER?
('42', 230, 3, 4, 429929) Professor Sam Higginbottom sent me some time ago for answer a series of questions 1 on India’s poverty.
('42', 230, 3, 5, 430033) As his inquiry was serious and as I know him to be desirous of helping us to solve this difficult problem, I thought that instead of merely giving my own answers, I would seek the assistance of experts in the matter.
('42', 230, 3, 6, 430250) Letters were therefore addressed to a few such friends asking if they would make time to give their considered opinion.
('42', 230, 3, 7, 430370) Professor C. N. Vakil of the University of Bombay has kindly sent me his opinion in a series of articles 2. The first instalment the reader will find elsewhere in this issue.
('42', 230, 4, 8, 430545) ALL INDIA COW PROTECTION ASSOCIATION 3
('42', 230, 5, 9, 430584) A general meeting of this Association will be held at the Satyagraha Ashram, Sabarmati, at 3.30 p.m.
('42', 230, 5, 10, 430685) on 25th instant to consider the following resolution 4: “In as much as the All India Cow protection Association has not been able to command public attention and sympathy commensurate with the all India character it has claimed, and inasmuch as its activities have been confined to the slow spread of the objects of the Association and especially to helping to conduct a dairy and tannery at the Satyagraha Ashram in terms of the objects of the Association, and inasmuch as the subscriptions and donations are mainly confined to those who are interested in the experiment, and inasmuch as the numerous goshalas and pinjrapoles which were expected to respond to and be affiliated to the Association have failed to do so, the existing members of the Association hereby resolve to disband it and to adopt the less pretentious title of Cow protection and Preservation Society and to entrust the affairs, management and
('42', 230, 6, 11, 431600) 1 Vide “Our Poverty”, 6 9 1928. 2 Entitled “The Poverty Problem in India”.
('42', 230, 6, 12, 431675) These were published in Young India on July 12, 19 and 26, August 2 and 9, 1928. 3 Formed by Gandhiji on April 28, 1925 4 For resolution as amended and adopted at the meeting, vide “Service, not Protection”, 2 8 1928.
('42', 231, 0, 1, 431893) 232 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 231, 1, 2, 431935) control of the funds and stock of the Association to the following Committee of Management of the Society with full powers to disburse the funds, conduct the said experiments, to add to their number and otherwise carry out the objects of the Association and to frame a constitution and rules for the management of the Society and to make such amendment thereof as may from time to time be required.” It is unnecessary for me to write anything more on the reason for bringing forward the resolution.
('42', 231, 1, 3, 432434) Jamnalalji and I have felt for a long time that we were not doing justice to the Association or thepublic by running it under the ambitious general title without showing work or results in keeping with the high title.
('42', 231, 1, 4, 432652) The funds too are principally those that he has received from personal friends and some received by me for the experiments, which I believe are most important if the cow is to be saved from destruction.
('42', 231, 1, 5, 432855) It therefore seems that it would be proper and more honest to make the Association a small society of those who are interested in and approve of the methods advocated in these pages for the preservation of the cow.
('42', 231, 1, 6, 433070) The funds at the present moment are about Rs. 17,000, the stock consists of a few books mostly gifts received by me.
('42', 231, 1, 7, 433187) The current monthly expenditure is about Rs. 55. The liability of the Association is to disburse such expenses as may be incurred by the Ashram for the purpose of conducting the experiments entrusted to it.
('42', 231, 2, 8, 433394) Young India, 12 7 1928
('42', 231, 3, 9, 433417) 266. AWAKENING AMONG STUDENTS
('42', 231, 4, 10, 433447) The message of Bardoli has not yet been fully delivered.
('42', 231, 4, 11, 433504) But incomplete as it still is, it has taught us lessons which we shall not easily forget.
('42', 231, 4, 12, 433594) It has revived our drooping spirits, it has brought us new hope, it has shown the immense possibilities of mass non violence practised not from conviction, but like most virtues with most of us as a policy.
('42', 231, 4, 13, 433801) The descriptions I have heard from eye witnesses of the wonderful demonstration held in Bombay in honour of Sjt.
('42', 231, 4, 14, 433914) Vallabhbhai Patel, the spontaneous offering of Rs. 25,000, the affectionate besieging of his car, the showering of gold and bank notes on him as he was passing through the huge crowds, the ovation that signalized his entry into the theatre are proof of what Bardoli has wrought in the space of a few months by its courage and sufferings.
('42', 232, 0, 1, 434252) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 233
('42', 232, 1, 2, 434296) Marked as the awakening has been throughout India, it has been more marked amongst the students and the most among the Bombay students.
('42', 232, 1, 3, 434432) I tender my congratulations to Sjt.
('42', 232, 1, 4, 434468) Nariman and the brave lads and lasses on whom he has acquired such a wonderful hold.
('42', 232, 1, 5, 434553) And among the students the eye witnesses single out the three Parsi girls, Miss Davar and Misses Bhesania, who by their boundless enthusiasm and courage are said to have electrified the student world in Bombay.
('42', 232, 1, 6, 434764) Mahadev Desai has a letter from a student in a Poona College whose students on the 4th instant spontaneously observed the Students’ Bardoli Day, stopped all work and made collections to which there was a willing response.
('42', 232, 1, 7, 434986) May this manifestation of courage on the part of the students of Government colleges and schools never die out nor fail at the crucial moment.
('42', 232, 1, 8, 435129) The letters being received from students of self denial practised by them for the sake of paying their humble mite to the Bardoli funds are most touching.
('42', 232, 1, 9, 435284) The students of the Gurukul Kangri, Vaishya Vidyalaya, Sasawane, a hostel in Ghatkopar, Supa Gurukul near Navasari and several other institutions which I cannot recall at the time of writing have been either doing labour to earn a few rupees or denying themselves milk and ghee for a month or less.
('42', 232, 1, 10, 435583) It would have been monstrous if the lesson that the rustics of Bardoli, especially the illiterate women whom we have hitherto refused to count amongst the fighters for freedom, have been teaching us by their silent suffering and cool courage, had been wholly lost upon us.
('42', 232, 1, 11, 435856) It can be said without fear of contradiction that it was the students of China who led the fight for freedom in that great country, it is the students in Egypt who are in the forefront in Egypt’s struggle for real independence.
('42', 232, 1, 12, 436084) Students of India are expected to do no less.
('42', 232, 1, 13, 436130) They attend schools and colleges or should attend not for self but for service.
('42', 232, 1, 14, 436210) They should be the salt of the nation.
('42', 232, 1, 15, 436249) The greatest obstacle in the way of students is fear of consequences mostly imaginary.
('42', 232, 1, 16, 436336) The first lesson therefore that students have to learn is to shed fear.
('42', 232, 1, 17, 436408) Freedom can never be won by those who are afraid of rustication, poverty and even death.
('42', 232, 1, 18, 436497) The greatest fear for students of Government institutions in rustication.
('42', 232, 1, 19, 436571) Let them realize that learning without courage is like a waxen statue beautiful to look at but bound to melt at the least touch of a hot substance.
('42', 232, 2, 20, 436719) Young India, 12 7 1928

('42', 241, 0, 1, 448020) 242 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 241, 1, 2, 448062) 281. MY NOTES
('42', 241, 2, 3, 448076) THE SCORPION OF PASSION
('42', 241, 3, 4, 448100) A student from Calcutta writes to say 1:
('42', 241, 4, 5, 448141) It has been my experience as well as that of my associates that if a husband and wife voluntarily observe brahmacharya, they can experience maximum happiness and see it increase every day.
('42', 241, 4, 6, 448330) There is no difficulty in demonstrating the glories of brahmacharya to an uneducated wife or, we may say, that brahmacharya knows no distinction between the educated and the uneducated.
('42', 241, 4, 7, 448516) It is simply a matter of having moral strength.
('42', 241, 4, 8, 448564) I know some uneducated women who observe brahmacharya although they are married.
('42', 241, 4, 9, 448645) A husband who observes brahmacharya is better able to protect the virtue of his wife even in a corrupt social environment.
('42', 241, 4, 10, 448768) Absence of brahmacharya does not prevent a wife from deviating from the path of virtue, but instances can be cited where it has provided a cover to a wife’s depravity.
('42', 241, 4, 11, 448936) The power of brahmacharya is immeasurable.
('42', 241, 4, 12, 448979) It is my experience in many cases that he who observes brahmacharya is himself not free from lust and is hence unable to impress his wife with his endeavours.
('42', 241, 4, 13, 449138) Lust is a clever fellow; hence he does not take longto discover his friends.
('42', 241, 4, 14, 449215) A wife who is not free from lust and is not yet ready to shed it, perceives at once the passion hidden in her husband’s heart and secretly laughs at his feeble and fruitless endeavours while she herself remains fearless.
('42', 241, 4, 15, 449436) None should doubt that the brahmacharya which is constant and full of pure love burns up the lust of the other person and reduces it to ashes.
('42', 241, 4, 16, 449579) Among the many beautiful images which I saw at Belur, there was one where the craftsman had given passion the form of a scorpion.
('42', 241, 4, 17, 449709) This latter had stung a woman.
('42', 241, 4, 18, 449740) Its intensity had made her naked and thereafter lifting its tail and lying at the woman’s feet in the pride of its victory, it smiled at her.
('42', 241, 4, 19, 449882) There is the pleasant coolness of brahmacharya in the eyes, in the touch, in the speech of a husband who has conquered this scorpion.
('42', 241, 4, 20, 450016) Within an instant, he cools off and pacifies the lust around him.
('42', 241, 5, 21, 450082) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('42', 241, 5, 22, 450119) The correspondent had asked Gandhiji how one could observe brahmacharya with regard to one’s wife.
('42', 242, 0, 1, 450218) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 243
('42', 242, 1, 2, 450262) MARRIAGE OF OLD AND YOUNG OR DEBAUCHERY?
('42', 242, 2, 3, 450303) I take the following extract from a sister’s letter 1: There is justification in this sister’s argument.
('42', 242, 2, 4, 450408) But the remedy is the same that I have already pointed out.

('42', 242, 2, 12, 451281) It is a matter of regret that society is as unconcerned about unions of old men and child brides as it is about adultery.

('42', 242, 2, 15, 451668) It is the verdict of law that “those who wish to seek justice must purify themselves and then enter the temple of justice.” Experience fully supports this rule.

('42', 243, 9, 13, 453291) 282. QUESTIONS OF A GRADUATE
('42', 243, 10, 14, 453320) “SILK AND TIGER SKIN”
('42', 243, 11, 15, 453342) A graduate of the Vidyapith writes to say: 1
('42', 243, 12, 16, 453387) I have no doubt that from the point of view of ahimsa silk and tiger skin should be given up.
('42', 243, 12, 17, 453481) Similarly, things like pearls too should also be given up.
('42', 243, 12, 18, 453540) It seems that people in the age in which the custom of wearing silk and tiger skin was prevalent, did believe in the dharma of ahimsa, but still continued to use these things.
('42', 243, 12, 19, 453716) This is because at that time they realized the usefulness and necessity of silk and tiger skin and hence despite their faith in ahimsa, they used both these.
('42', 243, 12, 20, 453874) Despite their belief in the principle of ahimsa our predecessors made sacrificial offerings of animals, and we find some people doing so even now.
('42', 243, 12, 21, 454021) Those who sacrifice animals state on the authority of the Shastras that violence done for the sake of yajna cannot be termed
('42', 243, 13, 22, 454146) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('42', 243, 13, 23, 454183) The correspondent wondered how silk and tiger skin could be considered sacred by people who professed nonviolence.
('42', 244, 0, 1, 454298) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 245
('42', 244, 1, 2, 454342) violence.
('42', 244, 1, 3, 454352) Similarly, those of us who eat a strictly vegetarian diet, destroy vegetables which have life in them, and believe that this does not affect our ahimsa.
('42', 244, 1, 4, 454505) The moral we derive from all this is that human beings cannot altogether abstain from himsa.
('42', 244, 1, 5, 454598) Even those living only on air and water are guilty of himsa to some extent.
('42', 244, 1, 6, 454674) Therefore, we can make a rule that the use of anything which involves himsa should as far as possible be abandoned.
('42', 244, 1, 7, 454790) And while practising such renunciation, we should not criticize but extend charity to those who do not do so.
('42', 244, 1, 8, 454900) Although, as mentioned above, we needs must be simple in our habits of eating and dressing, and although our dharma is to save the lives of lower beings, yet we should realize that the ahimsa practised in such self control is not everything but only a small part of dharma.
('42', 244, 1, 9, 455174) We find every day that a person who meticulously practises this type of ahimsa can also be guilty of great himsa, and may have no sense of ahimsa at all.
('42', 244, 1, 10, 455328) From the fact that, following inherited traditions, we use certain things for eating and dressing we cannot claim that we practise ahimsa towards these objects.
('42', 244, 1, 11, 455489) Let the material results be the outcome of ahimsa which is practised through tradition or necessity; in itself, however, ahimsa is a noble sentiment and can only be attributed to the person whose mind is non violent and is overflowing with compassion and love towards all beings.
('42', 244, 1, 12, 455769) A person who does not take non vegetarian food even today because he has never done so, but loses his temper every moment and robs others regardless of morality or immorality?
('42', 244, 1, 13, 455945) And is unconcerned about the happiness or unhappiness of those whom he robs, such a person can in no case be regarded as non violent but may be said to be guilty of great himsa.
('42', 244, 1, 14, 456123) Diametrically opposed to him is the person who eats meat in accordance with inherited traditions, but is overflowing with love, free from anger and hatred and treats everyone as equal; he is truly non violent and deserves to be revered.
('42', 244, 1, 15, 456360) While considering ahimsa we always think of it in terms of eating and drinking; that is not ahimsa, that is a state of unconsciousness.
('42', 244, 1, 16, 456496) That which gives moksha, that which is the supreme dharma, in whose presence ferocious beasts shed their violence, an enemy sheds his hatred, a hard heart is softened, this ahimsa is a supernatural power and it is only attained by a few after great effort and penance.
('42', 245, 0, 1, 456765) 246 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 245, 1, 2, 456807) CAPITAL AND LABOUR
('42', 245, 2, 3, 456826) The second question of the graduate is as follows: 1
('42', 245, 3, 4, 456879) The distinction between capital and labour is not a recent one.
('42', 245, 3, 5, 456943) It has been in existence since ancient times.
('42', 245, 3, 6, 456989) In this age it has reached an acute stage because there is a great awakening in the labour class.
('42', 245, 3, 7, 457087) Again there has been an increase in the number of capitalists in this age, and capitalism has assumed a fierce form.
('42', 245, 3, 8, 457204) In olden days the king was the principal capitalist, besides a few who came into contact with him.
('42', 245, 3, 9, 457303) But in our times there has been a sudden increase in the number of capitalists.
('42', 245, 3, 10, 457383) How can it be said that the world is progressing in such circumstances?
('42', 245, 3, 11, 457455) But the way to mend the situation is not through hatred of the capitalists, that is by using force against them.
('42', 245, 3, 12, 457568) I believe that capital and labour will always remain in greater or smaller proportions.
('42', 245, 3, 13, 457656) I believe too that we can, by conscious effort, reduce a good deal the differences between the two.
('42', 245, 3, 14, 457756) The words of a Chinese king quoted by the graduate are as good as gold.
('42', 245, 3, 15, 457828) In this world, someone has to carry the burden of whoever sits idle.
('42', 245, 3, 16, 457897) Therefore, it is a sin to sit idle even for a moment; if we understand this, we will be able to resolve many of our problems and, just as it is wrong for anyone to sit idle, so it is for anyone to take or hoard more than one needs.
('42', 245, 3, 17, 458129) If people starve, this is the reason.

('42', 246, 2, 13, 460137) The Gita has suggested this easy road.

('42', 247, 2, 4, 461393) Some persons claim that the Imperial Government, sitting on the Simla heights, is charging the Bombay Government with incompetence for allowing leadership to pass into the hands of Sardar Vallabhbhai, and is now issuing orders from Simla as if the Bombay Government had not itself fully exploited the four weapons of sama, dama, etc.

('42', 260, 1, 2, 484050) 299. FOR SOUTH AFRICA INDIANS
('42', 260, 2, 3, 484080) A cable from the Secretary, South African Indian Congress, Johannesburg, says:
('42', 260, 3, 4, 484159) Condonation scheme accepted.
('42', 260, 3, 5, 484188) Illegal entrants in the Union now in India must either return before 30th September next or send applications to reach before that date the Commissioner, Asiatic Affairs, Pretoria.
('42', 260, 3, 6, 484369) After sending applications they must return to the Union before 30th March, 1929. Give wide newspaper publicity all parts India.
('42', 260, 3, 7, 484498) This ends the agitation that was going on in South Africa in respect of the condonation scheme and was making the Rt.
('42', 260, 3, 8, 484616) Sastri’s position difficult and causing an anxious time in South Africa as well as here.
('42', 260, 3, 9, 484705) Let those Indians, who have domiciled rights in South Africa, are holders of certificates and are desirous of availing themselves of the right of return, make haste to send their applications so as to reach the Commissioner of Asiatic Affairs, Pretoria, on or before the 30th September next, unless they propose to proceed to South Africa themselves so as to reach there before that date.
('42', 260, 3, 10, 485094) Each applicant should give full particulars, giving name, address, occupation, date and number of certificate and disclose all relevant facts.
('42', 260, 3, 11, 485237) The application should be sent by registered post in good time.
('42', 260, 3, 12, 485301) I wish that I could give more definite guidance.
('42', 260, 3, 13, 485350) Not having got the application form 1 or any text of the scheme 2 before me, I am powerless to do so.
('42', 260, 3, 14, 485452) And whilst I hope to publish further informationas fast as I get, et no one delay sending his application pending the receipt of further and fuller information.
('42', 260, 4, 15, 485613) Young India, 19 7 1928
('42', 260, 5, 16, 485636) 300. NON CO OPERATION OR CIVIL RESISTANCE
('42', 260, 6, 17, 485678) Fear has been entertained in Government circles that the movement going on in Bardoli is one of non co operation.
('42', 260, 6, 18, 485792) It is necessary therefore to distinguish between non co operation and civil resistance.
('42', 260, 6, 19, 485880) Both are included in the wider term ‘satyagraha’ which covers any and every effort based on truth and nonviolence.
('42', 260, 6, 20, 485995) The term ‘non co operation’ was designed to include among other things the
('42', 260, 7, 21, 486070) 1 Vide Appendix “South African Condonation”, August 9 and 16, 1928. 2 ibid
('42', 261, 0, 1, 486145) 262 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 261, 1, 2, 486187) items named in the programme of 1920 at the special session of the Congress at Calcutta 1 and re affirmed the same year at Nagpur 2 with the object of attaining swaraj.
('42', 261, 1, 3, 486356) Under it no negotiation with or petition to the Government of the day was possible except for the purpose of attaining swaraj.
('42', 261, 1, 4, 486483) Whatever the Bardoli struggle may be, it clearly is not a struggle for the direct attainment of swaraj.
('42', 261, 1, 5, 486587) That every such awakening, every such effort as that of Bardoli brings swaraj nearer and may bring it nearer even than any direct effort is undoubtedly true.
('42', 261, 1, 6, 486745) But the struggle of Bardoli is to seek redress of a specific grievance.
('42', 261, 1, 7, 486817) It ceases the moment the grievance is redressed.
('42', 261, 1, 8, 486866) The method adopted in the first instance was through conventional prayer and petition.
('42', 261, 1, 9, 486953) And when the conventional method failed utterly, the people of Bardoli invited Sjt.
('42', 261, 1, 10, 487037) Vallabhbhai Patel to lead them in civil resistance.
('42', 261, 1, 11, 487089) The civil resistance does not mean even civil disobedience of the laws and rules promulgated by constituted authority.
('42', 261, 1, 12, 487208) It simply means non payment of a portion of a tax which former the aggrieved ryots contend has been improperly and unjustly imposed on them.
('42', 261, 1, 13, 487349) This is tantamount to the repudiation by a private debtor of a part of the debt claimed by his creditor as due to him.
('42', 261, 1, 14, 487468) If it is the right of a private person to refuse payment of a debt he does not admit, it is equally the right of the ryot to refuse to pay an imposition which he believes to be unjust.
('42', 261, 1, 15, 487653) But it is not the purpose here to prove the correctness of the action of the people of Bardoli.
('42', 261, 1, 16, 487749) My purpose is to distinguish between non co operation with attainment of swaraj as its object and civil resistance as that of Bardoli with the redress of a specific grievance as its object.
('42', 261, 1, 17, 487939) This I hope is now made clear beyond doubt.
('42', 261, 1, 18, 487983) That Sjt.
('42', 261, 1, 19, 487993) Vallabhbhai and the majority of the workers under his command are confirmed non co operators is beside the point.
('42', 261, 1, 20, 488107) The majority of those whom they represent are not.
('42', 261, 1, 21, 488158) National non co operation is suspended.
('42', 261, 1, 22, 488198) The personal creed of a non co operator does not preclude him from representing the cause of those who are helplessly co operators.
('42', 261, 2, 23, 488330) Young India, 19 7 1928
('42', 261, 3, 24, 488353) 1 Vide “The Non COoperation Resolution”, September 5, 1920. 2 Vide Appendix on “Congress Resolution on Non Cooperation”, December 30, 1920.
('42', 262, 0, 1, 488493) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 263
('42', 262, 1, 2, 488537) 301. SPINNING IN SAWANTWADI
('42', 262, 2, 3, 488565) The following report 1 prepared by Sjt.
('42', 262, 2, 4, 488605) S. P. Patwardhan 2 has been lying in my file for some time.
('42', 262, 2, 5, 488665) It will be read with interest by the general reader and with profit by khadi workers.
('42', 262, 3, 6, 488751) Young India, 19 7 1928
('42', 262, 4, 7, 488774) 302. BY PRODUCTS OF KHADI
('42', 262, 5, 8, 488800) On the 14th instant the Gandhi Ashram conducted by Sjt.
('42', 262, 5, 9, 488856) C. Rajagopalachari near Tiruchengodu in Tamil Nadu had a free dispensary opened by Dr. Ray.
('42', 262, 5, 10, 488948) From the report read at the meeting it appears that round khadi as the centre, removal of untouchability and of the drink evil, rural sanitation and medical relief have sprung up.
('42', 262, 5, 11, 489128) The Ashram serves 175 villages among which annually 45,000 rupees are distributed through khadi.
('42', 262, 5, 12, 489225) Removal of untouchability is done through the personal service of the ‘untouchables’ exactly on the same terms as the rest.
('42', 262, 5, 13, 489349) The Ashram now proposes as soon as funds permit to dig five wells and build cottages for them.
('42', 262, 5, 14, 489444) They need Rs. 10,000, five being for five wells.
('42', 262, 5, 15, 489493) The wells are a sore need as the ‘untouchables’ “have to go long distances and suffer many humiliations and hardships to get their daily pot of water”.
('42', 262, 5, 16, 489645) In 15 months the Ashram gave medical relief to 28,095 men and women.
('42', 262, 5, 17, 489714) The need for expansion became so great that they had to build a proper dispensary at a cost of Rs. 5,000. It was to open this that Dr. Ray travelled all the way to the Ashram.

('42', 265, 5, 14, 495184) 306. INTERVIEW TO ASSOCIATED PRESS OF INDIA ON BARDOLI
('42', 265, 6, 15, 495239) AHMEDABAD, July 20, 1928
('42', 265, 7, 16, 495264) Interviewed by a Press representative on the Bardoli question, Mr. Gandhi said that his views were the same as those of Mr. Vallabhbhai Patel.
('42', 265, 7, 17, 495407) It was, he added, a matter of deep regret to him that there was a possibility of the negotiations failing but if they did, the fault would be, so far as he could judge, entirely the Government’s.
('42', 265, 8, 18, 495603) The communique that was published after the Surat Conference 1 baffled him.
('42', 265, 9, 19, 495679) 1 Held on July 18; as representatives of the agriculturists of Bardoli, Vallabhbhai Patel, Abbas Tyabji, Sharada Mehta, Bhaktilakshmi Desai, Mithubehn Petit and Kalyanji Mehta met the Governor of Bombay, who put the following conditions for a settlement: “Firstly either the full assessment shall be paid forthwith or the difference between the old and the new assessment be paid into the treasury on behalf of the peasants.
('42', 265, 9, 20, 496104) Secondly that the movement to withhold land revenue shall be abandoned.
('42', 265, 9, 21, 496176) If these proposals were accepted, Government would be prepared to take steps by the establishment of a special enquiry into the alleged errors of the official calculations of facts, either by a Revenue Officer who had nothing to do with the present case, or by a Revenue Officer with a Judicial Officer associated with him, it being the duty of the latter to decide any disputed questions of facts or figures .
('42', 265, 9, 22, 496587) .” (The Story of Bardoli, p.
('42', 266, 0, 1, 496616) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 267
('42', 266, 1, 2, 496660) missed there the friendly and trustful spirit that was essential for an honourable compromise.
('42', 266, 1, 3, 496755) To a lay mind like his, this insistence upon the deposit of the enhanced part of the assessment seemed inconceivable, and if he could so put it, absurd.
('42', 266, 1, 4, 496908) It passed comprehension how the great Government could possibly demand such a deposit from people who were under their jurisdiction and control..
('42', 266, 1, 5, 497054) On the other hand, it was not difficult to understand why the people were definitely against making any such deposit.
('42', 266, 1, 6, 497172) For them, it was a point of honour.
('42', 266, 1, 7, 497208) In waiving the deposit, the Government stood to lose nothing.
('42', 266, 1, 8, 497270) There were several points in the communique on which it was easy to enlarge, he should seek another channel 1 for placing his views before the public.
('42', 266, 2, 9, 497421) Asked if he realized that the failure of the negotiations might lead to very serious consequences to the peasants of Bardoli, Mr. Gandhi said that nothing more serious could befall the people of Bardoli than that they should break the pledge they had taken deliberately and repeated times without number.
('42', 266, 3, 10, 497726) Asked whether he thought that all the suffering and sacrifice involved in this struggle would ultimately result in any good either to the people of Bardoli or to the country at large, he said that he certainly thought so; the greater the sacrifice, the greater the gain to the country and the people of Bardoli.
('42', 266, 4, 11, 498038) Asked if he was in entire agreement with all the methods adopted by Mr. Vallabhbhai Patel in his campaign, Mr. Gandhi said that he was in perfect agreement with all the methods pursued by Mr. Patel.
('42', 266, 4, 12, 498237) He knew absolutely nothing to warrant the charge, which he could only call a libel, that Mr. Vallabhbhai Patel had in any way directly or indirectly countenanced violence.
('42', 266, 5, 13, 498409) The Bombay Chronicle, 21 7 1928
