('42', 271, 1, 2, 505249) 312. PROHIBITION OF SILK
('42', 271, 2, 3, 505274) Apropos what I have written 1 in Navajivan about silk and tiger’s skin, Kakasaheb sends me the following reasons 2 for prohibiting silk, which are worth considering.
('42', 271, 3, 4, 505440) [From Gujarati]
('42', 271, 4, 5, 505456) Navajivan, 22 7 1928
('42', 271, 5, 6, 505477) 313. EVIL GENIUS OF GOVERNMENT
('42', 271, 6, 7, 505508) When the Governor of Bombay went to Simla, and I saw newspaper reports about this visit, I felt that the change that Shri Vallabhbhai was anxious to bring about in the Government had taken place.
('42', 271, 6, 8, 505704) But, from the results of the deliberations at Surat, 3 it appears that the Government’s heart has not yet softened; how then can one talk about a change?
('42', 271, 6, 9, 505858) That heart has become harder than a stone.
('42', 271, 6, 10, 505901) I see bad motives in every line of the Government’s circulars which are published in all the newspapers.
('42', 271, 6, 11, 506006) Even after five hours of deliberations, the problem defied solution.
('42', 271, 6, 12, 506075) Apart from what we read in the newspapers, there is not a single new point in the Government’s Press Note.
('42', 271, 6, 13, 506182) Not even an effort has been made to understand what the satyagrahis of Bardoli demand.
('42', 271, 6, 14, 506269) Just as a child who, in his innocence, lets go a useful object and
('42', 271, 7, 15, 506336) 1 Vide “Questions of a Graduate”, 15 7 1928, sub title, “Silk and Tiger skin”.
('42', 271, 7, 16, 506415) Gandhiji had expressed the view that from the point of view of ahimsa, both silk and tiger skin had to be given up.
('42', 271, 7, 17, 506531) 2 Not translated here.
('42', 271, 7, 18, 506554) D. B. Kalelkar had pointed out that all people in the world used skins of animals in olden times, that in the Vedic period sages used to sit upon deer skins while performing yajnas, that Kshatriyas and dutiful kings went ahunting and killed deer and tigers for protecting crops and cattle.
('42', 271, 7, 19, 506844) Since skins of dead animals and of animals killed for food could not be thrown away, they were freely used.
('42', 271, 7, 20, 506952) As animals were currently being killed merely for their skins these latter ought to be discarded from the point of view of ahimsa.
('42', 271, 7, 21, 507083) Kalelkar had made the further point that our ancestors were not unaware of silk though he held that originally there was no silk in India.
('42', 271, 7, 22, 507222) As the people did not know that it came from China and was produced from the body of insects, they must have welcomed it.
('42', 271, 7, 23, 507344) Once the people liked a thing, it was difficult to discard it.
('42', 271, 7, 24, 507407) However, the moment this fact became known, they gave it up.
('42', 271, 7, 25, 507468) 3 Vide, footnote 1 to “Interview to Associated Press of India on Bardoli”, 20 7 1928.
('42', 272, 0, 1, 507554) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 273
('42', 272, 1, 2, 507598) asks for a toy, the Government is giving up a useful thing like justice and is clinging to the toy of prestige.
('42', 272, 1, 3, 507710) And the more the Government tries to cling to this prestige, the further it recedes.
('42', 272, 1, 4, 507795) At the end of the struggle, the Government will incur disgrace rather than earn a good name.
('42', 272, 1, 5, 507888) The enquiry to which the Government has consented is different from what the satyagrahis want.
('42', 272, 1, 6, 507983) They do not demand an enquiry in order to examine omissions, commissions or any factual errors.
('42', 272, 1, 7, 508079) Those mistakes are apparent to anyone who sees the pages of the Enquiry Committee’s reports.
('42', 272, 1, 8, 508172) It is their contention that the Enquiry Committee has not carried out the enquiry according to the provisions of law.
('42', 272, 1, 9, 508290) Therefore they want that the entire enquiry should be conducted afresh.
('42', 272, 1, 10, 508362) So long as this is not done, people would not get justice, whatever type of enquiry is undertaken.
('42', 272, 1, 11, 508461) Hence the terms of reference for the enquiry should be made clear at the very outset.
('42', 272, 1, 12, 508547) The people of Bardoli or Valod do not say that there has been injustice only in two or three cases, but that the whole enquiry is full of mistakes.
('42', 272, 1, 13, 508695) The case of the satyagrahis is that the Government does not have adequate basis in their rules and regulations for collecting revenue on a higher assessment.
('42', 272, 1, 14, 508853) Hence, the burden of proof that there is such justification falls on the Government.
('42', 272, 1, 15, 508938) This should have been clearly stated in the terms of reference of the Enquiry Committee, but this was not done.
('42', 272, 1, 16, 509050) Again another condition is absolutely necessary.
('42', 272, 1, 17, 509099) The Committee should also enquire whether Government was justified in adopting a policy of oppression in the collection of revenue.
('42', 272, 1, 18, 509231) Whatever redress can be given to the people should be with regard to the hardships suffered by them as a result of this policy.
('42', 272, 1, 19, 509359) They lost health; their cattle became weak, some of them died.
('42', 272, 1, 20, 509422) Misfortunes such as these are inevitable in a satyagraha struggle.
('42', 272, 1, 21, 509489) People should not ask for compensation in these matters.
('42', 272, 1, 22, 509546) But what of those who are in jail, of those whose land has been confiscated and of those whose property has been sold away at ridiculously low prices?
('42', 272, 1, 23, 509697) Hence, if a settlement is indeed to be arrived at and if the Government wishes to do justice, no sooner is the document for the settlement 1 drawn up than the following should be done: 1. Satyagrahi prisoners should be released.
('42', 272, 1, 24, 509926) 2. Land attached (whether sold or not) should be returned to
('42', 272, 2, 25, 509987) 1 For the terms of Bardoli Settlement, vide Appendix on “Bardoli Settlement”, before July 22, 1928.
('42', 273, 0, 1, 510087) 274 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 273, 1, 2, 510129) the owners.
('42', 273, 1, 3, 510141) 3. The market price of buffaloes, liquor, etc., Which have been auctioned or sold should be paid back.

('42', 274, 4, 11, 513213) 314. MY NOTES
('42', 274, 5, 12, 513227) MY RELATIONS WITH BARDOLI
('42', 274, 6, 13, 513253) There is no need for me to explain to the readers of Navajivan my connection with the Bardoli struggle.
('42', 274, 6, 14, 513357) But it has become necessary to state it clearly because a dangerous rumour has been spread lately.
('42', 274, 6, 15, 513456) Let it be known to the readers that I have associated myself with the Bardoli Satyagraha from its very beginning.
('42', 274, 6, 16, 513570) Its leader is Shri Vallabhbhai and he can take me to Bardoli whenever he needs me.
('42', 274, 6, 17, 513653) Not that he needs my advice; but, while taking any important decisions, he consults me.
('42', 274, 6, 18, 513741) He does all the work whether small or big on his own responsibility.
('42', 274, 6, 19, 513810) I do not go to attend the meetings, etc., But this is an understanding reached between him and me before the struggle began.
('42', 274, 6, 20, 513935) My health does not permit me to carry on all kinds of activities.
('42', 274, 6, 21, 514001) That is why he has taken a vow not to take me anywhere in Ahmedabad or elsewhere in Gujarat without sufficient justification, and he has kept this vow to the letter.
('42', 274, 6, 22, 514167) I have full sympathy with all the steps undertaken in the struggle.
('42', 274, 6, 23, 514235) I have full sympathy with the steps that may be taken by Vallabhbhai in the dangerous situation which may possibly arise now.
('42', 274, 6, 24, 514361) And if he is arrested, I am fully prepared to go to Bardoli.
('42', 274, 6, 25, 514422) Neither he nor I have seen any need for me to go to Bardoli or take any active part so long as he is there.
('42', 274, 6, 26, 514530) Where complete mutual trust exists, there is no room for outward show or politeness.
('42', 274, 7, 27, 514615) THE INFLUENCE OF THE SPINNING WHEEL
('42', 274, 8, 28, 514651) Bhai Fulchand, the soul of the Wadhwan Rashtriya Educational
('42', 275, 0, 1, 514712) 276 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 275, 1, 2, 514754) Society, has been in the Bardoli struggle right from the beginning.
('42', 275, 1, 3, 514822) He is at present working in Vedchhi.
('42', 275, 1, 4, 514859) He writes from there: 1
('42', 275, 2, 5, 514883) Those who have no faith in the spinning wheel may question the claim that Bhai Fulchand has made for the spinning wheel and say that the same result can be achieved by any other kind of industry.
('42', 275, 2, 6, 515079) Although it is true that a good deed produces good results, nevertheless, there is always some difference between one type of industry and another.
('42', 275, 2, 7, 515227) Some occupations build up a man’s physique, others strengthen the mind, yet others bring peace, while some make him restless.
('42', 275, 2, 8, 515353) I have already quoted the opinion of an experienced teacher of Scotland that working on the spinning wheel is such an occupation that, if a restless and unsteady person takes to it, he becomes peaceful and steady.
('42', 275, 2, 9, 515567) A fiery tempered person will be able to give up anger.
('42', 275, 2, 10, 515622) Moreover, the nature of the sentiments underlying an activity determines the qualities which it generates.
('42', 275, 2, 11, 515729) If the activity of the spinning wheel is carried on by a saintly couple and if they make the spinning wheel the means for spreading the spirit of saintliness amongst the people, this quality would then be visible in this activity.
('42', 275, 2, 12, 515960) The advantages of the spinning wheel which are seen in Vedchhi may not be seen everywhere.
('42', 275, 2, 13, 516051) Hence it can be said that the fearlessness and frankness which Bhai Fulchand notices around Vedchhi owe their existence not to the spinning wheel, but to Bhai Chunilal and his wife.
('42', 275, 2, 14, 516233) They have spun their good qualities around the spinning wheel.
('42', 275, 2, 15, 516296) It can certainly be claimed that they were able to spread these qualities through the spinning wheel with much greater ease than they could have done through any other means.
('42', 275, 2, 16, 516471) The same is true of the Bhajan Mandali.
('42', 275, 2, 17, 516511) Through a Bhajan Mandali, fraud can be spread, and such a Bhajan Mandali can also be an everlasting medium for the spread of purity.
('42', 275, 2, 18, 516644) There is no doubt that the Mandali has played an important role in the Bardoli struggle, and the root of these two activities is in religion.
('42', 275, 2, 19, 516786) If the Bardoli struggle had not been carried on through the medium of religious sentiment, the success that it has achieved today would never have been gained.
('42', 275, 3, 20, 516946) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('42', 275, 3, 21, 516983) The correspondent had described the beneficial results following the introduction of the spinning wheel in Vedchhi and propaganda done by the Bhajan Mandali for khadi, prohibition and other good causes.

('42', 276, 1, 3, 517286) They saw religion in satyagraha and in the commander of the satyagrahis; hence, they followed him and we can see signs that they will do so to the end.

('42', 278, 1, 4, 520929) The conditions named by Sjt.
('42', 278, 1, 5, 520958) Vallabhbhai Patel have been the conditions always contemplated by him and in various ways conveyed to the Government.
('42', 278, 1, 6, 521076) He has asked for nothing that has not always been done in honourable settlements.
('42', 278, 1, 7, 521158) If it is acknowledged, as it has been acknowledged even in unexpected quarters, that the people of Bardoli and Valod have undergone terrible sufferings for the sake of what to them is a matter of principle, they have not done so merely to have an inquiry by a subordinate revenue official into individual cases which the inquiry proposed by the Government amounts to in fact; nor can the people be expected to forgo valuable land which they contend has been wrongly forfeited; nor yet can they as honourable men and women leave in the lurch those who have been wrongly made to suffer.
('42', 278, 1, 8, 521743) The Government offer means that although the people have done wrong in refusing payment of the enhancement, they would graciously reopen individual cases if the people will cease to do wrong and if they will deposit the very amount which they say is wrongly imposed on them.
('42', 278, 1, 9, 522018) This is a position which no leader worth the name can possibly subscribe to, when he has no conviction of such wrong on the part of the people and when on the contrary he has the deep conviction that the people are altogether in the right and the Government hopelessly in the wrong.
('42', 278, 1, 10, 522301) But Sjt.
('42', 278, 1, 11, 522310) Vallabhbhai does not make, like the Government, impossible conditions.
('42', 278, 1, 12, 522381) He does not ask the Government to own themselves to be in the wrong.
('42', 278, 1, 13, 522450) His letter reduced to one sentence asks the Government to refer the question of right or wrong to a committee of the Government’s choice with the only reasonable proviso that it will adequately represent the people.
('42', 278, 1, 14, 522666) And in making his counter proposal he asks the Government to recognize the natural and logical consequence of such an impartial committee, viz., to revert to the status quo ante bellum.
('42', 278, 1, 15, 522852) I venture to suggest that he would be guilty of a gross breach of trust if he asked for or took less.
('42', 278, 1, 16, 522954) In his proposal there is no humiliation intended or implied of the Government.
('42', 278, 1, 17, 523033) His reasonableness and anxiety to come to any honourable compromise limits him to the barest minimum.
('42', 278, 1, 18, 523135) For it is surely open to him to raise the whole question of the revenue policy of the Government and ask for damages for the terrible losses suffered by the people during the past four months without any fault of theirs.

('42', 282, 4, 20, 530282) VALLABHBHAI’S REPLY
('42', 282, 5, 21, 530302) Vallabhbhai Patel has issued the following statement 2 to the Press in reply to His Excellency’s Council speech on the 23rd instant: I must confess that I was unprepared for the threatening deliverance of His Excellency the Governor.
('42', 282, 5, 22, 530536) But threats apart, I want to remove the confusion that the speech is consciously or unconsciously intended to create.
('42', 282, 5, 23, 530654) The Governor says in effect
('42', 282, 6, 24, 530682) 1 Subhas Chandra Bose; vide “Telegram to Subhas Chandra Bose”?
('42', 282, 6, 25, 530745) 23 7 1928. 2 Vide “Letter to Vallabhbhai Patel”, 24 7 1928.
('42', 283, 0, 1, 530805) 284 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 283, 1, 2, 530847) that if civil disobedience is the issue, he is prepared to meet it with all the power which Government possesses, but “if the only question to be dealt with is the justice or injustice of the re assessment, then Government is prepared to submit the whole case, after the revenue now due to the Government has been paid and the present agitation ceases, to a full open and independent inquiry as outlined in the statement which has been published”.
('42', 283, 1, 3, 531295) I venture to point out that civil disobedience has never been the issue.
('42', 283, 1, 4, 531368) I know that there is no unanimity of opinion amongst all parties about the wisdom or legitimacy of civil disobedience.
('42', 283, 1, 5, 531487) I have my own opinion which I hold strongly about it.
('42', 283, 1, 6, 531541) But the Bardoli people are not fighting in order to have the right of civil disobedience vindicated.
('42', 283, 1, 7, 531642) They are fighting by way of civil disobedience or whatever name the method adopted may be given in order to induce the Government either to waive the enhancement, or if they are not convinced that the enhancement is improperly made to appoint an impartial, independent inquiry to find out the truth.
('42', 283, 1, 8, 531942) The only question therefore is that justice or injustice of the re assessment.
('42', 283, 1, 9, 532021) And if the Government are prepared to have that question examined by a “full, open and independent inquiry”, they must surely accept the logical consequence of the proposition they themselves lay down, namely, not to insist upon the payment of the enhancement which is in dispute and to restore the people to the condition they occupied before the struggle commenced.
('42', 283, 1, 10, 532389) I warn the public also about the qualifying clause that is attached to “the full, open and independent inquiry”, viz., “as outlined the statement which has been published” is a dangerous clause.
('42', 283, 1, 11, 532584) For what is promised in the Surat communication is not “a full, open and independent inquiry” but a mockery of it.
('42', 283, 1, 12, 532699) The Surat statement contemplates a very limited inquiry to be conducted by a revenue officer assisted by a judicial officer to investigate errors of calculation and fact and totally different thing from “a full, open and independent inquiry”.
('42', 283, 1, 13, 532942) I hope therefore that undeterred by the threats contained in the Governor’s deliverance, public opinion will concentrate only on the one point that I have mentioned.
('42', 284, 0, 1, 533108) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 285
('42', 284, 1, 2, 533152) A TRIUMPH OF JUSTICE
('42', 284, 2, 3, 533173) There is in Wardha a well known and very well decorated shrine dedicated to Shri Lakshminarayana.
('42', 284, 2, 4, 533271) It was built by Seth Jamnalalji grandfather.
('42', 284, 2, 5, 533316) It is a private temple made accessible to the public.
('42', 284, 2, 6, 533370) Jamnalalji has been endeavouring to have this temple available to the so called untouchables also, as he has been trying with great success to have wells in Wardha made accessible to them and generally to procure for them all the facilities available to the other classes.
('42', 284, 2, 7, 533643) He had difficulty with the trustees in bringing them round to his view that this select temple should be thrown open to those whom blind orthodoxy has suppressed.
('42', 284, 2, 8, 533806) Success has at last attended his effort.
('42', 284, 2, 9, 533847) On the 17th instant the trustees unanimously passed the following resolution:
('42', 284, 3, 10, 533925) Whereas the question of admitting the so called untouchables inside the temple of Shri Lakshminarayana has been before the Committee on several occasions and they have been unable to come to a firm decision till now; and whereas the most representative body in India, namely, the Congress has insisted upon the removal of untouchability and whereas the Hindu Mahasabha has considered it necessary and just that all public temples should be made accessible to the so called untouchables, and whereas the well known leaders of public opinion in India have expressed the same opinion, the trustees hereby resolve, regard being had to the foregoing facts and after full consideration of the religious and the social condition of the country, that the above named temple dedicated to Shri Lakshminarayana in Wardha be declared open to the ‘untouchables’ and that the managing trustee, Sheth Jamnalal Bajaj, be authorized to enforce this resolution in such manner as may appear to him to be best.
('42', 284, 3, 11, 534916) Accordingly a printed notice was widely circulated in Wardha that from the 19th instant, that is, two days after the resolution, the temple would be declared open for the ‘untouchables’.
('42', 284, 3, 12, 535103) It is stated that although there was no organized effort made beyond circulating the foregoing notice, nearly l,200 men and women and children including ‘untouchables’ visited the temple without the slightest untoward incident having occurred.
('42', 284, 3, 13, 535347) It is most significant that in an important centre like Wardha a celebrated temple could be flung open for the ‘untouchables’ without orthodoxy raising its voice of protest or some people in the name of sanatana dharma creating a disturbance at the time of ‘untouchables’ trying to cross the sacred and hitherto forbidden threshold of a Hindu shrine.
('42', 284, 3, 14, 535698) It is a striking demonstration
('42', 285, 0, 1, 535729) 286 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 285, 1, 2, 535771) of the tremendous headway that the movement against untouchability has made.
('42', 285, 1, 3, 535848) It shows too what quiet determination and persistence can do to create healthy public opinion in favour of a genuine movement for reform.
('42', 285, 1, 4, 535986) I congratulate Sheth Jamnalalji and his fellow trustees on the bold step that they have taken and hope that this example will be followed all over India.
('42', 285, 2, 5, 536140) PURDAH IN BIHAR
('42', 285, 3, 6, 536156) The organized demonstration against the purdah that was held in many important centres in Bihar on the 8th instant was, a Bihari friend’s letter tells me, successful beyond the expectations of the organizers.
('42', 285, 3, 7, 536365) The Searchlight report of the Patna meeting opens thus:
('42', 285, 4, 8, 536421) A unique spectacle was witnessed at the mixed meeting of ladies and gentlemen of the 8th July held at Patna in the Radhika Sinha Institute on Sunday last.
('42', 285, 4, 9, 536576) In spite of heavy rains that fortunately stopped just at the time of the meeting, the gathering was unexpectedly large.
('42', 285, 4, 10, 536696) In fact half of the spacious hall of the Radhika Sinha Institute was crowded with ladies, three fourths of whom were such as had been observing purdah a day before, nay, an hour before.
('42', 285, 5, 11, 536882) The following is the translation of the resolution adopted at the meeting: We, the men and women of Patna, assembled hereby declare that we have today abolished the pernicious practice of purdah, which has done and is doing incalculable harm to the country, and particularly to women, and we appeal to the other women of the province, who are still wavering, to banish this system as early as they can and thereby advance their education and health.
('42', 285, 5, 12, 537332) A provisional committee was formed at the meeting to carry on an intensive propaganda against purdah and for the spread of women’s education in the province of Bihar.
('42', 285, 5, 13, 537499) A third resolution advised the formation of Mahila Samitis in every town and every village of the province.
('42', 285, 5, 14, 537607) And a fourth resolution was passed to the effect that Mahila Ashrams should be started at different places where ladies might stay for certain periods and receive a training so as to become ‘good wives’, ‘worthy mothers’ and ‘useful servants’ of the country.
('42', 285, 5, 15, 537866) Over 5,000 rupees were promised on the spot for the purpose and I see many ladies among the donors, giving anything between Rs. 250 and 25. The paper publishes reports of similar meetings in several places in Bihar.
('42', 285, 5, 16, 538082) If the campaign is well organized and continued with zeal, the purdah should become a thing of the past.
('42', 285, 5, 17, 538187) It should be noted
('42', 286, 0, 1, 538206) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 287
('42', 286, 1, 2, 538250) that this is no Anglicizing movement.
('42', 286, 1, 3, 538288) It is an indigenous conservative effort made by leaders who are conservative by nature and are yet alive to all the evils that have crept into Hindu society.
('42', 286, 1, 4, 538446) Babu Brijkishore Prasad and Babu Rajendra Prasad who from far off London is keenly watching and supporting the movement are no westernized specimens of Indian humanity.
('42', 286, 1, 5, 538615) They are orthodox Hindus, lovers of Indian culture and tradition.
('42', 286, 1, 6, 538681) They are no blind imitators of the West and yet do not hesitate to assimilate whatever is good in it.
('42', 286, 1, 7, 538783) There need therefore be no fear entertained by the timid and the halting ones that the movement is likely to be in any shape or form disruptive of all that is most precious in Indian culture and especially in feminine grace and modesty so peculiar to India’s womanhood.
('42', 286, 2, 8, 539053) ASHRAM CONSTITUTION AND RULES
('42', 286, 3, 9, 539083) Since the publication of the draft constitution and rules of the Satyagraha Ashram, there has been a constant demand for copies.
('42', 286, 3, 10, 539212) Postage alone amounts to not an insignificant item.
('42', 286, 3, 11, 539264) Those who would possess a copy of the constitution will kindly send one anna stamp to cover the charge of packing and posting.

('42', 290, 7, 14, 544287) 331. GOVERNOR’S THREAT
('42', 290, 8, 15, 544310) It seems that the governing class in India refuses to learn even from experience.
('42', 290, 8, 16, 544392) They act as if they are not aware that the people have got over the fear of threats.
('42', 290, 8, 17, 544477) Not only threats make no impact on hundreds of thousands of people, but also a do or die class has now come into being on which even the carrying out of threats has no effect whatsoever.
('42', 290, 8, 18, 544664) What can punishment inflicted by the State do to those who have given up the fear of death and the infatuation for possessions?
('42', 290, 8, 19, 544792) What effect can a threat have upon those who love their self respect above everything else?
('42', 290, 8, 20, 544884) Hence the Governor’s threat and Earl Winterton’s full endorsement of it cannot have any influence on the people of Bardoli.
('42', 290, 8, 21, 545008) On the contrary, I learn that it has made the latter more resolute.
('42', 290, 8, 22, 545076) But it is not our intention to analyse the Government’s threat.
('42', 290, 8, 23, 545140) We are aware that the Government has the ability to implement it; it will not allow us to forget this even if we wish to.
('42', 290, 8, 24, 545262) Our prestige lies in assuming that the Government will act in accordance with its threats and in being prepared to welcome its wrath.
('42', 290, 8, 25, 545396) The people of Bardoli should inscribe on their doors the proverbial saying, “He who is on
('42', 291, 0, 1, 545486) 292 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 291, 1, 2, 545528) his guard is always happy”, and they should always be on their guard.
('42', 291, 1, 3, 545598) Vallabhbhai had warned the people at the very beginning of the struggle, saying:
('42', 291, 2, 4, 545679) If you wish to offer resistance, you will have to face perils.
('42', 291, 2, 5, 545742) The Government will seize your possessions, confiscate your land, sell yourpossessions at ridiculous prices, evict you from your land; it may even shoot you down.
('42', 291, 2, 6, 545905) Yet do not turn your backs but receive the showers of bullets on your chests as if they were flowers.
('42', 291, 2, 7, 546007) Those who remember these words need no further warning.
('42', 291, 2, 8, 546063) But we are not concerned with the wrath of the Government.
('42', 291, 2, 9, 546122) It is the ruler who has the monopoly of getting angry; we do not want to be angry at the wrath of the Government.
('42', 291, 2, 10, 546236) A satyagrahi has no right to be angry.
('42', 291, 2, 11, 546275) We wish to win over anger by an absence of it in ourselves.
('42', 291, 2, 12, 546335) Even if the Government utters angry words, we do not wish to swerve from the path of truth.
('42', 291, 2, 13, 546427) Whether the Government gets angry or not, our demand should remain the same.
('42', 291, 2, 14, 546504) The Governor has made a speech as fiery as the lava of a volcano.
('42', 291, 2, 15, 546570) Although the unintelligible Government Note issued at Surat is regarded as its final word, we keep hearing a talk of settlement.
('42', 291, 2, 16, 546699) We need not worry whether the Govern ment has a hand in these or not; but even if there is a single door open to settlement, we should be eager to enter through it.
('42', 291, 2, 17, 546864) When people who are determined to sacrifice their lives give up discretion, they are no longer fearless men but indiscreet, ignorant persons.
('42', 291, 2, 18, 547006) He who unnecessarily sacrifices himself is considered either insane or stupid, and his death not being a courageous one is of no advantage either to himself or to anyone else.
('42', 291, 2, 19, 547182) Although the people of Bardoli and Valod have the right to make more demands, they have not acted on that right.
('42', 291, 2, 20, 547295) But now that the Government has crossed all bounds of decency, they cannot make any more demands.
('42', 291, 2, 21, 547393) The satyagrahis need: 1. An independent and impartial committee to hear their complaints and give justice.
('42', 291, 2, 22, 547500) 2. Implementation of the conditions which should form the basis of such a committee, i.e., (a) release of those who have been imprisoned in connection with the struggle; (b) release of lands which have been confiscated in connection with the struggle; and (c) restoration of the direct losses suffered by the people and by other individuals for the sake of the people.
('42', 291, 2, 23, 547869) The satyagrahis have every right to demand compensation for
('42', 292, 0, 1, 547929) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 293
('42', 292, 1, 2, 547973) the indirect loss that people have suffered in respect of their cattle and property, yet they do not do so.
('42', 292, 1, 3, 548081) If they ask for it, it would not be regarded as a sign of compromise.
('42', 292, 1, 4, 548151) A satyagrahi always starts satyagraha after preparing himself to sacrifice his life and property.
('42', 292, 1, 5, 548249) Hence, the satyagrahi will not ask for any compensation for any indirect loss which has resulted from the policy of repression.
('42', 292, 1, 6, 548377) Once the Government accepts the above demands of the people, it would become the people’s dharma to pay the revenue arrears at once.
('42', 292, 1, 7, 548510) I take it that the people have always kept themselves in readiness to pay them.
('42', 292, 1, 8, 548590) At some time or other, these will have to be paid.
('42', 292, 1, 9, 548641) A newspaper report has reproduced a telegram sent by a gentleman from Bombay who has offered to pay the additional levy of land revenue against the injustice of which the satyagraha movement was started.
('42', 292, 1, 10, 548845) If he has decided to present that sum to the Government, no one can stop him.
('42', 292, 1, 11, 548923) If the Government feels satisfied by such a gift, we have no grudge against it.
('42', 292, 1, 12, 549003) Whether that gentleman of Bardoli Taluk, settled in Bombay, has done harm to himself or to the people by offering that money cannot he judged today.
('42', 292, 1, 13, 549152) If the Government is satisfied with the paying up of what should be regarded as an insignificant increase in assessment and, if it is possible to arrive at a settlement, it is the dharma of the satyagrahis to do so.
('42', 292, 2, 14, 549368) [From Gujarati]
('42', 292, 3, 15, 549384) Navajivan, 29 7 1928
('42', 293, 0, 1, 549405) 294 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 293, 1, 2, 549447) 332. MY NOTES
('42', 293, 2, 3, 549461) WE OURSELVES SHOULD DO IT
('42', 293, 3, 4, 549487) A young gentleman writes from Cambay: 1
('42', 293, 4, 5, 549527) I regard feasts given at marriages and similar occasions as pardonable, but would consider feasts given at the ceremony per formed at the time of simant 2 as shameful, and also would consider it sinful to give a feast after anyone’s death, whether it is for the 12th or the 13th day, whether it is for the old or the young.
('42', 293, 4, 6, 549851) All feasts seem to me meaningless and uncivilized.
('42', 293, 4, 7, 549902) I cannot understand why we allow the daily needs of the body to become means of enjoyment.
('42', 293, 4, 8, 549993) My weakness may tolerate such things, but if we do not become slaves to tradition, we would not attend feasts given after death or at the simant ceremony.
('42', 293, 4, 9, 550148) Our own conduct may be something commendable, but we should not feel hurt if parents, wives or grown up children do not follow it.
('42', 293, 4, 10, 550279) We cannot force our views on them.
('42', 293, 4, 11, 550314) We should have the faith that, if our conduct is pure, others will be affected by it.
('42', 293, 4, 12, 550400) I do not know: what the Jain sadhus do, but if they remain indifferent about the evil customs of society, I have no doubt that it is improper.

('42', 293, 6, 15, 550580) 333. BOYCOTT OR NON CO OPERATION

('42', 293, 8, 18, 550759) At such a time, if we use the words boycott and non co operation and if we use individual or collective adjectives before these words, it is bound to be
('42', 293, 9, 19, 550912) 1 The letter is not translated here.

('42', 294, 0, 1, 551569) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 295
('42', 294, 1, 2, 551613) misunderstood.
('42', 294, 1, 3, 551628) Hence, we should merely suggest the limitation of each thing and, while putting it into practice, fully bear in mind those limitations and be satisfied.
('42', 294, 1, 4, 551781) Even in individual boycott or non co operation, there ought not to be the slightest degree of himsa.
('42', 294, 1, 5, 551882) I do not suggest hatred towards those who in old age marry young girls.
('42', 294, 1, 6, 551954) These persons are to be pitied.
('42', 294, 1, 7, 551986) When the passion of enmity possesses a man he loses his senses.
('42', 294, 1, 8, 552050) The most sacred relationships are obliterated.
('42', 294, 1, 9, 552097) This intoxication is even worse than that of drink.
('42', 294, 1, 10, 552149) Therefore, remembering our own weaknesses and faults, we should pity the old men who are full of lust.
('42', 294, 1, 11, 552252) But to pity them and to co operate with them are two distinct things.
('42', 294, 1, 12, 552322) True compassion has no room for blind love or infatuation.
('42', 294, 1, 13, 552381) Hence, anyone who has erred is guilty of an offence against society and it is extremely important that he should be made to realize it.
('42', 294, 1, 14, 552517) And that realization can be brought about only through boycott or non cooperation.
('42', 294, 1, 15, 552600) It may be imparted either by punishing the offender or by depriving him of rights which society has given him on certain terms.
('42', 294, 1, 16, 552728) There is a difference between depriving them of the rights and punishing them.
('42', 294, 1, 17, 552807) It is one thing if I employ a person as a servant, believing that he is honest, and dismiss him upon finding him to be not.
('42', 294, 1, 18, 552931) But it is another if I give him physical punishment, or deprive him of his house, etc., or register a complaint with the authorities and get him punished.
('42', 294, 1, 19, 553086) And if I do not punish him or get him punished, would I at all tolerate such treatment to his family or relatives?
('42', 294, 1, 20, 553201) Actually, when the element of punishment or violence enters into boycott or non cooperation, it ceases to be a powerful weapon, because the one who inflicts it becomes an offender himself while the latter, believing that he has done prayaschitta for his acts becomes more confirmed in his viciousness and ready to repeat the offence, if occasion arises.
('42', 294, 1, 21, 553555) It is because of this that till today the infliction of punishment or violence has not prevented sin or crime.
('42', 294, 1, 22, 553666) I have therefore suggested in all my writings that the reformer should be pure and respectful and that all his acts should be non violent or full of love.
('42', 294, 1, 23, 553821) Thus I; have suggested that boycott should mean that we do not accept any service from the one who is boycotted; that we put up with inconvenience and deny him any special rights.
('42', 294, 1, 24, 554001) However, we should render him service when the need arises.
('42', 294, 1, 25, 554061) The person who is boycotted thus cannot attend a community feast.
('42', 294, 1, 26, 554127) If we have made him a professor, that position should be taken away from him.
('42', 294, 1, 27, 554205) If he is a teacher and we happen to be studying under him, we should discontinue doing so.
('42', 294, 1, 28, 554296) If he happens to be our tenant, he should cease
('42', 295, 0, 1, 554344) 296 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 295, 1, 2, 554386) to be one.
('42', 295, 1, 3, 554397) But if he is ill, he can avail himself of our services.
('42', 295, 1, 4, 554453) If he is suffering from hunger for no fault of his, we should give him food.
('42', 295, 1, 5, 554530) This is Just by way of illustration.
('42', 295, 1, 6, 554567) In short, we should think consciously and should never wish or do to others what we do not wish done to ourselves.
('42', 295, 1, 7, 554682) [From Gujarati]

('42', 301, 6, 8, 563378) 346. SERVICE, NOT PROTECTION
('42', 301, 7, 9, 563407) Although the meeting (for 25th July last) of the All India Cow protection Association was advertised in Young India and Hindi and Gujarati Navajivan and although circular letters were sent to the members individually, even defaulters, there was an attendance of not more than perhaps a dozen, the majority being from the Ashram itself.
('42', 301, 7, 10, 563743) This was an eloquent testimony, if any was needed, in support of the preamble of the draft resolution that was published in these pages and unanimously adopted by the meeting.
('42', 301, 7, 11, 563919) Here is the full text of the resolution as amended and carried at the meeting: Inasmuch as the All India Cow protection Association has not been able to command public attention and sympathy commensurate with the all India character it has claimed, and inasmuch as its activities have been confined to the slow spread of the objects of the Association and especially to helping conduct a dairy and tannery at the Satyagraha Ashram in terms of the objects of the Association, and inasmuch as the subscriptions and donations are mainly confined to friends who are interested in the experiment, and inasmuch as the numerous goshalas and pinjrapoles which were expected to respond to and be affiliated to the Association have nearly entirely failed to do so, the existing members of the Association resolve to disband it, and not retaining the existence of the Association in any shape
('42', 302, 0, 1, 564801) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 303
('42', 302, 1, 2, 564845) or form, to adopt the less pretentious title of Go Seva Sangha (Cow Service Society) and irrevocably to entrust the affairs, management and control of the funds and stock of the Association to the following permanent Standing Committee of management of the Society, viz., M. K. Gandhi (Chairman), Revashankar Jagjivan Jhaveri (Treasurer), Jamnalalji Bajaj, Vaijnathji Kedia, Manilal Vallabhji Kothari, Mahavirprasad Poddar, Shivlal Mulchand Shah, Parameshvariprasad Gupta, Dattatreya Balkrishna Kalelkar, Vinoba Bhave, Chhaganlal Khushalchand Gandhi, Chhaganlal Nathubhai Joshi, Narandas Khushalchand Gandhi, Surendranath, Chimanlal Narsinhdas Shah, Pannalal Balabhai Jhaveri, Yashvant Mahadev Parnerkar, Valji Govindji Desai (Secretary), with full powers to disburse the funds, conduct the said experiments, to add to their number, to fill up vacancies caused by the resignation or the death of a member, to expel a member by a majority vote and otherwise carry out the objects of the expiring Association and to frame a constitution and rules for the management of the Society and to make such amendments thereof as may from time to time be required.
('42', 302, 1, 3, 565998) The name suggested in the published draft for the much smaller body that was to take the place of the All India Association was ‘Cow Protection Society’.
('42', 302, 1, 4, 566152) The eagle eye of Sjt.
('42', 302, 1, 5, 566174) Jamnalalji detected the incongruity in the name.
('42', 302, 1, 6, 566223) He rightly argued that the very small body of persons mostly unknown to fame could not arrogate to themselves the function of protecting the cow, they could only and in all humility endeavour to serve the cow to the best of their ability.
('42', 302, 1, 7, 566462) He therefore suggested the proper title, Go Seva Sangha, literally, Cow Service Society.
('42', 302, 1, 8, 566551) This was acclaimed by those present as the better title.
('42', 302, 1, 9, 566608) Ther eader may know that the majority of the members of the new Society are inmates of the Ashram and then too only those who are either actually conducting the dairy and the tannery experiment or are specially interested in it.
('42', 302, 1, 10, 566837) The rest are those who whole heartedly believe in this class of constructive work as the only real means of saving the cow from inevitable destruction.
('42', 302, 1, 11, 566989) It will be the duty of these workers to try to interest the shepherds and the govals in the science of cattle preservation.
('42', 302, 1, 12, 567113) If this numerous body of men and women could be induced to take a more intelligent and humanitarian view of their occupation than which there can be nothing more honourable,
('42', 303, 0, 1, 567287) 304 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 303, 1, 2, 567329) half the battle is won.
('42', 303, 1, 3, 567353) There is at present a close race for life being run between the cow and man in India.
('42', 303, 1, 4, 567439) And if the cow is not scientifically bred and profitably used, she must eat us or be eaten by us.
('42', 303, 1, 5, 567537) Whilst therefore the ambitious title and the equally ambitious constitution are withdrawn the work survives only to be done in an intenser form.
('42', 303, 1, 6, 567682) I hope therefore that those who have hitherto sent donations in cash or kind to the defunct Association will help the successor.
('42', 303, 1, 7, 567811) The Managing Committee will at no distant date publish the new constitution and rules.
('42', 303, 1, 8, 567898) But donors need not wait for it for sending their donations.
('42', 303, 1, 9, 567959) Lastly, although it was proper for the old Association to be disbanded it may be claimed that its existence was not altogether purposeless.
('42', 303, 1, 10, 568099) It was instrumental in putting before the public valuable literature on the subject in a popular, cheap and handy form.
('42', 303, 1, 11, 568219) Above all it succeeded in removing to a large extent the Hindu prejudice against tanneries.
('42', 303, 1, 12, 568311) Whereas four years ago everyone laughed at the idea of tanneries being any part of a scheme of cow protection, now everybody recognizes at least in theory their tremendous importance in cow preservation.
('42', 303, 1, 13, 568515) Again, four years ago, no one worth mentioning thought of constructive work in connection with cow protection.
('42', 303, 1, 14, 568626) The all pervading idea was hat the cow could be saved if the Mussalman could be induced not to slaughter her for Bakr Id.
('42', 303, 1, 15, 568748) Now almost everyone recognizes that without the constructive work of the kind mapped out by the defunct Association the cow cannot be saved.
('42', 303, 1, 16, 568889) But before it is taken up in practice by the public at large, an ocular demonstration of the feasibility of the constructive method has to be given.
('42', 303, 1, 17, 569038) That is the work inherited by the Go Seva Sangha from the parent body.
('42', 303, 1, 18, 569109) I know from four years’ experience how difficult it is, what patient study and labour it requires.
('42', 303, 1, 19, 569208) It asks therefore for the help and prayer of those who will serve the cause of the cow — the chosen representative of the dumb creation, so idolized by Hindu humanity and yet so ill used by reason of its ignorance and superstition.
('42', 303, 2, 20, 569440) Young India, 2 8 1928
('42', 304, 0, 1, 569462) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 305
('42', 304, 1, 2, 569506) 347. SELF SUPPORT IS SELF RESPECT
('42', 304, 2, 3, 569540) The suggestion has often been made in these columns that in order to make education compulsory or even available to every boy or girl wishing to receive education, our schools and colleges should become almost, if not wholly, self supporting, not through donations or State aid or fees exacted from students, but through remunerative work done by the students themselves.
('42', 304, 2, 4, 569912) This can only be done by making industrial training compulsory.
('42', 304, 2, 5, 569976) Apart from the necessity which is daily being more and more recognized of students having an industrial training side by side with literary training, there is in this country the additional necessity of pursuing industrial training in order to make education directly self supporting.
('42', 304, 2, 6, 570261) This can only be done when our students begin to recognize the dignity of labour and when the convention is established of regarding ignorance of manual occupation a mark of disgrace.
('42', 304, 2, 7, 570445) In America, which is the richest country in the world and where therefore perhaps there is the least need for making education self supporting, it is the most usual thing for students to pay their way wholly or partially.
('42', 304, 2, 8, 570667) Thus says the Hindustanee Student, the official bulletin of the Hindustan Association of America, 500, Riverside Drive, New York City:
('42', 304, 3, 9, 570802) Approximately 50% of the American students use t summer vacation and part of their time during the academic year to earn money “Self supporting students are respected”, writes the bulletin of the California University.
('42', 304, 3, 10, 571021) With reasonable diligence a student can devote from 12 to 25 hours per week (during the academic year) to outside work without seriously interfering with college work of 12 to 16 units (credits) involving 36 to 48 hours a week .
('42', 304, 3, 11, 571250) A student should have some sort of practical knowledge of the following: carpentry, surveying, drafting, bricklaying, plastering, auto driving, photography, machine shop work, dyeing, field work, general farm work, instrumental music and so on.
('42', 304, 3, 12, 571495) Such common work as waiting on table for two hours, etc., is available during the academic years, which relieves a student from expenses for board.
('42', 304, 3, 13, 571643) A partially self supporting student by working during the summer vacation may save up from $150 to 200. Kansas, N.Y. University, Pittsburg, Union University, Antioch College offer ‘co operative’ courses in Industrial Engineering by which a student can earn one year’s tuition fees working in industrial plants for which he also receives credit for his practical experience.
('42', 305, 0, 1, 572017) 306 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 305, 1, 2, 572059) The University of Michigan has under consideration the opening of similar co operative courses in Civil and Electrical Engineering.
('42', 305, 1, 3, 572191) One year more is required to graduate in engineering by pursuing co operative courses.
('42', 305, 1, 4, 572278) If America has to model her schools and colleges so as to enable students to earn their scholastic expenses, how much more necessary it must be for our schools and colleges?
('42', 305, 1, 5, 572452) Is it not far better that we find work for poor students than that we pauperize them by providing free studentships?
('42', 305, 1, 6, 572569) It is impossible to exaggerate the harm we do to India’s youth by filling their minds with the false notion that it is ungentlemanly to labour with one’s hands and feet for one’s livelihood or schooling.
('42', 305, 1, 7, 572773) The harm done is both moral and material, indeed much more moral than material.
('42', 305, 1, 8, 572853) A free scholarship lies and should lie like a load upon a conscientious lad’s mind throughout his whole life.
('42', 305, 1, 9, 572963) No one likes to be reminded in after life that he had to depend upon charity for his education.
('42', 305, 1, 10, 573059) Contrarily where is the person who will not recall with pride those days if he had the good fortune to have had them when he worked in a carpentry shop or the like for the sake of educating himself mind, body and soul?
('42', 305, 2, 11, 573278) Young India, 2 8 1928
('42', 305, 3, 12, 573300) 348. LIMITATIONS OF SATYAGRAHA
('42', 305, 4, 13, 573331) Sardar Sardul Singh is an esteemed worker.
('42', 305, 4, 14, 573374) His open letter advising me to invite sympathetic civil disobedience for Bardoli demands a reply especially because it enables me to clear my own position.
('42', 305, 4, 15, 573530) If Bardoli Satyagraha were a campaign of lawlessness as the Government paint it, nothing would be more tempting or more natural than sympathetic satyagraha and that too without the limits prescribed in the Sardar’s letter.
('42', 305, 4, 16, 573753) But the Sardar rightly says:
('42', 305, 5, 17, 573782) I find in prominent Gujarat workers a tendency to allow Bardoli peasants to be kept isolated.
('42', 305, 5, 18, 573876) This impression has been created in my mind by the reports of Sjt.
('42', 305, 5, 19, 573943) Vallabhbhai’s speeches and your writings.
('42', 305, 5, 20, 573985) Friends think that any more scruples on this point go beyond the limits of practical politics.
('42', 305, 5, 21, 574080) The Sardar’s impression is correct.
('42', 305, 5, 22, 574116) In order strictly to limit the scope of the struggle to the purely local and economic issue and to keep it non political Sjt.
('42', 305, 5, 23, 574242) Vallabhbhai would not let Sjt.
('42', 305, 5, 24, 574273) Rajagopala chari and other leaders to go to Bardoli.
('42', 305, 5, 25, 574326) It was only when the Govern ment gave it a political character and made it an all India issue by their coercive measures that the reins were loosened and Vallabhbhai
('42', 306, 0, 1, 574492) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 307
('42', 306, 1, 2, 574536) could no longer prevent public men from going to Bardoli, though where his advice or permission was sought, he said, “Not yet.” I do not know what Sjt.
('42', 306, 1, 3, 574688) Vallabhbhai Patel would say to the Sardar’s suggestion but I can say, “Not yet.” Time has not come even for limited sympathetic satyagraha.
('42', 306, 1, 4, 574828) Bardoli has still to prove its mettle.
('42', 306, 1, 5, 574867) If it can stand the last heat and if the Government go to the farthest limit, nothing that I or Sjt.
('42', 306, 1, 6, 574968) Vallabhbhai can do will stop the spread of satyagraha or limit the issue to a bona fide re inquiry and its logical consequences.
('42', 306, 1, 7, 575097) The limit will then be prescribed by the capacity of India as a whole for self sacrifice and self suffering.
('42', 306, 1, 8, 575206) If that manifestation is to come it will be natural and incapable of being stayed by any agency no matter how powerful.
('42', 306, 1, 9, 575326) But so far as I understand the spirit of satyagraha and its working, it is the duty of Sjt.
('42', 306, 1, 10, 575418) Vallabhbhai and myself to keep to the original limits in spite of the Government provocations which are strong enough even as they are to warrant the crossing of the original boundary.
('42', 306, 1, 11, 575603) The fact is that satyagraha presupposes the living presence and guidance of God.
('42', 306, 1, 12, 575684) The leader depends not on his own strength but on that of God.
('42', 306, 1, 13, 575747) He acts as the Voice within guides him.
('42', 306, 1, 14, 575787) Very often therefore what are practical politics so called are unrealities to him, though in the end his prove to be the most practical politics.
('42', 306, 1, 15, 575933) All this may sound foolish and visionary on the eve of what bids fair to become the toughest battle that India has hitherto had to face.
('42', 306, 1, 16, 576070) But I would be untrue to the nation and myself if I failed to say what I feel to be the deepest truth.
('42', 306, 1, 17, 576173) If the people of Bardoli are what Vallabhbhai believes them to be, all will be well, in spite of the use of all the weapons that the Government may have at its command.
('42', 306, 1, 18, 576342) Let us wait and see.
('42', 306, 1, 19, 576363) Only let the M.L.C.s and others who are interested in compromises not take a single weak step in the hope of saving the people of Bardoli.
('42', 306, 1, 20, 576502) They are safe in the hands of God.
('42', 306, 2, 21, 576537) Young India, 2 8 1928
('42', 307, 0, 1, 576559) 308 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 307, 1, 2, 576601) 349. N0TES
('42', 307, 2, 3, 576612) FOREIGN PROPAGANDA
('42', 307, 3, 4, 576631) I observe that my cablegram 1 to Deenabandhu Andrews has given rise to the opinion that I have changed my views and that I have now begun to pin my faith to foreign propaganda.
('42', 307, 3, 5, 576808) Let me hasten to clear any such misunderstanding.
('42', 307, 3, 6, 576858) My views about foreign propaganda remain what they were in 1920 and before.
('42', 307, 3, 7, 576934) My cablegram to the Deenabandhu was in reply to his.
('42', 307, 3, 8, 576987) A close friend though he is, I never worried him over the Bardoli affair.
('42', 307, 3, 9, 577061) But when he sent me a cable asking me to acquaint him from time to time with particulars, I could not resist him.
('42', 307, 3, 10, 577175) And if this is called foreign propaganda, I should still prosecute it and advise others to do likewise with their friends in England or elsewhere.
('42', 307, 3, 11, 577322) But when it comes to sending people from here or establishing an agency for such propaganda my soul rebels against it and tells me that we are beating the wind.
('42', 307, 3, 12, 577483) The foreign public is not eager to listen to our talk or writings however cogent and truthful they may be.
('42', 307, 3, 13, 577590) They expect and would eagerly learn about our deeds.
('42', 307, 3, 14, 577643) The field for our propaganda is here and now.
('42', 307, 3, 15, 577689) And when we have made good our position in our own country, the rest will follow.
('42', 307, 4, 16, 577771) INDIAN SHIPPING
('42', 307, 5, 17, 577787) The tragic history of the ruin of the national village industry of cotton manufacture in India is also the history of the ruin of Indian shipping.
('42', 307, 5, 18, 577934) The rise of Lancashire on the ruin of the chief industry of India almost required the destruction of Indian shipping.
('42', 307, 5, 19, 578052) It will be remembered that in 1923 the Indian Mercantile Marine Committee was appointed in order to explore among other things the means of encouraging indigenous shipping “by a system of bounties, subsidies, etc.” Its timid and overcautious recommend ations provide for the reservation of the coastal traffic for Indian shipping.
('42', 307, 5, 20, 578383) Sarabhai Haji now seeks through two bills to secure legislative effect for the recommendations of the Committee.
('42', 307, 5, 21, 578496) One bill aims at the abrogation of unhealthy monopolies and the other aims in five years at the passing of all the tonnage of the coastal traffic into the hands predominantly of Indians.
('42', 307, 5, 22, 578683) Both the bills are necessary and
('42', 307, 6, 23, 578716) 1 Vide “Cable to C.F. Andrews”, on or after 30 7 1928.
('42', 308, 0, 1, 578771) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 309
('42', 308, 1, 2, 578815) both should pass without delay or difficulty.
('42', 308, 1, 3, 578861) I am an out and out protectionist.
('42', 308, 1, 4, 578896) I hold that every country, especially a poor country like India, has every right and is indeed bound to protect its interest, when it is threatened, by all lawful protective measures and to regain by such measures what has been wrongfully taken away from it.
('42', 308, 1, 5, 579155) I have my doubts about anything substantial being done under the existing system through legislative effort.
('42', 308, 1, 6, 579264) But I take up the same position that I have always maintained regarding organized industries such as mills.
('42', 308, 1, 7, 579372) I should welcome and support all action that would protect them against foreign aggression or free them from foreign competition especially when the latter is grossly unfair as it is in the case of foreign shipping and foreign piece goods.
('42', 308, 1, 8, 579612) I therefore wish Sjt.
('42', 308, 1, 9, 579634) Sarabhai Haji every success in his very moderate effort.
('42', 308, 1, 10, 579691) He might quite justly have gone further than he has.
('42', 308, 2, 11, 579744) Young India, 2 8 1928

('42', 311, 6, 10, 583501) 356. DISCUSSION IN BARDOLI 2
('42', 311, 7, 11, 583530) August 2, 1928
('42', 311, 8, 12, 583545) On the eve of starting for Bardoli Gandhiji said: I am going to Bardoli in response to the command of the Sardar.
('42', 311, 8, 13, 583659) Of Course Vallabhbhai often consults me, but does not a commander consult even a private serving under him?
('42', 311, 8, 14, 583767) I am going to Bardoli not to take Vallabhbhai’s place but to serve under him.
('42', 311, 9, 15, 583845) On coming to Bardoli he maintained the same attitude and has emphasized it at several places so as to burn the lesson of discipline deep into the minds of all engaged in public work.
('42', 311, 10, 16, 584028) Peasants from various places came wading through water and mire to pay their respects to Gandhiji.
('42', 311, 10, 17, 584127) “We have surrendered our head to the Sardar, not our honour (literally, nose),” said a group of them.
('42', 311, 11, 18, 584229) Gandhiji said: Then you may be sure that your honour is safe but a great test is still to come.
('42', 311, 11, 19, 584325) When you have stood the final heat, victory is yours.
('42', 311, 11, 20, 584379) But tell me one thing.
('42', 311, 11, 21, 584402) Supposing Vallabhbhai is taken away and others also with him, won’t you he Cowed down?
('42', 311, 12, 22, 584489) “No fear,” said one of them with firmness, “Vallabhbhai has done enough to turn our iron into steel, and we know that the only thing we have to do is to be true to
('42', 311, 13, 23, 584653) 1 Vide “Letter to U. K. Oza”, 14 7 1928. 2 From Mahadev Desai’s “Bardoli Week by Week”
('42', 312, 0, 1, 584740) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 313
('42', 312, 1, 2, 584784) our word, even if the very heavens fall.”
('42', 312, 2, 3, 584826) Gandhiji was delighted.
('42', 312, 2, 4, 584850) Some friend suggested that he should visit some of the villages.
('42', 312, 2, 5, 584915) “Not unless Vallabhbhai wants me to do so” was the reply.
('42', 312, 2, 6, 584973) It was only at Vallabhbhai’s desire that Gandhiji visited Sarbhon and Rayam and met there hundreds of peasants from scores of villages in the vicinity.

('42', 312, 3, 8, 585147) 357. PREFACE TO “SELF RESTRAINT V.SELF INDULGENCE” 1
('42', 312, 4, 9, 585200) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, 2
('42', 312, 5, 10, 585232) August 3, 1928
('42', 312, 6, 11, 585247) It is gratifying to note that the third edition of this volume is required by the public.
('42', 312, 6, 12, 585337) I wish that I had time to add one or more chapters to the volume, but I cannot delay publication so that I might add the chapters.
('42', 312, 6, 13, 585468) I would have done so if I could be sure of finding the time needed for it.
('42', 312, 7, 14, 585543) From what, however, I have discovered from the letters that regularly come to me from inquirers, I would like to issue this definite warning: Those who believe in self restraint must not become hypochondriacs.
('42', 312, 7, 15, 585753) The letters that come to me show that many corres pondents brood over their ill success in the exercise of self restraint.
('42', 312, 7, 16, 585876) Like everything else that is good, self restraint too requires an inexhaustible store of patience.
('42', 312, 7, 17, 585975) There is absolutely no reason to despond, and there must be no brooding.
('42', 312, 7, 18, 586048) There should be no conscious effort to drive away evil thoughts.
('42', 312, 7, 19, 586113) That process is itself a kind of indulgence.
('42', 312, 8, 20, 586158) The best prescription perhaps is non resistance, i.e., ignoring the existence of evil thoughts and a continuous pre occupation with duties that lie in front of one.
('42', 312, 8, 21, 586323) This presupposes the existence of some kind of all absorbing service requiring the concentration of mind, soul and body upon it.
('42', 312, 8, 22, 586452) “Idle hands some mischief still will ever find to do”, is never so applicable as in this case.
('42', 312, 8, 23, 586547) Evil thoughts, much more, evil deeds, are impossible when we are thus pre occupied.
('42', 312, 8, 24, 586631) Strenuous labour in accordance with one’s physical capacity is, therefore,
('42', 312, 9, 25, 586706) 1 A draft (S.N. 14063) of this is available at the Sabarmati Sangrahalaya, Ahmedabad.
('42', 312, 9, 26, 586792) 2 Permanent address
('42', 313, 0, 1, 586812) 314 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 313, 1, 2, 586854) absolutely necessary for those who will obey the law of self restraint which is indispensable for individual as well as universal progress.
('42', 313, 2, 3, 586994) M. K. GANDHI

('42', 322, 9, 13, 600214) DEAR FRIEND, I am sorry, I have been unable to reach your letter before now.
('42', 322, 9, 14, 600291) We have evidence enough of the majority of mankind that their ancestors do not show, to our knowledge, any dissatisfaction because the rites that the Hindus perform are not performed for them.
('42', 322, 9, 15, 600484) The references in the Ramayana and the Mahabharata do not prove that at one time the rites referred to in them were performed by us.
('42', 322, 9, 16, 600617) To me, it seems that real reverence to our ancestors and remembrance of them should consist in copying their virtues.
('42', 322, 9, 17, 600735) Personally I perform no rites in connection with my father, nor do I keep the anniversary, for I endeavour to think of my parents and copy their virtues in my life from day to day.

('42', 324, 0, 1, 602161) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 325
('42', 324, 1, 2, 602205) 379. SPEECH AT SARBHON
('42', 324, 2, 3, 602228) August 4, 1928
('42', 324, 3, 4, 602243) Gandhiji accompanied by some prominent local workers motored to Sarbhon yesterday where, besides the volunteers of Sarbhon and the patels and talatis who had resigned and the representatives from 25 villages comprising Sarbhon division had gathered together in the Swaraj Ashram to meet him.
('42', 324, 3, 5, 602535) In explaining the object of his visit Gandhiji said that he had come there only to congratulate them and to learn more about their achievements.
('42', 324, 3, 6, 602680) Addressing the talatis Gandhiji said: I hold that the talatis have shown greater spirit and valour in this fight than any other section.
('42', 324, 3, 7, 602817) May I express the hope that you will maintain the same fine spirit when peace comes as you have shown in this fight?
('42', 324, 3, 8, 602934) For I have noticed that talatis often tyrannize over the poor villagers and harass them.
('42', 324, 3, 9, 603023) It is up to you to set them at their ease so that they might learn to regard you as friends and helpers, not as objects of terror.
('42', 324, 3, 10, 603154) For the rest, the people have understood the secret of unity and combination, and once that lesson is learnt victory becomes an easy matter.
('42', 324, 4, 11, 603295) He next had a short talk with the representatives of the 25 villages of Sarbhon division numbering about sixty, in the course of which he said: Although your leaders would be the last persons to stand in the way of an honourable settlement they are bound to reject any settlement that is abject or humiliating.
('42', 324, 4, 12, 603606) We are all anxious for peace, but we want peace with honour, a peace that would be worthy of the satyagrahis and the cause which they represent.
('42', 324, 4, 13, 603751) Some representatives of Bajipura the other day told Vallabhbhai that they had pledged their all to him but not their honour.
('42', 324, 4, 14, 603876) 1 My advice to you is that you should surrender your honour to nobody in the world.
('42', 324, 4, 15, 603960) As for Vallabhbhai, he would be the last person to wish you to do so.
('42', 324, 4, 16, 604030) For he holds his own honour dear and the honour of others is as dear to him as his own.
('42', 324, 4, 17, 604118) No one can deprive another of his honour if he is determined not to surrender it.
('42', 324, 4, 18, 604200) A time may shortly come when Dr. Sumant 2, Abbas Tyabji and all the local workers and volunteers may be snatched away from you and clapped into jail.
('42', 324, 4, 19, 604350) Then will come your real test.
('42', 324, 4, 20, 604381) Let each one of you when that hour comes defend the citadel of his honour with his last breath, for that is the meaning of swaraj.
('42', 324, 4, 21, 604512) The substitution of a brown for a white bureaucracy won’t bring us swaraj.
('42', 324, 5, 22, 604587) 1 Vide “Discussion in Bardoli”, 2 8 1928. 2 Sumant Mehta
('42', 325, 0, 1, 604644) 326 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 325, 1, 2, 604686) Swaraj will come to us only when we have developed the capacity to safeguard our honour.
('42', 325, 1, 3, 604775) And if you make truth and non violence your shield then I tell you that whatever be the end of this struggle you will come out of it with your honour unscathed.
('42', 325, 1, 4, 604936) The Government may riddle you with bullets or turn you out of your homes.
('42', 325, 1, 5, 605010) You must be prepared for both.
('42', 325, 1, 6, 605041) Only remember what Vallabhbhai told you, that a soldier receives bullets on his chests not on his back.
('42', 325, 1, 7, 605145) As for being deprived of your hearth and home what fear can you have so long as you have sound limbs with which to do labour.
('42', 325, 1, 8, 605271) It is after all not Government that gives you your daily bread but He who watches over all creation.
('42', 325, 1, 9, 605372) You have already achieved much and if you can stand the last heat unflinchingly the world will ring with fame of your deeds.
('42', 325, 1, 10, 605497) But if you fail in the crucial test your fall will be as great as your present success.
('42', 325, 1, 11, 605585) Even so in 1922 you came within an ace of success but you could not maintain that position and the result was that you sank back into the morass till Vallabhbhai by his penance and sacrifice again raised you to the old heights.
('42', 325, 1, 12, 605813) He has done his part.
('42', 325, 1, 13, 605835) It now remains for you to do yours.
('42', 325, 2, 14, 605871) The Bombay Chronicle, 7 8 1928

('42', 326, 4, 8, 606813) 381. MAGANKAKA
('42', 326, 5, 9, 606828) Under this heading, Prabhudas Gandhi has written a good, detailed and yet very brief biographical sketch 1 of the late Maganlal Gandhi.

('42', 326, 7, 15, 607423) 382. LACK OF COTTON OR EFFORT?
('42', 326, 8, 16, 607454) The Secretary, Children’s Conference of Kasunda, situated in the Manbhoom region of Bihar, writes: 2
('42', 326, 9, 17, 607555) The writer is a Gujarati and takes interest in the life of the children of Bihar and in khadi.
('42', 326, 9, 18, 607650) I congratulate him on doing so.
('42', 326, 9, 19, 607682) But I am grieved by what he says in his letter, that due to want of slivers and cotton, the plying of charkhas has had to be stopped.
('42', 326, 9, 20, 607816) Those who have the means to procure charkhas can obtain cotton from anywhere and there should be no need to get slivers from elsewhere.
('42', 326, 9, 21, 607952) I have often written in Navajivan that those who do not know how to card and make slivers cannot be said to know spinning.
('42', 326, 9, 22, 608075) Only those can be said to know how to make the flour rotis who know how to knead, make
('42', 326, 10, 23, 608162) 1 Not translated here 2 The letter is not translated here.
('42', 326, 10, 24, 608221) The correspondent had stated that the spinning wheel had ceased to operate in certain parts of Bihar for want of slivers.
('42', 327, 0, 1, 608343) 328 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 327, 1, 2, 608385) rolls and roast rotis.
('42', 327, 1, 3, 608408) Similarly, only those who know how to card cotton, make slivers and spin can be called spinners.
('42', 327, 1, 4, 608505) In fact, all the three processes constitute a single activity.
('42', 327, 1, 5, 608568) Perhaps it would not be improper to call slivers the thickest of yarn.
('42', 327, 1, 6, 608639) The process of carding is easy and beautiful.
('42', 327, 1, 7, 608685) It does not take much time to learn it.
('42', 327, 1, 8, 608725) Hence, my reply to the writer of the above letter is that slivers should be available in the village of Kasunda itself.
('42', 327, 1, 9, 608845) It is not due to want of cotton or slivers that plying of charkhas has had to be stopped but rather due to want of effort, and in this fact I also see the absence of a genuine love for the charkha.
('42', 327, 1, 10, 609043) I hope that wherever charkhas are plied as yajna spinners would immediately learn how to card cotton and make slivers.
('42', 327, 1, 11, 609162) [From Gujarati]
('42', 327, 2, 12, 609178) Navajivan, 5 8 1928
('42', 327, 3, 13, 609198) 383. SETTLEMENT OR WAR?
('42', 327, 4, 14, 609222) Reports of a settlement are coming in from all quarters, and, behind it, are also heard the echoes of a battle.
('42', 327, 4, 15, 609334) At one time we hear that the Government is firm and is not prepared to change even one of the points in the talks held at Surat, while at other times we hear that the Government is eager to arrive at a settlement, that it is ready to yield as much as possible and would fight only if it cannot help it.
('42', 327, 4, 16, 609637) God alone knows which of these two versions is correct.
('42', 327, 4, 17, 609693) A satyagrahi remains indifferent towards both, but at the same time should be prepared to face either.
('42', 327, 4, 18, 609796) He should not let go a single opportunity for a settlement but should always be prepared for a battle.
('42', 327, 4, 19, 609899) He should never adopt devious ways.
('42', 327, 4, 20, 609935) He should not have the chakravyuha 1 of Abhimanyu, he should have only one golden, straightforward path, which even a child can see.
('42', 327, 4, 21, 610068) He has nothing to hide, he can have recourse to no underhand dealings; what then has he to think about?
('42', 327, 4, 22, 610172) It is immaterial for him whether on Monday he gets the news of a settlement or of Shri Vallabhbhai’s arrest.
('42', 327, 4, 23, 610281) If satyagrahis have fully learnt their lesson under the leadership of Shri Vallabhbhai, they would not be scared at all at his arrest or that of other leaders and, while allowing things to take their own course,
('42', 327, 5, 24, 610493) 1 An impregnable phalanx of the Kaurava army which Abhimanyu alone was able to destroy
('42', 328, 0, 1, 610580) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 329
('42', 328, 1, 2, 610624) would remain steadfast in their determination.
('42', 328, 1, 3, 610671) Those who are trying to bring about a settlement have a right to do so; it is the dharma of every citizen to take a hand in preventing an unnecessary war.
('42', 328, 1, 4, 610826) But if they get involved in efforts at a settlement out of misplaced pity for satyagrahis, they will harm the nation and prove that they do not understand the satyagrahis.
('42', 328, 1, 5, 610998) The latter do not need pity, they do not hanker after it; what they crave for is justice.
('42', 328, 1, 6, 611088) Hence, it is possible that the efforts of those who seek pity for satyagrahis by regarding them as weak, may be in vain.
('42', 328, 1, 7, 611209) If the demands of the satyagrahis are just, it is the dharma of the mediators to make a determined effort to see that justice is done to them.
('42', 328, 1, 8, 611352) In order to do so, it is essential for the former to understand the demands and the struggle of the satyagrahis.
('42', 328, 1, 9, 611465) A satyagrahi enters the struggle by regarding sorrows as joys.
('42', 328, 1, 10, 611528) Therefore no one has the right to enter into any negotiations on his behalf out of distress for his sufferings.
('42', 328, 1, 11, 611640) It is my confirmed belief that those who intervene in such a manner prolong the struggle rather than shorten it.
('42', 328, 1, 12, 611753) A satyagrahi always desires to educate public opinion.
('42', 328, 1, 13, 611808) Therefore he wishes to make his facts fully known.
('42', 328, 1, 14, 611859) In spite of this, those, who in their ignorance, build tabernacles of truce with imagined facts, would find that these will burn down with a single spark of the match stick of truth, just like tents made of paper.
('42', 328, 1, 15, 612073) Those who wish to bring about a compromise need to have the faith that persons prepared for suffering will never be guilty of exaggeration; they have taken to the path of satyagraha only as a last resort, after all the other avenues had been closed to them.
('42', 328, 1, 16, 612331) The satyagrahis of Bardoli and Valod fall into this category.
('42', 328, 1, 17, 612393) They have resorted to satyagraha after all other methods had failed.
('42', 328, 1, 18, 612462) [From Gujarati]
('42', 328, 2, 19, 612478) Navajivan, 5 8 1928
('42', 329, 0, 1, 612498) 330 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('42', 331, 3, 12, 616263) It was that spirit of discipline which made such a mighty personality as Lord Krishna humbly serve as Arjuna’s charioteer and serve as the meanest of the menials on the occasion of King Yudhishthira’s Rajasuya Sacrifice.
('42', 331, 3, 13, 616484) Icannot therefore do anything more than congratulate you.

('42', 337, 7, 10, 623224) BARDOLI, Tuesday, August 7, 1928
('42', 337, 8, 11, 623257) KUSUM, I got your letter.
('42', 337, 8, 12, 623283) I find it difficult to understand you.
('42', 337, 8, 13, 623322) I know that you would not use the language of humility when writing to me.
('42', 337, 8, 14, 623397) I do not believe that you cannot keep a diary.
('42', 337, 8, 15, 623444) 1 Your saying that your letter became too long and that you do not know how to make a letter brief is also false humility.
('42', 337, 8, 16, 623567) All your letters are good.
('42', 337, 8, 17, 623594) I personally would not be able to shorten them, and I know fairly well the difference between a long and a short letter.
('42', 337, 8, 18, 623715) If, therefore, you really have a high opinion of yourself, get rid of it and stop self depreciation if you are making a show of it as a mere formality.
('42', 337, 8, 19, 623867) The matter about .
('42', 337, 8, 20, 623886) bhai 2 seems to have been settled now.
('42', 337, 8, 21, 623925) It seems that he has admitted his error.
('42', 337, 8, 22, 623966) His admission has not been conveyed personally to me, but it seems he has admitted his error before Surendra and Chhotelal.
('42', 337, 8, 23, 624090) Your part in the affair was indeed very good.
('42', 337, 8, 24, 624136) The programme for the Bal Mandir seems all right.
('42', 337, 8, 25, 624186) If you can adhere to it, the project is bound to prosper.

('42', 341, 4, 12, 628526) 406. ALL’S WELL
('42', 341, 5, 13, 628542) It is a matter for sincere joy that the settlement has at last been reached 1 over the Bardoli Satyagraha.
('42', 341, 5, 14, 628649) All’s well that ends well.
('42', 341, 5, 15, 628676) I tender my congratulations both to the Government of Bombay and the people of Bardoli and Valod and Sjt.
('42', 341, 5, 16, 628782) Vallabhbhai without whose firmness as well as gentleness the settlement would have been impossible.
('42', 341, 5, 17, 628882) The reader will note that the satyagrahis have achieved practically all that they had asked for.
('42', 341, 5, 18, 628979) The terms of reference to the Committee of Enquiry are all that could be desired.
('42', 341, 5, 19, 629061) True, there is to be no inquiry into the allegations about the coercive measures adopted by the Government to enforce payment.
('42', 341, 5, 20, 629188) But it, was generous on the part of Sjt.
('42', 341, 5, 21, 629229) Vallabhbhai to waive the condition, seeing that the lands forfeited including lands sold are to be restored, the talatis are to be reinstated and other minor matters are to be attended to.
('42', 341, 5, 22, 629418) It is well not to rake up old wrongs for which, beyond the reparation made, there can be no other remedy.
('42', 341, 5, 23, 629524) The inquiry into the assessment question will be carried in a calmer atmosphere for the waiver of the clause about the coercive processes.
('42', 341, 5, 24, 629663) Let not the satyagrahis sleep over their well deserved victory.
('42', 341, 5, 25, 629727) have to collect and collate material to prove their allegations about the assessment.
('42', 341, 5, 26, 629813) And above all, if they are to consolidate their position, they must
('42', 341, 6, 27, 629881) 1 On August 6, 1928 at Poona; for the terms of settlement, vide Appendix on “Bardoli Settlement”.
('42', 342, 0, 1, 629979) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 343
('42', 342, 1, 2, 630023) proceed with constructive work with redoubled vigour.
('42', 342, 1, 3, 630077) Their strength lies in their ability and willingness to handle this difficult, slow and unpretentious work of construction.
('42', 342, 1, 4, 630201) They have to rid themselves of many social abuses.
('42', 342, 1, 5, 630252) They must better theireconomic condition by attention to the charkha.
('42', 342, 1, 6, 630322) It was the charkha that led to the awak ening among them.
('42', 342, 1, 7, 630380) They must remove the reproach of drink from their midst.
('42', 342, 1, 8, 630437) They must attend to village sanitation and have a properly managed school in every village.
('42', 342, 1, 9, 630529) The so called higher classes must befriend the depressed and the suppressed classes.
('42', 342, 1, 10, 630614) The greater the attention given to these matters, the greater will be their ability to face crises like the one they had just gone through.
('42', 342, 1, 11, 630754) The noble band of volunteers who had the privilege of serving under Vallabhbhai deserve the highest praise for their devotion and splendid discipline.
('42', 342, 1, 12, 630905) The task is not yet finished.
('42', 342, 1, 13, 630935) Those who can spare the time must help the Sardar in his constructive work.

('42', 343, 3, 6, 632164) A CORRECTION
('42', 343, 4, 7, 632177) In Young India of 19th July last appears an acknowledgment of Rs. 2,000, sent through Lala Lajpat Rai to the Bardoli Fund.
('42', 343, 4, 8, 632300) In this the sum of Rs. 500 has been acknowledged as from “othercontributors”.
('42', 343, 4, 9, 632378) The amount, however, was a personal contribution from Lalaji himself.
('42', 343, 4, 10, 632448) I am sorry for the blunder, but when numerous entries have to be made daily and when they pass from hand to hand such omissions often become inevitable in spite of all efforts to avoid errors.

('42', 344, 4, 6, 633289) I have your letter.
