('42', 344, 4, 10, 633598) I am not perturbed over the position you feel you have to take up.
('42', 344, 4, 11, 633665) We had a death of a very brave young girl at the Swaraj Ashram who was quite all right yesterday and came in order to meet her father who is at the Sabarmati Jail and whose discharge was imminent.
('42', 344, 4, 12, 633862) She developed violent pain in the abdominal region.
('42', 344, 4, 13, 633914) Doctors could not diagnose.
('42', 344, 4, 14, 633942) She died peacefully early in the morning.
('42', 344, 4, 15, 633984) 2 And so, though I am mechanically doing today’s programme, I am holding silent converse with the God of Death and making the meaning of death more clear for myself.
('42', 344, 4, 16, 634150) More when we meet.

('42', 347, 5, 13, 638419) 414. SPEECH AT VALOD 1
('42', 347, 6, 14, 638442) [August 11, 1928] 2
('42', 347, 7, 15, 638462) Even amongst the satyagrahis there were not wanting people who were dissatisfied with the result and addressed notes to Gandhiji and to the Sardar to say that they would have preferred a fight to the finish to a half hearted compromise.
('42', 347, 8, 16, 638699) In reply to these impatient men of Valod Gandhiji said: You will recognize that I am the acharya 3 of the science of satyagraha, and as such I tell you that no victory could have been cleaner, straighter and more decisive.
('42', 347, 8, 17, 638922) What if your Sardar was not taken into confidence by Government?
('42', 347, 8, 18, 638987) Every one of your conditions has been fulfilled and you want nothing more.
('42', 347, 8, 19, 639062) You need not care as to how and through whose instrumentality the settlement was brought about.
('42', 347, 8, 20, 639158) A satyagrahi is satisfied with the substance, he does not fight for the shadow.
('42', 347, 8, 21, 639238) And why do you talk of a fight to the finish?
('42', 347, 8, 22, 639284) Because you did not get an opportunity of proving your mettle against the worst odds, against power and shot?
('42', 347, 8, 23, 639394) Well, it does not behove a satyagrahi to wish that his opponent should stoop to brutishness in order that his own bravery may be proclaimed to the world.
('42', 347, 8, 24, 639548) A satyagrahi always prays that his opponent’s heart may be converted by the grace of God and not that it may be rendered more stony.
('42', 347, 9, 25, 639681) 1 From the Bombay Secret Abstracts, p.
('42', 347, 9, 26, 639720) 552, paragraph 1353(3) 2 ibid 3 Preceptor
('42', 348, 0, 1, 639762) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 349
('42', 348, 1, 2, 639806) why are you impatient?
('42', 348, 1, 3, 639829) The bigger battle is still before us—the battle for freedom of which the campaign was planned in 1921 and which has yet to be fought.

('42', 365, 2, 16, 680165) Our true standard can be ascertained by what the majority of people get to wear and to protect themselves with.
('42', 365, 2, 17, 680277) We must assess our needs on the basis of that standard and spend money accordingly.

('42', 366, 4, 7, 681525) 423. SPEECH AT SURAT 1
('42', 366, 5, 8, 681548) [August 12, 1928] 2
('42', 366, 6, 9, 681568) For a satyagrahi nothing can be truer than to say that no one but God is to be thanked and praised for the triumph of the Bardoli Satyagraha.
('42', 366, 6, 10, 681710) Indeed we need say nothing more.
('42', 366, 6, 11, 681743) But I know that that is not going to give us satisfaction, for the conviction has not yet gone home to us that we are but instruments in His hand and He uses us as He wills.
('42', 366, 6, 12, 681917) We have not yet learnt the virtue of surrender to God.
('42', 366, 6, 13, 681972) Man is yet part man part beast, indeed more beast than man and so his ego is not satisfied with praising God alone.
('42', 366, 6, 14, 682088) In fact in remembering Him on occasions like this we feel as though we were obliging Him.
('42', 366, 6, 15, 682178) Following our animal nature therefore we may congratulate our Sardar, his companions and his volunteers and the men and women of Bardoli.
('42', 366, 6, 16, 682316) Vallabhbhai alone would not have won the battle without the faithful co operation of his co workers.
('42', 366, 6, 17, 682417) But even so should we thank His Excellency the Governor, the officials, and M.L.Cs for their having helped in bringing about a happy settlement.
('42', 366, 6, 18, 682562) We should be lacking in humility, we should be so much the less satyagrahis if we failed in our duty to render our thanks to those who were opposed to us.
('42', 366, 6, 19, 682717) The vast gathering of the citizens of Surat, seated before me on wet earth, with so much inconvenience to themselves, reminds me of 1921. I still remember the words I addressed to you in 1921 on this very spot.
('42', 366, 6, 20, 682928) 3 Possibly some of you also can recall what I said, and I

('42', 367, 0, 1, 683277) 368 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 367, 1, 2, 683319) propose to remind you how we have failed to do the things that we decided to do seven years ago.
('42', 367, 1, 3, 683416) The lesson of Bardoli will have been lost on us if Bardoli and Surat go to sleep over the Bardoli victory after having had victory celebrations and dinners.
('42', 367, 1, 4, 683573) Vallabhbhai has been telling the Bardoli people that it is easier to fight Government than to fight our own people, for we naturally make—and should make, if we were men—mountains out of molehills of Government’s injustice.

('42', 367, 1, 10, 684240) How will you utilize the unprecedented awakening that has come amongst the women of Bardoli?
('42', 367, 1, 11, 684333) How will you serve them, how will you identify yourselves with them and help to remove their misery?
('42', 367, 1, 12, 684434) Satyagraha includes civil disobedience, civil resistance to the tyranny of blind authority, but the capacity of resistance presupposes self purification and constructive work.
('42', 367, 1, 13, 684610) If I were to ask you to render account of what you have done since 1921 in the direction of self purification and constructive work I know you and I would have to shed bitter tears.
('42', 367, 1, 14, 684792) I want to tell you that I continue to be what I was in 1921. I have the same inexorable conditions to place before you, conditions which are a sine qua non for peace, prosperity, swarajya, Ramarajya, or the Kingdom of God that we are hankering after.
('42', 367, 1, 15, 685043) What right have the Hindus and Mussalmans of ease loving Surat to talk of swaraj, so long as they run at the another’s throat in the name of God, and then run to the courts to seek Justice?
('42', 367, 1, 16, 685233) If you are truly brave, you may fight one another on equal terms, but you may not seek the protection of courts of justice.
('42', 367, 1, 17, 685357) The English and the Germans fought on fields of battle, but did not go to law courts.
('42', 367, 1, 18, 685443) There is some bravery in free and fair fighting, but none in running to law courts.
('42', 367, 1, 19, 685527) Let the Hindus and Mussalmans fight a pitched battle, if they will, let them fight fair and clean and decide their issues.
('42', 367, 1, 20, 685650) Their names will then go down in history.
('42', 367, 1, 21, 685692) But this fighting, followed by protracted wrangles in lawcourts, is not bravery.
('42', 367, 1, 22, 685773) Our present ways are not ways of bravery but of cowardice.
('42', 367, 1, 23, 685832) True bravery lies in laying down one’s life for the
('42', 367, 2, 24, 685884) 1 Vide “Speech to Volunteers, Bardoli”, 12 8 1928.
('42', 368, 0, 1, 685935) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 369
('42', 368, 1, 2, 685979) sake of religion, in voluntary surrender of non essentials.
('42', 368, 1, 3, 686039) That is the lesson of Bardoli, and it will have been lost on us if we lose ourselves in the frenzy of victory celebrations.
('42', 368, 1, 4, 686163) Until we who have sprung from the same soil and are children of the same motherland, though belonging to different faiths, learn to love one another as blood brothers, victories like that of Bardoli will be of no avail.
('42', 368, 1, 5, 686383) Another item is the purification of Hinduism.
('42', 368, 1, 6, 686429) Have you purged it of its deepest stain?
('42', 368, 1, 7, 686470) True swaraj I repeat is impossible without self purification.
('42', 368, 1, 8, 686532) I do not know any other way.
('42', 368, 1, 9, 686561) Call it my limitation, but then it is the limitation of satyagraha If there is any other way, I do not know it, and anything won by means other than those of self purification will not be swaraj but something else.
('42', 368, 1, 10, 686776) The third and the last thing in our programme is the duty of men of all religions and all races towards the skeletons of the land.
('42', 368, 1, 11, 686907) The charkha, I may repeat ad nauseam, is the only remedy.
('42', 368, 1, 12, 686965) I have come across a strong justification of the charkha from a strange quarter.
('42', 368, 1, 13, 687046) Sir Lallubhai Samaldas in his review of the ponderous Agricultural Commission’s Report has shown how the Commissioners have shunned like an untouchable even the mention of the word spinning wheel in the chapter on subsidiary industries.
('42', 368, 1, 14, 687283) How is it that they have fought shy of a thing which provides the only occupation to the starving millions?
('42', 368, 1, 15, 687391) I submit that the potency of the spinning wheel lies in that very fact.
('42', 368, 1, 16, 687463) They might have at least criticized it and even ridiculed it.
('42', 368, 1, 17, 687525) But no.
('42', 368, 1, 18, 687533) They could not contemplate with equanimity its infinite possibilities.
('42', 368, 1, 19, 687604) (A heavy shower of rain.) Well I have really done, and need say nothing more.

('42', 377, 0, 1, 698569) 378 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 377, 1, 2, 698611) 440. A SIGN OF THE TIMES
('42', 377, 2, 3, 698636) Bardoli is a sign of the times.
('42', 377, 2, 4, 698668) It has a lesson both for the Government and the people—for the Government if they will recognize the power of the people when they have truth on their side and when they can form a non violent combination to vindicate it.
('42', 377, 2, 5, 698890) By such recognition a wise Government consolidates its power which is then built upon people’s goodwill and co operation not merely in act enforced by brute power but in speech and thought as well.
('42', 377, 2, 6, 699088) Non violent energy properly stored up sets free a force that becomes irresistible.
('42', 377, 2, 7, 699171) So far as I have been able to see, there is no doubt that the settlement has been wrung from an unwilling Government by the pressure of a public opinion that was ever gathering force in geometrical progression.
('42', 377, 2, 8, 699382) It is said that His Excellency the Governor was most willing from the commencement to concede the satyagrahis’ demands but that his advisers were equally determined in their opposition.
('42', 377, 2, 9, 699568) If that is so, whilst it reflects credit upon the Governor, it bodes ill for the Government; for the British Government is not individualistic, it is a powerful organization capable of working irrespective of individuals.
('42', 377, 2, 10, 699790) It has persisted without Gladstone and Disraeli, without Kitchener and Roberts.
('42', 377, 2, 11, 699870) The organization behind the Government in India is the Civil Service.
('42', 377, 2, 12, 699940) What the Sardar of Bardoli wanted was a change of heart in the Civil Service.
('42', 377, 2, 13, 700018) What one is told and observes is that the Civil Service is not satisfied with the settlement.
('42', 377, 2, 14, 700112) If it was satisfied the persistent campaign of lies carried on about the Sardar and his doings would have stopped.
('42', 377, 2, 15, 700227) Whilst I was in Bardoli, I constantly heard the complaint through inspired newspaper paragr aphs that Vallabhbhai Patel had not carried out his part of the settlement, and I knew that he was carrying it out as fast as he could and had already carried out that part of it about which the complaint was made and before it was made.
('42', 377, 2, 16, 700557) I can only say that the Government, if it is true that the Civil Service is resisting the settlement, is doomed, assuming of course that the non violence of Bardoli is an organization capable of being sustained without particular individuals.
('42', 377, 2, 17, 700800) Let us therefore turn to the people of Bardoli.
('42', 377, 2, 18, 700848) The lesson that they have to learn is that so long as they remain united in non violence they have nothing to fear, not even unwilling officials.
('42', 377, 2, 19, 700994) But have they learnt that lesson, have they recognized the unseen power of non violence, have they realized that if they had committed
('42', 378, 0, 1, 701129) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 379
('42', 378, 1, 2, 701173) one single act of violence, they would have lost their cause?
('42', 378, 1, 3, 701235) If they have, then they will know from day to day that they will not become a non violent organization unless they undergo a process of what may be called continuous corporate cleansing.
('42', 378, 1, 4, 701422) This they can only do by engaging in carrying out a well thoughtout constructive programme requiring combined effort and promoting common good.
('42', 378, 1, 5, 701566) In other words before they can claim to have become a non violent organization, they must receive education in non violence not through speeches or writings, necessary as both may be, but through an unbroken series of corporate acts, each evoking the spirit of non violence.
('42', 378, 1, 6, 701841) Vallabhbhai Patel knows what he is about.
('42', 378, 1, 7, 701883) He has set for himself this more difficult task of constructive effort or internal reform.
('42', 378, 1, 8, 701974) May God grant him therein the same measure of success that has attended the struggle against the Government.
('42', 378, 2, 9, 702083) Young India, 16 8 1928
('42', 378, 3, 10, 702106) 441. THE NEHRU REPORT
('42', 378, 4, 11, 702128) Pandit Motilal Nehru and his colleagues 1 deserve the highest congratulations for the very able and practically unanimous report they have been able to bring out on the question that has vexed all parties for the past long months.
('42', 378, 4, 12, 702359) The report is well got up, accessible in book form and printed in bold type.
('42', 378, 4, 13, 702436) No public man can afford to be without it.
('42', 378, 4, 14, 702479) It is signed by Pandit Motilal Nehru, Sir Ali Imam, Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru, Sjt.
('42', 378, 4, 15, 702559) M. S. Aney, Sardar Mangal Singh, M. Shuaib Qureshi, Sjt.
('42', 378, 4, 16, 702616) Subhas Chandra Bose, and Sjt.
('42', 378, 4, 17, 702646) G. R. Pradhan.
('42', 378, 4, 18, 702661) About M. Shuaib Qureshi’s signature however there is the following note at the end of the report:
('42', 378, 5, 19, 702759) Mr. Shuaib Qureshi was unfortunately unable to be present at the last meeting of the Committee when the draft report was considered.
('42', 378, 5, 20, 702892) The draft however was sent to him and he has informed us that in regard to the recommendations contained in Chapter III he is of opinion that one third seats in the Central Legislature should be reserved for Muslims.
('42', 378, 5, 21, 703109) Further, he says: “I agree with the resolution adopted at the informal conference of July 7 but do not subscribe to all the figures and arguments produced in its support.” The report covers 133 pages, appendices 19 pages.
('42', 378, 5, 22, 703331) The report is
('42', 378, 6, 23, 703345) 1 Sub committee appointed by the All Parties Conference held in Bombay on May 19, 1928 “to determine the principles of a constitution for India” (India in 1928 29, p.
('42', 379, 0, 1, 703512) 380 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 379, 1, 2, 703554) divided into ten chapters, of which four deal with the communal aspect, reservation of seats, re distribution of provinces and Indian States.
('42', 379, 1, 3, 703696) The seventh chapter contains the final recommendations of the Committee.
('42', 379, 1, 4, 703769) I must not attempt to summarize the report, if only because it has come into my hands at the moment of sending the last articles for Young India.
('42', 379, 1, 5, 703915) I have not even the time to study the report in full beyond having a cursory glance through it.
('42', 379, 1, 6, 704011) But the great merit of it is that the All Parties Conference Committee has at last been able to produce a unanimous report bearing weighty representative signatures.
('42', 379, 1, 7, 704177) In the matter of the constitution the main thing was not to present perfect recommendations but to secure unanimity for the recommendations that might in the circumstances be considered the best possible.
('42', 379, 1, 8, 704382) And if the practical unanimity arrived at after strenuous labours by the Committee is sealed by the Conference about to meet at Lucknow, 1 a tremendous step will have been taken in the direction of constitutional swaraj as distinguished from what might be termed organic swaraj.
('42', 379, 1, 9, 704661) For if the country arrives at a workable unanimity about the questions that have been agitating it for years, the next thing would be to work for the acceptance of our demands.
('42', 379, 1, 10, 704838) And we have arrived at such a step in the country’s history in our evolution that if we can secure real unanimity about any reasonable proposal, there should be no difficulty in securing acceptance.
('42', 379, 1, 11, 705037) I hope therefore that the Conference will meet at Lucknow with a fixed determination to see the thing through and that the members who will be there will not engage in a critical examination of the report with a view to tear it to pieces but with the determination of arriving at a proper settlement.
('42', 379, 1, 12, 705338) And if they will approach the report in that spirit, they will endorse the.
('42', 379, 1, 13, 705414) recommendations, except for valid reasons which would appeal to any sane persons.
('42', 379, 1, 14, 705496) In thus commending this report to the public, I tender my congratulations to Pandit Motilal Nehru without whose effort there would have been no Committee, there would have been no unanimity and there would have been no report.
('42', 379, 2, 15, 705723) Young India, 16 8 1928
('42', 379, 3, 16, 705746) 1 On August 28, 1928; vide “After Lucknow”, 6 9 1928.
('42', 380, 0, 1, 705800) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 381
('42', 380, 1, 2, 705844) 442. NOTES
('42', 380, 2, 3, 705855) FOR BARDOLI FUND DONORS
('42', 380, 3, 4, 705879) The generous and spontaneous response that has been made to the appeal for funds for Bardoli Satyagraha is a sure index to the India wide popularity of Bardoli Satyagraha.
('42', 380, 3, 5, 706051) The settlement of the Bardoli question and the consequent stoppage of satyagraha render it unnecessary to keep the fund open any longer.
('42', 380, 3, 6, 706188) The public are requested therefore not to send in fresh contributions to the fund.
('42', 380, 3, 7, 706271) This however does not mean that no more money will now be required.
('42', 380, 3, 8, 706339) The work in connection with the inquiry has still to be done and will involve some amount of expense.
('42', 380, 3, 9, 706441) And if the tremendous energy generated during the satyagraha campaign is not to be frittered away, the constructive work must be done with redoubled vigour.
('42', 380, 3, 10, 706598) The balance left will therefore be utilized first for the expense that might be incurred in connection with the inquiry and secondly and simultaneously for constructive work in the two taluks.
('42', 380, 3, 11, 706791) There is no doubt that the organization of the campaign became possible only because constructive work had been going on in Bardoli for the last seven years.
('42', 380, 3, 12, 706949) I am aware that there are places where Congress Commit tees and individuals have more funds collected for Bardoli but they have chosen to send these amounts in instalments.
('42', 380, 3, 13, 707122) I need scarcely inform them that they should forward whatever is now in their hands either to the Ashram at Sabarmati, or Swaraj Ashram at Bardoli, or Navajivan Office or Congress Office in Ahmedabad.
('42', 380, 3, 14, 707323) I understand that Sjt.
('42', 380, 3, 15, 707346) Vallabhbhai Patel has already arranged to have the accounts to date properly audited and published.
('42', 380, 4, 16, 707446) SOUTH AFRICA’S CONTRIBUTION
('42', 380, 5, 17, 707474) A friend writes from South Africa:
('42', 380, 6, 18, 707509) Reuter cabled from India that the South African Indians are sending every month five lakhs of rupees for the Bardoli no tax campaign.
('42', 380, 6, 19, 707643) A mischievous thing, besides being a gross exaggeration.
('42', 380, 6, 20, 707700) The prejudice caused by the remittance of moneys to India will now be deepened and given a sharp edge.
('42', 380, 6, 21, 707803) So far as I have been able to ascertain, about £500 have been sent in all for the Bardoli fund.
('42', 380, 6, 22, 707899) It has not been without pain that I have followed the campaign of lies that has gathered round the Bardoli struggle.
('42', 380, 6, 23, 708016) Nothing was
('42', 381, 0, 1, 708028) 382 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 381, 1, 2, 708070) evidently considered too mean or too palpably absurd to damage a cause which had no secrecy about it and which was intended to cause no injury to a single soul and which had no direct political aim.
('42', 381, 1, 3, 708269) Without verification and probably from malice prepense the falsehood that lakhs of rupees were being received by satyagrahis from South Africa was given currency.
('42', 381, 1, 4, 708432) Well, the cause of satyagraha was not damaged by the false statement.
('42', 381, 1, 5, 708502) But the cause of Indians in South Africa can be easily damaged if the white colonists can be persuaded to believe that vast sums of money are being sent from South Africa to Bardoli and that to sustain an agitation which they may dislike.
('42', 381, 1, 6, 708741) I hope however that not much notice was taken of the statement in South Africa.
('42', 381, 1, 7, 708821) Anyway I can corroborate what the correspondent says.
('42', 381, 1, 8, 708875) Anyone can look at the accounts lying at Bardoli of receipts for the Bardoli Fund and he will find that the correspondent’s information is much nearer the truth than the inflammatory statement cabled to South Africa.
('42', 381, 2, 9, 709092) Young India, 16 8 1928
('42', 381, 3, 10, 709115) 443. OUR JAILS
('42', 381, 4, 11, 709130) In spite of my two years in Indian jails, I see that others who have been in them for much shorter periods than I have more knowledge of their working than I. The satyagrahi prisoners who were recently discharged tell me of the many hardships which can be avoided if there is some consideration shown to the prisoners as human beings.
('42', 381, 4, 12, 709465) The experiences of a satyagrahi prisoner in the Surat Jail are that the prisoners are all cooped up in a small ill ventilated and ill lighted room, the food served is hardly digestible and not much facility given to the prisoners for keeping themselves clean.
('42', 381, 4, 13, 709725) The prisoners at the Sabarmati Central Prison give me more details.
('42', 381, 4, 14, 709793) The flour issued is gritty, the dal is pebbly and often contains animal dirt The satyagrahis were inclined to excuse the jail authorities for this defect saying it was the fault of the prisoners who had to do the cleaning and the grinding.
('42', 381, 4, 15, 710033) I am unable to adopt the view.
('42', 381, 4, 16, 710064) I feel that the authorities are bound to attend to the cleaning of foodstuff either by having it done outside or by effective supervision.
('42', 381, 4, 17, 710203) It is futile to expect the prisoners especially in the way they are kept to do this or anything well or conscientiously.
('42', 381, 4, 18, 710324) Instead of taking the most important work of cooking through them, it would be better and more
('42', 382, 0, 1, 710419) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 383
('42', 382, 1, 2, 710463) economical to have the cooking and the preparatory work done through reliable agency and take from the prisoners other tasks of a more remunerative nature and involving no danger to health.
('42', 382, 1, 3, 710653) Nor was unclean food indifferently cooked the whole of the complaint on this head.
('42', 382, 1, 4, 710736) A kind of dry fermented stinking cabbage was rationed as green vegetable.
('42', 382, 1, 5, 710810) From what the friends described I could gather that this cabbage was a kind of human silage copied from cattle silage, cabbage being re vitalized by subjecting it to high fermentatior If the information given to me is correct, I can only say that the prison authorities are playing with prisoners’ lives entrusted to their care.
('42', 382, 1, 6, 711139) Among the prisoners discharged were three in a weak condition; one a student who had completed his full term was discharged in a precarious condition.
('42', 382, 1, 7, 711290) His condition was so far gone that in spite of all the loving attention being bestowed upon him by the Mahavidyalaya professors and students and skilled medical assistance he is not yet out of danger.
('42', 382, 1, 8, 711491) I was informed that for several days in spite of his fever he was kept on coarse jowari bread for a time.
('42', 382, 1, 9, 711597) I should not at all wonder if this indigestible bread caused intestinal inflammation.
('42', 382, 1, 10, 711683) I shall be glad to publish any explanation that the authorities may have to give in regard to these allegations.
('42', 382, 1, 11, 711796) I know that conditions being as they are prisoners may not expect the comforts of home life.
('42', 382, 1, 12, 711889) I know too that satyagrahis may not grumble at their lot which in a way is of their own seeking.
('42', 382, 1, 13, 711986) Nevertheless even a satyagrahi whether he complains or not should receive human treatment and should get food that is suited to his constitution and that is, above all else, clean and cleanly prepared.
('42', 382, 2, 14, 712188) Young India, 16 8 1928

('42', 384, 1, 2, 713647) 446. SPEECH AT AHMEDABAD 1
('42', 384, 2, 3, 713674) [August 16, 1928] 2
('42', 384, 3, 4, 713694) For me there should be no need to attend this function or to say a word.
('42', 384, 3, 5, 713767) When Vallabhbhai is presented with an address and I am there, and am asked to say something, that means that we both of us have got together and with your permission and in your presence have formed a mutual admiration society of which we both have become members.
('42', 384, 3, 6, 714032) The intelligent citizens of Ahmedabad should never tolerate this.
('42', 384, 3, 7, 714098) Vallabhbhai is a Patel by name and by fame.
('42', 384, 3, 8, 714142) By achieving the victory of Bardoli he has made that fame his for ever.
('42', 384, 3, 9, 714214) Have you ever heard of anyone presenting an address to a business man who upholds his reputation?
('42', 384, 3, 10, 714312) How many addresses have you presented to Seth Mangaldas for the bills of exchange which he honours?
('42', 384, 3, 11, 714412) I do not know what you would do if he did not honour them.
('42', 384, 3, 12, 714471) If you really want to congratulate the satyagrahis, I wish you understood the implications of the triumph and digested as much as suited your constitution.
('42', 384, 3, 13, 714627) You may imitate the experiment, if you can, but I may tell you that imitation is not easy.
('42', 384, 3, 14, 714718) As every individual has his individuality, events have theirs.
('42', 384, 3, 15, 714781) Rather, therefore, than imitate an experiment, you should appreciate its inherent meaning and try to translate it in life.
('42', 384, 3, 16, 714904) Non co operation, satyagraha, civil disobedience are constantly on our lips, and as many good things have been done in their name, some undesirable things have also been done.
('42', 384, 3, 17, 715080) Let those who give these names their liployalty realize their true meaning and implications.
('42', 384, 3, 18, 715173) The fact that satyagraha is on every lip is an indication of the fact that all parties desire swaraj, but mere repetition of the word satyagraha or empty praise of it means nothing.
('42', 384, 3, 19, 715355) You have to work for it, if you are to achieve anything.
('42', 384, 3, 20, 715412) A thirsty man cannot quench his thirst by his merely shouting that he is thirsty.
('42', 384, 3, 21, 715494) He should work to construct tanks and sink wells, or fetch water from them.
('42', 384, 3, 22, 715570) In other words, his thirst can be quenched only by his working to that end.
('42', 384, 3, 23, 715646) Similarly, it will not help if you feel
('42', 384, 4, 24, 715686) 1 From Mahadev Desai’s “Meaning of Bardoli”; the first two paragraphs and the fourth one are translated here from Navajivan, 19 8 1928, where they appeared under the title “Immortal Words”.

('42', 385, 1, 2, 715977) satisfied merely by hearing at this meeting the praises of satyagraha.
('42', 385, 1, 3, 716048) I, therefore, request you to understand the meaning of satyagraha.
('42', 385, 1, 4, 716115) It is not Sjt.
('42', 385, 1, 5, 716130) Vallabhbhai Patel who has triumphed in Bardoli, it is truth and non violence that have triumphed.
('42', 385, 1, 6, 716228) If you think that they have rightly triumphed, you must adopt them as your weapons in every walk of life.
('42', 385, 1, 7, 716334) I cannot promise that you will have success every time you try them.

('42', 389, 2, 13, 723354) 454. GOVERNMENT’S POWER v.
('42', 389, 2, 14, 723381) PEOPLE’S POWER
('42', 389, 3, 15, 723396) Bardoli has proved that the power of the people is greater than that of the State as conclusively as that two and two make four.
('42', 389, 3, 16, 723525) It can further be claimed that such success depends solely upon the people’s capacity to remain peaceful and their capacity to offer peaceful resistance.
('42', 389, 3, 17, 723679) The power of the State is derived solely from its capacity to punish.
('42', 389, 3, 18, 723749) Those persons who rid themselves of the fear of this punishment, despise such punishment and, without opposing the power of the State violently, act as if it did not exist, will always triumph.
('42', 389, 3, 19, 723943) The people of Bardoli could not secure justice so long as they were afraid of being punished by the Government.
('42', 389, 3, 20, 724055) As soon as they rid themselves of that fear, they realized that the officers were dependent upon the people and not vice versa.
('42', 389, 3, 21, 724183) The people also saw that, if they opposed the Government’s violence by similar violence, the former would always succeed, whereas, if they suffered it, it lost its efficacy.
('42', 389, 3, 22, 724357) They also found that this punishment was limited to their persons and possessions, and that it left their hearts wholly untouched.
('42', 389, 3, 23, 724488) They freed themselves from its fear by surrendering their hearts to their Sardar.
('42', 389, 4, 24, 724570) 1 Vide “Telegram to Nanabhai I. Mashruwala”, 13 8 1928. 2 Not translated here 3 ibid
('42', 390, 0, 1, 724655) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 391
('42', 390, 1, 2, 724699) From this we find that the people require neither physical nor intellectual strength to secure their own freedom; moral courage is all that is needed.
('42', 390, 1, 3, 724850) This latter is dependent on faith.
('42', 390, 1, 4, 724885) In this case, they were required to have faith in their Sardar, and such faith cannot be artificially generated.
('42', 390, 1, 5, 724998) They found in the Sardar a worthy object of such faith and like a magnet he drew the hearts of the people to himself.
('42', 390, 1, 6, 725116) We, therefore, find that a satyagraha movement is bound to succeed if it gets a leader who is cultured, self sacrificing and can feel the pulse of the people, and if the people remain loyal to him.
('42', 390, 1, 7, 725314) Truth and non violence were the principal factors in this struggle.
('42', 390, 1, 8, 725382) The people’s demand was just and for securing it they did not resort to untruthful means.
('42', 390, 1, 9, 725472) There were many provocations to the people to become violent and resort to violent measures, but they remained completely peaceful.
('42', 390, 1, 10, 725604) This is not to say that the people had accepted non violence as a principle or that they did not harbour anger even in their minds.
('42', 390, 1, 11, 725736) But they understood the practical advantage of non violence, understood their own interest, controlled their anger and, instead of retaliating in a violent manner, suffered the hardships inflicted on them.
('42', 390, 1, 12, 725942) [From Gujarati] Navajivan, 19 8 1928

('42', 391, 2, 3, 726459) August 20, 1928
('42', 391, 3, 4, 726475) I do not think I am at all fitted to say anything on this great occasion, but I consented to come because of the great esteem in which I held the late Ramanbhai and because I could not resist Shrimati Vidyagauri.
('42', 391, 3, 5, 726688) I am unfit to say anything today for many reasons.
('42', 391, 3, 6, 726739) I have read nothing of or about Raja Ram Mohan Roy.
('42', 391, 3, 7, 726791) What I know about him is based on what I have heard from his admirers.
('42', 391, 3, 8, 726862) I do not claim to have studied the history of the Brahmo Samaj either.
('42', 391, 3, 9, 726933) I made a desperate effort to read something today, something from a brochure on Ram Mohan Roy that we have in our library, but I could not find a moment for it.
('42', 391, 3, 10, 727094) I therefore contented myself with the prayer that God might give me the right word to acquit myself of the task.
('42', 391, 3, 11, 727207) Although, then, I cannot claim to have studied the history of the Brahmo Samaj, I do claim to have a close connection with the members of the Brahmo Samaj extending over several years.
('42', 391, 3, 12, 727392) It dates as far back as 1896 when I first visited Calcutta.
('42', 391, 3, 13, 727452) In 1901 I came in contact with several eminent members of the Brahmo Samaj through Gokhale and Dr. P. C. Ray.
('42', 391, 3, 14, 727562) I used to visit occasionally the Samaj Mandir, and listen to the sermons of the late Pratap Chandra Mozumdar.
('42', 391, 3, 15, 727672) I also came in touch with the late Pandit Shivnath Shastri.
('42', 391, 3, 16, 727732) These experiences were enough to convince me that the Brahmo Samaj has rendered a great service to Hinduism, and that it has rescued the educated classes of India, especially Bengal, from unbelief.
('42', 391, 3, 17, 727930) I have always regarded it as a movement essentially designed for the educated classes.
('42', 391, 3, 18, 728017) Though religion in India sometimes takes the form of superstition, wooden formalism and hysterics, I cannot escape the conviction that a man cannot long remain an unbeliever in India.
('42', 391, 3, 19, 728201) But the faith of the educated class in the early part of the nineteenth century was in danger and it was Ram Mohan Roy who came to their rescue.
('42', 391, 3, 20, 728346) I have heard that he had come under the influence of Christian missionaries and Kakasaheb told me that he had made a deep study of Persian and Arabic.
('42', 391, 3, 21, 728497) There can be no question about his scholarship or

('42', 396, 1, 2, 736733) 461. ‘THE TRUE CAPITAL AND THE FALSE’
('42', 396, 2, 3, 736771) Sir Daniel Hamilton is a big proprietor, owns large estates in the Sundarbans, and is a careful student of banking and the cooperative movement.
('42', 396, 2, 4, 736916) He has written many papers during the past twelve months on Indian banking and has been kind enough to send them to me from time to time.
('42', 396, 2, 5, 737054) I invited him to write in a popular style on banking for the readers of Young India.
('42', 396, 2, 6, 737139) He readily consented and followed up his tentative promise with speedy performance.
('42', 396, 2, 7, 737223) The result is a paper entitled “Man or Mammon?
('42', 396, 2, 8, 737270) Or The True Capital and the False”.
('42', 396, 2, 9, 737306) I have divided the paper in five parts, the first of which appears elsewhere 1 in this issue of Young India.
('42', 396, 2, 10, 737415) I do not pretend to know anything of banking.
('42', 396, 2, 11, 737461) I am sorry to have to confess that I was never able to make time for studying Indian finance, important though I hold the subject to be.
('42', 396, 2, 12, 737598) I am therefore unable to pronounce any opinion upon Sir Daniel Hamilton’s argument.
('42', 396, 2, 13, 737682) It is however sufficient for my purpose that Sir Daniel has written apparently without bias and with great sincerity.
('42', 396, 2, 14, 737800) I commend Sir Daniel Hamilton’s articles to the readers of Young India for careful study and shall be pleased to publish any criticism that Indian financiers may care to offer.

('42', 396, 4, 16, 738000) 462. ALL EYES ON LUCKNOW
('42', 396, 5, 17, 738025) The Nehru Committee report has rightly attracted universal attention.
('42', 396, 5, 18, 738095) All the leading Indians who have spoken upon it have blessed it.
('42', 396, 5, 19, 738160) The critics have been obliged to write about it with marked restraint and often involuntary admiration.
('42', 396, 5, 20, 738264) It has set everyone thinking.
('42', 396, 5, 21, 738294) All eyes are naturally therefore centred on Lucknow where Dr. Ansari has invited the All Parties Conference to meet.
('42', 396, 5, 22, 738411) A report that has compelled such attention is bound to draw a large and represen tative gathering.
('42', 396, 5, 23, 738510) What will the Conference do?
('42', 396, 5, 24, 738539) It will be easy enough to render the proceedings of the conference nugatory and reduce to nothin gness the labours of the Nehru committee.
('42', 396, 5, 25, 738678) Mussalmans may destroy the great edifice built by patient effort on the ground that they have
('42', 396, 6, 26, 738772) 1 Not reproduced here.
('42', 396, 6, 27, 738795) The other four parts appeared weekly in successive issues.
('42', 397, 0, 1, 738854) 398 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 397, 1, 2, 738896) not got all they wanted.
('42', 397, 1, 3, 738921) Hindus may vow never to yield an inch and thus make an advance impossible.
('42', 397, 1, 4, 738996) Political theorists may pick big holes in the report.
('42', 397, 1, 5, 739050) But they will all be wrong if they approach the report from their individual standpoints.
('42', 397, 1, 6, 739140) We shall not easily get again anything so good as the report bearing the representative signatures it does.
('42', 397, 1, 7, 739248) Let all therefore approach the report from only one standpoint, i.e., the national.
('42', 397, 1, 8, 739332) There is room enough under the constitution devised by the Committee for all to rise to their full height.
('42', 397, 1, 9, 739439) Every legitimate interest has its protection guaranteed if it has enough vitality in itself for expansion.
('42', 397, 1, 10, 739546) The franchise is the broadest possible.
('42', 397, 1, 11, 739586) Of course the impatient extremist will be dissatisfied.
('42', 397, 1, 12, 739642) Let him know that the report represents the largest common measure possible for parties often representing opposite views.
('42', 397, 1, 13, 739765) It will be anti national to resist to the breaking point what is offered by this representative report.
('42', 397, 1, 14, 739869) Apart however from the standpoint of expediency, I venture to suggest that the report satisfies all reasonable aspirations and is quite capable of standing on its own intrinsic merits.
('42', 397, 1, 15, 740054) All therefore that is needed to put the finishing touch to the work of the Nehru Committee is a little forbearance, a little mutual respect, a little mutual trust, a little give and take and much confidence not in our little selves but in the great nation of which each one of us is but a humble member.
('42', 397, 2, 16, 740358) Young India, 23 8 1928
('42', 397, 3, 17, 740381) 463. NOTES
('42', 397, 4, 18, 740392) HINDI HINDUSTANI
('42', 397, 5, 19, 740409) That Sir T. Vijayaraghavachari should deliver a public lecture at the Hindu High School in Triplicane, Madras, on the “Place of Hindi in Indian Education” is a sign of the times and proof of the efficacy of the work done by the Hindi Prachar Office in Madras which has carried on Hindi propaganda for the last seven years.
('42', 397, 5, 20, 740732) The lecturer had no difficulty in showing that the fact that of the 300 million people of India, l20 million spoke Hindi and 80 million more understood it and that Hindi was the third most widely spoken language in the world “was by itself a strong reason for everyone learning Hindi”.
('42', 397, 5, 21, 741018) The learned speaker rightly thought that “six months would be a suffi 
('42', 398, 0, 1, 741089) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 399
('42', 398, 1, 2, 741133) cient period for learning the language well.” He contended that “the place of Hindi in Indian education must be compulsory.
('42', 398, 1, 3, 741257) It ought to be a compulsory language in school, college and university.” He concluded:
('42', 398, 2, 4, 741344) We are all eagerly looking forward to the day when we shall all be Indians first and Madrasis or Bangalis next.
('42', 398, 2, 5, 741456) The day will be hastened if Madrasis, who are the worst offenders in this respect, begin to learn Hindi in larger number.
('42', 398, 2, 6, 741578) The people of the South have every facility afforded to them through the Hindi Prachar Office of learning Hindi.
('42', 398, 2, 7, 741691) Surely if we have real love of India as we have of our respective provinces, we would all learn Hindi without delay and avoid the humiliating spectacle of carrying on our proceedings in the popular assembly, i.e., the All India Congress Committee, predominantly, if not often wholly, in English.
('42', 398, 2, 8, 741987) Let me repeat once more what I have often said that I do not contemplate the suppression of provincial languages by Hindi but addition of Hindi to the former so as to enable provinces to establish a living contact with one another.
('42', 398, 2, 9, 742219) This must result also in enriching both the provincial languages and Hindi.
('42', 398, 3, 10, 742295) BARDOLI—A VICTORY OF PEACE
('42', 398, 4, 11, 742322) The following poetic bit from a love letter of Shrimati Sarojini Devi’s bears reproduction:
('42', 398, 5, 12, 742414) A pastoral vision of quiet beauty is spread all around me; the sunset has dyed the clouds in the west in the glowing colours of flame, and in the east in the tender colours of flowers; the low hills have taken on every dreamlike shadow steeped in blue and purple, and the undulating valley just below is settling down to rest, gathering the wandering sheep, hushing the wild doves and wild hawks to slumber, collecting the little groups of peasants and labourers to their thatched huts under the boughs of sheltering trees....
('42', 398, 5, 13, 742941) Soon all the denizens of the secluded colony set in the heart of such sylvan beauty will be at rest, each in his or her own bed, and soon the nightfall will wrap the hills and valley and woods in a velvet darkness....
('42', 398, 5, 14, 743159) But the darkness, alas, does not always bring comfort to the suffering.
('42', 398, 5, 15, 743231) No sleep .
('42', 398, 5, 16, 743242) What poignant vigils does the night witness, that the world never knows?
('42', 398, 5, 17, 743315) How many such poignant vigils have the people of Bardoli kept night after night?
('42', 398, 5, 18, 743396) But I rejoice that tonight the darkness will bring dreams of sweetness to those whose spirit was so unwearied in battle through long and terrible weeks....
('42', 398, 5, 19, 743552) The sleep of the satyagrahi when his work is over is indeed a gift of the gods.
('42', 398, 5, 20, 743632) Do you remember the words of the German philosopher: “Let your work be a battle, let your peace be a victory.” So it has been at Bardoli.
('42', 398, 5, 21, 743770) The peace has indeed been a victory of peace and peaceful ways.
('42', 399, 0, 1, 743834) 400 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 399, 1, 2, 743876) I have just finished the last page of the English version of your moving and vivid history of the South African Satyagraha when the post brought the papers with the longed for and joyful news of the Bardoli settlement .
('42', 399, 1, 3, 744096) honourable to both sides.
('42', 399, 1, 4, 744122) As I wrote to ‘Sardar’ Vallabhbhai a month ago, I have always felt and known that satyagraha in its deep authentic sense is literally “the treasure of the lowly”—Maeterlinck’s beautiful phrase, of those who are content with realities and not seekers after false values and false standards....
('42', 399, 1, 5, 744415) Your dream was to make Bardoli the perfect example of satyagraha.
('42', 399, 1, 6, 744481) Bardoli has fulfilled itself in its own fashion interpreting and perfecting your dream.

('42', 403, 6, 12, 750001) 471. LIMITS OF SATYAGRAHA 1
('42', 403, 7, 13, 750029) A correspondent impatient to stop the marriages of aged men with young girls writes:
('42', 403, 8, 14, 750114) This evil requires drastic remedies.
('42', 403, 8, 15, 750151) Twenty five young men of character should form themselves into a band of satyagrahis, proceed to the place of the marriage eight or ten days before the event and plead with both the parties, with the heads of the caste organization, and with all concerned.
('42', 403, 8, 16, 750408) They should parade the streets with suitable placards condemning such marriages and produce an atmosphere of opposition to the proposed marriage.
('42', 403, 8, 17, 750554) They should persuade the people of the town or village to declare a peaceful boycott against the parties to the marriage, and court arrest or whatever other punishment that comes to them.
('42', 403, 9, 18, 750742) Thus the satyagrahi band would soon become a power in the locality, and these marriages would be a thing of the past.
('42', 403, 9, 19, 750860) The suggestion looks attractive, but I am afraid it cannot be of use on more than one occasion.
('42', 403, 9, 20, 750956) Where lust and cupidity join hands the slaughter of the innocents becomes almost impossible to avoid.
('42', 403, 9, 21, 751058) As soon as lustful old candidates for brides and the greedy parents get scent of the invasion of the satyagrahi band, they will evade the band by performing the wedding secretly, and they will find enough priests and wedding guests to help them in the ceremony.
('42', 403, 9, 22, 751320) The readers of Navajivan may be aware of an incident that happened some time
('42', 403, 10, 23, 751397) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Navajivan, 26 8 1928. This is a translation by Mahadev Desai.
('42', 404, 0, 1, 751503) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 405
('42', 404, 1, 2, 751547) The old man in that case feigned contrition, and successfully threw dust into the eyes of all by a hollow public apology.
('42', 404, 1, 3, 751669) The reformers were delighted, but before they had finished congratulating themselves the old man managed to get secretly married.
('42', 404, 1, 4, 751799) What happened in one case may happen in many cases.
('42', 404, 1, 5, 751851) We should therefore devise other means to grapple with the evil.
('42', 404, 1, 6, 751916) I have an idea that it may be easier to reach the greedy father of the bride than the slave of his lust.
('42', 404, 1, 7, 752021) There is a great necessity for cultivating public opinion in the matter.
('42', 404, 1, 8, 752094) The parents who readily sell away their girls, out of cupidity, should be sought out and pleaded with, and caste organizations should be persuaded to pass resolutions condemning such marriages.
('42', 404, 1, 9, 752288) Evidently such reforms cannot be carried out all at once by the same band in large areas.
('42', 404, 1, 10, 752378) Their field must needs be circumscribed.
('42', 404, 1, 11, 752419) A satyagrahi band in Cape Comorin will, not be able to prevent a monstrous marriage in Kashmir.
('42', 404, 1, 12, 752515) The reformers will havetherefore to recognize their limitations.
('42', 404, 1, 13, 752580) We may not attempt the impossible.
('42', 404, 1, 14, 752615) Love and ahimsa are matchless in their effect.
('42', 404, 1, 15, 752662) But in their play there is no fuss, show, noise or placards.
('42', 404, 1, 16, 752723) They presuppose self confidence which in its turn presupposes self purification.
('42', 404, 1, 17, 752804) Men of stainless character and self purification will easily inspire confidence and automatically purify the atmosphere around them.
('42', 404, 1, 18, 752937) I have long believed that social reform is a tougher business than political reform.
('42', 404, 1, 19, 753022) The atmosphere is ready for the latter, people are interested in it, and there is an impression abroad that it is possible without self purifica tion.
('42', 404, 1, 20, 753173) On the other hand people have little interest in social reform, the result of agitation does not appear to be striking, and there is little room for congratulations and addresses.
('42', 404, 1, 21, 753353) The social reformers will have therefore to plod on for some time, hold themselves in peace, and be satisfied with apparently small results.
('42', 404, 1, 22, 753494) I may here throw out a practical suggestion.
('42', 404, 1, 23, 753539) The most effective means of creating an atmosphere against the marriages of aged persons with young girls is to create public opinion against the actual marriage and to set in motion a peaceful social boycott against the aged bridegroom and the greedy father of the bride.
('42', 404, 1, 24, 753812) If a successful boycott can be carried out even in one single instance, parents will hesitate to sell their daughters and old men will hesitate to run after young brides.
('42', 404, 1, 25, 753983) It will not be easy to wean lustful old men from their lust.
('42', 405, 0, 1, 754044) 406 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 405, 1, 2, 754086) may be therefore induced to marry old widows, if they must marry.
('42', 405, 1, 3, 754152) In Europe old men easily seek out old widows.
('42', 405, 1, 4, 754198) In conclusion, we must be clear about our objectives in opposing these marriages.
('42', 405, 1, 5, 754280) It cannot be our object to wean old men from their lust; if it is we will have first to deal with lustful young men.
('42', 405, 1, 6, 754397) But that is a tall order.
('42', 405, 1, 7, 754423) Our objective can be only to save young girls from the clutches of lustful old men and the cupidity of their parents.
('42', 405, 1, 8, 754541) The reformer must therefore address himself to carrying on a crusade against the sale of brides.
('42', 405, 1, 9, 754638) It is the bride’s parents who have to be reached.
('42', 405, 1, 10, 754688) Let the satyagrahi therefore chalk out the field of his activities, have a census of all girls of a marriageable age living in that area, let him get into touch with their parents, and awaken them to a sense of their duty towards their daughters.
('42', 405, 1, 11, 754935) Let not the reformer go outside these limits if he wants to achieve success.
('42', 405, 1, 12, 755012) The scheme proposed in the correspondent’s letter easily transgresses these limits.

('42', 405, 4, 15, 755132) EXPLOSION OF MATRICULATES
('42', 405, 5, 16, 755158) A correspondent writes to say: 1
('42', 405, 6, 17, 755191) This question is well worth asking.
('42', 405, 6, 18, 755227) It has often been answered in this paper.
('42', 405, 6, 19, 755269) The lure of a Government stamp makes slaves of us.
('42', 405, 6, 20, 755320) Hence I have suggested that it is our duty to leave Government schools.
('42', 405, 6, 21, 755392) But who will free the students from this infatuation?
('42', 405, 6, 22, 755446) How can one secure, without a Government stamp, a job where there are chances of getting a bribe?
('42', 405, 6, 23, 755544) The student will be unable to free himself from this infatuation so long as he does not willingly accept work involving physical labour and value it more than literary education.
('42', 405, 6, 24, 755723) This is one of the reasons why the spinning wheel has been given such importance.
('42', 405, 6, 25, 755805) It is a widely accepted symbol of manual labour.
('42', 405, 6, 26, 755854) In the first issue of Navajivan a picture was given which contained figures of the spinning wheel and the plough.
('42', 405, 6, 27, 755968) As the status of the spinning wheel improves, physical labour and honourable poverty will
('42', 405, 7, 28, 756058) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('42', 405, 7, 29, 756095) The correspondent had drawn attention to the increasing number of matriculates in the country and the problem of their employment.
('42', 406, 0, 1, 756226) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 407
('42', 406, 1, 2, 756270) automatically find the place that they deserve.
('42', 406, 1, 3, 756318) This does not imply that everyone should earn a living by means of the spinning wheel, but it does imply that everyone should do so by means of productive labour.
('42', 406, 1, 4, 756481) It is the atmosphere of the schools which is responsible for an increase in the students’ love of British ways of life and their love of British goods.
('42', 406, 1, 5, 756633) Only a handful of students remain unaffected by the atmosphere.
('42', 406, 2, 6, 756697) FIRES CAUSED BY THE PRIMUS STOVE
('42', 406, 3, 7, 756730) The same correspondent writes as follows about the Primus stove: 1
('42', 406, 4, 8, 756797) It is true that the Primus stove has enslaved the minds of Gujarati women.
('42', 406, 4, 9, 756872) I also believe that this stove is not as necessary as it is generally believed to be.
('42', 406, 4, 10, 756958) It is undoubtedly true that a Gujarati woman’s sari lends grace to her, but it does cause great inconvenience to the working women.
('42', 406, 4, 11, 757090) It seems to be a fact that the sari is responsible for the accidents through the Primus stove in which Gujarati women have been involved.
('42', 406, 4, 12, 757228) If I could persuade these women, I would rid them of their fascination for this stove and have them imitate the tucked up sari worn by the brave women of Bardoli.
('42', 406, 4, 13, 757391) In my opinion, the sari draped in that manner is no less graceful.
('42', 406, 4, 14, 757458) It also gives full freedom of movement while working and, looking at the matter more deeply, we see that it affords better protection to women inasmuch as they are more fully clad in this dress.
('42', 406, 4, 15, 757653) Those who have seen the women of Bardoli at work would testify that they could do no work in the field if they wore the sari with one end of it hanging in front of them.

('42', 412, 1, 2, 764824) 483. LETTER TO R. DORAISWAMY
('42', 412, 2, 3, 764853) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, August 28, 1928
('42', 412, 3, 4, 764899) DEAR FRIEND, I have your letter.
('42', 412, 3, 5, 764932) I must draw your attention to the fact that my definition of a “spinner” applies to voluntary spinners, not to paid spinners.
('42', 412, 3, 6, 765058) I know from experience that not much time has to be given to doing one’s own carding and that those who do spinning for the love of it should generally be able to find time for doing their own carding a small quantity.
('42', 412, 3, 7, 765277) I have done it myself, though in order to save every minute of my time I have given it up, because there are so many to supply me with slivers.
('42', 412, 3, 8, 765421) But for the sake of accuracy, I propose to do my own carding, even though I am now supposed to be in a very weak state of health, and publish the result in Young India.
('42', 412, 3, 9, 765590) You should certainly be supplied with spindles from the Tamil Nad Branch as also from the Satyagraha Ashram or Bardoli.
('42', 412, 3, 10, 765710) There is however a great difficulty in having an unlimited supply of true spindles, because straightening taxes the eyes of workers, so much so that one man who used to straighten up 60 spindles per day very nearly lost his eyes.
('42', 412, 3, 11, 765940) At the Ashram and at Bardoli, therefore, not much encouragement is given to those who want true spindles.
('42', 412, 3, 12, 766046) Straightening can be learnt by application.
('42', 412, 3, 13, 766090) Once a person learns it, he can straighten his own spindle in a very short time and straightening once in a way does not tax the eye at all.
('42', 412, 3, 14, 766231) Attempts were being made by the Association to get a piece of machinery whereby true spindles can be turned out.
('42', 412, 3, 15, 766344) But in spite of all effort, up to now such a machine has not been found.
('42', 412, 3, 16, 766417) I am however forwarding your letter to the Tamil Nad Branch in order that whatever is possible might be done in order to help voluntary spinners.
('42', 412, 4, 17, 766563) R. DORAISWAMY KHADI AGENT, KUMBAKONAM
('42', 412, 5, 18, 766601) From a microfilm: S.N. 13675

('42', 415, 6, 7, 769552) 488. EUROPE GOERS BEWARE
('42', 415, 7, 8, 769577) Now that so many people have begun to go to Europe and the interest in India and Indians has since the days of Non co operation grown, there is a growing demand on their time on the part of European public bodies and political parties.
('42', 415, 7, 9, 769813) Not one of us was however prepared for what befell Babu Rajendra Prasad.
('42', 415, 7, 10, 769886) Rajendra Babu went to London some months ago to fulfil an important legal engagement.
('42', 415, 7, 11, 769972) Having finished his case he did a bit of travelling on the Continent and among other things attended the War Resisters’ Conference in Vienna.
('42', 415, 7, 12, 770114) Prompted by a stranger, he accepted another engagement in the neighbourhood.
('42', 415, 7, 13, 770191) There was some days ago in The Bombay Chronicle a cable to the effect that a meeting at which Babu Rajendra Prasad was speaking on peace was broken up by Fascists and that he was seriously assaulted.
('42', 415, 7, 14, 770391) In the absence of any cable from Rajendra Babu, I refused to believe in the assault.
('42', 415, 7, 15, 770476) The same day that I saw the Press cable, I had a cable from Rajendra Babu asking for a message 1 for the Youth Conference in Holland.
('42', 415, 7, 16, 770610) This removed all suspicion about the assault; but by the last mail I received a letter from Austrian friends, a professor and his wife, containing a graphic description and confirmation of the assault reported in the Press.
('42', 415, 7, 17, 770834) I reproduce below the relevant portion of the letter which moreover contains a warning important for all who visit the Continent:
('42', 415, 8, 18, 770964) Though very rejoiced at your letter of introduction of Mr. Rajendra Prasad I was terrified by a postscript of one—whose name we had never heard before at the backside of your letter.
('42', 415, 8, 19, 771147) In your kind letter there was no word about any meeting, but at the back, this Mr. .
('42', 415, 8, 20, 771232) 2 wrote: “Comrade Raj.
('42', 415, 9, 21, 771255) 1 Vide “Cable to Rajendra Prasad”, On or after 16 8 1928. 2 Omissions as in the source
('42', 416, 0, 1, 771342) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 417
('42', 416, 1, 2, 771386) speak at the Steinfelder Sale, and requests you to meet him there.” I was very much astonished and terrified.
('42', 416, 1, 3, 771496) For, in the “Steinfelder Sale”, which is a beerhouse, there was on the same day a meeting of ‘International Women’s League for Peace and Freedom’.
('42', 416, 1, 4, 771643) I did not know this League.
('42', 416, 1, 5, 771671) This letter came into our hands at 9 in the morning of the 1st August, and we tried the whole forenoon to find out whether this meeting guaranteed security, but we could not find in any directory or telephone book any address or name of the members of this League.
('42', 416, 1, 6, 771936) So we went to the station to fetch brother Prasad, to take him with us to our home.
('42', 416, 2, 7, 772020) Mr. Prasad did not know the circumstances of this meeting and did not know enough of this Mr....
('42', 416, 2, 8, 772117) He agreed with this Mr....
('42', 416, 2, 9, 772144) to speak at the meeting in which were concentrated from the surroundings and the town the followers of war and violence in order to disturb this women’s meeting.
('42', 416, 2, 10, 772306) Not knowing anything, .
('42', 416, 2, 11, 772330) and myself went there with Mr. Prasad to satisfy his obligation.
('42', 416, 2, 12, 772395) was not at the meeting, no one was there of the Women’s Committee, the hall was full of smoke, the tables full of beerglasses, men were yelling— there was no one of that Committee though it was already quarter of an hour later.
('42', 416, 2, 13, 772623) Going to the Women’s Committee table, we were suddenly attacked even before the beginning of the meeting, and though guarding him with our own bodies, we could not prevent brother Prasad from being injured.
('42', 416, 2, 14, 772830) After our injuries we came to know: (1) that he was taken to be one .
('42', 416, 2, 15, 772900) ., the name of whom we had never heard, who had to speak at this meeting; (2) that Mr....
('42', 416, 2, 16, 772990) was an anarchist and editor of an anarchistical newspaper!
('42', 416, 2, 17, 773049) We are very sorry at all this.
('42', 416, 2, 18, 773080) Not only because of our wounds—fortunately my double quilted khaddarhat and my hair knot caught up many of the blows with wooden lathis and chairs and glasses, nevertheless, brother Prasad was slightly hurt on the head, on the forehead and upon one hand, and .
('42', 416, 2, 19, 773341) was injured with a chair leg on the cheek under one eye.
('42', 416, 2, 20, 773398) This small wound of.
('42', 416, 2, 21, 773419) and a small wound on the forehead of Mr. Prasad could be dangerous for the eyes, perhaps also a stab with a knife which I caught up with my hand and which was soon healed.
('42', 416, 2, 22, 773591) I do not know whence I had the strength to hold up so many blows in order to make a way out through perhaps a thousand men beating us three, and insulting me because I was protecting the men, I had only one hand to hold up the blows, with the other hand I held Mr. Prasad whom .
('42', 416, 2, 23, 773870) and myself had between us, .
('42', 416, 2, 24, 773899) trying to save his Gandhi cap which was finally lost.
('42', 416, 2, 25, 773953) Our hands and feet were covered with blue spots, and for two days I had a slight commotion in the brain.
('42', 416, 2, 26, 774058) All were crying: “Slay him down,” ...
('42', 416, 2, 27, 774096) it was dreadful ....
('42', 416, 2, 28, 774117) We have kept the good brother in our home and dressed his wounds.
('42', 416, 2, 29, 774183) On the next day he felt well, and we travelled with him by railway one hour before leaving him.
('42', 416, 2, 30, 774279) The next day we received a letter from him reporting that he was feeling well, and
('42', 417, 0, 1, 774362) 418 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI

('42', 418, 4, 7, 776640) 307 dated 27 7 1928. It has given me full satisfaction and the clothes are admired by friends.
('42', 418, 4, 8, 776735) I feel that the message?
('42', 418, 4, 9, 776760) of khadi has reached only a small fraction of the people, and that in the matter of publicity, the movement lags behind even ordinary firms.
('42', 418, 4, 10, 776901) Those who would like to purchase khadi have got nothing for guidance as there is a very small number of shops in a province and that too does very little work in the way of publicity.
('42', 418, 4, 11, 777085) I am sure money will not be wasted if you were to enlarge and illustrate your price list.
('42', 418, 4, 12, 777175) The creation of a publicity department for khadi will not be a superfluous thing.
('42', 418, 4, 13, 777257) If and when you approve of this idea and action is taken thereon, I shall be glad to remit an amount of Rs. 100 as a contribution towards the fund required for the purpose.
('42', 418, 4, 14, 777430) There is much truth in the correspondent’s charge.
('42', 418, 4, 15, 777481) The All India Spinner’s Association has concerned itself more with perfecting the internal organization than with external effort such as advertisement, feeling that perfection of the internal organization will be its own advertisement.
('42', 418, 4, 16, 777718) The Association has therefore been chary of spending money on publicity work.
('42', 418, 4, 17, 777796) But, if sufficient response is made by khadi lovers towards the expense of publicity work, I have no doubt that the Council will gladly take it up.
('42', 418, 4, 18, 777944) Let it however be known that publicity work to be thorough is a costly affair.
('42', 418, 4, 19, 778023) Generally, the cost of publicity is included in the price of the material advertised.
('42', 418, 4, 20, 778109) The All India Spinners’ Association has been averse thus to increasing the price of khadi.
('42', 418, 4, 21, 778200) It is therefore necessary that if the publicity work is to be organized, the cost should come from those who appreciate the virtue of khadi and have the means of defraying it.
('42', 418, 4, 22, 778376) If therefore there are others like the correspondent who will shoulder the burden of the publicity department, let them send me their contributions earmarked for the purpose.
('42', 418, 4, 23, 778551) If sufficient response is not made and if the donors so desire, the donations will be refunded.
('42', 418, 5, 24, 778647) THE SPINNING WHEEL IN MYSORE STATE
('42', 418, 6, 25, 778682) Pujari of the All India Spinners’ Association who is assisting the Mysore State authorities in organizing hand spinning in that State
('42', 419, 0, 1, 778816) 420 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 419, 1, 2, 778858) sends me a letter from which I extract the following information:
('42', 419, 2, 3, 778924) The work was started on the 1st of November 1927. The movement has gained stability.
('42', 419, 2, 4, 779009) At the end of July last, 1,000 wheels were at work in 60 villages, supplying 52 looms; and the production of July amounted to Rs. 2,000.
('42', 419, 3, 5, 779146) Pujari says:
('42', 419, 4, 6, 779159) I can assert from my experience of nine months
('42', 419, 5, 7, 779206) 1. that a subsidiary cottage industry in these parts is a felt want;
('42', 419, 6, 8, 779275) 2. that the tiny wheels supply that want as nothing else can;
('42', 419, 7, 9, 779337) 3. that it has been possible to do this thing because of State encouragement and because the spinners and weavers are assured of a steady demand for their yarn and khaddar;
('42', 419, 8, 10, 779510) 4. that given similar conditions in other parts of India, the same results should be obtained;
('42', 419, 9, 11, 779605) 5. that hand spinning keeps the village revenue in constant circulation flowing from the raiyats’ cottages to the State and from the State to the raiyats;
('42', 419, 10, 12, 779760) 6. that it is the best method of utilizing the free energy of the vast agricultural population which is now running to waste in the 6,85,000 villages of India;
('42', 419, 11, 13, 779920) 7. and lastly, that hand spinning adds to the daily earnings of the villager three pies per hour that he spends at the wheel, a by no means negligible addition to the earnings of a population whose income per head is estimated at not more than 0 1 7 per day.
('42', 419, 11, 14, 780179) Pujari adds:
('42', 419, 12, 15, 780192) What a blessing it would be if other States of India were to copy the noble example of the Mysore State.
('42', 419, 12, 16, 780297) I echo the wish.
('42', 419, 13, 17, 780314) TORTURE OF BULLOCKS
('42', 419, 14, 18, 780334) An English lady writes:
('42', 419, 15, 19, 780358) I am much distressed and perplexed by the habitual torture of bullocks by the inhabitants of this country, chiefly Hindus, who call themselves protectors of the cow!
('42', 419, 15, 20, 780524) The sight of the dislocated, mutilated tail joints of the overburdened creatures toiling along roads is one never to be forgotten by a visitor to this country.
('42', 419, 15, 21, 780684) The way the hands of the drivers, made filthy by cruelty, grasp and twitch the very backbone of the shrinking creatures at the tail socket, when the tail itself is a broken twisted abomination, is a sight
('42', 420, 0, 1, 780889) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 421
('42', 420, 1, 2, 780933) which brings shame on the Hindu religion.
('42', 420, 1, 3, 780975) Can you do nothing through your paper Young India on behalf of these creatures, as also on behalf of the tormented fowls carried by the legs head down for miles to their destruction?
('42', 420, 1, 4, 781158) I enclose a picture of English oxen at work.
('42', 420, 1, 5, 781203) The Indian has adopted the motor car for himself, why not the harness for his bullocks?
('42', 420, 1, 6, 781291) Whilst it is true that this fair visitor to India has indulged in a hasty generalization by accusing the inhabitants of India of habitual torture of bullocks—for it is not very inhabitant, not even every tenth man who ill uses bullocks—there is no doubt that some drivers in the cities are guilty of the practice referred to in the letter, and there is no doubt also that the passer by goes his way totally oblivious of the torture and there is truth too in the statement about the inhuman carrying of fowls.
('42', 420, 1, 7, 781800) It is possible to say of us who talk about ahimsa that we strain at a gnat and easily swallow a camel.
('42', 420, 1, 8, 781903) We would be agitated if a rabid dog was shot, but we are indifferent, if not willing witnesses to the cruelties such as are mentioned in the letter I have reproduced.
('42', 420, 1, 9, 782070) We seem to think that we have fully carried out the doctrine of ahimsa so long as we do not actually kill.
('42', 420, 1, 10, 782177) In my opinion, this is a travesty of ahimsa; every act of injury to a living creature and every endorsement of such act by refraining from non violent effort wherever possible to prevent it is a breach of ahimsa.
('42', 420, 1, 11, 782390) Here, there is work for religious organizations that would be faithful to their convictions to conduct a crusade against cruelties to lower animals practised in the cities.
('42', 420, 1, 12, 782563) The change from the yoke to the harness is undoubtedly desirable.

('42', 426, 5, 8, 791948) 496. LETTER TO B. W. TUCKER 1
('42', 426, 6, 9, 791978) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, September 1, 1928
('42', 426, 7, 10, 792026) MY DEAR BOYD, Your letter has been on my file for some days.
('42', 426, 7, 11, 792087) I think you have stated my position fairly correctly except that the way in which you have put it may cause a misunderstanding.
('42', 426, 7, 12, 792215) I did not say that I would not desire that others should accept my viewpoint.
('42', 426, 7, 13, 792293) But I did say that I would not desire that others should accept my religion.
('42', 426, 7, 14, 792370) Evidently you have used the word viewpoint as synonymous with religion.
('42', 426, 7, 15, 792442) I do not.
('42', 426, 7, 16, 792452) Whilst I would not press my religion upon others, I would press my viewpoint upon others, as every one of us must.
('42', 426, 7, 17, 792567) Religion is a matter of feeling or the heart and, therefore, not a matter for argument, and I would hold everybody’s feeling as dear as my own, because I expect him to do so with reference to my feeling.
('42', 426, 7, 18, 792771) Viewpoint is a matter of reasoning, the mind, the intellect.
('42', 426, 7, 19, 792832) It may shift from time to time without touching the heart.
('42', 426, 7, 20, 792891) Change of religion is a change of status.
('42', 426, 7, 21, 792933) Change of viewpoint is an accident often due to external causes.
('42', 426, 7, 22, 792998) My feeling about the existence of God cannot be easily altered.
('42', 426, 7, 23, 793062) My viewpoint regarding the connotation of the term may vary from time to time and expand with the expansion of my
('42', 426, 8, 24, 793176) 1 In reply 10 his letter (S.N. 13491) of August 15, 1928, which read: “There is one question that was raised at the Council of the International Fellowship held at Sabarmati last January, about which I would appreciate some further explanation
('42', 427, 0, 1, 793420) 428 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 427, 1, 2, 793462) reason.
('42', 427, 1, 3, 793470) Religion is beyond explanation and it seems to me to be impertinent for anyone to touch another’s religion.
('42', 427, 1, 4, 793578) A viewpoint must always be capable of explanation.
('42', 427, 1, 5, 793629) I have entered upon this distinction because it enables me to explain my position about religion more clearly than by any other means.
('42', 427, 1, 6, 793764) I do not want you to become a Hindu.
('42', 427, 1, 7, 793801) But I do want you to become a better Christian by assimilating all that may be good in Hinduism and that you may not find in same measure or at all in the Christian teaching.
('42', 427, 1, 8, 793976) I can’t explain why I delight in calling myself and remaining a Hindu, but my remaining does not prevent me from assimilating all that is good and noble in Christianity, Islam and other faiths of the world.
