('42', 427, 5, 15, 794428) 497. AHIMSA IN EDUCATION 1
('42', 427, 6, 16, 794455) For some time past Gandhiji has been following the practice of giving weekly talks to the students of the Gujarat Vidyapith.
('42', 427, 6, 17, 794580) He used on these occasions to invite questions from students and teachers which he would answer.
('42', 427, 6, 18, 794677) Before their interrogatories could be exhausted, however, he had to take up the reading of Hind Swaraj with them at their request.
('42', 427, 6, 19, 794808) But as some of the questions received by him are of general interest he proposes to deal with them in the pages of Navajivan.
('42', 427, 6, 20, 794934) The substance of one is given below.
('42', 427, 6, 21, 794971) —MAHADEV DESAI One of the questions put to me was as follows:
('42', 427, 7, 22, 795033) The moment one begins to talk of ahimsa, a series of trifling questions are mooted, e.g., whether it is permissible to kill dogs, tigers and wolves, snakes, lice, etc..
('42', 427, 7, 23, 795202) and whether one may eat brinjals or potatoes or else the questioner engages in a disputation over the.
('42', 427, 7, 24, 795305) question of maintaining an army or of offering armed resistance.
('42', 427, 7, 25, 795370) Nobody seems to trouble to inquire how the principle of ahimsa should be worked out as part of education.
('42', 427, 7, 26, 795476) Will you kindly
('42', 427, 8, 27, 795492) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Navajivan, 2 9 1928.
('42', 428, 0, 1, 795557) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 429
('42', 428, 1, 2, 795601) shed some light on this question?
('42', 428, 1, 3, 795635) This is not a new problem.
('42', 428, 1, 4, 795662) It has been discussed threadbare in these columns off and on in one shape or another.
('42', 428, 1, 5, 795748) But I know that I have not succeeded in making it absolutely clear to my readers.
('42', 428, 1, 6, 795830) The task, I am afraid, is beyond my capacity.
('42', 428, 1, 7, 795876) But I should be thankful if I could succeed in contributing somewhat to its solution.
('42', 428, 1, 8, 795962) The introductory part of the question shows that questions be betraying a narrow outlook are often put.
('42', 428, 1, 9, 796066) By unnecessarily exercising ourselves over conundrums about the justifiability of man’s killing creatures and animals of a lower order, we often seem to forget our primary duties.
('42', 428, 1, 10, 796246) Every one of us is not faced every day with the question of killing obnoxious animals.
('42', 428, 1, 11, 796333) Most of us have not developed courage and love enough to practise ahimsa with regard to dangerous reptiles.
('42', 428, 1, 12, 796441) We do not destroy the vipers of ill will and anger in our own bosom, but we dare to raise futile discussions about the propriety of killing obnoxious creatures and we thus move in a vicious circle.
('42', 428, 1, 13, 796639) We fail in the primary duty and lay the unction to our souls that we are refraining from killing obnoxious life.
('42', 428, 1, 14, 796752) One who desires to practise ahimsa must for the time being forget all about snakes, etc.
('42', 428, 1, 15, 796841) Let him not worry if he cannot avoid killing them, but try for all he is worth to overcome the anger and ill will of men by his patient endeavour as a first step toward cultivating universal love.
('42', 428, 1, 16, 797038) Abjure brinjals or potatoes by all means, if you will, but do not for heaven’s sake begin to feel yourself self righteous or flatter yourself that you are practising ahimsa on that account.
('42', 428, 1, 17, 797228) The very idea is enough to make one blush.
('42', 428, 1, 18, 797271) Ahimsa is not a mere matter of dietetics, it transcends it.
('42', 428, 1, 19, 797331) What a man eats or drinks matters little; it is the self denial, the self restraint behind it that matters.
('42', 428, 1, 20, 797439) By all means practise as much restraint in the choice of the articles of your diet as you like.
('42', 428, 1, 21, 797535) The restraint is commendable, even necessary, but it touches only the fringe of ahimsa.
('42', 428, 1, 22, 797623) A man may allow himself a wide latitude in the matter of diet and yet may be a personification of ahimsa and compel our homage, if his heart overflows with love and melts at another’s woe, and has been purged of all passions.
('42', 428, 1, 23, 797849) On the other hand a man always overscrupulous in diet is an utter stranger to ahimsa and a pitiful wretch, if he is a slave to selfishness and passions and is hard of heart.
('42', 428, 1, 24, 798023) Whether India should have an army or not, whether or not one may offer armed resistance to Government, these are momentous
('42', 429, 0, 1, 798146) 430 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 429, 1, 2, 798188) questions that we shall have to solve one day.
('42', 429, 1, 3, 798235) The Congress has in its creed already furnished an answer to them in part.
('42', 429, 1, 4, 798310) But important as these questions are, they do not much concern the man in the street, they do not touch the aspect of ahimsa with which an educationist or a student is concerned.
('42', 429, 1, 5, 798489) Ahimsa in relation to the life of a student stands quite apart from these questions of high politics.
('42', 429, 1, 6, 798591) Ahimsa in education must have an obvious bearing of the mutual relations of the students.
('42', 429, 1, 7, 798681) Where the whole atmosphere is redolent with the pure fragrance of ahimsa, boys and girls studying together will live like brothers and sisters, in freedom and yet in self imposed restraints; the students will be bound to the teachers in ties of filial love, mutual respect and mutual trust.
('42', 429, 1, 8, 798972) This pure atmosphere will of itself be a continual object lesson in ahimsa.
('42', 429, 1, 9, 799048) The students brought up in such an atmosphere will always distinguish themselves by their charity and breadth of view, and a special talent for service.
('42', 429, 1, 10, 799201) Social evils will cease to present any difficulty to them, the very intensity of their love being enough to burn out those evils.
('42', 429, 1, 11, 799331) For instance, the very idea of child marriage will appear repugnant to them.
('42', 429, 1, 12, 799408) They will not even think of penalizing the parents of brides by demanding dowries from them.
('42', 429, 1, 13, 799501) And how dare they after marriages regard their wives as chattel or simply a means of gratifying their lust?
('42', 429, 1, 14, 799609) How will a young man brought up in such an environment of ahimsa ever think of fighting a brother of his own or a different faith?
('42', 429, 1, 15, 799740) At any rate no one will think of calling himself a votary of ahimsa and do all or any of these things.
('42', 429, 1, 16, 799843) To sum up: Ahimsa is a weapon of matchless potency.
('42', 429, 1, 17, 799895) It is the summum bonum of life.
('42', 429, 1, 18, 799927) It is an attribute of the brave, in fact it is their all.
('42', 429, 1, 19, 799985) It does not come within reach of the coward.
('42', 429, 1, 20, 800030) It is no wooden or lifeless dogma, but a living and a life giving force.
('42', 429, 1, 21, 800103) It is the special attribute of the soul.
('42', 429, 1, 22, 800144) That is why it has been described as the highest dharma (law).
('42', 429, 1, 23, 800207) In the hands of the educationist therefore it ought to take the form of the purest love ever fresh, an ever gushing spring of life expressing itself in every act.
('42', 429, 1, 24, 800370) Ill will cannot stand in its presence.
('42', 429, 1, 25, 800409) The sun of ahimsa carries all the hosts of darkness such as hatred, anger and malice before himself.
('42', 429, 1, 26, 800510) Ahimsa in education shines clear and far and can no more be hidden, even as the sun cannot be hidden by any means.
('42', 429, 1, 27, 800625) One may be sure that when the Vidyapith is filled with the atmosphere of this ahimsa, its students will no more be troubled by puzzling conundrums.

('42', 430, 2, 3, 800853) PRICE OF A BRIDEGROOM
('42', 430, 3, 4, 800875) A correspondent writes as follows about the cruel hardship of finding a husband: 1
('42', 430, 4, 5, 800958) It is indeed an evil custom for the father to sell his daughter, but the very limit of depravity is reached when the bridegroom accepts money from the bride’s father as a price for the favour of marrying her.
('42', 430, 4, 6, 801167) The father of a daughter should vow not to pay this penalty, the daughter should be permitted to grow up and a grown up girl should not even look at a mercenary young man.
('42', 430, 4, 7, 801339) Marriage is not one’s supreme duty in life.
('42', 430, 4, 8, 801383) Marriages which have been contracted with a mercenary motive are not marriages but base deals.
('42', 430, 4, 9, 801478) Young men in this age should shun such deals.
('42', 430, 4, 10, 801524) They should realize that enjoying the good things of life or receiving education by fleecing the father in law is a sin.
('42', 430, 5, 11, 801645) TYRANNY OF SADHUS
('42', 430, 6, 12, 801663) One of the questions asked by the correspondent is as follows: 2
('42', 430, 7, 13, 801728) Those who tyrannize people in this way do not deserve to be called sadhus.
('42', 430, 7, 14, 801803) In this country where people are deceived by garments, those who wear the saffron robe or wear only a langoti are worshipped as sadhus.
('42', 430, 7, 15, 801939) No one can become a sadhu by virtue of his dress alone.
('42', 430, 7, 16, 801995) Thousands of persons who are the very opposite of sadhus dress themselves like sadhus and roam around this country.
('42', 430, 7, 17, 802111) Villagers need not be afraid of persons who pose as sadhus or have been proved to be the very opposite.
('42', 430, 7, 18, 802215) They should know how to recognize genuine sadhus and rid themselves of the fear of the wicked.
('42', 430, 7, 19, 802310) They should cultivate the strength to oppose them.
('42', 430, 7, 20, 802361) It is necessary for educated persons to go into the villages in order to rid them of the two enemies of fear and superstition.
('42', 430, 7, 21, 802488) Sardar Vallabhbhai has pointed out to the whole of India the royal road for entering the villages.
('42', 430, 7, 22, 802587) A good many such activities will now be carried on as in Bardoli as part of the constructive programme and the people will be taught new object lessons.

('42', 431, 1, 2, 802819) IN WHAT DOES DHARMA CONSIST?
('42', 431, 2, 3, 802848) The following is the last question 1 asked by this correspondent: I have known from childhood the aversion of the Jains to eating tubers and bulbs.
('42', 431, 2, 4, 802996) However, I have been unable to understand why they are forbidden by religion.
('42', 431, 2, 5, 803074) One can understand the idea that there is a larger number of living creatures clinging to such roots, but I do not see non violence in making such subtle distinctions.
('42', 431, 2, 6, 803242) The Jain who, although he has never eaten potatoes, etc., deceives people every day, is far more guilty of violence than the honest business man who eats potatoes regularly.
('42', 431, 2, 7, 803416) The violence committed by the latter proceeds from his intellectual attitude and does not touch his heart whereas he who deceives others kills his own soul.
('42', 431, 2, 8, 803573) Self control as such is good.
('42', 431, 2, 9, 803603) It is commendable for mankind, steeped in violence though it is, to practise some non violence in its eating habits.
('42', 431, 2, 10, 803720) It is proper that we should deliberately cultivate compassion even for plant life.
('42', 431, 2, 11, 803803) It is necessary to give up pampering the palate in order to acquire control over one’s senses.
('42', 431, 2, 12, 803898) Though admitting all this, though I am accustomed to a life of self denial and though I have happy and close associations with jains, my heart positively refuses to see any great religious merit in avoiding the use of potatoes, etc.
('42', 431, 2, 13, 804131) Not eating them seems to have no connection at all with one’s character.
('42', 431, 2, 14, 804204) I feel that our ancestors must have started making subtle distinctions between what should be eaten and what should not be eaten at a time when the religious spirit was at a low ebb.
('42', 431, 2, 15, 804387) Those who wish to give up potatoes, etc., in deference to common practice may do so.
('42', 431, 2, 16, 804472) But such practice cannot be made the basis of one’s religion and the matter should not become a subject of dispute between a husband and wife.

('42', 431, 5, 20, 804679) Following the announcement of Shri Nagindas’s gift of rupees one lakh, he has been receiving letters concerning the gift and making suggestions.
('42', 431, 5, 21, 804824) He has passed these on to me, and I, in turn, have handed them over to Kakasaheb Kalelkar.
('42', 431, 5, 22, 804915) The reader will find published in
('42', 431, 6, 23, 804949) 1 Not translated here.

('42', 432, 0, 1, 805105) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 433
('42', 432, 1, 2, 805149) this issue that part of Kakasaheb’s letter to Shri Nagindas which deals with the scheme itself and explains it, so that Gujaratis may not remain in the dark about how and in what manner that gift is going to be utilized.
('42', 432, 1, 3, 805370) From this the reader will see that the scheme is divided into three parts.
('42', 432, 1, 4, 805445) 1. In the first place, it consists in training some students to become teachers or workers who will be able to serve the people, or rather, educate them.
('42', 432, 1, 5, 805599) It is obvious that such service, if it is to benefit the people, should necessarily be rural service.
('42', 432, 1, 6, 805701) 2. Secondly, establishment through these teachers of rural schools, which would be mobile in the first instance and become permanent later on.
('42', 432, 1, 7, 805844) 3. Thirdly, preparing suitable literature and getting it prepared by others.
('42', 432, 1, 8, 805921) Readers will see that the scope of this scheme is both ambitious and large.
('42', 432, 1, 9, 805997) Shri Nagindas’s philanthropy will have borne fruit if it is implemented.
('42', 432, 1, 10, 806070) This task cannot be accomplished in a hurry.
('42', 432, 1, 11, 806115) The scheme seeks to break new ground.
('42', 432, 1, 12, 806153) Till now education has served the needs of city life, if it has served any purpose at all.
('42', 432, 1, 13, 806244) I deliberately say “if it has served any purpose at all”.
('42', 432, 1, 14, 806302) I fear, or rather I hold, that since education so far has not been of a national character, it is found not to have served even the needs of city life.
('42', 432, 1, 15, 806454) It was planned to support foreign rule, and that is what we find it has done, This character of our education has resulted in preparing a bureaucratic class of servants and copy writing clerks.
('42', 432, 1, 16, 806648) The scheme described above has to make its way through this atmosphere.
('42', 432, 1, 17, 806720) Hence its implementation will necessarily take some time.
('42', 432, 1, 18, 806778) Kakasaheb has estimated that its implementation will take ten years and that is not too long a time.
('42', 432, 1, 19, 806879) It may conceivably happen that during this period, the public comes to be fired with widespread enthusiasm similar to that of 1921 which would also be of a permanent nature, and the required number of students and persons fit to impart education are immediately available.
('42', 432, 1, 20, 807152) If that happens, we may safely hope that the task will be completed within a shorter period.
('42', 432, 1, 21, 807245) The programme should be framed in conformity with present circumstances.
('42', 432, 1, 22, 807318) Kakasaheb is determined not to take up anything in haste without due deliberation.
('42', 432, 1, 23, 807401) He wishes to proceed gradually but on a sure foundation, as an educationist should do.
('42', 433, 0, 1, 807488) 434 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 433, 1, 2, 807530) Not only is Shri Nagindas’s gift large in itself, but I also find from his letter that he has handed over all his savings to be used for educational purposes.
('42', 433, 1, 3, 807689) This increases further the value of his contribution and adds to my responsibility as well as Kakasaheb’s.

('42', 435, 2, 3, 810794) Niranjan Patnaik who represents the All India Spinners’ Association in Utkal writes a letter from which I take the following:
('42', 435, 3, 4, 810920) For some months past the selling work of the Utkal Branch of the All India Spinners’ Association has not been quite satisfactory.
('42', 435, 3, 5, 811050) Production work is going on quite well, the present rate of production being about Rs.1,000 a month.
('42', 435, 3, 6, 811151) At your suggestion we have started two new centres in the more distressed areas,—at Aul in Cuttack District and Tihidi in the Balasore District—these two centres have now on their rolls nearly 300 spinners and their yarn production up to date has come to nearly nine maunds (I maund = 80 lb.) most of which is 12s to 15s and some even 20s.
('42', 435, 3, 7, 811491) The sales, however, are low.
('42', 435, 3, 8, 811520) Last year we sold on an average Rs. 2,741 per month; during the current year, though we sold nearly Rs. 20,000 worth a few weeks before and during your visit to the province, there was a fall subsequent to that.
('42', 435, 3, 9, 811732) That is, though the current year’s average monthly sale would be nearly Rs. 3,500, the sale during the last few months went down even below Rs. 2,000 per month.
('42', 435, 3, 10, 811893) The result is that our khadi stock is now nearly Rs. 40,000. Last year our gross profit was 10.3 per cent, and our prices this year also are fixed on that basis.
('42', 435, 3, 11, 812055) I take a typical variety of production and show below what relation the cost of production bears to sale price: Shirting piece 10 yds.

('42', 435, 7, 24, 812859) I have requested the Secretary of the All India Spinners’ Association to help us to sell our stock.
('42', 435, 7, 25, 812959) If you consider that the matter might usefully be mentioned in the columns of Young India, kindly help us.
('42', 435, 7, 26, 813066) Having faith in khadi and faith in the people I did tell Niranja
('42', 436, 0, 1, 813131) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 437
('42', 436, 1, 2, 813175) Babu during my Utkal tour last year that he should concentrat on production.
('42', 436, 1, 3, 813252) It was not possible to see those blank eyes of skeletons and stand still when one had work for them.
('42', 436, 1, 4, 813353) The reader will be surprised to learn that Utkal khadi is not cheaper than khadi from the other provinces except perhaps Gujarat.
('42', 436, 1, 5, 813483) The reason is that the people being more helpless than elsewhere, every new introduction carries more cost than it would in ordinary circumstances.
('42', 436, 1, 6, 813631) The tendency however is to bring down the prices as efficiency and production grow.
('42', 436, 1, 7, 813715) Meanwhile, appeal must be made to the philanthropy and patriotism of the people to take up this khadi and thus help the paupers of Orissa.
('42', 436, 1, 8, 813854) The analysis of cost given in the letter shows that the bulk of the money goes directly into the pockets of the poor people.
('42', 436, 1, 9, 813979) Only Rs. 0 7 4 out of Rs. 6 l1 6 go towards part payment of overhead charges which too after all, pay the middle class workers who man the khadi service.
('42', 436, 1, 10, 814133) Thus in khadi production there is no overlapping.
('42', 436, 1, 11, 814183) It means pure addition, be it ever so slight, to the wealth of the country, and a fresh avenue of honourable employment for honest middle class young men without the necessity of their having to pass through English schools and produce at least matriculation certificates if not higher.
('42', 436, 1, 12, 814470) There are two ways of helping to clear the surplus stock, either by buying the khadi for personal use or by paying a bounty towards reduction of the price of the khadi so that it could be sold at cheaper rates to poor local people.
('42', 436, 1, 13, 814702) I hope those who understand the condition of Orissa and appreciate the value of khadi in national economics will adopt one of the two courses suggested by me.
('42', 436, 1, 14, 814861) The address of the head office of the Utkal Branch of the All India Spinners’ Association is Swaraj Ashram, Berhampur, B. N. Rly.
('42', 436, 2, 15, 814991) Young India, 6 9 1928
('42', 436, 3, 16, 815013) 504. AFTER LUCKNOW
('42', 436, 4, 17, 815032) The most brilliant victory achieved at Lucknow 1 following as it does closely on the heels of Bardoli makes a happy conjunction of events.
('42', 436, 4, 18, 815171) Pandit Motilalji is today the’ proudest man in India and has every reason to be so.
('42', 436, 4, 19, 815255) But even he could have done nothing if
('42', 436, 5, 20, 815294) 1 Where the All Parties Conference met from August 28 to 30 and unanimously endorsed the Nehru Committee Report in favour of Dominion self government for India
('42', 437, 0, 1, 815454) 438 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 437, 1, 2, 815496) everyone had not conspired to make the proceedings a success.
('42', 437, 1, 3, 815558) It would have been easy for the Hindus or the Mussalmans to block the way.
('42', 437, 1, 4, 815633) The Sikhs could have done likewise.
('42', 437, 1, 5, 815669) But no one had the heart to destroy the patient labours of the Nehru Committee.
('42', 437, 1, 6, 815749) Little wonder that Pandit Malaviyaji the irrepressible optimist said that swaraj would be attained in 1930. The honours for the happy result must however be shared with Pandit Nehru by Dr. Ansari.
('42', 437, 1, 7, 815946) His invisible help was much greater than his visible and tactful guidance of the proceedings at Lucknow.
('42', 437, 1, 8, 816051) He was ever at the beck should call of the Nehru Committee.
('42', 437, 1, 9, 816111) He used all his unrivalled influence with the Mussalmans in disarming their opposition.
('42', 437, 1, 10, 816199) Hindus could not resist his transparent honesty and equally transparent nationalism.
('42', 437, 1, 11, 816284) The Liberals led by Sir Tej Bahadur Sapru lent a weight to the Conference which it would otherwise have lacked.
('42', 437, 1, 12, 816396) I join Dr. Besant in her wish that they would re enter the national organization.
('42', 437, 1, 13, 816478) They need not lose their identity even as the Hindu and Mussalman organizations do not lose theirs.
('42', 437, 1, 14, 816578) The mention of the Liberals brings us to the future work.
('42', 437, 1, 15, 816636) There is still much diplomatic work to be done.
('42', 437, 1, 16, 816684) But more than the diplomatic work is that of forging the sanction.
('42', 437, 1, 17, 816751) Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru truly observed that whether it was Dominion Status or Independence, a proper sanction would be necessary if the national demand was to be enforced.
('42', 437, 1, 18, 816923) Bardoli has shown the way, if the sanction has to be non violent.
('42', 437, 1, 19, 816989) The Congress creed has non violence as its integral part.
('42', 437, 1, 20, 817047) There is no denying the fact that non violence had receded in the background before Bardoli.
('42', 437, 1, 21, 817140) But even as the Nehru report has made unanimous demand possible, Bardoli has brought back the vanishing faith in non violence.
('42', 437, 1, 22, 817267) If then we are sure of the sanction, we need not worry whether swaraj is otherwise spelt Dominion Status or Independence.
('42', 437, 1, 23, 817389) Dominion Status can easily become more than Independence, if we have sanction to back it.
('42', 437, 1, 24, 817479) Independence can easily become at farce, if it lacks sanction.
('42', 437, 1, 25, 817542) What is in a name if we have the reality?
('42', 437, 1, 26, 817584) A rose smells just as sweet whether you know it by that name or any other.
('42', 437, 1, 27, 817659) Let us therefore make up our minds as to whether it is to be non violence or violence and let the rank and file work for the sanction in real earnest even as the diplomats must work at constitution making .
('42', 437, 2, 28, 817866) Young India, 6 9 1928
('42', 438, 0, 1, 817888) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 439
('42', 438, 1, 2, 817932) 505. OUR POVERTY
('42', 438, 2, 3, 817949) It is to be hoped that the reader has followed the carefully and ably written articles of Prof.
('42', 438, 2, 4, 818045) C. N. Vakil which he recently contributed to this journal on the problem of India’s poverty.
('42', 438, 2, 5, 818138) Sam Higginbottom sent me a circular letter propounding the following four questions:
('42', 438, 3, 6, 818223) 1. What are the tests of poverty?
('42', 438, 4, 7, 818257) 2. Whether India is richer or poorer today than 25 years ago or a longer period.
('42', 438, 5, 8, 818338) 3. Is poverty in India general or confined to particular groups?
('42', 438, 6, 9, 818403) 4. Causes and remedies.
('42', 438, 6, 10, 818427) As a layman I could but give my evidence on the questions without carrying conviction to a critic.
('42', 438, 6, 11, 818526) I therefore had the important and pertinent questions circulated among economist friends with a request to answer them in some detail if they could make time for the purpose.
('42', 438, 6, 12, 818701) Vakil promptly responded with the articles to which I have drawn attention.
('42', 438, 6, 13, 818777) The series is really not concluded.
('42', 438, 6, 14, 818813) When I came upon the last chapter dealing with the remedies, I observed that it admitted of re writing with a view to fuller and more accurate treatment.
('42', 438, 6, 15, 818967) I am now trying to induce Prof.
('42', 438, 6, 16, 818999) Vakil to re write the chapter if he can possibly find the time and has the inclination.
('42', 438, 6, 17, 819087) If he does send me anything the reader may expect a further instalment 1. Meanwhile, he may regard the series as concluded.
('42', 438, 7, 18, 819211) The articles show clearly and I venture to think conclusively that India is poorer today than 25 years or a longer period ago and that the poverty is general and not confined to groups.
('42', 438, 7, 19, 819397) Vakil has applied two tests for approving his proposition.
('42', 438, 7, 20, 819456) He has shown that though during the past 40 years our average income has increased in the ratio of l to 2.74 (and he has accepted top figures in every case) the cost of living has increased in the ratio of 1 to 3.78; in other words we are poorer today to the extent of 2/7 than we were 40 years ago.
('42', 438, 7, 21, 819756) He then examines the population figures and arrives at the same conclusion by showing that, whilst the population has increased, the capacity for coping with the increase has not only not kept pace with the increase but has probably deteriorated.
('42', 438, 8, 22, 820003) 1 C. N. Vakil’s new series of articles under the title “Remedies of Poverty” appeared in Young India dated September 27, October 4, 11 and 18, 1928.
('42', 439, 0, 1, 820152) 440 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 439, 1, 2, 820194) Vakil has enumerated the following six causes for this growing poverty:
('42', 439, 2, 3, 820266) 1. Not enough work for the vast mass of the agricultural population during the off season.
('42', 439, 2, 4, 820357) 2. The social system which imposes the burden upon one person of supporting a large family.
('42', 439, 2, 5, 820449) 3. The presence of a large number of able bodied beggars miscalled sadhus.
('42', 439, 2, 6, 820524) 4. Enervating climate.
('42', 439, 2, 7, 820547) 5. Resignation to fate and consequent want of determination to fight against poverty.
('42', 439, 2, 8, 820633) 6.Faulty educational system.
('42', 439, 2, 9, 820662) Whilst these are contributory causes or more or less value, With the exception of the first none seems to me to go to the root of the matter.
('42', 439, 2, 10, 820804) There is no doubt enough in the chapters to show that foreign exploitation of India is a cause of poverty.
('42', 439, 2, 11, 820911) But in collecting the causes the Professor has evidently felt some delicacy about mentioning what is obviously a primary cause.
('42', 439, 2, 12, 821039) This exploitation is a hydra headed monster taking a variety of shapes to suit given occasions.
('42', 439, 2, 13, 821135) The marine, the military, the currency, the railway and the revenue policy of the foreign Government is directed deliberately to promote an explo itation such as the world has never before witnessed.
('42', 439, 2, 14, 821335) Poverty of India will never be removed so long as the exploitation continues unabated.
('42', 439, 2, 15, 821422) Even the spinning wheel or any other subsidiary occupation that may be provided for the millions of peasantry will bring only partial relief, if the terrible drain, as Dadabhai Naoroji called it, is not stopped.
('42', 439, 2, 16, 821634) He, therefore, who would explore the remedies for removing poverty has to tackle first the question of stopping the continuous drain.
('42', 439, 3, 17, 821768) Young India, 6 9 1928
('42', 439, 4, 18, 821790) 506. LETTER TO JOHN HAYNES HOLMES
('42', 439, 5, 19, 821824) SATYAGRAHA ASHRAM, SABARMATI, September 7, 1928
('42', 439, 6, 20, 821872) DEAR FRIEND, Mr. Andrews is abridging “My Experiments with Truth” for an English firm.
('42', 439, 6, 21, 821959) I have not interfered with his work thinking that it does not in any way affect the Macmillan Company.
('42', 439, 6, 22, 822062) But on rereading the agreement between the Macmillan Company and me, I find there is
('42', 440, 0, 1, 822147) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 441
('42', 440, 1, 2, 822191) just a possibility that the Company may think that any publication of an abridgement will interfere with the contract.
('42', 440, 1, 3, 822310) If so, please let me know.
('42', 440, 1, 4, 822337) Personally I feel that the contract is of no value to the Macmillan Company seeing that the chapters are still running on and are likely so to do for many more months.
('42', 440, 1, 5, 822505) If the Company desires it, I am quite willing to cancel the agreement.
('42', 440, 1, 6, 822576) I am not at all anxious to make money from the publication of the chapters in book form.
('42', 440, 1, 7, 822665) But I would like not to interfere with interim abridgements, etc., being published.
('42', 440, 1, 8, 822749) If the Macmillan Company will at once publish the chapters in several volumes, they may then control abridgements or selections; but if they will not publish them in volumes, nor cancel the agreement, they should not mind abridgements being published in England or elsewhere outside India till the whole thing is ready for delivery into their hands.

('42', 444, 7, 14, 829445) 513. SPEECH AT DEAF AND DUMB SCHOOL, AHMEDABAD
('42', 444, 8, 15, 829492) September 7, 1928
('42', 444, 9, 16, 829510) My association with this school dates back to the year 1915. Despite numerous engagements, I have come here at the request of Seth Mangaldas and Pranshankar.
('42', 444, 9, 17, 829668) This is a small school for the deaf and dumb, but I have undertaken the task of running a school for thousands of the deaf and dumb and of removing the privation caused by ignorance.
('42', 444, 9, 18, 829851) A person like Seth Mangaldas cannot get away with it by merely donating a small sum.
('42', 444, 9, 19, 829936) One business man of Ahmedabad alone can run such a school.
('42', 444, 9, 20, 829995) Ahmedabad has the capacity to run many such schools.
('42', 444, 9, 21, 830048) We can show our gratitude to God for gifts of speech and sight by rendering some service to such deaf and dumb persons.
('42', 444, 9, 22, 830168) Shri Pranshankar gave you a report of the school but did not tell you how it came into existence.
('42', 444, 9, 23, 830266) One of his own sons was deaf and dumb and because he was convinced that he should receive an education, he began teaching him; later on because he combined the welfare of others with self interest, this school came into existence.
('42', 444, 9, 24, 830497) It should be a common thing to combine social service with self interest.
('42', 444, 9, 25, 830571) But it is difficult to persuade people in Ahmedabad where everyone has started accumulating wealth, to do welfare work while pursuing
('42', 445, 0, 1, 830705) 446 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 445, 1, 2, 830747) their own interest.
('42', 445, 1, 3, 830767) Shri Pranshankar has given figures to show there are only three schools for the 70,000 deaf and dumb in the province and out of two lakhs of deaf mutes in India only 500 are looked after.
('42', 445, 1, 4, 830955) From this we see that their education has been neglected.
('42', 445, 1, 5, 831013) We enable them to fill their stomachs by giving them alms but neglect the important task of educating them.
('42', 445, 1, 6, 831121) There is a saying that an idle man rides on the shoulders of two.
('42', 445, 1, 7, 831187) We should not make these deaf mutes mere idlers but should train them to make a living.
('42', 445, 1, 8, 831275) Ahmedabad should not look elsewhere for help for such schools but on the contrary it should give generous donations to deserving outsiders.
('42', 445, 1, 9, 831415) Talking of Ahmedabad, I will draw your attention to one more matter.
('42', 445, 1, 10, 831484) I have just come across a book written by Dr. Hariprasad 1 for the Gujarat Vernacular Society.
('42', 445, 1, 11, 831579) He says in it that of all Indian cities Ahmedabad has the highest death rate.
('42', 445, 1, 12, 831657) Since among countries India has the highest death rate, it follows that death rate in Ahmedabad is the highest in the world.
('42', 445, 1, 13, 831782) I receive visitors from America, England and different parts of the world and I have to bow down in shame when they talk of the dirty lanes and streets of Ahmedabad.
('42', 445, 1, 14, 831948) We should improve this state of affairs.
('42', 445, 1, 15, 831989) We can make Ahmedabad a beautiful city if we use our intelligence and physical strength.
('42', 445, 1, 16, 832078) Finally, I thank you for giving me the opportunity to lay the foundation stone of this school and hope that the school would prosper from day to day.
('42', 445, 1, 17, 832228) Let the educated class make money, but instead of amassing wealth for themselves they should give its benefit generously to others—this is my humble prayer.
('42', 445, 1, 18, 832385) [From Gujarati]
('42', 445, 2, 19, 832401) Prajabandhu, 9 9 1928

('42', 449, 6, 14, 837790) 521. ‘WHAT DO CHILDREN UNDERSTAND?’
('42', 449, 7, 15, 837826) A student of the Gujarat Vidyapith writes to say: 1
('42', 449, 8, 16, 837878) I have been unable to go through the articles from which extracts have been given in this letter.
('42', 449, 8, 17, 837976) It is not always possible to interpret rightly a passage taken from an article without reference to the context.
('42', 449, 8, 18, 838089) Nevertheless, it is not difficult for me to reply to the question without reading the original article, as the idea in the passages quoted above is based on my own experience.
('42', 449, 8, 19, 838265) In this context, the reader should understand a child to mean not a child of two but a child of the age at which he or she is normally admitted to school.
('42', 449, 8, 20, 838420) From the fact that children fall asleep when I read the Gita, it cannot be concluded that their understanding is deficient.
('42', 449, 8, 21, 838544) It may be said that I am unable to create interest in my reading the Gita, it may even be the case that the child is tired at that time.
('42', 449, 8, 22, 838681) I have often seen children asleep while they are being taught arithmetic, told amusing
('42', 449, 9, 23, 838768) 1 Renunciation
('42', 450, 0, 1, 838783) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 451
('42', 450, 1, 2, 838827) stories or when taken to see a play.
('42', 450, 1, 3, 838864) I have also seen adults dozing while the Gita or other scriptures are being read.
('42', 450, 1, 4, 838946) Hence, when considering the question posed above, we should leave out of account the fact of children falling asleep or displaying lack of interest.
('42', 450, 1, 5, 839095) These doubts should not arise in the mind of anyone to whom it is as clear as daylight that the child’s soul existed before he or she was born, that the soul has no beginning and knows no such states as childhood, youth and old age.
('42', 450, 1, 6, 839328) It is because of our connection with the physical form, because of the current trends of thought and because of our disinclination to go deep into the matter that we conclude that the child knows only how to play or, at the most can write the alphabet and, going further, can memorize the tongue twisting names of the rivers, etc., of Europe and America and understand the history and learn the names, although difficult to pronounce, of the kings, plunderers and killers of various countries.
('42', 450, 1, 7, 839822) My own experience is the very opposite of this.
('42', 450, 1, 8, 839870) The ideal of soul, truth and love can easily be put before children in language which they can understand.
('42', 450, 1, 9, 839977) I have heard not one but many children, who have no knowledge of the world, ask about a dead person:
('42', 450, 2, 10, 840078) This letter is not translated here.
('42', 450, 2, 11, 840114) The correspondent had stated that Gandhiji’s writings showed that he expected too much from children.
('42', 450, 2, 12, 840216) “Where has this man’s soul gone?” A child who asks this question can easily be taught about the soul.
('42', 450, 2, 13, 840318) Crores of illiterate Indian children realize the distinction between truth and falsehood, between love and hate, from the very age that they begin to understand things.
('42', 450, 2, 14, 840487) Is there a child who would not recognize the nectar like stream of love or, the embers of wrath glowing or blazing from his parents’ eyes?
('42', 450, 2, 15, 840626) The student who has put the question seems to have forgotten his own childhood.
('42', 450, 2, 16, 840706) I therefore wish to remind him of the fact that he had experience of parental love before he acquired a knowledge of the alphabet.
('42', 450, 2, 17, 840837) Love, truth and the soul would have been forgotten long ago had these required language in order to reveal themselves.
('42', 450, 2, 18, 840956) The passages quoted by the correspondent do not advise putting abstract truth before children.
('42', 450, 2, 19, 841051) but explain that we should exhibit before them immortal virtues like truth and prove to them that they, too, have them.
('42', 450, 2, 20, 841171) In brief, formation of character should have priority over knowledge of the alphabet.
('42', 450, 2, 21, 841257) If this order is reversed, the attempt would be like putting the cart before the horse and making it push the cart with its nose, and would meet with the same success as the latter
('42', 451, 0, 1, 841438) 452 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 451, 1, 2, 841480) course.
('42', 451, 1, 3, 841488) It is because he realized the truth of this that Darwin’s contemporary, the scientist Wallace, said at the age of ninety that in basic moral standards he saw in the so called educated and reformed nations no progress over the Negroes who are regarded as uncivilized.
('42', 451, 1, 4, 841755) If we were not under the spell of the various external temptations that exist today, we would realize the truth of Wallace’s statement and plan and frame our educational curriculum in a different manner.
('42', 451, 1, 5, 841959) I will ask a counter question in reply to the question regarding the ten headed Ravana.
('42', 451, 1, 6, 842047) Which of the two ideas can be more readily explained to a child?
('42', 451, 1, 7, 842112) Is it easier to convince him that a ten headed creature which could never have been created existed in the form of Ravana, or is it easier to make him aware of the ten headed Ravana who lives secretly like a thief in the heart of each one of us?
('42', 451, 1, 8, 842358) In believing that the child is devoid of imagination and intellectual powers, we do him grave injustice and belittle ourselves.
('42', 451, 1, 9, 842486) To say that a child does understand does not imply that he understands things without our explaining them to him.
('42', 451, 1, 10, 842600) Despite every effort to convince a child to that effect, he will not accept the idea that a human being with ten heads can actually exist, whereas he will understand the idea of the ten headed Ravana who has entered our hearts as soon as it is explained to him.
('42', 451, 1, 11, 842862) I hope now that the student will not ask me why I do not feel ashamed to read Tulsidas’s Ramayana and Vyasa’s Gita before children.
('42', 451, 1, 12, 842994) I do not wish to teach the children the philosophical implications of the idea of karma, tyaga or sthitaprajna 1 I do not believe that I myself have acquired such knowledge or rather I know I have not.
('42', 451, 1, 13, 843196) Perhaps I would not understand books which are full of philosophical discussions about karma, etc., and, even if I do understand them with difficulty, I would certainly be bored.
('42', 451, 1, 14, 843375) And when one is bored one may even fall asleep.
('42', 451, 1, 15, 843423) However, when I think of spinning or doing work as sacrifice for the benefit of the millions and giving up self indulgence so that I might do that, sweet slumber would seem like poison to me and I would wake up.
('42', 451, 1, 16, 843635) It is my unshakable faith, based on experience, that if the Gita and such other works are explained in a simple manner to children, the effort will certainly benefit them in later years.

('42', 452, 1, 2, 843927) 522. LUCKNOW
('42', 452, 2, 3, 843940) If the Bardoli victory is part of history, so will be the victory at Lucknow.
('42', 452, 2, 4, 844018) Bardoli has shown the way to organic swaraj—to Ramarajya, while Lucknow has opened the gates of constitutional swaraj.
('42', 452, 2, 5, 844137) Both things were essential.
('42', 452, 2, 6, 844165) Whereas learned and politically astute leaders were required for the Lucknow swaraj, the ordinary, illiterate masses served the purpose for the Bardoli swaraj.
('42', 452, 2, 7, 844325) While the intellect played the chief role in the one case, faith did that in the other.
('42', 452, 2, 8, 844413) The fact that the meeting at Lucknow was held immediately after the victory at Bardoli was not deliberately contrived.
('42', 452, 2, 9, 844532) Hence those who have faith in God would look upon it as an indication of His will.
('42', 452, 2, 10, 844615) Pandit Motilal deserves to be complimented for the people’s victory in Lucknow.
('42', 452, 2, 11, 844695) Were it not for his single minded devotion to the cause, his ability, his hard work and his faith, the task would not have been accomplished.
('42', 452, 2, 12, 844837) The success consists not in the leaders having devised the best constitution, but in their achieving unity over a constitution which preserves everyone’s self respect and safeguards the rights of all.
('42', 452, 2, 13, 845038) Meetings of various parties were being held for many months.
('42', 452, 2, 14, 845099) But it was only in Lucknow that they bore visible fruit.
('42', 452, 2, 15, 845156) This success must be attributed to Pandit Motilalji.
('42', 452, 2, 16, 845209) Dr. Ansari’s name must be added to his.
('42', 452, 2, 17, 845249) Everyone could see that by means of his tact and patience he kept the followers of various parties together.
('42', 452, 2, 18, 845358) However, it is only a few who know of the work that he had been doing behind the scenes for the past few months.
('42', 452, 2, 19, 845471) Success would not have been possible if Dr. Ansari had not stood by the Nehru Committee whenever that was necessary.
('42', 452, 2, 20, 845588) He took full advantage of his love for the Muslims.
('42', 452, 2, 21, 845640) It was impossible for any Hindu to question his ardent patriotism.
('42', 452, 2, 22, 845707) He could thus win the confidence of all.
('42', 452, 2, 23, 845748) The presence of the members of the Liberal Party and that of Sir Ali Imam and Dr. Besant added to the distinction and importance of the gathering.
('42', 452, 2, 24, 845895) However, just as the Sardar cannot go to sleep after the victory at Bardoli, similarly Panditji and the other members cannot rest after the Lucknow triumph.
('42', 452, 2, 25, 846052) Bharatbhushan Madan Mohan Malaviya’s happy prophecy about swaraj being established in 1930 will not come true if the remaining tasks are not completed without delay.
('42', 452, 2, 26, 846218) God helps only those who are awake, not those who slumber.
('42', 452, 2, 27, 846277) There is of course the task of mobilizing public opinion behind the Nehru constitution.
('42', 453, 0, 1, 846365) 454 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 453, 1, 2, 846407) the more important task is that of developing the strength to get that constitution accepted.
('42', 453, 1, 3, 846501) Pandit Jawaharlal had reminded the meeting of this fact even at Lucknow.
('42', 453, 1, 4, 846574) Whether you are in favour of Dominion Status or of Independence, it will be necessary to cultivate the strength to secure either.
('42', 453, 1, 5, 846704) Without this strength neither can be won.
('42', 453, 1, 6, 846746) Swaraj is not going to descend on us from the heavens.
('42', 453, 1, 7, 846801) It will not be received as a gift from the British Empire either.
('42', 453, 1, 8, 846867) It can only be the reward of our own efforts.
('42', 453, 1, 9, 846913) The very word swaraj means effort by the nation.
('42', 453, 1, 10, 846962) What does a goat know of swaraj?
('42', 453, 1, 11, 846995) Can she taste its sweetness merely because lions and other beasts of prey let it alone?
('42', 453, 1, 12, 847083) If not the lion, his cousins will be there to eat her up.
('42', 453, 1, 13, 847141) We are in the same position.
('42', 453, 1, 14, 847170) No one will be able to stand in our way when we have developed the strength to win swaraj.
('42', 453, 1, 15, 847261) Everyone’s freedom is within his own grasp.
('42', 453, 1, 16, 847305) There are two alternatives before us.
('42', 453, 1, 17, 847343) The one is that of violence, the other of non violence; the one of physical strength, the other of soul force; the one of hatred, the other of love; the one of disorder, the other of peace; one that is demoniac, the other that is godly.
('42', 453, 1, 18, 847580) Bardoli has taught us an object lesson in peace.
('42', 453, 1, 19, 847629) The path of peace is the one mentioned in the Congress pledge.

('42', 453, 1, 21, 847786) After that victory, it seems to have recovered it.

('42', 454, 1, 2, 848327) 523. TEMPERANCE WORK IN SURAT DISTRICT
('42', 454, 2, 3, 848366) Shrimati Mithubehn Petit, by whose initiative a temperance league has been set up for the Surat district, has sent the following note 1: Sardar Vallabhbhai has very often said that he had received strong support from Mithubehn.
('42', 454, 2, 4, 848594) This Parsi lady, who had never before suffered any hardships, lived in peasant homes as one of them.
('42', 454, 2, 5, 848695) She was content with their simple food and, despite her frail constitution and despite the absence of the comforts she was accustomed to, she managed to keep physically fit and work ceaselessly day and night.
('42', 454, 2, 6, 848904) Through her own bravery she has taught the lesson of courage to the men and women of Bardoli; her untiring efforts have put young men to shame.
('42', 454, 2, 7, 849048) Being in love with khadi she went from door to door hawking khadi and created interest in the people for it.
('42', 454, 2, 8, 849157) As she cannot remain idle for a single moment, Vallabhbhai has given her the name ‘Chanchalbehn’ 2. This lady discovered that liquor was consumed in large quantities in the Surat District.
('42', 454, 2, 9, 849346) She also saw that most of the owners of liquor booths were Parsis.
('42', 454, 2, 10, 849413) She, therefore, decided to take up temperance work in the entire Surat District, and now, through her initiative, the league referred to above has been established.
('42', 454, 2, 11, 849578) From the names of the members of the executive committee I could see that Mithubehn intends to exact hard work from them.
('42', 454, 2, 12, 849700) I hope that they will not spare themselves.
('42', 454, 2, 13, 849744) Mithubehn will not let them easily.
('42', 454, 2, 14, 849780) If this league succeeds in its aim, its success will be a very valuable contribution to the constructive work undertaken in Bardoli, and it will not only save lakhs of rupees in the Surat District, but will also have an effect throughout the country.
('42', 454, 2, 15, 850031) Not only are twenty crores of rupees thrown away every year through the consumption of liquor, but it also destroys the moral character of millions of people and ruins innumerable families.
('42', 454, 2, 16, 850221) Anyone who has really developed interest in khadi immediately sees this.
('42', 454, 2, 17, 850294) Mithubehn has seen it and her heroic spirit has now inspired her to take up this gigantic task.
('42', 454, 2, 18, 850390) May God grant her good health and strength.

('42', 455, 1, 2, 850615) 524. CASTE DISTINCTIONS AT MEALS IN NATIONAL HOSTELS
('42', 455, 2, 3, 850668) One of the letters in Kakasaheb’s increasingly large mail dealt with the subject of caste distinct or at meals.
('42', 455, 2, 4, 850780) He has sent me a copy of his reply to it.
('42', 455, 2, 5, 850822) I give below his ideas in his own words, as they will be of value in guiding the hostels: 1
('42', 455, 3, 6, 850914) Kakasaheb wishes to tread the ground carefully.
('42', 455, 3, 7, 850962) As far as possible, he does not wish to hurt the feelings of either the students or their parents; hence he says: “Only Brahmin cooks prepare meals in the hostel.
('42', 455, 3, 8, 851125) As our rules of purity demand that meals should be prepared in a particular manner, these are observed by the employment of Brahmin cooks.” In my opinion, it will not be possible to insist upon having Brahmin cooks for long.
('42', 455, 3, 9, 851350) It is not true that only Brahmins—in the sense in which the word is used here—are capable of observing the rules of purity.
('42', 455, 3, 10, 851474) Moreover, it is also not a fact that Brahmins will necessarily abide by these rules.
('42', 455, 3, 11, 851559) I have seen many Brahmin cooks who are dirty and who violate the laws of hygiene.
('42', 455, 3, 12, 851641) Everyone who keeps his eyes open will see them.
('42', 455, 3, 13, 851689) I have also come across many Non Brahmin cooks who know and observe the rules of cleanliness and hygiene.
('42', 455, 3, 14, 851795) Hence if we bear in mind the original meaning of the word Brahmin and regard anyone who abides by the laws of purity as a Brahmin, all national hostels will readily be able to follow the rule laid down by Kakasaheb.
('42', 455, 3, 15, 852011) If, only those who are Brahmins by birth are regarded as such, we shall not get many Brahmin cooks who will abide by the rules of purity and those who are available will demand such high salaries and act in such a headstrong manner that it will become impossible to keep them in employment.
('42', 455, 3, 16, 852302) As the Vidyapith worships truth and non violence, it should declare the position as it really is in our hostels.
('42', 455, 3, 17, 852415) It cannot close its eyes to facts either within itself or in the outside world.
('42', 455, 3, 18, 852495) Hence Kakasaheb has stated that caste distinctions at meals have no place in the hostels of the Vidyapith.
('42', 455, 3, 19, 852602) Such distinctions imply distinctions of high and low.
('42', 455, 3, 20, 852656) The varna system, on the other hand, has nothing to do with distinctions of high and low.
('42', 455, 3, 21, 852746) The Brahmin who claims to be high falls and becomes low.
('42', 455, 3, 22, 852803) The world raises high those who regard themselves as low and lead a common man’s life.
('42', 455, 3, 23, 852890) Where is the room for high and low when moksha is the ideal, when non violence is the
('42', 455, 4, 24, 852976) 1 Kalelkar’s reply is not translated here.
('42', 455, 4, 25, 853019) He had stated that the hostels of the Vidyapith did not approve of or encourage such distinctions.
('42', 456, 0, 1, 853118) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 457
('42', 456, 1, 2, 853162) supreme dharma and we believe in the oneness of the atman in all?
('42', 456, 1, 3, 853228) Hence, I think all that we can say in regard to national hostels is that every effort will be made to observe in them all the rules of cleanliness, which means that the true Brahmana dharma will remain their ideal.
('42', 456, 1, 4, 853443) We cannot have as our ideal the practice of Brahmana dharma which concerns itself with outward forms and lacks the true essence, for it is an evil and, therefore, to be shunned.

('42', 456, 3, 7, 853657) 525. MY NOTES
('42', 456, 4, 8, 853671) DISREGARD FOR THE LIVING QUERN
('42', 456, 5, 9, 853702) A volunteer who works in Bardoli writes to say: 1
('42', 456, 6, 10, 853752) The complaint which this volunteer makes can be made about many other classes of people.
('42', 456, 6, 11, 853841) The teeth are an important gift of nature.
('42', 456, 6, 12, 853884) They are a living quern.
('42', 456, 6, 13, 853909) Anyone who ignores it, shortens his life.
('42', 456, 6, 14, 853951) Grain that has been once ripened by the rays of the sun needs no other form of cooking.
('42', 456, 6, 15, 854039) However, ever since man learnt to enjoy tasty food with his palate, he started cooking again what had already been cooked once, with the result that his life span was shortened.
('42', 456, 6, 16, 854217) It may well be that we cannot all at once give up a bad practice which has come down to us from ancient times and cannot altogether dispense with the oven, however, we could save a great deal of time and money if we make minimum use of it.
('42', 456, 6, 17, 854457) We can never eat sun ripened grain in the same quantities as we eat it in cooked form.
('42', 456, 6, 18, 854544) We cannot eat as much of dry food as we can eat food which is soaked and crushed.
('42', 456, 6, 19, 854626) Nature has provided us with nectar in our palate in order to moisten dry food, and with teeth for the purpose of grinding it to paste.
('42', 456, 6, 20, 854761) We ignore both these gifts by becoming slaves of our palate, and thereby we not only commit a crime but also needlessly burden our intestines and shorten our lives, and even during this short life span we fall a prey to many diseases.
('42', 456, 6, 21, 854996) Hence, although we may not be ready to eat uncooked, sun ripened grain and be satisfied with it, we should form the practice of carefully chewing cooked food when eating it.
('42', 456, 7, 22, 855170) 1 The letter is not translated here.
('42', 456, 7, 23, 855207) The correspondent had drawn attention to the common practice of villagers eating wheat or bajri cakes soaked in milk, without chewing them properly.
('42', 457, 0, 1, 855356) 458 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 457, 1, 2, 855398) rice can be chewed, and green vegetables can certainly be eaten uncooked.
('42', 457, 1, 3, 855472) Doctors recommend the latter.
('42', 457, 1, 4, 855502) We get from uncooked vegetables the nutrients that we require.
('42', 457, 1, 5, 855565) They are known as ‘vitamins’ in English, and doctors claim that these vitamins are destroyed as a result of cooking, and that their destruction leads to ill health.

('42', 457, 3, 8, 855766) 526. RELIGIOUS EDUCATION 1
('42', 457, 4, 9, 855793) A student of the Gujarat Vidyapith writes:
('42', 457, 5, 10, 855836) What concrete form ought religious instruction to take in the Vidyapith?
('42', 457, 5, 11, 855909) To me religion means truth and ahimsa or rather truth alone, because truth includes ahimsa, ahimsa being the necessary and indispensable means for its discovery.
('42', 457, 5, 12, 856071) Therefore anything that promotes the practice of these virtues is a means for imparting religious education and the best way to do this, in my opinion, is for the teachers rigorously to practise these virtues in their own person.
('42', 457, 5, 13, 856301) Their very association with the boys, whether on the playground or in the class room, will then give the pupils a fine training in these fundamental virtues.
('42', 457, 5, 14, 856459) So much for instruction in the universal essentials of religion.
('42', 457, 5, 15, 856524) A curriculum of religious instruction should include a study of the tenets of faiths other than one’s own.
('42', 457, 5, 16, 856631) For this purpose the students should be trained to cultivate the habit of understanding and appreciating the doctrines of various great religions of the world in a spirit of reverence and broad minded tolerance.
('42', 457, 5, 17, 856843) This, if properly, done, would help to give them a spiritual assurance and a better appreciation of their own religion.
('42', 457, 5, 18, 856963) There is one rule, however, which should always .
('42', 457, 5, 19, 857013) be kept in mind while studying all great religions and that is that one should study them only through the writings of known votaries of the respective religions.
('42', 457, 5, 20, 857176) For instance, if one wants to study the Bhagavata one should do so not through a translation of it made by a hostile critic but through one prepared by a lover of the Bhagavata.
('42', 457, 5, 21, 857354) Similarly to study the Bible one should study it through
('42', 457, 6, 22, 857411) 1 The Gujarati original of this appeared in Navajivan, 9 9 1928. This is a translation by Pyarelals.
('42', 458, 0, 1, 857512) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 459
('42', 458, 1, 2, 857556) the commentaries of devoted Christians.
('42', 458, 1, 3, 857596) This study of other religions besides one’s own will give one a grasp of the rock bottom unity of all religions and afford a glimpse also of that universal and absolute truth which lies beyond the “dust of creeds and faiths”.
('42', 458, 2, 4, 857822) Let no one even for a moment entertain the fear that a reverent.
('42', 458, 2, 5, 857887) study of other religions is likely to weaken or shake one’s faith in one’s own.
('42', 458, 2, 6, 857967) The Hindu system of philosophy regards all religions as containing the elements of truth in them and enjoins an attitude of respect and reverence towards them all.
('42', 458, 2, 7, 858131) This of course presupposes regard for one’s own religion.
('42', 458, 2, 8, 858189) Study and appreciation of other religions need not cause a weakening of that regard; it should mean extension of that regard to other religions.
('42', 458, 3, 9, 858334) In this respect religion stands on the same footing as culture.
('42', 458, 3, 10, 858398) Just as preservation of one’s own culture does not mean contempt for that of others, but requires assimilation of the best that there may be in all the other cultures, even so should be the case with religion.
('42', 458, 3, 11, 858608) Our present fears and apprehensions are a result of the poisonous atmosphere that has been generated in the country, the atmosphere of mutual hatred, ill will and distrust.
('42', 458, 3, 12, 858781) We are constantly labouring under a nightmare of fear lest someone should stealthily undermine our faith or the faith of those who are dear and near to us.
('42', 458, 3, 13, 858937) But this unnatural state will cease when we have learnt to cultivate respect and tolerance towards other religions and their votaries.
('42', 458, 4, 14, 859072) Young India, 6 12 l928

('42', 461, 0, 1, 862074) 462 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 461, 1, 2, 862116) APPENDIX I
('42', 461, 2, 3, 862127) WHAT IS THE BARDOLI CASE?
('42', 461, 3, 4, 862153) BY MAHADEV DESAI
('42', 461, 4, 5, 862170) In the matter of revision settlements there has been calculated flouting of public opinion and of resolutions of the Legislative Council during recent years.
('42', 461, 4, 6, 862328) In pursuance of the advice of the Joint Parliamentary Committee, “that the process of revising the land revenue assessments ought to be brought under closed regulation by a Statute”, the Bombay Legislative Council passed by a large majority in March 1924 a resolution to the effect that a committee be appointed to consider the question of regulating revision of assessment by legislation, and that “no revision be proceeded with and no new rates under any revised settlement be introduced till the said legislation is brought into effect”.
('42', 461, 4, 7, 862869) The first part of the resolution was carried out by Government appointing the Land Revenue Assesment Committee, but the second part was ignored, and revision settlement of one taluk after another was proceeded with in the teeth of the resolution.
('42', 461, 4, 8, 863116) In the mean time the Land Revenue Committee had set and published its report, and the Bombay Legislative Council in March 1927 passed by a very large majority another resolution recommending to the Governor in Council to give immediate effect to the resolution of March 1924 by effecting necessary legislation after taking into consideration the Report of the Land Revenue Assessment Committee, and “pending such legislation to issue orders to the revenue authorities concerned not to collect the assessment enhanced in revision after the 15th March 1924”.
('42', 461, 4, 9, 863673) The legislation suggested by the Land Revenue Assessment Committee is at present before the Legislative Council, but revision settlements have gone on, almost with the deliberate intention of frustrating the very object of the legislation when it should ultimately come to pass.
('42', 461, 4, 10, 863952) Bardoli is only one of several taluks where there should have been no revision and no levying of new rates in the terms of these resolutions.
('42', 461, 4, 11, 864094) This is a fundamental preliminary objection to the revision settlement in Bardoli, apart from the merits of the case.
('42', 461, 5, 12, 864212) I shall briefly discuss the merits.
('42', 461, 5, 13, 864248) The new Bardoli revision settlement was prepared by Mr. Jayakar who submitted his recommendations in November 1925. He recommended 30 per cent enhancement.
('42', 461, 5, 14, 864404) The Settlement Commissioner Mr. Anderson disagreed with the basis on which Mr. Jayakar had made his recom mendation, adopted a new basis, and recommended 29 per cent.
('42', 461, 5, 15, 864571) Government disagreed with the recommendations of both and fixed 22 per cent.
('42', 461, 5, 16, 864648) The original assessment of the taluk which was Rs. 5,14,762 is under the new revision something over Rs. 6,20,000.
('42', 462, 0, 1, 864763) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 463
('42', 462, 1, 2, 864807) As against this the agriculturists of Bardoli contend that the taluk is assessed right up to the full limit and that there is absolutely no case for enhancement.
('42', 462, 1, 3, 864969) The occupants in the taluk are divided as under according to the size of their holdings :
('42', 462, 2, 4, 865059) 1 to 5 acres 10,379
('42', 462, 3, 5, 865079) 6 to 25 acres 5,936
('42', 462, 4, 6, 865099) 26 to 100 acres 829
('42', 462, 5, 7, 865119) 101to 500 acres 40
('42', 462, 6, 8, 865138) It may be safely assumed that all the occupants having not more than 25 acres cultivate their own land and that those with larger holdings lease their land to the agriculturists.
('42', 462, 6, 9, 865317) This means that 16,315 occupants actually cultivates 1,27,045 acres which is the total occupied area, i.e., each occupant cultivate on an average something like 8 acres of land.
('42', 462, 6, 10, 865495) It is inequitable to go on the strength of rents— economic or uneconomic—enjoyed by a very small fraction, i.e., 869 large landholders.
('42', 462, 6, 11, 865631) The land revenue assessment ought to be fixed having regard to the value of the land held by the 16,315 agriculturists and to the profits of agriculture enjoyed by them under See.
('42', 462, 6, 12, 865811) 107 of the Land Revenue Code.
('42', 462, 6, 13, 865841) The agriculturists of Bardoli contend that assuming the average yield per acre and assuming the very high standard of prices adopted by the Settlement Officer as accurate (though the prices have considerably gone down since the report), an agriculturist cultivating 8 acres of land (the average) does not earn profits entitling the Government to make any increase in the existing rate of assessment.
('42', 462, 6, 14, 866241) They are prepared to prove this statement and they maintain that even if the basis of 50 per cent of the profits be accepted, no increase is warranted, and if the basis of 25 per cent of the profits be accepted, a considerable reduction in the existing rates would be necessary.
('42', 462, 7, 15, 866520) They thus rely for their contention on the actual conditions obtaining in the taluk, but they also rely on attacking the value and accuracy of the Government reports.
('42', 462, 7, 16, 866687) They contend, inter alia, that Mr. Jayakar, the Settlement Officer, made no enquiry worth the name, visited few villages, afforded no opportunities to villagers of making representations pertaining to the question of increasing the assessment, and prepared a perfunctory survey.
('42', 462, 7, 17, 866966) He prepared the most essential statistics in his office, without exercising the slightest scrutiny and relied for his recommendations of 30 per cent on the sole basis of rise in the value of gross produce.
('42', 462, 7, 18, 867172) The perfunctory nature of Mr. Jayakar’s inquiry, if inquiry it could be called, is enough to render it valueless.
('42', 462, 7, 19, 867286) But Mr. Anderson seriously questioned the value of Mr. Jayakar’s report on another and very substantial ground which was pointed out be the people’s representatives also.
('42', 462, 7, 20, 867457) He rejected the most vital part of Mr. Jayakar’s report—viz., where he bases his recommendations on the value of gross pro duce—as “irrelevant” and “positively dangerous as affording no justification for his pro posals and suggesting arguments against them”.
('42', 462, 7, 21, 867716) In the circumstances Mr. Anderson’s ob vious duty was to suggest to
('42', 463, 0, 1, 867784) 464 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 463, 1, 2, 867826) Government a fresh inquiry.
('42', 463, 1, 3, 867854) But he overshot the mark and proceeded to make his own recommendations on the basis of rental statistics—a basis of which the equity has been seriously challenged by several high placed Government officials, and the statistics themselves have in the present case been seriously challenged as lacking scrutiny.
('42', 463, 1, 4, 868164) If Mr. Jayakar drove a coach and four through the Settement Manual, in making no real inquiry, Mr. Anderason went one better in contravening the Settlement Manual which lays down that rents should be only one of the factors to be considered and that even when they are taken into account, “they cannot be used as the basis for definite conclusions.
('42', 463, 1, 5, 868513) unless they exist in considerable volume and unless their reliability has been carefully tested”.
('42', 463, 1, 6, 868611) Mr. Anderson grossly erred (1) in exclusively relying on the rental statistics and (2) in assuming that the two essential conditions for their being of any value and been satisfied.
('42', 463, 1, 7, 868793) In one place, Mr. Anderson charges Mr. Jayakar with having made “no attempt to compile statistics showing the area rented and the area cultivated by its owners,” and yet proceeds on Appendix H and wrongly arrives at the conclusion that “at least half the total area is held by landlords who do not cultivate it”.
('42', 463, 1, 8, 869106) The error is based on his hastily assuming seven years’ statistics—42,923 acres—as one years’s statistics and on his utter disregard of Mr. Jayakar’s own estimate of land held by non agriculturists, which is 23,995 acres, i.e., about 18 per cent of the total area—a more plausible, though not a strictly accurate estimate, because not based on inquiries on the spot.
('42', 463, 2, 9, 869473) For these reason both Mr. Jayakar’s and Mr. Anderson’s reports are worthless and the rate of 22 per cent fixed by Government is absolutely arbitrary as it is based on no fresh or accurate data.
('42', 463, 3, 10, 869667) The satyagrahis of Bardoli have therefore pledged themselves to pay no assessment until either
('42', 463, 4, 11, 869762) 1. the enhancement is cancelled; or
('42', 463, 5, 12, 869798) 2. an independent impartial tribunal is appointed to examine the whole case.
('42', 463, 6, 13, 869875) Young India, 14 6 1928
('42', 464, 0, 1, 869898) VOL. 42 : 2 MAY, 1928 9 SEPTEMBER, 1928 465
('42', 464, 1, 2, 869942) APPENDIX II
('42', 464, 2, 3, 869954) BARDOLI REPORT
('42', 464, 3, 4, 869969) In their report, absolutely pruned of epithets and adjectives, and as closely
('42', 464, 4, 5, 870047) reasoned and concise as it could be, they addressed themselves to the consideration of
('42', 464, 5, 6, 870134) four questions: “As the enhancement is based on rents which land owners demand
('42', 464, 6, 7, 870213) from their tenants it is of utmost importance to determine whether the table relating
('42', 464, 7, 8, 870299) to the rents paid by the tenants has been prepared with due care so as to exhibit
('42', 464, 8, 9, 870381) economic rents only.
('42', 464, 8, 10, 870402) If it is found to be seriously defective, all conclusions drawn
('42', 464, 9, 11, 870466) from it must be regarded as valueless.
('42', 464, 9, 12, 870505) Again, it seems reasonable that before
('42', 464, 10, 13, 870544) competitive rents are accepted as the foundation of the settlement policy, it should be
('42', 464, 11, 14, 870632) determined what proportion of the cultivated area is in the hands of tenants paying
('42', 464, 12, 15, 870716) cash rents.
('42', 464, 12, 16, 870728) The third question which demands consideration is whether abnormal
('42', 464, 13, 17, 870795) periods have been excluded in inquiring into the course followed by rents during the
('42', 464, 14, 18, 870880) currency of the old settlement.
('42', 464, 14, 19, 870912) Lastly, we have to consider to what extent the Land
('42', 464, 15, 20, 870964) Revenue Code and the Settlement Manual justify almost exclusive reliance on rental
('42', 464, 16, 21, 871047) value for the purpose of determining new assessment rates.” And after a study of the
('42', 464, 17, 22, 871132) Code and the Settlement Manual and after personal.
('42', 464, 17, 23, 871183) investigation and inquiries made
('42', 464, 18, 24, 871216) in several villages from the people concerned, they found
('42', 464, 19, 25, 871274) 1. That the table was seriously defective inasmuch as mortgage transactions, or rents
('42', 464, 20, 26, 871360) not realized in full, or conditional sales had not been excluded, and no allowance was
('42', 464, 21, 27, 871447) made for rents, charged in consequence of improvements made at the cost of the
('42', 464, 22, 28, 871526) occupant according to Section 107 of the Land Revenue Code.
('42', 464, 23, 29, 871586) 2. That the cash rented area may be taken to be in the neighbourhood of 20 per cent
('42', 464, 24, 30, 871670) and that looking to the fact that “94 per cent of the occupants and owners cultivate
('42', 464, 25, 31, 871755) themselves” in 1895, even a proportion of 30 per cent as the land cultivated by
('42', 464, 26, 32, 871835) tenants appears surprisingly large today.
('42', 464, 27, 33, 871877) 3. That the boom period covering the years from 1918 19 to 1924 25 should
('42', 464, 28, 34, 871951) have been excluded according to the statement made by the Revenue Member
('42', 464, 29, 35, 872024) himself.
('42', 464, 29, 36, 872033) 4. That the Settlement Commissioner relied on insufficient and unscrutinized
('42', 464, 30, 37, 872110) rental statistics as his “one true guide”, not to check the results of the indirect
('42', 464, 31, 38, 872194) inquiry, but to avoid having to consider and allow for an increase in the cost of
('42', 464, 32, 39, 872276) cultivation, and that he used them not “to prevent the enhancement from going too
('42', 464, 33, 40, 872358) high” (in the words of Settlement Manual) but to enhance the assessment rates.
('42', 465, 0, 1, 872437) 466 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 465, 1, 2, 872479) In view of the foregoing findings Sjts.
('42', 465, 1, 3, 872519) Kunzru, Vaze and Thakkar came to the
('42', 465, 2, 4, 872556) conclusion that “the demand for a fresh inquiry is fully justified” and that “recent
('42', 465, 3, 5, 872641) announcement that revision settlement of the Viramgam taluk will be reconsidered
('42', 465, 4, 6, 872722) makes the case for the reconsideration of the settlement of the Bardoli taluk
('42', 465, 5, 7, 872800) unanswerable.”
('42', 465, 6, 8, 872815) Vaze issued an additional statement in which he laid special emphasis on
('42', 465, 7, 9, 872888) the fact that “the present struggle in Bardoli is a purely economic one; it is no part of
('42', 465, 8, 10, 872978) a general scheme of mass civil disobedience....
('42', 465, 8, 11, 873026) My observation satisfies me that the
('42', 465, 9, 12, 873063) leaders of the movement are actuated by no other motive in carrying on the campaign
('42', 465, 10, 13, 873147) than to undo, by using their best endeavours, what they genuinely believe to be a
('42', 465, 11, 14, 873229) cruel wrong to the peasantry of Bardoli.
('42', 465, 11, 15, 873270) It would be both inexpedient and unjust for
('42', 465, 12, 16, 873314) Government to invest the movement with a wider political significance which it does
('42', 465, 13, 17, 873398) not bear.”
('42', 465, 14, 18, 873409) The report appealed to leaders of all schools of political thinking, ranged the
('42', 465, 15, 19, 873489) sympathy of the few remaining waverers among Indian newspapers definitely on the
('42', 465, 16, 20, 873570) side of the satyagrahis, and was instrumental more than anything else in bringing
('42', 465, 17, 21, 873652) about a consensus of opinion among all circles including the Liberals about the
('42', 465, 18, 22, 873732) justice of the people’s demands and the minimum that was due to them.
('42', 465, 19, 23, 873802) The Story of Bardoli, pp.

('42', 466, 21, 18, 874650) Announcement of the Enquiry
('42', 466, 22, 19, 874678) Government thereafter announced the following enquiry:
('42', 466, 23, 20, 874733) The enquiry will be entrusted to a Revenue Officer and a Judicial Officer, the decision of the Judicial Officer to prevail in all matters of difference between the two, with the following terms of reference:
('42', 467, 0, 1, 874941) 468 THE COLLECTED WORKS OF MAHATMA GANDHI
('42', 467, 1, 2, 874983) To enquire into and report upon the complaint of the people of Bardoli and Valod
('42', 467, 2, 3, 875064) (a) that the enhancement of revenue recently made is not warranted in terms of the Land Revenue Code;
('42', 467, 3, 4, 875166) (b) that the reports accessible to the public do not contain sufficient data warranting the enhancement and that some of the data given are wrong; and to find that, if the people’s complaint is held to be justified what enhancement or reduction, if any, there should be upon the old assessment.
('42', 467, 4, 5, 875461) As the enquiry is to be full, open and independent, the people will be free to lead as well as test evidence before it with the help of their representatives including legal advisers.
